HEADLINE: TENNIS: Secret Sharer: O'Reilly Is Dead, but Her Gift Lives On;
A Tennis-Playing Triplet Made Sure She Spent Her Life as More Than a Mere Curiosity

BYLINE: By ROBIN FINN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIDGEWOOD, N.J. Oct. 13

 BODY:
When Maryann Tierney, coach of Ridgewood High School's girls tennis team, boarded a school bus for the ride to a meet against neighboring Paramus the other day, she was taken aback by the silence that had replaced her players' usual pre-game chatter.
As the bus inched out of the school parking lot and passed under the scarlet-tinged canopy of oaks and maples that make this suburban village seem more pristine than bustling, Tierney discovered the reason behind the long faces. 
 "The girls told me Christine O'Reilly had been killed in a car crash," she said. "It felt awful on the bus that day; it was the worst kind of shock. Everybody knew the O'Reilly girls."
 
Behind-the-Scenes Volunteer
 In her hometown, 25-year-old Christine O'Reilly, is being remembered this week not only as a member of the tennis-playing O'Reilly triplets who achieved recognition worldwide, but also as the ultimate overachiever and throwback to the do-gooders of yore.
"In her we recognized another Dorothy Day in our midst," said Sister Lucy Sullivan of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, referring to the social activist and founder of the Catholic Worker Movement in the 1930's. Sullivan is probably the only person in town who realized the extent of O'Reilly's behind-the-scenes volunteer work. "It just came to her naturally, that gift," she said. "No big speeches, no pious jargon."
O'Reilly went to Mass more often than to the mall, and her first move after returning from a tennis tournament abroad would be to shrug off her backpack and racquets in the hall of her family's spacious Tudor home and dash off to visit the more "difficult" shut-ins on Sister Lucy's list.
O'Reilly's grieving parents, Eugene and Delores, surrounded by condolence cards and floral tributes, said they're finding out only now just how deep their daughter's commitment to lending a charitable hand -- to children, to the old -- actually was. She kept that quality to herself, a semi-secret even from the two sisters who were born just minutes ahead of her on Jan. 18, 1968.
Tierney said: "I can't tell you enough good things about her and her sisters; it sounds trite, but they were a real class act, in triplicate. Even when they were 16-year-old students here, as an adult, I admired them."
Tierney never coached O'Reilly, who along with sisters Patti and Terri formed Ridgewood's famous triplet trio that dominated national junior competition in the Eastern region before all three were graduated from high school in 1986 and enrolled at Duke.
"Hands down, they were just plain too good to play high school tennis; the logical competition for them was elsewhere," said Tierney.
"Whenever you'd hear these ungodly thumps coming from the practice courts, you'd know that wasn't the sound of high school tennis, that was the triplets out there whacking volleys around," said Jim Reamer, Ridgewood High's dean of students.
"If we had a school activity, they were there to set it up and there to help clean it up," he said. "You might have thought having all three play tennis was ripe for an unhealthy sibling rivalry, but you never saw it. They were their own best friends, the kind of kids you'd take for your own."
All three O'Reillys received full scholarships from Duke, and after providing three successful cornerstones to Duke's fledgling tennis program, the sisters graduated with economics degrees and took their turn at the roulette wheel of the professional tennis circuit.
None was able to crack the top 100, but that didn't seem to matter: The O'Reillys, or the O's, as they are still referred to inside the cathedral-like brick high school here, were too busy pelting balls at every match available to them, be it a qualifier, a clinic, or a charity event, to care about their rankings.
And their joy was infectious: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, now ranked 2d in the world, remembers scurrying up into the bleacher rafters at Hilton Head Island last year because that was the only seat left for a spirited qualifying confrontation between Patti and Christine.
Patti, the sole O'Reilly still active on the circuit, reached as high as 210th in the world and is currently 270th, which matches the highest ranking Terri achieved before leaving competitive tennis for a career in sports promotion, a path Christine had already taken. Bothered by injuries that also hampered her college career, Christine never rose above 357th in the world ranking.
"I talked to her about it, giving up the dream of competing in order to get on with the next bit of life, and she really seemed comfortable with it," said Pam Shriver, the veteran player and president of the Women's Tennis Association. "But she'll be missed: The O'Reilly triplets is one of the great, fun stories of our tour in the last ten years. All three, besides being great players, were always ready and willing to help out whatever charity event we had. Maybe that comes with being triplets, that sense of being part of a team and giving back."
O'Reilly was working as a project coordinator for sports promoter John Korff, producer of the Mahwah, N.J., tennis exhibition that the triplets had played in for the last decade, when she was killed last weekend. She had decided to leave competitive tennis, she told Korff, because she was tired of being labeled a tennis triplet and nothing more. And because she was tired of having her back injury surface each morning and prevent her from standing up straight for the first hour of every day.
Last week, assigned to find a site for a balloon festival Korff was producing, she had arrived in Palm Springs, Calif., on Wednesday, Oct. 6, and hired a private pilot, Steven Evans, to take her site scanning on Thursday. On Friday, in a car borrowed from Korff's father, O'Reilly and Evan drove to several more sites. Late that night, with Evans at the wheel, the car overshot a curve on Newport Coast Drive, spun into a utility pole, and split in two. Evans died instantly; O'Reilly had massive internal head injuries and went into a coma from which she never recovered.
Patti and Terri O'Reilly arrived, along with their mother, at the hospital on Saturday, a day they had expected to spend celebrating their mother's birthday. By Sunday, when it was determined that Christine could not breathe on her own, they made the decision to disconnect the life-support system and donate her internal organs. Next, they went to the accident site to look for a cross Christine had worn around her neck; instead, they found a shoe and the hood ornament from the car. Then they took their sister home to Ridgewood where, by Wednesday, the only visible sign of the tragedy was the steady stream of florists' delivery vans arriving and departing from Madison Place.
Inside the hushed house, Christine's parents and five siblings, dry-eyed but drained, selected the readings and music for her funeral service on Saturday. When the quiet grew too confining, Patti and Terri opted to take a walk.
Dodging the leafy neighborhood's resident squirrels, hedges, and inquiring canines, the two remaining triplets reminisced about their sister in a stroll around the block as the sun began to set Wednesday evening. She was, they said, an inspiration to them, even if it did take them an hour of squabbling to arrive at a consensus whenever they tried to rent a video.
"We're almost like parts of the same person," said Patti. "From the time we were 10, we had our own little team, whatever sport it was: What mattered was being out there doing something."
"We always," said Terri, "had our foot in something."
The sisters supported Christine's decision to start a business career, but when Patti needed a grass-court warmup partner for Wimbledon this year, Christine made time to help -- and didn't mind beating her in their practice sessions.
Last summer, although busy assisting Korff's production of the Pathmark Tennis Classic in Mahwah, Christine not only competed in the event, and with her sisters squared off against Bjorn Borg and Guillermo Vilas for charity, but also organized a basketball exhibition to help the Tomorrow's Children Fund.
"If there was a moment when she could be useful to someone, she'd use it," said Terri. "If I have a spare moment, there I am, on the couch, but she would be out there trying to make a difference. She seemed to know that instinctively, that you can make a difference."
The two O'Reillys, trying to emulate their sister by taking something positive from her death, have made her life's dream part of their life's work and initiated the Christine O'Reilly Children's Fund. The ultimate goal is an orphanage; the immediate goal, said Terri, is to keep the third triplet's spirit alive.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patty, left, Christine, center, and Terri O'Reilly last summer at the Pathmark Tennis Classic in Mahwah, N.J. (Gayle Burns)

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Giuliani on the Attack

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Striving to put Mayor David N. Dinkins back on the defensive, Rudolph W. Giuliani has begun broadcasting two new 30-second television commercials and two similar radio ads, harshly attacking the Mayor's record in office and a range of personal or professional lapses dating back two decades. This is one of them.
 
ON THE SCREEN: The ad opens with big words on screen "Maybe we should have known better," next to a tiny picture of Mr. Giuliani noting that his campaign paid for it. Followed by pictures of a Comptroller's report, and a quotation from it: "...serious internal control weaknesses over revenue..." Then newspaper headlines, title noting that Mr. Dinkins failed to file tax returns from 1969 through 1972, footage of Korean boycott, Crown Heights, asbestos sign on a dumpster, and titles that repeat much of the narration. It ends with a picture of Mr. Dinkins, with a smirky smile, and the words "It's not my fault." Last image: White letters on black background, "Maybe it was our fault four years ago."
 
PRODUCER: Garth Group of New York
 
THE SCRIPT:
Male narrator: "Maybe we should have known better. When David Dinkins was City Clerk, a Comptroller audit found that his office was a financial mess. He also forgot to pay Federal, state and city income taxes four years in a row. You think you'd get away with it? Then he becomes Mayor, and we get the Korean boycott, the Crown Heights riots, the PVB scandal, asbestos in the schools and on top of that, we lose 350,000 jobs. And all David Dinkins says is, it's not my fault. Maybe he's right. Maybe it was our fault four years ago."
 
ACCURACY: Two audits by the City Comptroller did fault the management of the City Clerk's office during Mr. Dinkins's tenure from 1975 to 1985. He failed to file income tax returns and pay all taxes due from 1969 through 1972, but he later paid the taxes with penalities and there was no prosecution. As one of the Giuliani radio ads notes, the lapse prevented Mr. Dinkins from becoming the city's first black deputy Mayor in 1973. The school asbestos problem long predated the Mayor's tenure in office, and economists say the city government cannot be held accountable for all the jobs lost in a severe regional recession. Moreover, Mr. Dinkins has acknowledged fault in several of the cases cited, particularly with respect to Crown Heights.
 
SCORECARD: This tough ad attacks Mr. Dinkins for a range of old and new lapses, throwing in everything but the kitchen sink. It is Mr. Giuliani's attempt to counteract the Dinkins ads that have sought to rehash old aspects of his record of service to Republican administrations and link them to his current policy views. Similarly, this ad attempts to paint Mr. Dinkins's entire career as an endless skein of mediocrity and bumbling -- typified by his failure to pay income taxes. The "You think you'd get away with it?" line is an indirect echo of a charge the Giuliani camp sometimes makes more overtly: that if Mr. Dinkins were white, he would never have been forgiven such a lapse. That is a way of saying whites need not feel guilty for voting against him now, having given him a break four years ago. By citing the most notable crises of the Dinkins administration, the ad may ring uncomfortably true. But its rapid-fire mix of images and charges, and its final sneering tone of blaming the electorate may also put voters off.<? TODD S. PURDUM

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Whitman on Florio: Accusations of Corruption

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

 BODY:

Candidate: Christine Todd Whitman
 
Producer: The Murphey Pintak Gautier Agency. Washington
 
Text: (Voiceover) Whitman and Florio. Compare. Christie Whitman wants to cut state spending. Jim Florio increased spending by three billion dollars. Christie Whitman wants to create new jobs with tax cuts. Jim Florio raised taxes billions and he won't rule out raising taxes again. Whitman will clean up state Government. Florio's administration is under two grand jury investigations. Jim Florio. Rising unemployment, corruption, high taxes. We can't afford more. Christie Whitman. A change for the better.
 
Visual: Still photos of Mrs. Whitman and Mr. Florio appear side by side -- predictably she is smiling engagingly while he is frosty -- while graphics echo the truncated words of the narrator. Her image disappears when the specter of corruption is mentioned, replaced at the Governor's side by stacks of money and news headlines reading "State Jobless Rate Reaches 7.7 % For Second Rise in a Row" and "Lax Ethical Standards."
 
Analysis: What's new here is the odor of corruption. In earlier television spots, Mrs. Whitman tried to saddle Mr. Florio with all the bad effects of a prolonged recession while contrasting the $2.8 billion tax increases he pushed through the Legislature in 1980 with her campaign promise to cut taxes by $1.4 billion. (Mrs. Whitman herself refuses to sign a no-new-taxes pledge.) While mention of the two grand juries is fair game, equating them with proof of corruption is not, and Mrs. Whitman's pledge "to clean up state Government" not only lacks specifics but means little without evidence that it is dirty. A state grand jury is looking into allegations that $1.5 million in excess state school aid was sent to the Democratic-controlled town of Lyndhurst , which GOP partisans have painted as a political payoff ordered by the Governor's office. Meanwhile, a Federal grand jury has been examining the old practice, unique to neither party, of directing profitable state bond business to Wall Street fat cats who make hefty campaign contributions to the party in power. The fly in Mr. Florio's ointment here is that Joseph C. Salema Jr., his chief of staff and political satrap, was a partner in a bond consulting firm that profited handsomely from state decisions. Mr. Salema resigned last May to spare the Governor further embarrassment, but so far Federal investigators have not indicated that any laws were broken. Some Democrats question whether Mrs. Whitman, whose husband is a wealthy Wall Street broker and whose late father was a Republican power broker and fund-raiser, is all that shocked by back-room deals between Trenton and captains of finance. JON NORDHEIMER

HEADLINE: Why Does Israel Arm China?

 BODY:
Israel is expanding its cooperation with China on military technology, according to the Central Intelligence Agency. That's the latest sign of Israeli willingness to engage in dubious arms deals. In this case, Israel is supplying China with advanced technology that the U.S. and other Western powers won't supply.
In the past, compelling security needs drove an isolated Israel to forge alliances of convenience with outcasts like South Africa and Iran, sometimes with U.S. connivance. But why would Israel engage in such risky trade now -- especially with a country that has armed Israel's sworn enemies like Iran? Washington, Israel's protector, should demand a good answer before supplying its ally with more advanced military technology. 
 The Rand Corporation reported two years ago that Israel became "China's leading foreign supplier of advanced technology" after the 1989 Tiananmen massacre. The sales included missile technology like a new PL-8 air-to-air and air-to-surface missile and improvements in the CSS-2 ballistic missiles that China sold to Saudi Arabia.
Rand also detected "indications" that Israel had helped the Chinese develop a new fighter plane with technology from the canceled Lavi fighter. The U.S. originally supplied some of that technology. In August, the General Accounting Office warned that the transfer of U.S. technology to Israel for developing the Arrow anti-missile interceptor was inadequately supervised, raising the risk of possible diversion to third countries. Israel has repeatedly denied any such diversion. Given the close cooperation between the two allies, it's often difficult to know exactly when Israeli designers develop an original device or when they produce a knockoff of a U.S. design.
The C.I.A., in answer to questions from a Senate committee, was circumspect about whether the military technology Israel was transferring to China was Israel's own or had originated in the U.S. But it offered an unusually blunt public assessment of "broadening" Israeli-Chinese cooperation, noting that "a growing number of Israeli defense firms" are opening offices in China.
Israel's burgeoning cooperation with China is puzzling in the wake of progress in autonomy talks with the Palestinians and the prospect of peace with all its next-door neighbors. There's no new indication that Israel is reselling U.S. military technology in violation of U.S. law. Even so, a further puzzle persists: Why does Israel do business with a country that endangers its security by arming Iran, Pakistan and others?

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Mean What You Say

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
The crisis in Haiti offers President Clinton a difficult challenge -- but also an opportunity to answer swelling doubts about his foreign policy leadership. The doubts, to put it bluntly, go to whether his words carry any conviction.
Shilly-shallying has been a feature of Mr. Clinton's Presidency. Friends and allies have come to suspect that what he says, like a cut-rate air ticket, is good for that day only. 
A telling example -- and a tragic one -- has been his policy on Bosnia. Mr. Clinton began by calling for strong action to stop the Serbs' genocidal aggression. But he conditioned the action on European support, and then did nothing serious to get that support. It looked as though he really did not believe in the policy he proposed.
The President took an elusive position on the peace plans put forward by international mediators on the Yugoslav conflict. He did not endorse them, but he indicated that he would not object if the parties agreed. There was no leadership, or even a willingness to shoulder responsibility.
More recently Mr. Clinton said the U.S. would contribute 25,000 American soldiers to a NATO force of 50,000 that would police an agreement -- if there was one -- to partition Bosnia. But no sooner had he said that than he began attaching so many conditions that he effectively abandoned the promise.
In Somalia, Mr. Clinton inherited a commitment of American troops. But the purpose of the mission changed, from humanitarian relief to nation-building, without the Administration noticing -- or at any rate being able to explain it. When officials briefed members of Congress last week on Somalia, even Democrats complained that they got no rational explanation of the policy.
This week Senator Richard Lugar of Indiana, a Republican voice of reason and experience on the Foreign Relations Committee, spoke of what he called "the virtual collapse of Presidential leadership in these matters."
"There is no significant support for the President's policy" on Somalia, Bosnia or Haiti, Senator Lugar told R. W. Apple Jr. of The New York Times. "And it's his own fault."
The other day I asked an old foreign policy hand what President Clinton could do to restore faith in his leadership. The answer was: "Have some convictions, and act on them."
Of course it may be that those Americans who have traditionally been concerned with foreign affairs are simply seeing a President who is not -- and who wants to move the country away from caring. A turn toward isolationism is politically tempting, given the degree of xenophobia among the American people these days, and Mr. Clinton's desire to emphasize domestic reform.
Friends abroad certainly sense the possibility of America turning inward under this President. The Financial Times of London has an editorial headed "Uncle Sam in Retreat," and concluding: "Those who believed the cold war would be followed by a period of Pax Americana, worldwide or even in Europe, need to think again, and urgently."
The trouble is that feebleness abroad has consequences at home. Americans may say they want a President who focuses on domestic problems. But their image of the person in the White House is based very much on whether he is seen to act as a strong leader abroad.
Moreover, if members of Congress come to believe that a President can be moved to change his position abroad because he lacks real convictions, they may suspect that the same is true at home. And that would be fatal to Mr. Clinton's domestic ambitions, given the tendency of Congress to push the White House as far as possible in bargaining for regional or economic or ideological interests.
For those reasons, Mr. Clinton was protecting his own Presidency when he said yesterday that he would act unilaterally to enforce the agreed return to democracy in Haiti. It had the sound of a real commitment. But then came a new challenge by the Haitian thugs: the murder of the Justice Minister. What will Mr. Clinton do?
Public opinion may have been against U.S. involvement in Haiti. But I think Americans will support the President if he now offers firm leadership.
If Mr. Clinton had acted firmly last spring on Bosnia, think what he would have done for peace and order in Europe. And for himself.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Here We Go Again

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Israel sells weapons and the technology of warfare to Communist China. The U.S. prepares the way for the Chinese military to get the American supercomputers for which it has lusted so long.
So, fellow suckers, citizens of the Free World, here we go again. Democratic governments are helping increase the military power of despotism. 
 They are richly experienced at that -- one accomplishment after another, from Hitler Germany to Imperial Japan to the Haiti of the Duvaliers, to Ayatollah Iran and Saddamite Iraq, and so many other sales-points in between.
The C.I.A. has sent a report to the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs, which is investigating the proliferation of high-tech, high-kill weapons around the world. The C.I.A. says the Israel-China military link has involved planes, tanks and missiles and is moving into "cooperation" in electronics and space. This has been going on under Likud, "unity" and Labor governments.
Is Israel selling American weapons technology? In March 1992, I wrote columns refuting reports that Israel was about to sell American missile technology to China. The technology involved was Israeli.
But if both Israel-U.S. joint military enterprises and Israel-to-China military sales continue, the ice can get thinner. Already, Israeli diplomats have to keep answering Washington's questions about possible transfers -- bad for their alliance, believe it.
But in any case, I wrote when Likud ruled and repeat when Labor is in office: As an American friend of Israel and a lifetime anti-Communist and anti-Fascist, I believe Israel is in moral and political error in selling even a pistol to the keeper of a gulag that includes the entire nation of Tibet.
The U.S. is on the road to the same error. The Chinese will be able to buy U.S. supercomputer technology, directly or from another country, through "relaxations" in American computer-trade regulations.
That is not getting enough attention outside the Senate committee and nonproliferation specialists in and out of government. These valuable people devote their lives to fighting the spread of technologies and materials that carry the virus of death.
Why do Israel and the U.S. so stupidly soil and endanger themselves?
In a world where the U.S. cannot land a detachment of soldiers in Haiti, China's military power is already far greater and more deliverable than America's -- among Asians, it is psychologically no contest.
As for Israel, its Chinese customers are supplying Middle East dictators with missiles that can reach Israeli territory -- if handshakes ever close into fists.
Israelis say they need foreign arms sales to keep their defense industry going. As my mother used to say, I will sit right down and cry my heart out for them. The sales to China are a tiny part of Israel's growing economy, hardly worth the price in honor and relations with the U.S.
The American rationalization for supercomputer sales is that technology sooner or later gets around the world, so we might as well take the profit. Nonproliferation specialists like Prof. Gary Milhollin of the University of Wisconsin's Law School say that some technology cannot be duplicated and that anyway the time lag can be years.
If Saddam Hussein had had the benefit of even more relaxed trade rules, he could have developed nuclear weapons before the gulf war.
No, the reason is money -- money, as in profit for U.S. computer industry, as in cost reduction in Israel's defense industry. That always seems so sensible, until money comes whistling back as dictators' bombs.
The U.S. and Israel aren't alone in doing military-related business with China. Russia, Japan, Western Eur ope, all are bellying up to the trough.
I used to assume that U.S. economic strength could be used as political clout with our friends. Bushbaker certainly put the squeeze on Israel. But about trade with China we never do anything so indelicate.
Still, When the U.S. or Israel, a special ally, play around with trade rules or sales orders that could strengthen the Chinese military, we have the right and duty to protest until we get hoarse.
The U.S. and Israel have plenty of joint interests -- political freedom, history, security. We don't need the additional common ground of cupidity and stupidity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Art in Review

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:

'Berlin'
'Designing a Capital for the 21st Century'
 Goethe House
 1014 Fifth Avenue (at 82d Street)
 Through Oct. 23
This show of urban design proposals by New York architects for a new Government center in Berlin is a case study in displaced energy. Ostensibly, the 12 firms represented here have set their sights on the reunified German city. But what the show really records is the frustrated desire of these young architects to grapple with the urbanism of their own hometown. The Berlin wall has fallen, but an invisible barrier appears to separate New York's aspiring architects from those who actually plan and build their city. When will these divided sectors be reunited? 
 The Spreebogen Competition, named for a sparsely built-up 70-acre site in the center of Berlin, invited architects from around the world to propose plans for the relocation of the German Government from Bonn. The plans were not to be for actual buildings, but rather urban design schemes that envision ways to integrate a new Government hub into Germany's once and future capital.
The site, on a bend in the Spree River, is haunted by two architectural ghosts of the Nazi era. At one end sits the Reichstag, the Neo-Renaissance Parliament building whose burning in 1933 provided Hitler with a pretext to suspend civil liberties. Later, Albert Speer chose the site for his monumental Neo-Classical complex for the Thousand-Year Reich. Though it was not built, Speer's design has nonetheless acted as a powerful deterrent. The competition explicitly discouraged entrants from designing monumental expressions of state power.
The wild diversity of the New York proposals echoes the euphoria that accompanied the dismantling of the wall. Still, many of the schemes share a similar approach in their use of abstract forms to convey historical and political meanings. Kiss & Zwigard Architects, for example, proposes a "bridge building" to symbolize connection in a city formerly ruled by separation. Smith Miller & Hawkinson uses the metaphor of the urban map in a plan that integrates East and West but retains traces of their cold-war division.
Other proposals display skepticism that German reunification is something to cheer about. Michael Sorkin Studio's plan seeks to resist resurgent nationalism by dividing government functions into small buildings of somewhat reptilian aspect. A site plan by Hani Rashid and Lise Anne Couture proposes buildings inspired by the graffiti scrawls that turned the wall into a monument of political art.
But this show, organized by the New York architect Alexander C. Gorlin, is less significant for its individual projects than for the collective message they send. Here, a new generation of architects is reimagining urban design, exploring ideas that go beyond both the modernist blank-slate approach to urban planning and the decorative contextualism of recent years. This show is a group plea for the chance to try out new ideas -- an imaginary Checkpoint Charlie between vision and opportunity. HERBERT MUSCHAMP

GRAPHIC: Photo: A design by the architects Lise Ann Couture and Hani Rashid for a Berlin Government center.

HEADLINE: Diagnosing Realities of Health Care Reform;
Parity for Mental Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Health reform measures unveiled by the Clinton Administration offer real hope for better medical care for people with mental and emotional illnesses, but they will have to wait until the year 2001 for comprehensive coverage to become available. We applaud the Administration's bold movement toward coverage of mental illnesses on a par with physical illnesses, but questions remain why this parity cannot be achieved today. 
 Full parity was determined to be too expensive despite the fact that cost estimates were based exclusively upon the use of 10-year-old data from the Health Care Financing Administration. According to the National Mental Health Associations, more timely data from many states and Fortune 500 companies -- representing the actuarial experience of millions of Americans already covered -- demonstrate that a comprehensive, flexible mental health benefit is cost-effective and predictable.
Mental health care is a controllable benefit that can lead to significant national savings in overall care costs, and will reduce losses to the economy due to absenteeism and reduced productivity.
Positive steps toward true health care reform include universal coverage, portability of benefits from job to job, and elimination of exclusions based on pre-existing conditions. The proposal also does away with lifetime caps on mental health coverage which forces many of the most seriously ill into state mental hospitals.
However, the Administration proposal continues arbitrary limits on outpatient services, inpatient hospitalization and community-based health services that do not apply to physical health. Higher co-payments for mental health services will remain in place and continue to restrict access to care. Finally, the proposal adopts a cookie-cutter approach for adults and children, making no distinctions in mental health benefit.
We are most saddened by the Clinton plan's failure to address the special mental health needs of children. Common sense tells us that if we offer intensive mental health and/or substance abuse services to kids in child welfare, special education or juvenile justice systems, we can reduce future problems among these very high-risk groups. Our children continue to be overlooked. Let's not leave them out of this landmark legislation, nor add them on as an afterthought.
 
 GISELLE STOLPER
Executive Director
Mental Health Association
of New York and Bronx Counties
New York, Oct. 6, 1993

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Still Trying to Spread Democracy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Theory vs. Practice" (news article, Oct. 1), it is mistakenly argued that President Clinton's recent expressions of caution in undertaking new foreign policy initiatives reflect an abandonment of the Administration's announced policy of supporting democratic "enlargement." The mistake lies in confusing high-profile, expensive interventions, such as that in Somalia or that contemplated in Bosnia, with the long-term efforts of recent American Administrations to extend democracy. 
 Most of America's effort to extend or defend democratic institutions and improve international respect for human rights has been the responsibility of the State Department, the Agency for International Development and the National Endowment for Democracy (and the institutions grouped under it). These efforts are both bilateral and multilateral.
They concentrate on promoting democratic institutions at all levels in developing societies through educational programs and support for non-governmental "watchdog" institutions, as well as improvements in the news media, the judiciary and facilities available to legislatures.
Often support is focused on assuring that elections held in previously authoritarian countries are carried out democratically. In addition, the United States uses the traditional means of "carrot and stick" to support efforts to improve democratic or human rights performance in many countries (through the expansion or curtailment of aid or trade programs in countries as different as China and Peru).
With the end of the cold war, these efforts have been expanding steadily. The most important new efforts have been in assisting democratic transitions in Eastern Europe and the states of the former Soviet Union. There is every reason to believe that the Clinton Administration intends to continue this expansion.
Important characteristics of this effort are that the costs are minimal when compared with even small military interventions; the use of violence as an adjunct of American policy is abjured, and the United States does not become "sucked in" to involvements from which extrication becomes difficult if not impossible.
None of this argues that we should not also be willing to use or threaten violent force in situations such as Bosnia. It is only to argue that such willingness is not a necessary concomitant of a commitment to enlarging the areas of the world in which democratic institutions operate effectively.
 
RAYMOND D. GASTIL
Cos Cob, Conn., Oct. 7, 1993
The writer, an independent consultant, works occasionally for the Agency for International Development.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
What's Best? More Cash For Mortgage or 401(k)?

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:
YOU just received a raise. Would you be better off using the extra money for a bigger contribution to your 401(k) retirement plan or a larger payment on your mortgage?
Like so many other personal finance questions, it is not a black-and-white decision. Your choice depends not only on the interest rates in both categories, but also on your feelings about home ownership and investment risk. 
 Nevertheless, when asked to choose between the two, many financial advisers recommend the retirement account. Because the money is made through a payroll deduction with pretax dollars, the return is usually greater, they say.
"From a long-term standpoint, contribute to a 401(k) plan," said Joel S. Isaacson, president of Joel Isaacson & Company, a New York financial planning firm. "You don't get rich by paying off a mortgage."
Gary Cvach, a partner in the accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick, concurred, noting that "a 401(k) plan directly reduces your income." By comparison, the interest on a mortgage merits only a tax deduction, a smaller tax benefit than a reduction in income.
The popular 401(k) plans are established by corporations to allow employees to put a portion of their compensation into special accounts. The money continues to compound tax-free until withdrawn -- typically after retirement -- when an employee is probably in a lower tax bracket.
For 1993, the maximum worker contribution to a 401(k) plan is $8,994. Some employers encourage participation by matching all or part of their employees' dollars.
Most of the arguments in favor of paying down a mortgage instead of adding to a retirement plan emphasize the emotional element of owning a home free and clear. "Owning your home is the American dream and when you have only 20 percent of a home, you have 20 percent of the dream," said Marc Eisenson, publisher of The Banker's Secret Bulletin, a money management newsletter in Elizaville, N.Y. "If I had my choice between losing my home or having a few more dollars in a 401(k), I'd rather not live in a box."
Mr. Eisenson cited discomfort as another factor. "While speculative investments, like stocks, might beat your mortgage, if your heart sinks when the Dow dives, you might want to send some or all of that money upstairs, too," he said. "Pocket change prepayments save homeowners tens of thousands of mortgage dollars."
Mr. Isaacson, the financial planner, has created a financial model to support his assertion that an individual who contributes to a 401(k) plan would receive a greater return. His example assumes that you are in the 30 percent tax bracket, have $8,000 a year to spend and would earn 7 percent on your 401(k) investment or pay 7 percent for a mortgage.
After 10 years, you would have accumulated $110,531 in a 401(k) plan, while paying down only $70,108 on the mortgage. Assuming 30 percent of the retirement money went to taxes, you would still have $77,372, a $7,265 advantage over the net return for paying off the mortgage.
The discrepancy grows with a longer time frame. Subtracting taxes, the retirement plan's net return would be $46,531 more than the mortgage paydown after 20 years and $163,249 more after 30 years.
"When you use the money to pay off a house, you have simply taken liquid assets and made them illiquid," Mr. Isaacson said. "Investing in a 401(k) plan is better."

GRAPHIC: Graph: "The Clear Winner" shows net return on an investment of $8,000 a year, for a taxpayer in the 30 percent bracket. (Joel Isaacson & Company)

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: By Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Complaints Against Brokers
 
Q. How can a client initiate arbitration when he has a complaint against a stockbroker?
 DAN HARRISON, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.
 
A. Arbitration is the method used by member firms of the nation's major securities exchanges and the National Association of Securities Dealers for resolving disputes with their clients. These brokerage firms require individuals to arbitrate, rather than litigate, claims or controversies -- a process that is intended to make decision-making faster and cheaper. 
 When opening a brokerage account, "the investor must sign an agreement to submit the dispute to arbitration," said James E. Buck, senior vice president of the New York Stock Exchange. To begin an aribtration, the investor has to "provide a typewritten statement describing his or her claim and pay a filing fee, which varies depending on the size of the claim," he said.
Among the most frequent complaints that investors bring against brokers at arbitration hearings are excessive trading for the purpose of generating commissions (a practice often called churning), and providing misleading information about investments.
 
I.R.A. Distributions
 
Q. When I reach 70 1/2 and must begin taking distributions from my I.R.A. at a brokerage firm, will I have to liquidate some of the stock if there is not enough cash in the account?
 BETTY L. SHAVE, Amityville, L.I.
 
A. Not necessarily. Although distributions from an individual retirement account are normally made in cash, they do not have to be. They can be a transfer of securities or an annuity contract.
"The amount taxable is generally the fair market value of the assets transferred, or deemed transferred, as of the date of the distribution," said Edward Mendlowitz, a partner in the New York certified public accounting firm of Mendlowitz Weitsen. "However, there are special rules when the assets are pledged or where life insurance is part of the transaction."
 
Evaluating Premium Bonds
 
Q. Are there any advantages to buying premium bonds?
 NEIL MORAN, Floral Park, L.I.
 
A. A premium bond is a bond that was issued with a higher interest rate than is available today and therefore sells now at a higher price than it will be worth at maturity. If the extra interest income more than offsets the loss you will suffer when the bond matures, it may be worthwhile to buy a premium bond.
Another reason that premium bonds usually yield more than comparable bonds selling at par is less demand. Many individuals and institutions avoid buying bonds at a premium because of such factors as more complicated accounting, tax ramifications and the effects of early redemptions of the bonds.
"Pre-refunded tax-free bonds, collateralized with U.S. Government securities, almost always sell at a premium," said William K. Joseph, senior vice president of Smith Barney Shearson. "As long as the yield is competitive, these bonds are safe, secure and attractive."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN HAITI;
PRESIDENT ORDERS SIX U.S. WARSHIPS FOR HAITI PATROL

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
President Clinton ordered six American warships into the waters off Haiti today with instructions to stop and board any ships that appeared to be violating the reimposed United Nations embargo on the turbulent nation.
The President also dispatched a reinforced Marine company to the nearby Guantanamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, and Administration officials said they expected ships from Canada, France and Argentina to join the naval cordon. 
 If needed, the officials said, the troops and ships would be used to evacuate the 1,000-odd Americans still in Haiti. Part or all of the staff of the United States Embassy, and United Nations diplomats as well, could also be pulled out if this week's violence threatened to burst out of control.
 
Addresses Haitian Military
 "The military authorities in Haiti simply must understand that they cannot indefinitely defy the desires of their own people as well as the will of the world community," the President declared this afternoon.
Mr. Clinton, who has been heavily criticized in recent days for his handling of the Somalia and Haiti crises, sought to send a firm message, and some of his aides encouraged comparisons to the naval blockade imposed by John F. Kennedy during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. But as in his speech on Somalia earlier this week, the President's manner was more subdued than his words.
Haiti's defiant military and police leaders, who were scheduled to step down today under an accord brokered earlier this year by the United Nations, refused to do so. A White House aide said that at a meeting in Port-au-Prince with Lawrence A. Pezzullo, President Clinton's special envoy, the military leader, Gen. Raoul Cedras, "yielded not a single centimeter." [Page 4.]
 
U.N. Monitors Moved
 As a precautionary measure, the United Nations pulled its human rights monitors, scattered around the Haitian countryside, back into the capital, where conditions are considered a bit safer, and began to evacuate them.
"The ships and troops have an important symbolic function," a State Department official said. "We want these people to realize that we are willing to back up our words with force. Maybe they will think twice before they resort to bad behavior again. Conceivably we may even save a few lives."
At a brief news conference that came 24 hours after the assassination of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's Justice Minister, Guy Malary, Mr. Clinton said he was "very concerned about the safety of Americans there." He also declared a broad United States interest in "promoting democracy in a place where such a large number of Haitians have clearly expressed their preference for President."
Father Aristide, who won the Haitian presidential election in 1990, has been living in Washington since being deposed by a military coup in September 1991. Today's steps by the United States and other countries, intended to supplement the United Nations sanctions voted on Thursday and due to take effect on Monday, are part of an effort to return him to power by Oct. 30, the deadline set by an agreement reached by Father Aristide and the military government in July.
To encourage other countries to join in the naval action, the United States asked the United Nations to authorize member governments to do whatever was necessary to enforce the embargo, "and in particular to halt inward maritime shipping as necessary in order to inspect and verify their cargoes and destinations."
The Chinese delegation, which has a veto in the Security Council, asked for a delay to seek instructions from Beijing, and a decision on the request was put off until Saturday.
Father Aristide wrote today to the Governments of the United States, Canada, France and Venezuela, the so-called "four friends" that have been aiding the democratization effort in Haiti, asking them to take steps to protect members of his Government in the wake of the killing of Mr. Malary.
Mr. Clinton declined to say what the United States would do about that request. Administration officials said new security arrangements were being made, indicating that these did not involve the dispatch of American troops to Haiti anytime soon.
In what he later called "an offhand suggestion," President Aristide's lawyer, Michael Barnes, suggested at a news conference that one way to provide additional security for the ministers as well as American diplomats might be to beef up the Marine detail already on duty protecting the Embassy.
"That is something that I have not ruled out,"' Mr. Clinton commented.
In other moves intended to increase the pressure on those who have been fomenting violence in Haiti, the President said he would freeze the assets in American banks and revoke United States visas of those involved in blocking the transition to democratic control there. The State Department advised Americans not to travel to Haiti because of the potential for further disturbances.
Mr. Pezzullo headed back to the United States tonight, but the newly arrived American Ambassador, William Swing, remained behind in Port-au-Prince.
The American flotilla began forming near the island tonight with the arrival of the cruiser Sterett. Two other cruisers, the Vicksburg and the Gettysburg, both members of the $1 billion Aegis class, with sophisticated electronic monitoring equipment; two frigates, the Klakring and the Jack Williams, and a destroyer, the Caron, will arrive by nightfall Saturday, officials said.
Seeking to insure that no merchant ships take contraband oil, guns or other forbidden cargo to Haiti, the United States ships will rely on considerable experience in seeking to stem the flow of illegal drugs.
Mr. Clinton betrayed his lack of knowledge of military nomenclature in making his announcement.
He referred not to three cruisers, two frigates and a destroyer but to six destroyers, and he said he was placing an infantry company on alert when in fact the unit involved came from the Marine Corps, not the Army.
It is a reinforced company of 450 to 600 Marines, drawn from the Second Marine Expeditionary Force at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Once at Guantanamo, it will remain ready to move on at extremely short notice, with gear packed and transport standing by.
The President said he was not ordering a blockade as that word is understood in international law, but conceded that in layman's terms that was precisely what he had done.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: An Unfettered Milken Has Lessons to Teach

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Michael Milken is back from prison and forever barred from the Wall Street world of high-risk financing where he fell from reigning master to disgraced convict. But the tattered mogul hardly seems east of Eden these days as he buoyantly teaches his weekly class of young M.B.A. candidates much, if not all, that he has learned.
"Can you suggest when you'd use the zero-coupon bond?" he asks, endlessly animated as he moves about the classroom of 57 students who seek to enter that chastened world now forbidden to him. They sit raptly, knowing they are being taught by a man of fabulous wealth and considerable resiliency, a man who chuckles at academic business notions and stands as the epitome of real-world experience, 22 months of prison time for securities fraud included.
 
Worshipful Undergraduates
 Across the corridor from his class here at the University of California at Los Angeles, an overflow crowd of worshipful undergraduates, a few commuting for the night from distant campuses, audit the master's lessons. They watch the television screen as if it were a futuristic stock ticker. 
 "We're going to look at securitized business loans," Mr. Milken announces with a boyish smile that acknowledges his own notoriety. "I think that sounds better than 'junk bonds,' " he says of the risky but lucrative financial tool that he made his virtuoso instrument and that finally broke him as the most celebrated miscreant of what became known as the greed decade, the 1980's.
All of this is not quite behind him as the 47-year-old Mr. Milken, a bald, lean, avid-eyed figure who resembles the actor John Malkovich, scrambles back into public life with a certain air of unrepentance.
 
Galileo and Other Visionaries
 Ask him about the financing techniques that eventually scandalized Wall Street and saw him confess to six counts of securities fraud, and Mr. Milken discusses Galileo and other penalized visionaries proved right byhistory. Ask him about the decade of greed, and he talks of misperception becoming reality, citing data to argue that donations adjusted for inflation show Americans in general as charitable, not greedy, in the 1980's. Ask him about specific Americans prosecuted as principals in the biggest insider trading ring in financial history, and Mr. Milken urges the world to await his book on the subject.
"If there's no risk, there's no future," he says repeatedly, having to marshal his comeback on the cusp of the financial world since he left prison in January.
Still rich and self-confident after paying more than a billion dollars in penalties and settlements, Michael R. Milken is creating an educational television network and using himself as the prototype for new TV teaching methods. At a minimum, there are 600 graduate business schools as a potential market, he notes, plus an even larger world of gifted professors in all disciplines who might be recorded and disseminated in new ways that tap the modern electronic media's powers of entertainment and information.
 
Look at the Bottom Line
 Thus is his new vocation classic Milken in scope. Even his untelegenic wardrobe of blue suit jacket and brown pants and tie signals he is a man of bottom-line fanaticism, not Wall Street foppery. In his guest lectures here at the John E. Anderson School of Management, five cameras of his own production company record his every move for later editing and graphics-enrichment into a kind of Milken-become-Donahue approach to life after Wall Street.
"He is a great man -- a martyr, not a crook," insists one student, Scott Ragsdale, ardently absorbing all the Milken he can. "It's not fair, punishing him simply because society can not understand how one man could make $500 million in a single year."
University officials here are more restrained in citing the principles of academic freedom in explaining to the curious and the complaining alike that while they share the California copyright in Mr. Milken's new venture, he is an independent, unpaid guest who happened to become the star of the Management 298D course run by a friend, Bradford Cornell.
"There he is!" comes a cry from a crowd gathered outside room 2343 as Mr. Milken arrives with a retinue that includes two very active Wall Street traders, longtime friends and canny dealers who seem honored to help out. The onlookers include at least one skeptic, Danny Stolarsky, a 19-year-old science undergraduate. "I resent Milken's being here," the student says. "This is an institution of higher education, not a place for opportunists to make money."
That it can be both is the point of Mr. Milken's teaching mission. He is an innovator who became famous after he removed himself and his loyalist crew of investment bankers from New York, resettling here in his native state to focus better on stimulating Wall Street's credit-pumping heart. He set up an outpost of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. that through his junk-bond deals became the tail that wagged the dog and ultimately shook the Street.
 
Booming With Junk Bonds
 Getting the trading-day jump at 4 A.M. here, Mr. Milken was the adrenalized fulcrum of a big X-shaped dealing desk shared by his crew. It was a high-tech umbilical cord to Wall Street, eventually the fabled center of a universe of booming, high-yield junk bond financing that underpinned some of the flimsiest as well as some of the most creative ventures of the 1980's.
This financing was a factor in the decade's savings and loan debacle, in the arbitrage schemes of Ivan Boesky, and in the Wall Street frenzy of cannibalistic leveraged buy-outs. But Mr. Milken cannot help reminding an interviewer from CNN outside his classroom that his high-risk loan dynamics also gave life to CNN itself, and to MCI and other new age companies.
 
Relish for New Role
 As an ex-convict, Mr. Milken, tanned and hyperkinetic, says he lately needs an extra hour of sleep beyond the five hours he allowed himself as a junk-bond king. It may be hard to believe him when he insists he was growing tired of Wall Street even before he was banished from it. But there is no denying he relishes the role of teacher, of explaining how Wall Street really works and shattering some cliches of academia before his book-weary students.
"He is the smartest man in this country," says Art Stanyakovsky, a Soviet emigre and 24-year-old law student who is auditing the Milken series of 10 three-hour classes on Wednesday nights as if it were Aristotle teaching Adam Smith. "He was destroyed just because he stood against the Establishment."
James B. Stewart, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who wrote "Den of Thieves," a study of the corrupt trading manipulations of the 80's, has detailed how Mr. Milken spent extra millions beyond legal fees on public relations experts to spread this very idea that he is a misunderstood genius of creative finance, not of creative thievery.
Even in explaining the criminal case of sham transactions and customer cheating against Mr. Milken, the book concedes he is "a genius salesman" and meticulous researcher. He paid enough attention to economic history to rediscover the value of organizing the overlooked, low-grade bonds of corporate finance into diversified high-yield ventures with which he created masses of fresh investment capital and a personal fortune.
All this will be mere prologue if Mr. Milken has his way in wiring his busy new life. This includes three years of court-mandated full-time community service in which he is pursuing a long-running interest in after-school tutoring innovations for junior high school students here. At a minimum, he seems methodical and avid about building his post-prison role. He said he recently discovered he has prostate cancer. This problem has become a newly capitalized research cause for one of the Milken foundations' grants, part of his remaining empire estimated to run still into the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Mr. Milken is different from so many other celebrated white-collar felons in having no tale of personal conversion or zealous expiation to offer from his minimum-security months in a Federal prison camp in Pleasanton, Calif. He shows no sign of hungering after vengeance as he dreams of history with intimations of Galileo. But he cannot resist inquiring about the New York mayoral race, then smiling in open pleasure at the polls' reading that the candidacy of his Federal prosecutor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, remains an uphill, high-risk venture.
Free and full of ideas, Michael Milken would have us believe his prison time was only another pragmatic deal in a life of dealing. He can be amused in recalling parts of it. Among the jailhouse sustenance offered by outside fans were 22 copies of "Atlas Shrugged," the cult novel by Ayn Rand about willful, Promethean characters.
"I had not read it since the 60's," says Mr. Milken, chatting after teaching his fledgling successors all about Wall Street. "In retrospect, I'd have been better off had I re-read it in the early 80's," he adds, smiling and admitting he could have used a caution against hubris in that especially rich time right before his downfall.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Michael R. Milken has gone from Wall Street to prison to a class of 57 M.B.A. candidates. He taught this week in Los Angeles (pg. 1); Michael R. Milken, left, former financier, teaching his weekly class at the University of California at Los Angeles's graduate business school. In addition to teaching, he is creating an educational television network. (pg. 9) (Liliana Nieto del Rio for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
The Consumer Price Index was unchanged in September, bringing inflation so far this year to 2.5 percent, below last year's 2.9 percent rate for the first time this year. As a result, however, Social Security and other benefits for 50 million people will be raised only 2.6 percent next year, the second-smallest increase ever. [39.] 
 The U.S. foreign trade deficit fell by 6.8 percent in August, to $9.7 billion, helped by a $707 million increase, to $1.6 billion, in sales of civilian aircraft to foreign countries. [47.]
The Senate extended emergency unemployment benefits for workers who have been jobless for more than six months. [8.]
Michael Milken is captivating students at U.C.L.A., where he teaches high finance to young M.B.A. candidates. [1.]
 
Companies
C. R. Bard agreed to pay $61 million and plead guilty to fraud and human experimentation for selling untested heart catheters. The case is the largest health fraud ever handled by the F.D.A. and the Justice Department. Bard's chairman, George T. Maloney, and five former officials were indicted. [1.]
John Sculley resigned as Apple Computer's chairman. During his 10-year tenure, Apple grew tenfold, but recently Mr. Sculley has been criticized for ignoring details of Apple's business while playing a broader role in the industry. [39.]
The stocks of media companies have soared in the aftershock of the Bell Atlantic-Tele-Communications deal, as investors look for more potential builders of the data superhighway. [39.]
Barry Diller is set to announce a $500 million infusion into QVC by Cox Enterprises as a way to maintain the financial upper hand in the bidding war for Paramount Communications. [39.]
The dismissal of a suit involving defaulted Trump Taj Mahal bonds could help companies deflect similar suits over the adequacy of their financial disclosures. [39.]
Ford and the auto workers union settled a dispute that had delayed the signing of their new labor pact. [41.]
ITT will cut its world and division headquarters staff by about 25 percent, or about 1,100 people. [41.]
Texas Instruments' third-quarter net income more than doubled, helped by strong orders and higher royalties. [41.]
Wordperfect asked a court to block Microsoft from claiming its word processing software is the world's most popular. [41.]
 
 Markets
The stock market posted its third consecutive gain, propelled by a sharp rally in bonds. The Dow industrials gained 8.10. [40.]
Long-term interest rates fell to levels not seen since the late 1960's, pushed lower by a favorable inflation report. [48.]
Oil prices tumbled on reports that Iraq was closer to being allowed by the United Nations to export oil. [50.]
The dollar firmed against European currencies but drifted against the yen on reports of a sluggish U.S. economy. [50.]
 
Your Money
Early payouts of life insurance for the terminally ill are growing in popularity. But experts caution against using payouts as a replacement for health insurance coverage. [37.]
Phone company stocks are becoming riskier as the companies enter cable, cellular and other businesses. [37.]
Extra money? Should you make a bigger contribution to your retirement plan or a larger payment on your mortgage? [38.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Visionary Apple Chairman Moves On

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15

 BODY:
John Sculley brought an era to an end in Silicon Valley today by resigning from Apple Computer Inc., the innovative company he joined 10 years ago and built into a giant in the personal computer industry.
Mr. Sculley, a former Pepisco Inc. executive, made his mark by bringing marketing skills and corporate discipline to Apple, a company founded in Steven P. Jobs's parents' garage. During Mr. Sculley's reign the company's sales grew tenfold, from $800 million a year to $8 billion, and he was credited with helping the industry push the personal computer beyond office desktops and into the homes and onto the laps of America. 
 "His contribution to the field was significant," said Nicholas Negroponte, the director of the media laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "He can almost single-handedly be credited with America's re-entry into consumer electronics."
But in recent months, as Apple has stumbled financially, Mr. Sculley was criticized as having failed to attend to the details of its business while playing the roles of industry luminary, informal Presidential technology adviser and apostle of the creed of "convergence" -- the confluence of computers, communications, publishing and entertainment.
In June, a few weeks before Apple announced a $188.3 million third-quarter loss, Mr. Sculley relinquished the title of chief executive to the president, Michael Spindler. Today, a day after the company surprised Wall Street by posting a fourth-quarter profit, Mr. Sculley stepped down as chairman. He did not publicly indicate his plans other than to say in a statement that after "an extraordinary journey" he was "ready to head off to new challenges."
Mr. Sculley, 54, is being replaced as chairman by A. C. Markkula Jr., 51, a co-founder of Apple with Mr. Jobs and Stephen Wozniak in 1976. Mr. Markkula was previously chairman of Apple from 1977 until 1988.
Apple's shares jumped $4.50 each today, closing at $28.25 in Nasdaq trading. The surge follows the release of Apple's earnings report on Thursday evening after the stock market closed.
Mr. Sculley was not available for further comment today. Although his name has been floated as a candidate for several top corporate jobs, including the chief executive's position at Eastman Kodak, people close to him say he is more interested in finding a position that would allow him to pursue his vision of "convergence."
In the absence of Mr. Sculley's own explanations, it was left for industry executives to consider his legacy.
"His departure indicates that the phase of rapid growth in personal computing has come to an end," said Michael Borrus, a computer industry expert and co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on International Economics. "It's probably appropriate that someone else steward the company through the next phase."
Two years ago, in an attempt to cope in a changing industry, Mr. Sculley steered the company into an unprecedented alliance with the world's largest computer maker, I.B.M. He also led Apple directly into the consumer market with the introduction of the Newton Messagepad, a hand-held computer designed to recognize handwriting. Neither venture has yet proved a success.
Moreover, despite Apple's rapid growth, Mr. Sculley has been faulted for being too slow to respond to an assault on the company by rival computer makers whose machines are powered by Intel Corporation chips and run Microsoft Corporation software. Apple computers are based on the company's own software and use chips from Motorola Inc.
Many industry executives say they think Mr. Sculley missed an opportunity in the late 1980's to move Apple's Macintosh software to Intel-based computers before Microsoft was able to popularize its Windows program, which imitates the graphical Macintosh approach to computing. Many analysts also say he was too slow in reducing Apple's prices during the continuing personal computer industry price war, thereby losing valuable market share that the company has yet to reclaim.
Mr. Sculley's resignation as chairman came less than four months after he gave up the chief executive post following a board room drama full of intrigue, during which Mr. Spindler was made chief executive. Soon afterward the Cupertino, Calif., company laid off about 2,500 employees and reported the $188.3 million quarterly loss, its largest ever.
Today, an executive close to Apple's board said the directors had decided at a meeting in June that Mr. Sculley would leave the company before the end of October.
Neither Mr. Markkula nor Mr. Spindler was available for comment yesterday. "For the past 10 years, John Sculley has had one of the most compelling and articulate visions of how computing technology can improve the lives of people everywhere," Mr. Markkula said in a statement released by the company.
Mr. Sculley was president of Pepsico in 1983 when he was hired at Apple by Mr. Jobs. The two were initially close friends, but in 1985, after the Macintosh personal computer was introduced and was slow to gain momentum, they quarreled. Mr. Jobs was stripped of his position as head of the Macintosh division and left the company soon afterward.
Mr. Sculley was made chairman and proceeded to oversee the success of the Macintosh, which grew in popularity in part because of its success in desktop-publishing applications.
Although Mr. Sculley had originally been brought to Apple as a professional manager, after Mr. Jobs departed he increasingly styled himself as a visionary.
"What surprised me about John was that he changed from being the day-to-day manager to a visionary," said William H. Hambrecht, the president of Hambrecht & Quist, a San Francisco investment banking firm, which underwrote Apple's initial public offering in 1981. "I think he did a good job that way."
Mr. Sculley, who was paid $1.65 million in salary and bonus in 1992, owns less than 1 percent of Apple's stock.

HEADLINE: Price Data Flat, Curbing Cost-of-Living Raises

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Fifty million Americans who collect Social Security and other Federal benefits will get cost-of-living increases of only 2.6 percent for 1994, the Government announced today.
The increase, the second-smallest annual rise since the payments were automatically linked to inflation in 1975, was based on data released today showing that consumer price inflation had vanished in September. 
 The average monthly Social Security benefit for retired workers is to go up $17, to $674. The only percentage increase smaller than today's was the 1.3 percent rise in 1987, which reflected a collapse in oil prices.
Interest rates plunged on the news that the Consumer Price Index was unchanged in September. The 30-year Treasury bond's yield, which fell on Thursday on news that September producer price inflation was unexpectedly low, declined sharply again today. [Page 48.]
Inflation has retreated sharply in the last three years. Indeed, with September's data, the annual inflation rate fell below last year's 2.9 percent rate for the first time this year, dropping to a 2.5 percent annual rate.
But some economists interpret the low inflation numbers as a mixed message.
"It's good news and bad news," said Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Chemical Banking Corporation. "Economic conditions have to be pretty weak for consumer prices to be steady."
Indeed, the Federal Reserve reported today that industrial output in September edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent, while industry operated at 81.6 percent of capacity in the month, a level essentially unchanged since February.
The inflation report was a mixed indicator for many individuals as well as for the economy. While consumers benefit from soft prices, those relying on interest income suffer from the low rates that low inflation has brought.
And consumers with heavy medical costs will find that the 2.6 percent cost-of-living adjustments to their wages or their Social Security benefits are not enough to maintain this year's purchasing power. The medical component of the Consumer Price Index, which ticked up last month after an exceptionally low reading in August, has climbed 5.7 percent over the last 12 months, more than twice the 2.7 percent inflation for the Consumer Price Index as a whole in the 12-month period.
Horace D. Deets, executive director of the American Association of Retired Persons, also noted that many low-income elderly people would be getting a small Social Security increase accompanied by a rise of $4.50, to $41.10 a month, in what they pay for Medicare Part B coverage.
The cost-of-living adjustments are based on the amount by which the Consumer Price Index for urban wage earners and clerical workers rose between the third quarter of 1992 and the third quarter of 1993. This index is slightly different from the Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers, the one on which detailed news coverage is usually focused.
The 2.6 percent Social Security increase applies to about 45 million people collecting regular and supplemental benefits and to another five million in other Federal programs, mainly Civil Service and military retirees.
 
White House Is Pleased
 At the White House, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chief economic adviser to President Clinton, hailed the surprisingly low September Consumer Price Index and said "there don't seem to be out there any factors that would cause inflation to pick up in the near term."
But as the report was prompting another scramble to buy bonds and shorter-term debt, some private analysts noted temporary factors holding down September's inflation and cautioned that October might bring an unpleasant surprise.
They cited the 4.3-cent-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax that took effect at the beginning of this month. Other factors involve apparel, for which a six-tenths of 1 percent decline last month is unlikely to be repeated, and tobacco, which has already reflected the bulk of discounts from the industry's price war. At the producer level, in fact, tobacco prices rose last month.
Indeed, it is quite possible that the Consumer Price Index for this month will show a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent, perhaps even more, one Labor Department official suggested.
 
A Broad-Based Trend
 Still, September was almost uniformly favorable, with the so-called core rate, which excludes food and energy, edging up just one-tenth of 1 percent after rising three-tenths of 1 percent in August.
This gauge shows a steady decline this year from a 4.3 percent pace in the first quarter to 2.9 percent and 1.9 percent, respectively, in the second and third quarters.
The cost of medical care rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September, today's report showed, the same increase as in June and July but up from a two-tenths rise in August. The biggest factor was a rise in professional and hospital services.
So far this year, medical inflation has been 5.6 percent, a pace that if maintained for the rest of the year would be the lowest since 1973.
The Social Security cost-of-living data, published by the Department of Health and Human Services, showed that benefits for an elderly couple would rise to $1,140 from $1,111; for a widowed mother with two children to $1,316 from $1,282; for an elderly widow or widower to $631 from $615, and for a disabled worker with a spouse and one or more children to $1,092 from $1,064.
The amount that retired people can earn tax free rises to $11,160 a year from $10,560 for those age 65 through 69 and to $8,040 from $7,680, for those under 65.
As for the industrial production data, the overall rise of two-tenths of 1 percent last month mainly reflected a jump in car and truck assembly, to a 10 million annual pace. Factories raised production four-tenths of 1 percent, but utility output slumped 3.1 percent after sharp increases during an exceptionally hot summer, the Federal Reserve report stated.

HEADLINE: After Wrangling, House Supports Extending Extra Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
After more than two weeks of wrangling, the House voted today to extend the program of emergency unemployment benefits for workers who have been jobless for more than six months and have exhausted their state assistance.
It is the fifth extension of emergency Federal unemployment benefits since November 1991 and is intended to continue helping the 60,000 unemployed workers who become eligible for such assistance every week. 
 The one-sided 302-to-95 vote was deceptive. Less than 24 hours before, a coalition of Democrats and Republicans embarrassed the House Democratic leadership by rejecting a similar plan on a procedural vote of 274 to 149. An extension has been expected to receive full Congressional approval eventually, but the wrangling could have delayed the resumption of the benefits. The last extension expired on Oct. 2.
The problem arose before the first vote on Thursday. At issue was a provision that would prevent immigrants who have been in this country less than five years from obtaining Supplemental Security Income, the welfare program for the blind, elderly and disabled. These benefits are now available to immigrants after three years.
 
Money-Saving Move
 Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, had proposed the change as a way of saving $331 million to pay for the extension in unemployment benefits. A Congressional budget rule requires that the cost of extending the unemployment assistance be offset by either tax increases or spending cuts.
But the Democratic leadership dropped the Rostenkowski plan in the face of impassioned opposition by Hispanic members. The leaders instead proposed to save the same amount of money by extending the program for three months instead of four. But the concession to Hispanic members caused support among Democratic members to erode and led to the rejection on Thursday.
The bill passed today after the Hispanic members accepted defeat and dropped their insistence on retaining the current welfare policy for immigrants.
The legislation that passed today would extend the unemployment program for four months and includes the change in the the welfare program. Having the Administration's strong support, it is expected to pass the Senate.
"The caucus fought hard on this bill and will continue to battle against those who would make impoverished legal immigrants scapegoats for our problems," said Representative Jose E. Serrano, Democrat of the Bronx and chairman of the Hispanic caucus.
Mr. Rostenkowski praised the bill during the House debate. "The assistance we provide" for the unemployed, he said, "will in many cases mean the difference between scraping by or plunging into poverty."
Currently, 2.5 million people are receiving state jobless assistance. Another 1.4 million were receiving the Federal emergency benefits before that program expired on Oct. 2. The emergency benefits program would provide extra jobless benefits for seven weeks, except for those in Alaska, California, Rhode Island, West Virginia and Puerto Rico. In those states, where the unemployment rate is above 9 percent, the extension would be 13 weeks.
The average benefit is $179 a week.
Of the 95 lawmakers who voted against the extension today, 80 were Republicans and 15 were Democrats. Conservative Republicans led the opposition to the measure, saying the Government could not afford it.
"Unemployment is going down," said Representative David Dreier, Republican of California. "Nationwide, things are going better. Maybe it's time to consider these extended benefits may be contributing to the problem."
