HEADLINE: Stocks Continue Climb; Dow Advances by 8.10

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The stock market posted its third gain in a row yesterday, although some profit taking pulled prices down from their afternoon highs.
Contributing to the market's gains was the sharp rally in bond prices following the Government's favorable report on inflation. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the Nasdaq composite index and the American Stock Exchange index all finished again at record levels, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 8.10 points to close at 3,629.73. For the week, the Dow gained 44.99 points.
"The somewhat better-than-expected inflation numbers and the good bond market makes equities even more attractive," said Lawrence R. Rice, chief market strategist of Josephthal, Lyon & Ross. "We are winding up the week with a good environment."
The Government reported yesterday that the Consumer Price Index was unchanged in September, putting the annual inflation rate at 2.5 percent. The news followed Thursday's report that wholesale price inflation was unexpectedly low last month.
The inflation report yesterday sent bond prices surging, as the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell sharply to 5.78 percent. With few inflationary pressures, many analysts say, interest rates could decline even further. Low interest rates make stocks more attractive as investors seek higher returns on their money.
A number of stock options expired yesterday, but traders said the expirations had little effect on the market.
"I could hardly notice it," said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Smith Barney Shearson. "If anything, it gave the market a slight lift at the close."
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange continued to soar, with 366.1 million shares changing hands, up from 352.5 million shares on Thursday. On the American Stock Exchange, volume reached 42.9 million shares, just short of the record 43.4 million shares traded on Oct. 20, 1987, the day after the big market crash.
Shares of Apple Computer vaulted 4 1/2, to 28 1/4, in Nasdaq trading. Late Thursday, the computer maker reported a small profit, even though most analysts had anticipated a loss. Yesterday, John Sculley stepped down as Apple's chairman.
 
Personal Computer Companies
 Other personal computer companies also rose, with Dell gaining 1, to 18 3/4, and Compaq increasing 3/4, to 61 5/8.
Shares of the Baby Bells were higher for the second consecutive day, with many investors said to be considering them as potential growth stocks instead of as traditional utilities. BellSouth gained 1 5/8, to 62 1/4; Ameritech advanced 1/4, to 87 3/8, and U S West rose 1/4, to 49 7/8.
There was also a lift in the steels, following Thursday's big gains for the automobile stocks. USX-U.S. Steel was up 1/2, to 31 1/8, and Bethlehem Steel was up 1/4, to 14 1/2.
Among other issues, Texas Instruments was a standout, jumping 2 7/8, to 65 7/8, after recording stronger-than-expected third-quarter earnings.
Kellogg, which similarly beat the expectations of analysts for third-quarter net income, advanced 3 1/4, to 56. And Snapple also posted a large gain, climbing 2 3/8, to 25 1/4, after saying that its third-quarter profits are likely to triple the earnings of the period a year ago.
On the other hand, Rohm & Haas fell 1 7/8, to 47 7/8. The company said that it is projecting a third-quarter loss and will restate its first-quarter earnings for an accounting change.
In Japan, stocks rose modestly. The 225-share Nikkei average ended up 91.61 points, or 0.46 percent, at 20,174.42.

HEADLINE: Whitman Makes Public '90 Taxes

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
After months of badgering by Gov. Jim Florio, Christine Todd Whitman released her 1990 income tax returns today and confirmed again, to no surprise, that she is rich.
The returns showed that Mrs. Whitman, the Republican candidate for governor, and her husband, John, reported gross total income of $4,047,051 in 1990 -- $3.33 million in taxable income -- on which they paid $936,670 in Federal taxes and $254,293 in New Jersey and New York State and City taxes. 
 Mr. Whitman was the principal wage-earner in the family, receiving a nearly $2.6 million bonus from Prudential Bache Securities, where he was a financial consultant. The couple also received capital gains of $850,800, which accounted for another large chunk of their income.
After reviewing the returns, the Florio campaign -- which had criticized Mrs. Whitman for releasing returns for 1989, 1991 and 1992 but not 1990 -- raised questions about a refund of $235,648 from New York State. But despite months of innuendo and implication by the Governor, there were no major surprises immediately evident in the documents that Mrs. Whitman released today.
 
'Lusting' for a Return?
 "The Governor apparently was lusting after this 1990 tax return," said Carl Golden, a spokesman for the Whitman campaign. "I don't know what he thought was in there. Maybe now he'll come out of hiding and talk about jobs, taxes and the economy and stop nit-picking."
The Florio campaign, whose style throughout the race has been a hard-hitting and swift attack against Mrs. Whitman at every turn, was uncharacteristically slow to respond today. When it did, the attack was weak.
"The Florio campaign currently is examining Christine Todd Whitman's 1990 tax returns, released to the press only today and obtained by the campaign late in the afternoon," a Florio camp statement said. "The campaign will provide full comment once that analysis is completed."
Jo Astrid Glading, a spokeswoman for the Florio campaign, said the Governor had only sought from Mrs. Whitman the same information her campaign had asked of him in July.
"It has taken Mrs. Whitman nearly three years to release these documents," she said. "It will take us more than a day to analyze them."
In response to questions about the $235,648 refund the couple received from New York State, Mr. Golden, the Whitman spokesman, said the refund was the result of an overpayment based on the bonus that Mr. Whitman received at the end of 1990.
The returns showed that the Whitmans made a large profit very quickly, trading stock options in Great Northern Nekoosa shortly before the company was acquired by the Georgia Pacific Corporation. The return did not show when the options were purchased, but it clearly was before traders were sure that the takeover would happen. The Whitmans made a profit of $23,068 on an investment of just $1,128.
The biggest capital gain reported by the Whitmans came from the sale of stock in the Specialty Materials Corporation, a privately held steel company that was purchased by a French firm. The stock, which they acquired in 1986 for $76,211, was sold in 1990 for $981,553.
But there were also losses on other investments. The Whitmans reported a loss of $62,502 on $68,752 in warrants to buy shares of Dr. Pepper Seven-Up. And a $156,000 investment that was made in the privately held Fortress Corporation in 1989 was sold on the last day of 1990 for $1, providing a loss that offset income from the Specialty Materials deal.
A spokesman for the Whitman campaign said only Mr. Whitman could discuss the investments, and he was not available to comment.
The Whitmans' 1990 income was five times the $600,000 gross income they reported in 1991, but only relatively higher than the total income of $3,597,063 they reported in 1992.
In 1992 the Whitmans paid more than $1.3 million in taxes to the Federal Government and the states of New Jersey and New York. They were due refunds of nearly $131,000.
Mr. Florio and his wife, Lucinda, released their Federal and state income tax returns in April. They paid $30,160 in Federal taxes and $8,237 in New Jersey taxes on an income of $171,106. Most of their income was from Mr. Florio's $85,000-a-year salary as Governor and his official expense account of $75,000.
Mrs. Whitman was not compelled by state election law to make her tax returns public, but she was under tremendous political pressure to do so. She had said she had far exceeded disclosure requirements, having released her 1989, 1991 and 1992 tax returns in August.
 
Comes From Old Money
 Mrs. Whitman said she saw no reason to release her 1990 returns because she was a private citizen in 1991, when the returns were prepared. She resigned as president of the State Board of Public Utilities in February 1990 to challenge Senator Bill Bradley.
Mrs. Whitman is a member of one of the wealthiest and most politically powerful families in New Jersey. Her father, the late Webster B. Todd, was Republican state chairman for a decade, a major figure in the national party and a building contractor whose projects included Rockefeller Center and Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan.
Mr. Florio has tried to make Mrs. Whitman's wealth an issue in the campaign. He has tried to paint her as an elitist who is out of touch with the average voter and has made her refusal to release the return an integral part of his stump speech, hinting that she was trying to hide some politically damaging information.
On Monday the Whitman campaign announced that she would release the 1990 returns by the end of the week in order to silence Mr. Florio on the issue.

HEADLINE: Big Rally Puts 30-Year Bond at 5.78%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell yesterday to levels not seen since the late 1960's, pushed lower by another highly favorable report on inflation.
The Government's report that its Consumer Price Index was unchanged in September set off a flood of buy orders for 30-year Treasury bonds, quickly pushing the bond's yield down to 5.78 percent, from 5.85 percent late Thursday. 
 The consumer price report was the second consecutive low-inflation number. On Thursday, the Labor Department reported that wholesale prices rose an unexpectedly weak two-tenths of a percent last month.
Taken together, the reports made unusually sweet reading for credit market analysts. They said the inflation outlook not only made a rise in interest rates unlikely, but that for the time being the Federal Reserve Board had achieved its oft-stated goal of price stability.
Over the last 12 months, consumer prices have risen 2.7 percent. And the shorter-term trend is even more impressive: over the last six months, consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 1.8 percent, and in the last three months at an annual rate of 1.4 percent.
"I would be willing to say right now that inflation is not an important factor in economic decision making, and by that criteria the Fed has reached its objective," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International. "It is ironic that at the time the Fed is probably enjoying its greatest success, they are probably facing their greatest challenge from legislators."
Reprseentative Henry B. Gonzalez, chairman of the House Banking Committee and a longstanding critic of the secretive way the Fed conducts monetary policy, began hearings earlier this week intended to fashion legislation that would force the Fed to open up its policy-making process. The Clinton Administration, for its part, has said it sees no need to change the way the central bank conducts its business.
Any legislation fashioned along the lines that Mr. Gonzalez favors would be a distinct negative for the credit markets, analysts said. But aside from that, they said there was little reason to feel uncomfortable about the outlook for bonds.
"You can't get bearish here," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities. "The inflation performance has been so favorable that it's hard to come up with a bad scenario."
Yesterday's price movements in the secondary market for Treasury securities suggest that traders largely share that view.
Two days of strong rallies often lead to profit taking, especially when the second day is a Friday. That did not happen yesterday.
"Nobody wants to take any profits over the weekend," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "As long as the inflation news remains benign, short rates will stay pretty constant, and long rates will continue to come down. I can't think of a better environment for investors in financial assets. It's almost scary, it looks so good."
Because of the increase in Federal gasoline taxes, economists do not anticipate that October's consumer price numbers will come close to matching the September performance. But inflation expectations in the bond market are receding, the analysts said, so one month of disappointing inflation figures will probably not spook the market.
In the secondary Treasury market, the 6 1/2 percent 30-year bonds of 2023 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10619/32 , up nearly a point, to yield 5.78 percent, compared with 5.85 percent late Thursday. The drop set a new 25-year low for long-term bond yields. Prices and yields move in opposite directions.
Among Treasury notes, the 5 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 10414/32 , up 10/32 , to yield 5.16 percent. It is the lowest yield level on a 10-year note since 1967.
Because the Federal Reserve Board is seen as unlikely to ease monetary policy, short-term interest rates were basically unchanged.
In the corporate bond market, the inflation news prompted a number of companies to price new issues. Among them was the Norwest Corporation, which offered $200 million worth of 30-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 6.65 percent bonds, which are noncallable, were priced at 99.606 to yield 6.68 percent, 72 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 1/2 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Yesterday's flurry of new corporate issues capped a busy week in what has been an exceptionally busy year.
In all, 32 corporate debt issues were priced this week, raising a total of $5.12 billion, according to analysts at MCM Inc.

HEADLINE: August's Trade Deficit Was 6.8% Below July's

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Higher overseas sales of American-made aircraft helped shrink America's foreign trade deficit by 6.8 percent in August, the Commerce Department said today.
Exports grew 3 percent, to $38.2 billion, reversing two months of decline in June and July, while imports increased by only eight-tenths of a percent, to $47.9 billion, putting the deficit at $9.7 billion.
Most of the pickup in exports came from a $707 million increase, to $1.6 billion, in sales of civilian aircraft abroad.
 
Some Problem Areas
 But there were some disquieting elements in the trade report. The deficit with Japan, for example, climbed to $5.26 billion, from $4.74 billion in July, accounting for more than half the overall deficit. The August gap was the widest since a $5.5 billion deficit in April.
And in trade with China, the deficit widened to $2.4 billion in August from $2.3 billion.
The Commerce Department revised the overall July trade deficit up slightly to show a gap of $10.4 billion instead of the previously reported $10.3 billion.
Trade has become a weak spot in the economy because overseas markets remain so soft that exports are unlikely to provide a major push for the slow-paced recovery. The gross domestic product grew at only a 1.3 percent annual rate in the first half of the year and is not expected to get help from foreign trade soon.
"We still believe trade will not add to economic growth before the middle of next year," said Edward Yardeni, an economist at C. J. Lawrence/ Deutsche Bank Securities.
The Commerce Department said trade data for the first eight months of 1993 indicated that the full-year deficit was growing at an annual rate of $115 billion -- well above 1992's total of $84.5 billion deficit.
But Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown noted that August was the second consecutive month that the overall trade deficit had narrowed since touching a high for the year of $12.1 billion in June.
"The need to increase our exports to narrow the deficit remains an important Administration priority," he said.
The White House is pushing on several fronts to open markets abroad, not only by improving access to developed countries like Japan but also to secure a free-trade zone with Mexico's emerging market.
 
Regional Results
 In trade with Mexico during August, the United States had a surplus of $110 million after registering a surplus in July of $108 million.
The trade deficit with Western Europe fell to $813 million, from $1.78 billion in July.
The deficit with Canada, the nation that does the most trade with the United States, fell to $477 million, from $649 million in July.
The cost of imported petroleum products fell to $3.9 billion in August from $4.2 billion in July. The price of a barrel of imported crude oil dropped to $14.53 from $15.
Imports of autos and parts from all sources grew in value by $778 million in August to $8.5 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Yen On Signs of Slack Economy

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar firmed against European currencies yesterday but drifted against the yen following reports on the sluggish state of the United States economy.
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose to 1.6163 German marks, from 1.6130 marks on Thursday. But it slipped to 107.10 Japanese yen from 107.32 yen. 
 Several reports on the American economy underscored the slow pace of the recovery and slowed the dollar's advance, dealers said.
The Labor Department said consumer prices were unchanged in September, sparking a bond rally that pushed the 30-year Treasury bond yield to a new low of 5.78 percent. Even excluding the volatile food and energy components, consumer prices rose just a tenth of a percent.
Lower interest rates make United States assets relatively less attractive. Even though most dealers said they expected European rates to ease as economies there floundered, the softer United States rates did not encourage dollar purchases.
The dollar was also held back by the latest trade data. While the United States deficit narrowed to $9.71 billion, from $10.42 billion in July, the gap with Japan accounted for half the total and was the biggest since April.
 
Some Encouraging Data
 Jack Griffin, a corporate dealer at Fuji Bank, said the dollar could ease because the figures would heighten trade tensions with Japan. A lower dollar is widely viewed as a corrective to the United States trade deficit.
Other data were more encouraging. September industrial production and August business inventories showed increases of two-tenths of a percent. Consumer confidence also picked up, according to a survey by the University of Michigan.
The dollar was also aided in late trading as the German mark gave up gains against European currencies. Earlier, the mark had posted all-time highs against the French franc. The British pound finished in New York at $1.5132, down from $1.5157 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4280 Swiss francs, up from 1.4230; 5.7260 French francs, up from 5.7043; 1,585 Italian lire, down from 1,589; 35.54 Belgian francs, up from 35.31, and 1.3307 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3253.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Iraqi Exports More Likely; Oil Prices Drop as a Result

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Oil prices tumbled yesterday after a United Nations official said for the first time that Iraq was close to meeting most Security Council demands to scrap its weapons.
But the official, Rolf Ekeus, said plans for monitoring Iraqi arms purchases had not been accepted, an essential demand before the Security Council considers lifting the prohibition of Iraqi oil exports. 
 The United Nations has barred Baghdad from selling oil since its army invaded Kuwait in 1990.
Mr. Ekeus said Iraq had complied with all demands in the biological and ballistic missile field and most demands in nuclear weapons. In chemical arms, he said data still needed to be verified before his commission could reach a conclusion.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for November delivery fell 23 cents, to $18.27 a barrel.
"What we're doing now is testing the lower end of the price range," said Gerald Samuels of Arb Oil. "Some traders are hesitant to get too bullish based on the way the market acted the last two years during November, when prices fell considerably."
Traders also attributed the drop to weakness in gasoline prices, which had been strong most of the week.
"A lot of it was gasoline breaking 53 cents," said Victor Yu of Refco. "That was a green light for the market to go down."
Unleaded gas for November delivery fell 0.27 cent, to 52.65 cents a gallon; heating oil decined 0.99 cent, to 54.53 cents a gallon, and November natural gas firmed 0.5 cent, to $2.172 for 1,000 cubic feet.
On other commodity markets, precious metals trading turned quiet, with silver prices rising slightly after a steep fall Thursday. The December silver contract gained 0.7 cent, to $4.355 an ounce, while December gold lost 40 cents, to $366.20 an ounce, at the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Government reports showing a slowly growing economy and little inflation had put pressure on silver prices in particular, since silver is primarily a metal used by industry.
Elsewhere, cattle prices continued to rise as traders viewed a recent low as a bottom and supermarket retailers focused on beef. Live cattle for December delivery rose 0.625 cent, to 74.7 cents a pound, while November feeder cattle firmed 0.55 cent, to 85.025 cents.

HEADLINE: Death Benefits Become Living Benefits

BYLINE: By FRANCIS FLAHERTY

 BODY:
Ill with cancer, Patricia North faced a heart-rending problem last year. Her doctor had told her to go immediately to Duke University for a bone-marrow transplant. But her health insurer was taking weeks to decide whether to pay for the $150,000 procedure. What could she do?
Ms. North, a 38-year-old sculptor and painter from Northern California, found a solution in her $200,000 worth of Prudential life insurance policies. She obtained an early payout of more than $190,000 on those standard policies, with the remainder going to Prudential for interest charges and administrative fees. The money financed her care at Duke and enabled her husband to stay with her there for six weeks. 
 "I am the very biggest fan of accelerated benefits," Ms. North said in a recent interview. Like many policyholders who receive such payments, sometimes called living benefits, Ms. North was considered terminally ill by her insurer. "Conventional chemotherapy had not helped, and cancer was going to win" without the transplant, she said. But she is hopeful now, and said her condition had improved since treatment.
Although relatively new, early payouts of life insurance are growing in popularity, and experts applaud the added flexibility. But they caution consumers against using them as a replacement for health insurance or long-term care insurance.
Most important, policyholders should think through several issues -- from family needs to tax implications -- before taking an early payout. And they should get help. "I don't think people should do this without the benefit of professsional advice," said David Petersen, president of Affording Care, a New York-based nonprofit group that counsels the seriously ill about financial matters.
Beneficiaries are the ones who stand to lose, of course, so policyholders must carefully consider their loved ones' needs. "You can't use the money twice," warned Janel Patterson of the American Council of Life Insurance. Policyholders with families and dependent children may want to preserve the death benefit by selling other assets or by borrowing.
Without any dependents, Ms. North did not face this problem. On her policies, her husband was the sole beneficiary.
Prudential alone has awarded $47 million in early payouts to 572 policyholders since January 1990, when it became the nation's first insurer to offer living benefits. Half the policyholders had cancer, 28 percent had AIDS and the rest suffered from other ailments, said Jim Longo, a company spokesman.
More than 150 of the nation's 2,300 life insurers, including Aetna, Cigna and Northwestern Mutual, have followed Prudential's lead. All told, "more than three million policies now have these benefits," Ms. Patterson said. Originally offered only on cash-value policies, living benefits are now available on term and group policies, too.
The payouts can be used for any purpose. Many policyholders, suffering the financial strains of serious illness, spend the money on living or medical expenses. One Prudential policyholder bought his family a washing machine and dryer, and then treated them to a two-week vacation. Another paid off the car and the house to ease the burden on his wife.
Although Ms. North sought the payout to cover medical expenses, her health insurer eventually reimbursed her for the treatment. She then plowed the excess money into a house remodeling project -- which had been in the works when illness struck.
Along with life insurers, about 50 "viatical settlement" companies offer living benefits. A viatical company will pay a portion of a policy's face value in return for being named the policy's beneficiary. Then it pays the premiums until the policyholder dies, recouping its payout plus some from the insurer.
Since first appearing in 1988, viatical companies have bought about $250 million in policies, as measured by face value. "They're growing at the rate of one a month," Mr. Petersen said.
Policyholders considering an early payout should understand how insurers and viatical companies differ. "It's like selling a used car," Mr. Petersen said. "I tell people to shop their policy around to see what offers they'll get."
Prudential's practices are representative of insurers. To get living benefits, a Prudential policyholder generally must be certified by a doctor as having six months or less to live. For these policyholders, the insurer will pay the face amount of the policy, minus a $150 administrative fee and the six months of interest Prudential will presumably lose from the premature payout. No extra premium is charged.
At Prudential's 8 percent interest rate, a policyholder will now get about "95 to 96 percent of the policy's face value," Mr. Longo said. The interest charge is fixed at six months, whatever the policyholder's life expectancy.
Rules vary. Some insurers use a 12-month life expectancy; others, including Prudential, also make payouts to certain nonterminally ill policyholders, like those needing nursing home care or continuous life support. Some set minimum or maximum payouts. And some add 3 percent to 15 percent to premiums for the right to get living benefits. That practice does not appeal to J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization. "I think living benefits are basically a good thing," he said. "But why pay for them if I don't use them?"
While viatical companies tend to be more expensive than insurers, they fill a gap in the market and generally place fewer restrictions on payouts. Policyholders whose insurers do not offer living benefits can get early payouts only from viaticals, for instance, and, unlike viaticals, some insurers restrict living benefits to no 50 percent of a policy's face value.
Perhaps most important, people diagnosed with two years to live may be able to get payouts right away from a viatical instead of waiting to qualify for benefits from their insurers.
Among viatical companies, Living Benefits is the nation's oldest and largest. Based in Albuquerque, N.M., the company buys the policies of those with two years or less to live. Like an insurer, the company evaluates a potential client's medical record. But the payout varies based on the policyholder's estimated life expectancy. "Our minimum payout is 60 percent and our maximum is 80 percent" of face value, said Gerry Mandel, the company president.
Some of these companies, however, may be slow in paying. Large ones have cash at the ready, but small ones may have uneven cash flows or merely act as brokers who "shop" policies to investors.
Before selling, a policyholder should verify that the company has money is there. The policyholder should also make sure that the company protects his or her privacy as it seeks payout funds from potential investors.
Currently unregulated, viatical companies would be controlled by state insurance departments under a model law being drafted by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. Such regulation is welcomed by those who worry about exploitation.
"Older people and sick people are always easy prey," Mr. Hunter said. "At least an insurance company is checked." Such concerns stem partly from stories, some true, of "outrageous, vampire-like ripoffs" in the viatical industry's early days, he said.
Most experts play down these dangers now. "We haven't had a lot of instances" of exploitation, Mr. Petersen said. The consumer gets cash and knows the policy's face value, he explained, and this leaves little room for deception.
In the end, living benefits offer great value to careful policyholders. "If I didn't have this financial freedom, we would have had to put our house on the market in a very poor economy," Ms. North said. "But with the benefits, we wound up remodeling it instead."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patricia North, shown with a sculpture in progress, took a premature life insurance payout to cover costly medical treatment for cancer. (Rich Pedroncelli for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Press Clippings From Dinkins

BYLINE: By Todd. S. Purdum

 BODY:

ON THE SCREEN
Black-and-white photo of Rudolph W. Giuliani appears at left while titles repeating the narration flash on a bulletin board background, along with newspaper headlines ("A Victim's Mantle for Mr. Giuliani" and "Rudy's big, muddy guns"). Ominous music plays. Final image is cover of The Village Voice, with unflattering caricature of Mr. Giuliani, over tiny picture of Mr. Dinkins and credit line noting his campaign paid for commercial. As ad ends, black-and-white headline "Department of Dirty Tricks" turns brilliant blue.
 
PRODUCER
Doak, Shrum, Harris, Carrier, Devine of Washington 

THE SCRIPT
Male narrator: "First, Rudolph Giuliani ran ads The New York Times called 'explicitly racial.' Ads 'stirring feelings of racial paranoia.' Now his campaign's in trouble. And he's attacking Mayor Dinkins for everything from his tenure as City Clerk to jobs lost during the Reagan-Bush recession. Some charges are twenty years old, others half-truths and innuendo. More of what The Times called Giuliani's 'politics of disinformation.' But what else would you expect from a man whose last campaign was exposed by The Village Voice as having a "Department of Dirty Tricks."
 
ACCURACY
The Times editorial is quoted accurately, but the ad fails to mention that it also harshly criticized the Mayor's supporters for suggesting that Mr. Giuliani attracted facists, and chided Mr. Dinkins for "tepid disavowals" that were "possibly calculated" to inspire black voters. It is not so clear whose campaign is in trouble. Most polls show the contest is too close to call. Innuendo is in the eye of the beholder, of course, but there has been plenty to go around in the ads of both camps. The Village Voice headline refers to a story about Anthony J. Lombardi, an Internal Revenue Service agent who, the story said, looked into the backgrounds of Dinkins campaign aides in 1989 and inquired into former Mayor Edward I. Koch's sex life. But the story said there was no proof that Mr. Giuliani was aware of this, Mr. Giuliani has denied any involvement, and the Dinkins campaign itself has hired a private detective to look into Mr. Giuliani's record this year.
 
SCORECARD
This commercial, a response to Mr. Giuliani's latest attacks on the Mayor, is a classic of the "Let him that is without sin cast the first stone" genre, and the embodiment of the prevailing maxim that an attack unrebutted is an attack believed. It also uses another classic advertising technique: the expert arbiter -- in this case newspapers with editorial postures as diverse as The Village Voice and The Times -- to buttress its case that the other guy is worse. It tries to paint Mr. Giuliani as the one who started the fighting, but since the ad it criticizes was a response by Mr. Giuliani to attacks from the Dinkins camp, it is not fair to say, "First Rudolph Giuliani ran ads..."; it is hard to tell who did what first. Finally, by continuing to ratchet up harsh oratory, it may alienate as many voters as it persuades.
 TODD S. PURDUM

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Texas Instruments' Net Up on Strong Sales

BYLINE: BY KATHRYN JONES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 15

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc. said today that third-quarter net income more than doubled and revenues jumped 14 percent because of strong orders for microchips and higher royalty revenues.
The record results exceeded Wall Street expectations and helped increase the shares of Texas Instruments, which, along with other semiconductor stocks, had fallen in recent weeks amid investor worries about potentially weaker industry sales, eroding profit margins and slower growth next year. 
 Texas Instruments shares closed today at $65.875, up $2.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, said net income in the quarter soared to $146 million, or $1.54 a share, compared with $57 million, or 58 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues rose to $2.16 billion, compared with $1.89 billion in the corresponding period last year.
Sales of electronic components were up 29 percent and semiconductor profit margins improved for the sixth consecutive quarter, Texas Instruments said. The higher semiconductor profits helped offset a loss in its information technology unit and lower profits in military electronics. The company does not break out sales and earnings figures for its business segments on a quarterly basis.
John M. Geraghty, a semiconductor analyst at the First Boston Corporation, said the third-quarter results benefited from sales of specialized products with higher margins, as well as royalty payments, which are becoming a staple in the revenues of the company as it aggressively protects its technology patents.
"Their semiconductor business product mix is getting richer with more profitable products," said Mr. Geraghty, who had estimated Texas Instruments would earn $1.15 in the quarter. "This is a company that clearly has improved over the last several years relative to its product mix and the way it's running the business."
Royalties also doubled to $168 million in the quarter from $83 million a year ago. They included $37 million in one-time royalties for computer systems patents and higher continuing royalties for semiconductor patents.
Semiconductor orders and shipments hit record levels mainly because of demand for the microchips in computers and telecommunications equipment, said Jerry R. Junkins, Texas Instruments' chairman, president and chief executive. "The world semiconductor market remains strong," he said in a statement.
Customer demand has been so intense that Texas Instruments has had to limit some bookings of new orders, said William A. Aylesworth, Texas Instruments' chief financial officer, in a telephone interview. The company is also expanding and announced in August that it planned to build a $1 billion manufacturing plant to make next-generation microchips.
Texas Instruments officials still forecast worldwide industry growth at more than 20 percent this year, although some analysts expected growth to slow to 15 percent next year.

HEADLINE: Who Are You Calling a Drunk?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
To this 20-year resident of Corofin, in County Clare, Ireland, Peter Finn's review of Rosemary Maho ney's "Whoredom in Kimmage" (Aug. 29) ignores the obvious. This book is an ethnic and sexist assault on our highly respected village and its decent people. Her "research," limited largely to just one pub and one family, extrapolates venomously to a community composed predominantly of superstitious, obscene and unemployed drunkards with repellent physical features, seedy clothing and illegitimate babies. She conveys an image of rural Ireland that is grossly inaccurate. 
 The many thousands of American tourists who know Corofin will recognize Ms. Mahoney's selection and portrayal of subjects as prejudiciously atypical. Had she aimed her feminist invective, instead, at Spanish Harlem or Hasidic Brooklyn, no respectable house -- fearful of the political and legal backlash -- would have published it.
 
DANIEL R. MURPHY
Corofin, Ireland

HEADLINE: Rules vs. Risk

BYLINE: By Neil A. Lewis; Neil A. Lewis is a Washington correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

BREAKING THE VICIOUS CIRCLE
Toward Effective
Risk Regulation.
By Stephen Breyer.
127 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $22.95. 
 WHEN Ronald Reagan took office in 1981, leaders of the nation's largest corporations who had long chafed at the expanding regime of Federal regulations knew they had an ally in the White House. They set about waging a full-scale campaign to reverse the trend, even as liberals prepared to hold the fort at all costs.
By the time George Bush completed the dozen years of Republican rule, the debate over regulation was thoroughly debased by both sides. Vice President Dan Quayle's Competitiveness Council served as the vehicle for industry to get rid of as many regulations as it could as fast as it could. Many Congressional liberals were unyielding, insisting, for example, that complicated food labeling regulations apply to restaurant menus.
During that 12 years one of the most provocative commentator-critics on the subject was Stephen Breyer, the Federal appeals court judge in Boston whom President Clinton considered and then rejected for the Supreme Court this year. At the beginning of the Reagan Presidency, he wrote a book, "Regulation and Its Reform," whose theme was that problems with regulation were not the result of sloppy or stupid regulators but rather a mismatch of regulations to risks. Now he has written a new and brief (leave aside the footnotes and charts and it is barely an 80-page read) volume polishing his theories.
Business leaders and conservative economists of the anti-regulation, take-no-prisoners camp would do well to examine "Breaking the Vicious Circle" carefully. They would discover that, the analyses of Judge Breyer's views that circulated during the brief period he was under consideration for the Supreme Court notwithstanding, he is not one of them.
In essence, Judge Breyer fully accepts the need for a strong regulatory system and does not believe that rules designed to enhance safety and health menace market forces. (He does not, though, discuss his service as a senior aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the 1970's, when he served as the intellectual father of airline deregulation -- an experiment on which the jury is decidedly still out.) Judge Breyer is, however, a stern critic of how choices are made about which substances and practices to regulate and which hazards to spend time and money on.
The book reads like one of those intellectually exciting lectures for which some professors become so well known that their courses are fittingly oversubscribed every year. The style is clear and the analysis is dotted with the kind of provocative questions at the heart of this debate: how much regulation is enough, how much is too much, and the ultimate question, what is the dollar value of a life?
THE vicious circle of the title is a reference to the way priorities get distorted. He uses as an example a case in his own court about cleaning up a dump in southern New Hampshire. Regulators were pushed to clean up the last 10 percent of toxic chemicals from a swamp because of public concern. The issue was whether to spend $9.3 million to clean up the dump's last batch of pollutants. The site was clean enough for children playing on the site to eat small amounts of dirt daily for 70 days each year without harm. Getting rid of the last batch would have made it clean enough for the children to eat dirt for 245 days a year. Yet there were no dirt-eating children. The site was a swamp.
This, Judge Breyer writes, is a powerful argument, "not necessarily for deregulation, but for a serious effort to prioritize, and perhaps to reallocate, our regulatory resources."
Congress, enormously susceptible to public concern about toxic waste, contributes to the distortion of priorities, he says. He also contends that regulators aim their rules narrowly, to deal with one problem, while worsening another: "Proposed rules concerning disposal of sewage sludge, designed to save one statistical life every five years, would encourage waste incineration likely to cause two statistical cancer deaths annually."
But when Judge Breyer moves from the diagnostic to the prescriptive his persuasiveness evaporates. His proposal for breaking the vicious circle is a sort of super-regulatory agency to arbitrate with wisdom the competing claims on the Government's limited regulatory resources. Elitist? Yes, he acknowledges. But he fails to deal with the problems that raises in turn.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 5; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1996 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Life May Be a Madness, but It's Also a Poem

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL

DATELINE: DUBLIN

 BODY:
You can tell that Noel Pearson became a theatrical producer and not the priest he once thought he'd be by his two favorite words. The first is madness, which he uses to describe everything from talent to the weather. The second is delivered so often in his Irish brogue that it's almost a chant. It rhymes with hooking, except when it rhymes with hook.
Actually, Mr. Pearson inspired great choruses of this favorite word from the crew of the 1992 Tony Awards broadcast when he accepted the best play award for Brian Friel's "Dancing at Lughnasa." Mr. Pearson had produced the play about five Irish sisters in the summer of 1937 first at the Abbey Theater here, where he had been the artistic director. With the Tony show almost 15 minutes past its scheduled end, he pulled a book from his pocket and announced he would read "a wee short poem by William Butler Yeats, who founded the Abbey nearly 100 years ago." 
 As poems go, it was as wee short as a network could hope for. And since he never got to speak during the previous year's Academy Awards broadcast, when his film "My Left Foot," about the Irish writer and artist Christy Brown, lost to "Born on the Fourth of July," he was due.
This season he's back on Broadway with Mr. Friel's newest play, "Wonderful Tennessee," which is to open at the Plymouth Theater next Sunday. The reception here has been mixed. Three middle-aged couples inadvertently spend a night together on a pier, where they take stock of the small victories and big disappointments in their lives, yearning, as Mr. Friel's characters are wont, for even the slightest spiritual release. But after three months of work, Mr. Pearson says, the play opening next week is quite different from the one already reviewed.
" 'Lughnasa' was such a big and unlikely hit," Mr. Pearson says, "that I don't know what will happen to 'Tennessee.' But I'll stand over it no matter what. It's frustrating if they want us to get like Hollywood now, bringing over 'Lughnasa II,' 'III' and 'IV,' " he adds, sitting in the living room of his 1820 town house, where an excellent self-portrait by Daniel Day-Lewis hangs, painted with his left foot. Along with Patrick Mason, the director, Mr. Pearson has been staying close to the Abbey while Mr. Friel writes, dropping 10 minutes from the first act, adding 10 new ones to the second.
But will it work? Mr. Pearson, who is 50, seems jittery. "Everyone in New York is so cynical," he says. "You never hear anyone wish you good luck. And here, some of the critics have actually compared 'Tennessee' to 'Lughnasa' scene by scene. It's nonsense, y'know? On opening night Friel hid in the back corridor of the theater. He wouldn't even come into the bar.
"The Irish critics were equally split on 'Lughnasa,' " he continues. "I think there's too much truth in 'Tennessee' for the Irish to deal with." He starts to pace. "It's very up front about lives and mistakes. After a few drinks at 4 in the morning everything is not what it appears. All the pretense is set aside, and this bothers a lot of people."
Luckily for Mr. Friel, whose reclusiveness in recent years has bordered on fetish, Mr. Pearson plays his point man with civilization willingly. "Like a fine wine, he doesn't travel too well," he says, excusing Mr. Friel's absence at the Tony Awards. He even tolerates the 64-year-old playwright's refusal to speak into a microphone for the documentary Mr. Pearson is making about "Wonderful Tennessee," though he has agreed to appear on camera. "To get on Friel's wavelength takes a long time," Mr. Pearson admits. "He's a sensitive, vulnerable man. You have to build up a confidence."
Their relationship began in 1979, he recalls, in New York. Mr. Friel's play "The Faith Healer" had just opened on Broadway where it was poorly received, as was an Irish ballet of "The Playboy of the Western World," which Mr. Pearson had imported to City Center. "And that same time," he says, "Siobhan McKenna opened at the Palace in something, and it closed in one night. And this Irish journalist tracked me down at 5 in the morning at Eamonn Doran's on Second Avenue where I was singing the blues to myself and he said the critics had not been kind to Brian, and not to me, either, and could I last the whole two weeks with the ballet? It would be a sad day for Ireland, he said, if the count was Broadway 3, Ireland 0.
"I was staying at the Royalton then, back in the days when the roaches did jigs at the end of the room, and Brian Friel was staying across the street at the Algonquin. He was drinking sizable gins and feeling sore and we started to talk. We became friends. Then in 1987 I took over the Abbey and he wrote me a very warm letter and I asked him to give me a play. He gave me 'Lughnasa,' in 1988, two years before it moved to London. Nobody wanted it there. Nobody wanted it on Broadway, either, at first. An Irish play had not been successful there since 'Da.' "
Still, Mr. Pearson persevered and Mr. Friel is lyrical in his appreciation: "If a theater producer should have the head of a businessman, the heart of a gambler and the untutored intuitions of an artist, then Noel Pearson is thrice -- and abundantly -- blessed," he says.
Outside now, thunder rumbles as the sun shines, in what Mr. Pearson calls typical Irish weather. "Madness," he pronounces it, and chilled, moves near the fire. His face looks pale against his black shirt, though there's a twinkle about him, an almost kindly quality that lives side by side with a prankster, maybe even a hustler. If he offered you a game of three-card monte you'd have no choice but to run. Sometimes his eyes are the eyes of a choirboy, solemn and wide open, seeming to bare his soul and all its secrets. Sometimes he looks everywhere but at you, piling on all the blarney doubletalk he can find. His own joke is: "I don't lie. I'm economical with the truth."
Add in how difficult it is for him to articulate emotion, which only feeds his passion to find writing that can, and voila: a producer. Not a theater owner, not an investor, not a hanger-on. "I find it hilarious at the Tonys when 98 producers get up for one play. I break up laughing," he says. "I don't believe that investors get billing. A hundred thousand dollars doesn't make you a producer, and you can't teach people how to be producers. I was at Yale a year ago, and they didn't have a clue what I was talking about. All I tell investors they will get out of it is the first night party and a bit of a laugh. Can you imagine," he says, talking about "Angels in America," "all 13 producers having breakfast with Tony Kushner the next morning and giving him notes?
"I am terrible at raising money," he adds. "I could never go to a stranger for it." Happily for Mr. Pearson, the Shubert Organization is willing to finance his creative legwork, especially after "Lughnasa." "They put up with my madness," he says "and never ask to interfere."
His madness, as he calls it, is rooted in coming up the hard way. After graduating from a junior seminary, and rejecting the priesthood, Mr. Pearson went to work at the Dublin Fruit Market, which led him to become a union organizer. In the mid-60's he managed the Chessmen, a pop-rock band, moving on to manage the Dubliners, a well-regarded folk group. After 12 years with them, he tried the theater, bringing shows like "Jesus Christ Superstar" and "Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat" to Dublin.
Musicals were only part of what interested him. He produced a variety of dramas, including an unfinished Brendan Behan play, "Richard's Cork Leg" at the Peacock, the Abbey's second stage, which transferred to London's Royal Court. Like most impresarios, he loses as big as he wins. Broadway diehards might remember "Brothers," starring Carroll O'Connor, a play that closed at the Music Box Theater after one night in 1983. Conversely, his gamble on "Lughnasa" has paid off. In the next six months alone there will be 63 productions of it in the United States, though his Broadway offering of last season, "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me," a drama about three hostages in the Middle East by the Irish playwright Frank McGuinness, recouped only half its investment.
Undaunted, Mr. Pearson has hired Mr. McGuinness to write the book of a new musical called "Limelight." He found its composer, Chris Curtis, an American, playing piano in the bar of a Los Angeles restaurant. "It's about Charlie Chaplin -- not the little tramp but the rejection by America of Chaplin during the McCarthy era and their acceptance of him at the end."
Mr. Pearson has also purchased the film rights to the unfortunately titled novel "The Dork of Cork" by Chet Raymo, an astronomy professor at Stonehill College in Massachusetts. (Mr. Pearson promptly renamed the screenplay "The Seventh Moon.") He stayed up until 6 in the morning reading the book, he says, "an astonishing story about a beautiful French girl who wants to go to Hollywood and gets only as far as Ireland, where she gives birth to a dwarf.
"Studios would scream at a mad idea like this," he says with glee. After "My Left Foot," Universal gave him an exclusive producing contract, which, unsurprisingly, did not work out. "Everything I gave them they turned down, including 'Lughnasa,' " he says. "One guy told me to stop sending play scripts because they would think I'm nuts."
Sticking to the theater for now, Mr. Pearson plans to transfer the critically acclaimed Royal National Theater production of J. B. Priestley's "Inspector Calls" to a Shubert theater later this season.
"Since I've been going to Broadway, they say, 'It's dead, it's dead.' Everyone in New York should lighten up a little," he says. "The gossip on Broadway is frightening. You know that Sondheim song 'The Ladies Who Lunch'? It's the men who lunch now. I'm not a morning person, but when you open a play you get all the calls by 10 A.M. saying, 'Did you hear?' Instead of celebrating, they'll ring you about a show that's not a huge hit. There should be a place for those shows, anyway. You can't have genius every day, y'know?"
Though he spends the majority of the year working in New York, Los Angeles and London, his children remain in Ireland. His daughter, Catherine, 20, is earning a master's degree in English, and his son, Leo, 19, is a drummer. Mr. Pearson has been separated from his wife for 16 years.
He calls the dating rituals in New York "very strange." "When they introduce you, they never say your name. They say he's the producer of 'My Left Foot' and 'Dancing at Lughnasa,' then you meet these women who want a relationship after the soup. I met an Irish gal, a big-deal model, extraordinarily beautiful. We sat down to dinner and she says she's in therapy, takes singing and acting lessons, but now she's taking her Doberman and her white Jeep off into the desert to find herself. I said, 'If your poor mother in Ireland heard this! Did you ever think of having a few drinks and working it off?' You have this great word, relate. I find it hard to relate."
Hard, also relating to expectations for 'Lughnasa II.' But if he makes it to the Tony Awards again, will he leave the poetry at home? He looks wounded. "You know, when I got up there that night and thought about all my experiences in New York, that ballet and 'Brothers' that closed in one night, I didn't want to just thank my granny. Yeats was the founder of the Abbey, and the whole thing had come full circle. It wasn't meant to be opportunistic, or corny."
And with all of the tenderness of a man who can't write, he recites "He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven" again:
 
 Had I the heavens' embroidered cloths,
Enwrought with golden and silver light,
The blue and the dim and the dark cloths
Of night and light and the half-light,
I would spread the cloths under your feet:
But I, being poor, have only my dreams;
I have spread my dreams under your feet;
Tread softly because you tread on my dreams.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 10; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: DANCE VIEW;
An Artist Who Spoke For the People

BYLINE: By Anna Kisselgoff

 BODY:
Perhaps more than anyone, Agnes de Mille, who died on Oct. 7 at the age of 88, made ballet a household word in America: she was the art form's chief populist and popularizer. Anyone acquainted with the personal heritage she described so vividly in her many autobiographical books would realize how naturally she expressed these traits in her life and work.
The democratic streak that ran admirably through de Mille's ballets -- from "Rodeo," the masterpiece she created in 1942, to "The Informer" of 1988 -- came down from the principles of her maternal grandfather, the economist and social reformer Henry George. 
 What other choreographer and former dancer would have boomed out dire warnings against "big business" as Agnes de Mille did in the 1970's and 1980's? And she did so in her dazzling curtain speeches and in "Conversations About the Dance," the onstage dance-history narration that eventually reached millions on public television.
Class consciousness was relevant to her. In "Fall River Legend" (1948), she convicted Lizzie Borden of ax-murder although the real-life Lizzie was acquitted of killing her father and stepmother. It was de Mille's contention that the prominent citizens of Fall River, Mass., stood by a member of their milieu. Years later, doing original research, de Mille wrote a brilliant book about the case ("Lizzie Borden: A Dance of Death").
That was the populist strain in de Mille. "Rodeo," with its tomboy cowgirl getting her man in the land of opportunity -- the frontier of the American West -- was typical of the choreographer's faith in folk and future.
The popularizer in her came from the de Mille side. Uncle Cecil, with his film epics, needs no further introduction. But Henry C. de Mille and William de Mille, respectively Agnes's grandfather and father, were playwrights with Broadway hits (William later worked in Hollywood). It was undoubtedly from them that de Mille took her cardinal belief that dance, like theater, meant communication: in her words, "a statement that has to be witnessed and shared."
The choreographer's most famous exercise in accessibility was the dream ballet in the 1943 hit "Oklahoma!," her first Broadway show. Unsuspecting audiences were served up genuine ballet choreography in the form of de Mille's astute amalgam of a 19th-century vision scene and psychological dance-drama, which she and Antony Tudor promoted in the 1940's.
De Mille remained most at home in the dominant esthetics of the 1940's. Her enduring ballets are few and date from that period: "Rodeo," "Fall River Legend" and the comic "Three Virgins and a Devil" (1941). A self-described "overwrought pantomimist" at the beginning of her dancing career, she picked up her classical training on a scattershot basis and was more interested in motivated gesture than what she called "French steps." In the end, this approach had possibly restricted her creative range.
Yes, she was a better writer than a choreographer (although she could be inaccurate, notably in her book about Martha Graham, published last year). But these volumes popularized dance and American social history. Those that reached an eloquent pitch (especially "Where the Wings Grow") also revealed the true Agnes de Mille, full of gumption and go.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
What Parson Rather Left Out of His Sermon

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
Courtesy demands that in musing over Dan Rather's recent criticisms of television news, one resist the conclusion that he had Connie Chung in mind. After all, Mr. Rather greeted his new partner with gallant affection when she arrived a few months ago to help him do a job that anchors down the years have managed to do single-handedly without visible strain.
So when he says now of the unnamed masters of his fate, "They've got us putting more and more fuzz and wuzz on the air," he cannot have in mind the undeniably decorative Ms. Chung. And when he accuses market researchers of subverting the judgment of professional journalists, he cannot be implying that she owes her new status to her popularity and the prospect that she may lift the "CBS Evening News" ratings. By no means. 
 Indeed, Mr. Rather's call for more minorities on news programs may be interpreted as an invitation to Peter Jennings and Tom Brokaw to follow his example and share their roles with Asian-American women. Yet his talk somehow leaves the impression that he does not deeply relish sitting there many a night and looking on with fond interest as his teammate delivers headlines from the prompter. Can it have been a need to escape that drove him to spend several summer days at the scene of a hurricane that did not live up to his presence and possibly his hopes? You'd think that having a network anchorman in the vicinity would inspire the winds to blow with extra gusto.
Ms. Chung aside, or beside, what makes Mr. Rather's brave denunciation of the commercial television mentality ring hollow is his refusal to utter an unkind word about the brains or taste of the great American audience, those co-conspirators of their own exploitation.
Television's many critics can hardly fault Mr. Rather for delivering to the annual convention of the Radio and Television News Directors Association the sort of complaints they themselves have been churning out for years to no great effect, and his strong words like "complacency" and "cowardice" are especially welcome. The promise of television, he told the news directors, has been "squandered and cheapened." Invoking the sainted Edward R. Murrow (who deserves a rest), he invited mass contrition. "We should all be ashamed of what we have and have not done, measured against what we could do."
Now, coming from such a source, that is a veritable expose. Advertising and publicity for network news programs give the anchors star billing as super reporters and in-charge types. Any allusion to their prodigious salaries is quickly followed by notice that their responsibilities go far beyond introducing the dispatches of working stiffs in the field. One of Mr. Rather's titles, remember, is managing editor of the "CBS Evening News." Viewers are left to assume that the anchors are in charge of choosing, shaping, positioning and interpreting the day's stories. What else could justify their high pay?
But here is Mr. Rather confessing that power over what has until lately been advertised as his program is in the hands of others, fearful creatures at the mercy of ratings. He laments over "the things that fear makes them make us do," like substituting "live pops" for thoughtful analysis. Those shadowy decision makers are making Mr. Rather do things he doesn't want to do. "We -- you and I -- have allowed them to do it, and even helped them to do it."
Well, that's news. Not only does it explain his program's increased attention to soft features and other adornments, but it must also explain why Mr. Rather ended his recent interview with Hillary Rodham Clinton with a lame joke and why the interview was so brief. He is confessing that he, and by implication Mr. Jennings and Mr. Brokaw, are paid by the standards of entertainment, not journalism, for their on-screen personas more than their professional skills. Behind the camera, these authoritative figures are evidently being pushed around, like glamorpusses in the old Hollywood turned to jelly by bullying producers. One's heart goes out.
Imitating generations of critics of radio and television, Mr. Rather blames market researchers for the "showbizzification" of news programs and for promoting the following propositions: "American audiences won't put up with news from other countries. Americans won't put up with economic news. Americans won't put up with serious, substantive news of any kind." To such negative thinking, Mr. Rather cries, "Bull feathers!"
Is that so? Delighted though any reviewer must be with Mr. Rather's exhortations to news directors to confront the decision makers and to "go with quality and substance" instead of sleaze and glitz, his dismissal of market research as bull feathers is bull feathers. Such populist effusions have long served as smokescreens for critics who are willing to put the blame for the deficiencies of television anyplace but on the audience. The cigar chewers in the executive suites are, after all, easy marks; everyone enjoys despising them.
Mr. Rather condemns pandering. Well, it is a form of pandering, not to mention bad reporting, to blame advertisers or corporate chiefs or their functionaries for imposing inferior stuff on an America athirst for quality. Just as he flattered his audience of news directors with the assurance that "your own knowledge of news and human nature, your own idealism and professionalism will guide you more surely than any market researcher ever will," he flattered the television audience by saying it craves better programs than it is being offered.
The ratings may not be all that scientific, but the bottom-liners have learned that they are more reliable guides to the nation's taste than high-minded journalists. Corporate executives are not by and large suicidal. If they were persuaded by the figures that news from other countries, economic news and serious, substantive news of any kind would bring in more money than game shows or crime shows, America would have an hour's worth of such nourishment every night. The problem faced by Mr. Rather and his allies is that mass merchandising does not permit much in the way of boutique programming. That's the reason for public television.
So good luck to Mr. Rather in his campaign to stand up to the bad guys and rouse others in his trade to do likewise. But he had better recognize that the fat cats he is fighting have nothing more devious in mind than catering to the enormous audience he wants to serve, and that bold talk notwithstanding, he is more a beneficary of the show-biz system than a victim. He has to hope that the watering down and dolling up of the "CBS Evening News" do not increase its ratings, for otherwise he may be driven to flee the studio and charge about the land trying to stir up new hurricanes against the old windmills.

HEADLINE: TROUBLED WATER

 BODY:
Many of the tests required under the current Safe Drinking Water Act have nothing to do with preventing the kind of public health problems cited in Sara Terry's article "Drinking Water Comes to a Boil" (Sept. 26). Instead, Congress has made public water suppliers spend large sums of money to search for and eliminate contaminants that present little or no public health risks. Thus, when "violations" occur, they are often meaningless bureaucratic occurrences that cause money to be spent for no real purpose. 
 Terry belittles attempts to compare the benefits and the costs of meeting higher standards, giving credence to the comment that water must be "completely safe." While long on emotion, such a statement is short on science, economics and public policy. It is entirely appropriate for society to make choices about the relative costs and benefits of different levels of pollution control, public safety and the like. Among the issues to be resolved are whether public water supplies should meet standards for immune-deficient people or for the public in general. As difficult as such decisions are, we have to remember that society needs to decide where and how to spend its money to best protect the public. The Safe Drinking Water Act is one law that has not done this very well.
 
PAUL F. LEVY
Executive Director, Massachusetts Water Resources Authority, 1987-1992
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: Habitats/S.R.O.;
New Deal for Old Hotel

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
THERE is the unmistakable bustle of a construction site as carpenters coated with plaster dust hop over electrical cables running along the floor in the lobby of the Narragansett, a single-room-occupancy hotel at 93d Street and Broadway in Manhattan.
Within a few months, the lobby, with its austere glass-partitioned front desk, will become much more elegant, with a concierge's desk in the corner inside the front door. Burgundy carpet salvaged from the Russian Tea Room will be used to redecorate the rooms. Kitchens are being installed on each of the 11 upper floors. 
 The 47,000-square-foot hotel was bought for $3.45 million this summer by Housing and Services Inc., a nonprofit group that is rehabilitating the building while keeping its occupants, many of whom receive rent subsidies, in residence. The group's goals include housing persons with the AIDS virus. Of the Narragansett's 14 full-time and 6 part-time employees, 4 are full-time social workers and substance-abuse counselors.
"It's the first time that a building that was already a major residence for AIDS tenants was taken over by a group that wanted to house the same people -- only better," said Claire Haaga, president and founder of H.S.I.
Right now, about 40 percent of the Narragansett's occupants are rent-stabilized tenants who have lived there for years. The rest are persons with AIDS, who were living there when HSI bought the building. There are city transit workers, musicians and unemployed people, among others, Ms. Haaga said.
Frances DeMartino-Gonzalez, who has lived at the Narragansett for 11 years, has seen changes in the first two months with the new landlord. "Already some of the more undesirable tenants have left," she said, "and H.S.I. has started providing two meals a day, where before some people had to beg on the street for food."
David Smith, known as Dee to his friends, has lived at the Narragansett only since April. He likes the H.S.I. people, he said, because "they just don't talk about things -- they do them." He said he had been reluctant to move to an S.R.O. because his friends had lived in a drug-ridden one. "They were scared to go out and scared to come in," he said.
NOT at The Narragansett, however. "This is by far the best," he said, looking around his carpeted 150-square-foot room with lustrous yellow walls and private bath -- one of the 50 rooms with private baths out of the total 100 rooms there.
To buy the Narragansett, the current owners put together a combination of city rental subsidies and private loans. Chase Community Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan, lent $4.9 million at 8 percent for acquisition and rehabilitation. "We've never done anything like this before," said Mark A. Willis, the Chase unit's president, who said it was the first time a private bank in New York City had lent money to an S.R.O. with AIDS tenants.
Ms. Haaga and the project lawyer, Richard Higgins, had to sort through a tangled web of details. The past owners had filed for bankruptcy, and the building was in foreclosure, according to Ms. Haaga, who is also a lawyer. Because of title problems, the closing lasted from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. "Our last extension from the bankruptcy court expired on July 30 and we closed on July 29," she said.
"The whole thing was a stretch," she said, "but we think it's a good kind of risk to take."

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Sharing a Studio In a Co-op
 
Q. My wife and I own an alcove studio on East 77th Street. We have been renting it out with board approval and the board scrutinizes tenants thoroughly. We now feel we would like to use the apartment ourselves, but because the maintenance is so high we would like to give the key to two other couples. Each couple would use the apartment for a whole or partial week once every three weeks. Do we need board approval? . . . Manny Zahav, Belle Harbor, Queens 

A. Yes. According to Arthur Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer, under most proprietary leases you would need to get board approval for this type of arrangement. "This is a sublet," he said. Mr. Weinstein also said many boards might be reluctant to give that approval because they might feel the arrangement was transient.
 
Structural Change In a Co-op Studio
 
Q. I replaced a co-op-installed 10-foot sliding room divider in my studio apartment with a permanent wall, turning a large alcove into a permanent one-bedroom. Nothing else was changed. The room already had a standard separate door from a hallway. Even though I bought the apartment, I have heard the board can make me tear down the wall. Is this true? . . . Robert Stradder, Manhattan
 
A. Yes. According to Stuart Saft, president of the Council of New YorkCooperatives, in a co-op you cannot make a structural alteration without board approval. He also said the city could cite the co-op for violations because the building no longer complied with its certificate of occupancy because the number of rooms on that floor would have changed. "The co-op would rightly be concerned about safety," he said. "They would want to make sure that the wall was properly installed, made with the proper permits, and make sure that it won't come down and kill somebody or adversely affect the floor, which is the ceiling of the apartment below."
 
Getting a List Of Mortgage Rates
 
Q. I would like to get a listing of all the New York State mortgage bankers and their rates. I remember a listing the New York State Department of Banking puts out. Does it still exist? If so, How can I get one? . . . Stephen Silverman, Brooklyn
 
A. The State Department of Banking puts out a consumer bulletin three times year. It lists the rates offered by all state-chartered and some of the federally chartered banks in New York. Clare E. Sykes, a spokeswoman for the department, said you could get a copy by contacting the office of your Assemblyman or State Senator. Ms. Sykes also said that the bulletin was generally available at most public libraries in New York or can be obtained by writing to the Public Information Office, New York State Department of Banking, 2 Rector Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10006.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Opening Loan Windows

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
NOT everyone has been able to profit from the giant refinancing party that has enabled thousands of homeowners to tap into rock-bottom interest rates.
Those left out in the cold include people whose homes may have plunged in value, leaving the old mortgages as high or higher than prevailing prices. Or their incomes may have dropped, disqualifying them for the same amount of credit. Still others may own co-op apartments in New York buildings that are no longer eligible for financing, or they may have been tardy paying bills. 
 But such people should not give up. Lenders are easing terms, new programs are emerging and unconventional sources are being tapped to make mortgage refinancing possible. "Both the market and lending practices have changed a lot in the past year," said Nancy Boles, a senior vice president at Arbor National Mortgage in Westbury, L.I.
The changes include a special state program beginning in Connecticut this month, the impact of more owner-occupied units in many New York City co-ops, the margin loans now increasingly available through brokerage houses in place of conventional financing and even the chance to borrow temporarily from a 401K plan.
Connecticut borrowers can benefit from a new state program called Mortgage Refinance Guarantee. Open to anyone irrespective of income, it guarantees the difference between the amount a bank is willing to lend and what the homeowner needs to borrow.
An example would be a case in which a homeowner has an outstanding balance of $110,000, but because of the drop in values, a bank would only refinance up to $100,000. The state will now guarantee the difference, allowing the bank to go ahead with a loan for $110,000.
Investor properties are not eligible, though two- and three-family, owner-occupied houses will qualify. And there is a $100,000 limit on each guarantee. Moreover, the loan cannot exceed 125 percent of the current appraised value of the home. For details and an explanatory brochure call the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority at (203) 721-9501 or contact a local bank.
Another way to make up the difference in loan size without an infusion of personal cash would be to use a program like the one offered by Merrill Lynch & Company. It allows anyone with a portfolio of securities with Merrill Lynch's brokerage division to pledge those securities in place of cash. The program is called Mortgage 100.
A margin loan, available from any brokerage house where you might hold securities, offers a similar opportunity to raise the difference at rates that may even be lower than those from any lender, though the interest may not be tax deductible.
A retirement portfolio would not qualify. This exclusion should not apply, however, to anyone contributing to a 401K plan at work. According to Hewitt Associates, a benefits consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., 74 percent of employers permit borrowing against equity built up in a 401K plan.
Say a lender is asking for another $20,000 in cash to compensate for depreciation in value or a drop in family income. The borrower could use $20,000 from the accumulated assets in his or her 401K plan and gradually repay the loan through payroll deductions, said Christine Seltz, a spokeswoman for Hewitt. But she warned that the loan could be recalled or expensive penalties imposed if the borrower lost his or her job before the loan was fully paid back.
ANYONE previously unable to get refinancing because of a drop in the value of a mortgaged property should also keep on top of changing market conditions. Homes priced from $100,000 to $250,000 in Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Long Island and Fairfield County in Connecticut have been rising sharply this year, said Ms. Boles of Arbor National Mortgage. Local real estate agents can usually provide an updated appraisal. And most will do so free.
Where declining household income has been the stumbling block, having a family member, like a parent, co-sign a new loan to help get it approved is yet another technique, said Nancy Gordon, manager of the Globe Mortgage office in Hackensack, N.J.
Another way to qualify, Ms. Gordon said, is to extend the existing term of the new loan -- say from 15 years back to 30.
Co-op shareholders in New York should continually monitor the percentage of owner-occupied units vs. sponsor-owned units in their buildings. The "acceptable" range to qualify for refinancing is usually 70 percent shareholder-owned units or more.
Consider what happened at the 72-unit co-op at 320 West 76th Street in Manhattan. This year, more than 20 units were repossessed by the co-op from a defaulting sponsor, of which more than a dozen were purchased by tenants already in the building. Overnight, this raised the level of owner-occupied units from 34 percent, to 72 percent.
"I'd been waiting for this moment for three years," said Vincent McGowan, the co-op's president. Dropping his mortgage from an interest rate of 11 percent to 7 1/2 percent will save him $260 a month, he said.
He now wants everyone else in his building to do the same -- thus making it easier for them to meet maintenance payments. So he has been lining up interested banks and circulating the list to residents.
The Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae) is also taking a fresh look at the plight of New York's co-op shareholders.
Fannie Mae's policies set the tone for local lenders. And its new co-op guidelines, which are not yet completed, should help ease the gridlock, said Wayne Curtis, a spokesman at its Northeastern regional office in Philadelphia. Details were not available.
To find a local lender who is willing to observe more relaxed rules, it helps to apply through a mortgage broker (listed in the Yellow Pages). They work with many lenders and are on top of policy changes. It should cost no more.
Then there are programs like the one at Arbor National Mortgage. Since September, it has been taking a more lenient view toward people with troubled credit -- provided they have at least 25 percent equity in the home.
