HEADLINE: For the Deep of Pocket, Tailored Homes

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE grass has yet to be planted on the broad lawn of James and Eileen Farley's new house at a development called Highland Woods, off Annin Road in Basking Ridge, N.J. The long, gravel-covered driveway has yet to be paved.
But Mrs. Farley, who is 34 years old, nevertheless feels a sense of fulfilment. Encountered in the driveway a few days ago, she said she and her husband had met three goals they set in 1991 when they started house shopping in the hills of northern Somerset County. These were to find a property "in a family neighborhood, on a quiet street, with a level backyard." 
 Could they not have found that at less cost in a resale house, she was asked. "We looked but we couldn't find just what we wanted," she said. The Farleys went into contract in February 1992 on a New England colonial-style house with a two-car garage on an acre of land. Construction started a year later and they and their two young children moved in last month.
As with the Farleys, so with Irwin and Elizabeth Gotlieb in Westchester County. They couldn't find just the thing in resale housing either. Their special needs included suitable display space for Mr. Gotlieb's bonsai collection and Mrs. Gotlieb's formidable collection of perfume bottles.
A home builder provided it -- built-in and handsomely lit -- in a house they occupied last year at a development called Willoughby II, still under construction on 20 acres of a rocky hillside off Old Chappaqua Road in Briarcliff Manor, in the Town of Mount Pleasant.
There is no shortage of resale housing in a wide range of price categories on the market in the suburban and almost exurban communities of the wider metropolitan area. Yet, like the Farleys and the Gotliebs, many well-to-do house seekers continue to choose a semi-customized, detached single-family house.
The buyers are usually people with a disposition to modernity and a taste for self-expression, said Louis Winnick, a housing economist. "They are making the statement to the world, 'This is me,' " he said.
Fortunately for the regional economy, there are still pockets of this sort of highend home building activity. Most of it is semi-customized housing, often on subdivisions of no more than 30 lots. A far smaller segment is the fully customized house, perhaps on a piece of land that the buyer has purchased and proceeded to hire an architect to design and a contractor to build. The cost to do this as primary housing in the metropolitan often ranges well above $1 million.
BASE prices for the semi-customized houses usually range from $500,000 to $800,000. The value of the land and the size of the house are key determinants of cost.
The typical house in this category probably provides about 4,000 square feet on two levels on a one-acre lot. A basement level provides additional square footage. If the terrain is sloping, there may be an additional level. There is a two-car or three-car garage.
Buyers often spend more than the base price, not only for upgrades of fixtures, finishes and equipment but also for customization of construction to meet an individual family's needs. This may add as much as 10 percent to the base price.
Figures on the extent of new high-end, single-family home construction are hard to come by. The National Association of Home Builders, based in Washington, tracks the pace of new-home construction by large regions -- the Northeast, the Midwest, the South and the West -- in five price categories starting at "under $80,000." The highest-price category is $200,000 and over.
In the Northeast, figures for the first half of 1993 show that 31 percent of all new single-family sales were for more than $200,000, a total of 21,000 houses, compared with 32 percent in all of last year and 35 percent in 1990. "The indication is that the higher end hasn't recovered yet," said Dean Crist, a research economist at the association.
New-home construction generally is marginally improved. Last year there were only 65,000 one-family houses built at all price levels in the Northeast, according to the home builders' association. That compares with 57,000 in 1991. Total construction was 116,000 in the Midwest, 259,000 in the South, and 170,000 in the West. All these figures were slightly higher than 1991's.
But housing markets have niches and the niches differ not only in pace of sales but also in the nature of the "product" -- the house -- even when prices seem roughly comparable.
In 1993 the builders are selling in an environment quite different from pre-recessionary 1987. There are fewer single-family subdivisions in development. Since market prices are lower, land values are down. Builders who can acquire sites at reduced prices can charge somewhat less for the basic house, perhaps a more modest product than the previous owner intended.
On long-held subdivisions builders have sometimes modified the product in size or degree of interior completeness to be able to maintain sales at economically viable level at current market prices.
Buyers of new housing often comment that they are struck by their ability to buy new and get just what they want without paying much of a premium over a comparable but less satisfactory resale house.
Joseph and Laura Ferrari make that point. They wanted to move from a house in Bedford Hills, in northern Westchester County, that they had lived in since 1985.
"We looked at resale houses in the $350,000 to $400,000 range," said Mr. Ferrari, "but we decided we would be better off moving into a new house than buying a resale and making the renovations we wanted for another $30,000 to $50,000."
They bought a house listed at $435,000 in January in a development called Pine Hill Estates, 14 one- and two-acre lots off Pines Bridge Road in the town of Bedford. Mr. Ferrari enjoys landscaping -- "I'm a perpetual worker," he says -- and he is putting in all the landscaping of his new house himself. He declined to say what he paid for the house.
In Huntington, L.I., Harry and Blossom Weiss moved in September into a new four-bedroom colonial "in the $400,000 range" at an eight-house development called Walden Place near Lake Road. "We looked at resales but many owners were asking top dollar for houses that had not been touched in years," Mrs. Weiss said. "For the same amount of money we could buy something new."
The Weisses bought a four-bedroom colonial with three-and-a-half baths and a maid's room on one acre of land. They also took a package of upgrades that included an outside deck and a floor-to-ceiling stone fireplace eight feet wide. Tane Construction of Huntington was the builder.
SOME custom-home buyers are repeating the experience of buying new.
"We like the feeling of the new," said Joseph Friedman, 37, a sales and marketing executive. "We don't like old things we consider gloomy. 'New' represents fresh for us."
Mr. Friedman and his wife, Nancy, and four children moved in August into a new house at the Charter Club at the Hamptons development, which, notwithstanding its name, is in Marlboro, N.J., off Route 520. The Friedmans were moving from another house that they bought new in Marlboro nine years ago. The builder was the same organization, the Kramer Group, based in Marlboro, a home builder since 1960.
THE Friedmans bought their three-quarters-of-an-acre lot five years ago and waited for development on the 125-lot site to reach them. "I knew the lot I wanted and I knew it would be gone by the time development got to it," Mr. Friedman said.
He also benefited from a past experience of working with a builder on a house. "We knew southeast exposure is best for the front of the house so there's no north wind blowing at it," he said. "And there's no sun beating on our bedroom window. The back corner on the east has no windows."
But there are 84 windows in the house, along with seven bedrooms, six baths, three garages, five air-conditioning zones and six heating zones. The basic model cost something over $500,000, but beyond that the Friedmans spent heavily, probably close to $40,000 on granite tile alone.
"In a new house you'll have added costs, but you'll get what you want," Mr. Friedman said.
A similar conviction led the Gotliebs of the bonsai and perfume-bottle collections to the Willoughby development in Briarcliff Manor.
"We needed a lot of closets," Mrs. Gotlieb said. "The builder said, 'You want closets? I'll give you closets.' " He gave them three walk-in closets in the master bedroom alone, with track lighting. One of them has a built-in refrigerator.
The house has three bedrooms and four-and-a-half baths, Palladian-style windows, and an octagonally shaped breakfast table built as an extension of the center-island stoves in the kitchen. It also has a fully equipped exercise room, a sauna and several fireplaces, including one in the master bedroom that is clad in marble and stocked with gas-burning logs.
"People say building a house is a terrible experience, but we just had a wonderful time," Mrs. Gotlieb said.
Their neighbors are William and Barbara Bastardi , who moved into a five-bedroom three-bath contemporary cedar-and-stone house with their three young daughters and newly born son only this month. They, too, tinkered with the basic model, adding a third garage, putting another room above it, and rearranging an upstairs bathroom so that it can serve two rooms.
Mrs. Bastardi and her husband, William, who is in the automotive-parts business, believe in buying new. They lived for 10 years in a house in Briarcliff Manor, which they are trying to sell for $439,000. "In a new house you have all new problems instead of old problems," Mrs. Bastardi said.
All these buyers sought customization that involved special construction, not mere upgrades of materials and equipment, which in high-end housing is at a luxury level in the basic package. At Willoughby II buyers typically spent 3 to 5 percent above base prices of $625,000 to $725,000 for customized construction, said Richard Syracuse, a partner in the Syracuse Brothers Development Corporation of Briarcliff Manor, the builder.
The pricing of new housing is basically determined by three factors -- the builder's "hard" costs of construction (labor and materials); the soft costs for fees and construction-period interest and other nonconstruction expenses; and perhaps above all, the cost of the land, the key variable.
IN the Somerset County hill country of central New Jersey, ready-to-build sites that might have cost a de veloper $200,000 to $300,000 in the 80's now sell for $150,000 to $200,000, Bruce Bocina, a principal in Bocina Development Corporation of Basking Ridge, the developer of Highland Woods and other Somerset County developments.
"Land prices are about half what they were in the 80's," he said. "The home buyer who is paying $600,000 today would have paid $750,000 in 1987."
The perceived quality of local schools seems to exercise an extraordinary influence on land values between otherwise comparable neighboring communities.
"In the school district where we were looking lot prices ranged from $225,000 to $350,000," said Marc Goldstein, a financial advisor who bought a house at Willoughby II, which is in the Briarcliff Manor school district. He also looked at houses in the Chappaqua school district. "Elsewhere house lots were $150,000 to $200,000 in the area," he said.
On the north shore of Long Island, David E. Eisenberg, a partner with Peter C. Lewis in the construction of Woodbury Oaks, a single-family-home development in Syosset, said that land prices were 40 percent higher in the Syosset-Woodbury area than they are in neighboring Hicksville solely because of the reputation of the schools. Selling of the quarter-acre house lots began in January at a basic price of $425,000. Prices for the three remaining lots have risen to $525,000. A minimal amount of customization is available.
Another factor in sales is price relative to those for single-family houses generally within the area. In Syosset, unrenovated houses 30 years old sell for about $350,000 and for new customized housing builders ask between $700,000 and $800,000, Mr. Eisenberg said. The new houses of Woodbury Oaks are therefore in a favorable market position with a small-lot neo-colonial with modest customization possibilities.
A few miles east of Woodbury Oaks a long-standing Long Island building partnership, Anton Cerrone Associates, based in Port Washington, is building the 44-lot Rolling Hills at Woodbury project, customized houses in the 4,200-square-feet-and-up range that sell for $740,000 and more. It has maintained its prices through the recession, said Robert Anton, the 36-year-old son of one of the founding partners, Irving Anton, and 30 houses have been sold, most of them already occupied. Four are in construction.
"We had hoped to finish in three years," Mr. Anton said. "We should finish in 12 to 18 months."
On two-acre parcels the Anton-Cerrone partnership is also selling high-end houses in Muttontown, off Brookville Road. There are 45 lots and houses with 4,700 square feet selling at prices starting at $840,000. Fifteen have been sold, Mr. Anton said.
Also in construction on the North Shore after a lull caused by an ownership change is the final phase of The Links at North Hills, off Shelter Rock Road. Allan V. Rose, principal in AVR Development Company, based in Yonkers, originally won subdivision approval for 210 town houses plus a lavish clubhouse on the 125-acre site, once a golf course. AVR took over the site from another builder.
The third and final section was planned as 96 additional attached and semi-detached town houses on 45 acres, but it has been redesigned as 40 semi-detached and fully detached units, Mr. Rose said. A sales campaign began in July at prices of $675,000 to $825,000. Six buyers are in contract.
How much to spend on upgrades over the builder's basic package is often a puzzle for buyers. "You can go berserk on extra charges," said Mrs. Farley at Highland Woods in Basking Ridge.
ONE buyer there, Steven Spinner, told of putting in a limited number of special improvements in his five-bedroom, three-and-a-half bath house, spending about 6 percent more than the base price to do so. The upgrades included wider moldings at the floor and ceiling in the living room and dining room, wainscotting in the foyer and an additional two feet of space in the kitchen. Mr. Spinner, his wife, Holly, and their three young children moved in on Sept. 27.
"You can spend $800,000 on a $450,000 house," he said. "I wish we had more money to spend."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

MAGIC LANTERN
An authentic re-creation of a raucous Victorian magic lantern Halloween show will be presented next weekend at the Ivoryton Playhouse by Terry Borton and his American Magic Lantern Theater, based in East Haddam. 
 Slides for the magic lantern were hand-painted on glass plates in the 1890's and the lantern itself is a century old. The troupe of costumed actors, narrators and singers give dramatic voice to the ghosts, goblins, macabre and comedic goings-on depicted on the slides, and the audience is encouraged to toot horns and join in the singing.
The theater is on Main Street in Ivoryton, and performance times are on Friday at 7:30 P.M.; Saturday at 11 A.M. and 2:30 P.M.; and Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets are $8, $5 for children. The show is suitable for children from the age of 4. Call 767-4035, extension P for reservations.
 
ARTISTS AND HUNTERS
 For the past eight years, artists, conservationists, hunters and art collectors have converged on the New England Wood Carving and Wildlife Art Expo. The ninth edition will be held on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the Radisson Hotel in Cromwell.
More than 400 East Coast artists from Canada to Florida will display and sell their carvings, prints, photographs and paintings, and some $5,000 will be awarded in competitions. The winning works will be auctioned at 3 P.M. on Sunday.
Demonstrations will be given by the guest carvers Frank Switaj and Richard Magane, by the guest artist Bob Zarczynski, and by Tom Hirata, Connecticut's first duck stamp artist.
Admission is $6, free for children through the age of 12. Proceeds will benefit Connecticut's wildlife habitat projects, land acquisitions and biological studies. The hotel is just off Exit 21 of Interstate 91, nine miles south of Hartford.
 
RIVALS AND LOVERS
 Richard Rodriguez, author, critic, and essayist on the MacNeil/Lehrer News Hour, will be the lecturer today at 2:30 P.M. at the Yale Art Gallery, Chapel and York Streets in New Haven. His talk, titled "Mirror, Mirror, on the Wall: The United States and Mexico as Moral Rivals and Painted Lovers," is one of several events accompanying the current exhibition "Mexico in the American Imagination, 1914-1947," which remains on view through Nov. 21.
A day of family-oriented programs on Saturday from 10 A.M. to 11 P.M. begins with Hernandez Chavez and Rafael Weil discussing their work as muralists with middle- and high school students from 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. They will initiate a mural project to be placed on exhibition.
From 10:30 to noon, elementary school children will be involved in a mask-making project under the direction of Colleen Coleman and Don Wunderlee. Their creations will also be put on display.
James Oles, curator of the exhibition, will give a gallery talk in Spanish at 11 A.M., and a food and craft bazaar will fill the sculpture hall from noon to 2 P.M.
Performances by two musical groups, Gropo Choqui and El Sol Americano, will focus on the variety of music within Latin American countries from 2 to 5:30 P.M., and from 8 to 11 P.M. Latin American dance music will be offered by Versatil, an 12-member ensemble of trumpets, trombones, bongos, maracas and other instruments. Admission is free and the number to call for more information is 432-0601.
 
POLO MATCHES
 UConn has started a series of polo matches that will take place annually in the fall and spring. Male teams from UConn and Cornell will meet at 4 P.M. in the university's outdoor polo arena on Horsebarn Hill Road in Storrs. Female teams from UConn and Cornell will square off next Sunday at 1 P.M. There is no charge for admission and more information may be obtained by calling 486-1088.
 
USING THE LAND
 The E. F. Schumacher Society of Great Barrington, Mass., a nonprofit educational organization dedicated to better understanding and use of the land, and the Yale Student Environmental Coalition will present a program about land use with three speakers on Saturday in New Haven.
The first is Wes Jackson -- plant geneticist, farmer, author, teacher, a founder and director of the Land Institute in Salina, Kansas. The organization seeks to establish a town in Kansas where the most innovative methods for developing a sustainable agriculture can be practiced.
The second speaker will be Winona LaDuke, a member of the Mississippi Band of Anishinaabe from the White Earth Reservation, and campaign director of the White Earth Land Recovery Project, which is attempting to regain ancestral Anishanbeg lands from Federal, state and county government control.
Finally, George Davis, former executive director of the Wilderness Society, will speak about an international land use policy consulting firm that he founded in Wadhams, N.Y., called Davis Associates. He is currently leading an international effort to develop a comprehensive land use plan for the Lake Baikal watershed area in Siberia.
Registration begins at 9:30 A.M., lectures and audience response periods will continue to 4:30 P.M., with a break for lunch from 1:45 to 3 P.M. Tickets at $20, or $7 for students, and optional lunch at $7, must be ordered in advance by calling 432-7222. The program will be held in Sheffield-Sterling-Strathcona Hall, at Grove and Prospects Streets on the Yale campus.
 
RELIGIOUS EXPLORATIONS
 Religious fundamentalism and its effect on the three major faiths will be the subject of a seminar on Thursday from 5 to 10 P.M. at the Hartford Seminary, 77 Sherman Street in Hartford.
Christian fundamentalism will be discussed by Scott Appleby, assistant director of the fundamentalism project of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences at the University of Chicago, and Martin E. Marty, author of "The Glory and the Power: The Fundamentalist Challenge to the Modern World."
Following a light kosher supper served on the premises, the Islamic resurgence will be addressed by Sami al'Aryan, an associate professor at the University of South Florida.
Jewish fundamentalism will be the concluding topic, presented by Samuel Heilman, professor of Jewish studies and sociology at the City University of New York.
The seminar will end with an open dialogue among speakers and audience members.
Tickets in advance are $30, or $35 at the door. Call 232-4451 for reservations or more information.
 
HORROR MOVIE MAGIC
 "The Witch's Dungeon is a hobby that got a bit out of control," Cortlandt Hull, creator of the Horror Museum in Bristol that opens each year for Halloween, said. The dungeon will unfold its terrors for the 27th time on Friday, Saturday and Sunday evenings through Oct. 31, from 7 P.M. to 10 P.M., and it is not recommended for children under 6.
As an illustrator, make-up and prop specialist, and horror movie buff since childhood, Mr. Hull fell quite naturally into his hobby. Each year the life-sized replicas of Bela Lugosi as Dracula, Boris Karloff as Dr. Frankenstein's monster, Lon Chaney as the Phantom of the Opera, and Vincent Price as the abominable Dr. Phibes, among others, have increased in numbers, accuracy and artistry.
So, too, have the vignette settings in which they appear, until today the Witch's Dungeon is the only such exhibition sanctioned by Universal Pictures, which produced the films. Many of the original costumes and special effects body parts are incorporated into the display that is housed in a specially built structure on Mr. Hull's front lawn.
To set the mood as visitors enter, they will be guided by the frightfully familiar voice of Vincent Price and some cautionary commentary by Mark Hamill. In their wanderings through the dark corridors they will hear in-character voice-overs by June Foray, a veteran witch-voice of Hollywood cartoons.
Admission of 50 cents defies inflation but Mr. Hull regards his museum as a public service comemmorating his beloved vintage horror films. The dungeon is at 90 Battle Street. For more information call 583-8306 or 584-4718. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Interest Drops to 5.9%;
Sonyma Raises Income Limits

 BODY:
The State of New York Mortgage Agency has renovated its Low Interest Rate Mortgage Program, raising income-eligibility ceilings in all 62 counties and lowering the interest floor.
The income limits, based on statistics on median income in each area supplied by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, vary county by county and according to family size. They are also are higher for people purchasing homes in what are called target areas, neighborhoods targeted for economic development, than they are elsewhere. 
 Target areas in Manhattan, for instance, include Central and East Harlem, Inwood, areas of the West Side and parts of SoHo.
In New York City, the maximum allowable income for a family of three or more seeking a loan in the program for a home in a target area is $61,740, an increase of $3,640 over last year; for a nontarget area, it is $50,710, a rise of $2,990. In Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the target-area ceiling for families of three or more is $88,340, an increase of $11,340; in nontarget areas, it is $72,560, a rise of $9,310.
The interest rate has dropped from 6 percent to 5.9 percent. Loans, which the agency says are primarily for first-time home buyers, are available through the agency's network of 72 participating lenders statewide. They cover co-ops, condominiums and one-family homes, as well as two-family homes more than five years old, in all areas, and two-family homes that are newly constructed or less than five years old in target areas. Information is available from Sonyma's toll-free number, (800) 382-HOME.

HEADLINE: Time to Change Farmland Assessment

 BODY:
Given the documented statewide abuse of the New Jersey Farmland Assessment Act ("Farm or Fake? State Is Checking Up," Sept. 19), it is obvious that local, country and state officials have little capacity and/or the ethical fortitude to enforce this 1964 state constitutional amendment.
Illegal farmland assessment has become an important political perk offered under New Jersey's "justice and democracy for a select few" home rule system. Farmland assessment is held by less than 2 percent of New Jersey's population but accounts for nearly 25 percent of the state's land mass. 
 We believe it is time for Trenton to wake up and change the law accordingly. We recommend these initial legislative changes:
*The minimum qualifying acreage should be doubled, from 5 to 10 acres. In all but a few cases, five acres does not contribute enough to a local economy to warrant a tax break that amounts to hundreds of dollars per acre.
*Minimum yearly qualifying receipts must be raised to a more economically justifiable level, and thus we recommend raising the $500 yearly minimum to $10,000. We can no longer afford to subsidize property owners whose property tax break is greater than the average yearly receipts generated by their property.
*The present two-year rollback system should be doubled to four years and rollback law-enforcement capability should be strengthened. These revenues will help our rural communities to weather the present financial upheaval created by new development by providing monies for school system and infrastructure expansion.
Isn't good government all about providing tax equity to 100 percent of the people instead of supporting an outdated property tax scheme that gives a huge property tax break to 2 percent of the citizens at the expense of the other 98 percent?
Let's have a farmland assessment program, but Trenton must bring it into the realities of the 1990's.
 
RICHARD G. SMITH JR.
JOSEPH A. SARAFIN
Upper Freehold Township

HEADLINE: Beyond Issues in County Executive Contest

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IT was 1 P.M. on a recent Friday and Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a candidate for county executive, was on the steps of the County Office Building, demanding that state and Federal officials look into alleged misuse of a County Medical Center fund used for miscellaneous expenses. Those who were alleged to have misused the fund were officials appointed by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who is seeking re-election.
Mr. Brodsky was doing what he hopes will win the election for him -- challenging.
 
Challenging and Governing
 Mr. O'Rourke, who has held the county's highest office for 11 years, was not in the building, however. He was several miles away, sitting under a sugar maple tree at Muscoot Farm in Somers, a county-run working farm, flanked by supervisors and other officials from several towns in northern Westchester, issuing a warning that impending actions by New York City on its reservoirs in the county could have a devastating impact on local communities. 
 Mr. O'Rourke was doing what he hopes will win his re-election -- governing.
Challenging and governing are hardly unusual activities for office seekers and their incumbent rivals, but this year, in what is essentially a re-run of a 1989 race, they have been honed to a fine point. The election on Nov. 2, which could be closer than the 52-46 percent spread of the earlier race, will be decided by how well the candidates fulfill their self-assigned roles.
There are issues that separate Mr. Brodsky and Mr. O'Rourke, but the question likely to confront many voters on Election Day may be the classic one: is it time for a change?
Mr. O'Rourke says no. "I don't think Richard could do the job," he says. "He is a lot of talk, but very little action. He has never actually confronted anything that a county executive does, which is run things.
"I think he is probably all right as a legislator; you don't have to carry a lot of water as a legislator. You can pretty much skate around issues, and you don't have to have a position on everything that happens in Westchester County."
Mr. O'Rourke castigated his challenger for helping to maintain what he called the "tax and spend" mentality in Albany, especially in resisting two taxes fiercely sought in recent years by the O'Rourke administration and the Republican-controlled Board of Legislators: a hotel tax and an increase in the county sales tax, both of which were eventually approved.
"I honestly believe that, driven by ambition, Richard has tried to hurt Westchester County in holding out against the sales tax and the hotel tax because he never wanted us to succeed," Mr. O'Rourke said. "He wanted to run for county executive and needed a budget problem."
Mr. Brodsky characterized Mr. O'Rourke as "tired," "exhausted" or "worn out," basically running for an office that he thought last year he would be giving up for a more prestigious Federal judgeship. He had been endorsed by President Bush, but the end of the Republican regime in Washington all but doomed his chances of confirmation.
 
Dueling for Two Decades
 Mr. Brodsky, 13 years younger than Mr. O'Rourke, who will celebrate his 60th birthday on Oct. 26, has made corruption the central theme of his campaign, saying that Mr. O'Rourke cares more about his family and friends than the people of Westchester, a reference to the efforts that Mr. Brodsky said Mr. O'Rourke made to find jobs for or direct county contracts to his children and close friends.
The candidates, who have been dueling for two decades, know each other well, beginning with the Board of Legislators where Mr. O'Rourke, as chairman, and Mr. Brodsky, as a Democratic thorn in his side, struggled, often with clever and highly amusing exchanges, for verbal if not political domination.
They do not find each other so amusing as this, their second confrontation for the county's top job -- which pays $119,085 a year -- nears a conclusion. Their increasingly direct exchanges carry an acerbic bite, with the recitation and angry rebuttal of now familiar charges.
They have put forward economic plans that seem unusually similar, with Mr. Brodsky claiming that Mr. O'Rourke lifted the major tenets -- retraining of the unemployed with special emphasis on the white-collar jobless and assistance for small-business owners -- from the Brodsky plan.
 
On the Matter of Taxes
 In a midweek debate at the Women's Club of White Plains, each candidate summarized the thrust of his campaign, with Mr. Brodsky emphasizing the "need to clean up the O'Rourke government," especially the "ethical lapses," which he said characterizes its recent history.
Mr. O'Rourke sought to associate Mr. Brodsky with what he saw as free-spending liberals in Albany who have "imposed $6 billion in new taxes over the last four years," with Mr. Brodsky "voting for new taxes 48 times." He said his opponent left the chamber for the final vote on the current budget "so he wouldn't have to be recorded" as favoring its passage.
Mr. O'Rourke held up a chart showing that the county tax bills have remained the same or gone down over the last three years and will remain even for the next year. Mr. Brodsky said county taxes have gone up 120 percent during Mr. O'Rourke's tenure in office.
Both are correct, and Mr. Brodsky held up a tax bill, urging members of the audience to ignore Mr. O'Rourke's chart in favor of checking their own bills to determine the truth of the argument. Again, both were right because while the county's tax is statistically even, individual communities see their assessments rise or fall.
 
Dispute Over Hospital Fund
 Mr. O'Rourke said his 27 years of experience as an elected official enabled him to maintain Westchester's AAA bond rating, one of the nation's best. Mr. Brodsky spoke of the need for a change, one that will produce a government "that is candid and that can be trusted."
Mr. Brodsky also referred to what has become a major issue in his campaign, a story in the Gannett Suburban Newspapers stating that a special fund maintained at the County Medical Center and intended for medical research, professional education, patient benefits and the purchase of medical equipment had been used also for parties, plaques, golf outings and dinners.
Mr. O'Rourke said that there had been no misuse of the money and that the fund, known as the Medical Center's Supplementary Fund, was built on private contributions and was used, for example, to collect $20 donations for a retirement gift and to pay for restoration of the hospital lobby and emergency room area.
Mr. Brodsky, delighted with the disclosure so near the end of the campaign, demanded that law-enforcement officials investigate the fund's activities. A similar request came from Stephen P. Tenore, the Republican chairman of the Board of Legislators, who said the fund's activities should be studied "for possible criminal wrongdoing."
Mr. O'Rourke sought to de-emphasize the story's impact by saying that no public money was involved and that Mr. Brodsky was seeking to make much out of very little. But the County Executive helped fuel the political fire by asking for the resignations of four of the five hospital officials who controlled the fund.

LENGTH: 532 words

HEADLINE: Forget Border Wars, Think Globally

 BODY:
According to "Business Border Wars Heat Up" (Aug. 22), Westchester's leaders apparently believe that we should match the kinds of financial incentives offered by competing states so that we can lure companies to our county. This kind of "vestigial thinking" fails to address the major cause of our economic downturn -- global competition. Westchester's real challenge over the next few years is not to win border wars but to reposition the county and its businesses as world-class competitors. 
 Westchester's leaders continue to view the economic development process through the wrong end of the telescope, focusing very narrowly on the most visible symptom of economic decline -- empty buildings -- instead of on the fundamental issue: creating jobs for a transformed economy. Now is the time for "new thinking" in Westchester. Recognizing that the historic flow of small- to mid-sized businesses moving from New York City to the suburbs is continuing, we should redirect our focus from wooing out-of-county companies to expanding the business activity of the 28,000 businesses that are already here and to stimulating new "home-grown" entrepreneurial efforts.
Westchester's current level of economic activity (measured by employment) is back where it was at the end of 1982. Two challenges face our county today -- how to recoup the nearly 40,000 jobs lost over the last four years and how to get job growth back to its healthy 1980's rate of expansion, at 2 percent a year. Complicating these challenges is the apparent contradiction of abnormally high unemployment combined with a looming shortage of high-skilled workers.
People currently unemployed will not see their former jobs reappear in Westchester. Downsized-assembly-line workers are no more likely to find similar production jobs than "early-retired" middle managers are likely to find executive positions.
Yet many of our high-tech and information-intensive service businesses cannot find enough properly trained workers. The sharp instrument needed to cut this Gordian tangle is leading-edge technological training and retraining and improved education in poorer school districts.
To broaden, strengthen and expand Westchester's business and tax base, a county economic development strategy must harness the following forces: a brutally competitive global economy, the lightning pace of technological innovation, the expansion of world trade, the trend toward telecommuting, the demand for information-intensive services, the rapid transition from high-volume production jobs to high-value-added jobs requiring knowledgeable workers, the need for a highly sophisticated and fully digital telecommunications infrastructure and the need for affordable housing.
It is time to turn the telescope around and look through the eyepiece to get a view of the county's economic challenges and opportunities. Economic development is the process of creating wealth. Westchester needs an economic development strategy with a farsighted vision sharply focused on grappling with the compelling forces of structural change.
 
CONNIE FREID
President
STAN FREID
Chairman
Multinational Market
Services Group
White Plains

HEADLINE: World Markets;
OPEC Sits Atop Shaky Barrels

BYLINE: By Youssef M. Ibrahim

DATELINE: TUNIS

 BODY:
THE good news for OPEC is that oil prices stand about $2 per barrel higher since the oil cartel struck a deal in Geneva last month to rein in the runaway production of oil by some of its 12 member countries.
The bad news is that these higher oil prices are still roughly $3 a barrel below where they were a year ago. 
 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' temptation to rejoice over indications that demand for oil is increasing worldwide is checked by the fact that supplies of oil are also rising from producers who are not members of the cartel, and therefore, not bound by any production limits.
Oil economists and industry officials say that oil output in the North Sea oil fields, shared by Britain and Norway, is expected by the end of this year to be 1 million barrels a day higher than it was in 1992, to a record high of 5.2 million barrels a day.
Elsewhere on the globe, oil output from Oman, Syria, Colombia, Yemen and other third world countries is also inching ahead.
That's a great deal of oil poured into world markets every day.
What's worse is that the largest chunk of this increase in production is controlled by countries fiercely opposed to interference with market forces.
Britain and Norway have repeatedly asserted that they were committed to producing all the oil they can, leaving the matter of setting prices to market forces -- a philosophy that is diametrically opposed to OPEC's goal of pushing prices up by restricting output.
"In general they are not doing well except that if they hadn't come to an agreement, prices would have been something like $5 a barrel below the present level," said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "The bottom line for OPEC is that the idea of oil prices rising sharply any time soon because of a shortage in supplies is a far-fetched thought," Mr. Lichtblau added.
The only gain brought by the Geneva accord reached unanimously by the members of OPEC is that it has sent a faint signal to skeptical oil markets, improving OPEC's poor image and credibility, which had deteriorated since 1986. That was the year when similar challenges coupled with an internecine war in OPEC brought about an oil price crash to $10 a barrel.
In the two weekssince the OPEC accord, prices of Brent oil, which is traded in London, have moved up from $15.75 a barrel -- when OPEC met in the last week of September -- to $17 a barrel now. Other crudes have moved up by about $2 a barrel.
Provided these gains hold up for the rest of the year, the increase in prices will bring badly needed infusions of several billion dollars into the hard-pressed treasuries of OPEC members whose countries depend almost entirely on oil exports.
It is estimated that each dollar rise or fall for the barrel roughly represents a billion dollars in income, making such swings a highly destabilizing factor for those attempting to plan a budget in Tehran, Riyadh, Caracas, Algiers or in other oil-producing capitals.
Lower incomes in the last two years have brought political turmoil and instability to several major oil producers including Venezuela, Ecuador, Algeria and Iran.
Even rich OPEC members, like Saudi Arabia, which is the world's largest producer and exporter of oil, as well as Kuwait, have gone into deficit spending to sustain their budgets in the last few years.
These pressures have always pushed OPEC members to abandon agreements and rush to pump more oil in a vicious circle that only lowers oil prices.
"This is the most durable agreement they have struck among themselves since 1986," said Mehdi Verzi, an OPEC expert at Kleinwort Benson, a securities firm based in London. "We still have to go through a testing period to see if they adhere to it. They have to run a very tight ship. My feeling is that they will," Mr. Verzi said.
But is it enough?
Virtually all oil experts argue OPEC will have to do a great deal more if it wants to recapture its position of the 1960's and 70's as the arbitrator of higher oil prices or even reach the modest goal boosting oil prices closer to $21 a barrel, the official OPEC wish price.
That means bringing the ceiling significantly below the current 24.5 million barrels a day for the 12 members.
OPEC also has to be a little luckier. If this winter turns out to be a mild one, the industrialized countries of the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, the world's largest group of oil consumers, may significantly cut oil demand, especially as all 24 members have accumulated hefty amounts of oil purchased at cheaper prices in the last few months. The variables between a cold or a mild winter can be as much as one million barrels a day.
Then there is the problem of Iraq, which is a key, but dormant, OPEC member.
If the United Nations allows Iraq to resume the production and export of oil, prices will drop sharply. Iraq, which has the world's second largest oil reserves after Saudi Arabia, is capable of putting at least 1.5 million barrels of oil on world markets every day.
"I am very ambivalent. I wouldn't be surprised at all if prices start falling again," said Peter Gignoux, manager of the petroleum trading division of Smith Barney Shearson in London.

HEADLINE: Tech Notes;
Computerizing the Clunker

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
COMPUTERS work well in new cars to reduce air pollution, but what can be done with old ones, especially in third world countries where old models predominate? In those lands, where often the only gasoline is leaded, catalytic converters are not practical.
A start-up company in Maryland won a patent last week for a device that cleans car exhaust and reduces fuel consumption by harnessing a computerized sensor to an old-fashioned carburetor. The system can continually adjust the air-fuel mixture, making it as lean as possible at any given instant without hindering the engine's performance. It can also work with fuel-injected cars. 
 The Lean Power Corporation of Silver Spring, Md., attaches a magnetic sensor that monitors the speed of the engine's flywheel. The sensor looks not only at revolutions per minute (a measure of engine speed) but also at the flywheel's smoothness of revolution (an indication of performance) and sends the appropriate signals to an air-control device attached to the carburetor.
"When combustion is smooth and uniform, the sensor tells our controller that the engine will tolerate a leaner mixture," said Michael D. Leshner, the company's vice president and senior scientist. "When it gets rough, it tells our controller it's a little too lean."
From a chemistry standpoint, air and gasoline mix best at a ratio of 14.7 parts air to 1 part gasoline. But power is maximized at a richer mixture, 12 to 1, and cleanliness is maximized at a higher mixture, 19 to 1.
The Lean Power system decides how rich the mixture needs to be by looking at fluctuations in the flywheel, which runs faster after a cylinder fires and slows down between firings. A four-cylinder engine fires twice in each revolution, and the engine runs between 600 and 6,000 revolutions per minute, which means measuring a cycle of acceleration and deceleration 100 times per second or less. Using mechanical means to measure something that fast is hard, but Mr. Leshner said, "for modern electronics, that's slow. It's 100,000 times slower than your personal computer."
The company has been concentrating on Mexico, where it hopes soon to announce a joint-venture partnership with a manufacturer. Tests at Ford de Mexico's engineer labs showed carbon monoxide reduction of 60 to 70 percent, hydrocarbon reduction of 20 to 40 percent and nitrogen oxide reduction of 15 to 25 percent. The product is supposed to sell for less than $200, and the company hopes it will be popular not solely on environmental grounds but also because it improves fuel economy by 10 to 15 percent.
 MATTHEW L. WALD

GRAPHIC: Diagram: "Digital Carburetion" shows Lean Power's digital carburetion system. (Lean Power)

HEADLINE: Trade You Two Robert Solows for a J.K. Galbraith

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
JERRY HAUSMAN. Didn't he play third base for the Padres in the early 80's? Great glove man, but never learned to hit a screwball?
No way. He's an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Invented something called the Hausman specification test that propelled him into the big leagues of number-crunching. More important, it got him into the elite group of 29 "Economist Greats" whose trading cards are sold by the economics club at the University of Michigan at Flint. The price: $5 a set. 
 Where else would you learn that Gerard Debreu "gave formal conditions for the Pareto optimality of an economic allocation, for the local uniqueness and (with K. Arrow) the existence of general equilibria."
M.I.T. gets the most mentions on the list (6), with Harvard (4) the runner-up. Princeton (3) and Columbia (3) split the bronze. Men outnumber women. In fact there's just a single female entry (Irma Adelman of the University of California); one might expect calls to send the club's officers to gender-sensitivity classes.
No one, though, could accuse them of age-ism: The group averages 70.
The rest of the list: William Baumol, Gary Becker, Abram Bergson, Jagdish Bhagwati, Alan Blinder, Kenneth Boulding, Gregory Chow, Sir Alec Cairncross, Edward Denison, Evsey Domar, Robert Dorfman, Stanley Fischer, Franklin Fisher, Milton Friedman, Victor Fuchs, John Kenneth Galbraith, Alfred Kahn, Charles Kindleberger, Wassily Leontief, Jacob Mincer, Edmund Phelps, Robert Solow, Herbert Stein, Lawrence Summers, Jan Tinbergen and James Tobin.
Discretion leads one not to question who does not belong. But there are puzzling omissions: Kenneth Arrow, Robert Eisner, Martin Feldstein, Claudia Goldin, Zvi Griliches, Gottfried Haberler, James Heckman, Dale Jorgensen, Anne Krueger, Paul Krugman, Robert Lucas, Franco Modigliani, Jeffrey Sachs, Tom Sargent and Paul Samuelson -- and last week's Nobel Prize winners, Robert Fogel and Douglass North.
But be the first to collect all 29! Send that check or money order to the Department of Economics, University of Michigan, Flint, Mich. 48502.

HEADLINE: When Smoking Is a Patriotic Duty

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
MEET Dr. Ei Kubota, the man with the toughest job in Japan.
As the Health and Welfare Ministry official who directs Japan's anti smoking efforts, Dr. Kubota faces two adversaries familiar to public-health officials in the United States: the tobacco industry, whose hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising here have imbued smoking with a rakish cachet, and smokers, who find it hard to quit. 
 But Dr. Kubota, a good-natured physician who once worked with Mother Teresa in the slums of Calcutta, faces another, more formidable, foe -- the Government itself. The Finance Ministry, the most powerful arm of the Government, operates a near monopoly in the production and sale of cigarettes in one of the world's largest and most lucrative tobacco markets. The Government-owned company, Japan Tobacco Inc., generates a cascade of taxes -- $15 billion last year -- making it the largest corporate taxpayer in Japan.
The company's success is no accident. By law, the ministry is charged with looking after Japan Tobacco's financial health above all else, including public health, and maintaining the huge flow of tax revenues. Thus, while the United States and other industrial nations have long since begun aggressive campaigns to warn citizens of tobacco's long-term health dangers, the Japanese Government has not. On the contrary, the Government is one of the few in the world that still permits cigarette advertising on television, finances almost no smoking research and, indeed, leavens reports on the health hazards of smoking with claims of the benefits of cigarettes.
Never has the conflict between health concerns and financial interests been sharper than now. The ministry is counting on windfall profits early next year from the sale to the public of one-third of the shares of Japan Tobacco Inc. The pending sale has made the Government particularly eager to put the tobacco business in the best possible light.
 
The Exploitable Consumer
 The Japanese Government, in its attitude toward cigarettes, provides an important insight into its priorities. The protection of the tobacco interests is one of the starkest examples of a national strategy the Government has pursued vigorously for decades -- putting manufacturing might first, while often regarding consumers as a national resource to be exploited. The strategy transformed the country into a ferocious industrial competitor, but Japan is beginning to wake up to its long-term cost.
"Eventually, this is going to create a catastrophe in the health care system," said Dr. Takeshi Hirayama, director of the Institute of Preventive Oncology and former head of epidemiology at the National Cancer Center. "By the early 21st century, the costs are going to rise significantly."
In some respects, this strategy has benefited consumers: with Japanese manufacturers so very competitive, job security is high, even in the midst of the current two-year-old recession. But consumers also pay among the highest prices in the world, find it almost impossible to afford a home, generally commute long distances and enjoy fewer public amenities like parks and modern sewerage facilities than in most other industrial countries. Nor do consumers here enjoy the protection of a product liability law.
In fact, belated recognition of the burden consumers have been bearing helped evict the Liberal Democratic Party last summer after 38 years in power and helped install the reformist coalition of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa.
On a few occasions in the past, the Government has responded to the ill effects of its industrial policies. For instance, after egregious air and water pollution began to take a horrific toll in the late 1950's and early 1960's, Japan instituted some of the most stringent industrial pollution standards in the world.
There has been no such response to the impact of smoking, however. With the tobacco industry enjoying state support, this is what Japan looks like:
* It has what is thought to be the highest smoking rate in the industrialized world, 36.1 percent (compared with 25.7 percent in the United States). More than 60 percent of Japanese men -- and 44 percent of doctors -- smoke.
* Life insurers offer no discounts to nonsmokers, in spite of Western research that finds nonsmokers live longer.
* Hundreds of thousands of vending machines dot street corners across the land, putting cigarettes within reach of minors.
* No-smoking sections in restaurants and offices remain curiosities.
Meanwhile, Dr. Kubota is left to pursue his quixotic campaign with an annual budget of less than $200,000 and a staff of two. A stroll through the hallways of the Health and Welfare Ministry also makes it clear what he is up against: cigarette vending machines can be found throughout the building. Said Dr. Hirayama: "The big difference between Japan and the United States is that the Finance Ministry is the tobacco industry in Japan. It is a gorilla."
Physicians like Dr. Kubota and Dr. Hirayama are among the small but growing number of experts who say that, contrary to the Finance Ministry's assertions, the medical costs to the Japanese Government of not fighting harder against smoking will overwhelm the money raised from cigarette sales. Deaths from lung cancer, heart disease and other illnesses related to tobacco are mounting. Although smoking rates have been declining slowly, the rates at which Japanese come down with these debilitating illnesses will continue to rise because of heavy consumption of cigarettes for most of the past four decades, these experts say.
 
Lung Cancer on the Rise
 The trends, they say, are troubling. In 1955, cancer of the lung, trachea and bronchus -- linked by Western research to smoking -- ranked seventh among cancers, taking 3 out of every 100,000 lives. By 1991, however, the lung, trachea and bronchus cancers ranked second, killing 31 of every 100,000 Japanese, compared with a rate of 39 deaths from stomach cancer, long the No. 1 cancer killer. (In the United States, about 50 of every 100,000 die annually from lung cancer, and 5 from stomach cancer. Doctors speculate that the rates of stomach cancer in Japan are much higher because of the salty diet.)
Finance Ministry officials sneer at such figures as propaganda. "People who say these things have come to their conclusion before they examine the evidence," said Hideki Yamada, deputy director of the Finance Ministry's Tobacco and Salt Business Division. "We are not saying tobacco is good for health, but for smokers it has some merits, like a good mental feeling. They help people relax."
That attitude, in turn, angers anti smoking activists here. Dr. Reiko Saito, a pediatrician and the founder last year of a minuscule antismoking movement among doctors, said: "The bureaucrats have a narrow view. They only look at tax revenues for this year, not the medical costs of smoking, or the life of a person who smokes 20 years from now."
 
Hostility From Doctors
 The Government's prosmoking bias has created an environment unusual among industrialized countries. Dr. Kubota enjoys no organized support, and even some hostility, from the medical establishment, which relies heavily for its livelihood on the Finance Ministry. Under Japan's universal health insurance scheme, all doctors' fees are fixed through negotiations with the Finance Ministry.
Dr. Minoru Sugiura, executive director of the Japan Medical Association, was indignant when it was suggested that doctors should disseminate more information to young people on the health effects of tobacco and that more doctors might set an example by not smoking.
The culture of Europe and America is "dry" and too logic-oriented, he complained, "so if something is bad, you think it is only bad. But Japanese traditional culture is 'wet,' or more flexible."
Dr. Sugiura was quick to add: "People are receiving benefits from the tobacco sales tax. Without this money, the Government might have to increase the consumption tax rate. We have to think about the total social balance. Therefore, though I do not myself smoke, I do not think we should especially work on it as an organization."
That attitude is common here. While there are no-smoking sections in restaurants and offices today, they are still rare. The Government, rather than financing smoking research, relies on the tobacco industry, which claims no clear proof of a link between smoking and ailments like lung cancer and heart disease.
In fact, a Finance Ministry advisory council reported several years ago that smokers learn more easily, are more relaxed, are more extroverted and suffer fewer neuroses than nonsmokers. It also argued that tobacco addiction is very mild, with those who quit experiencing no great desire to smoke again.
By contrast, the United States Surgeon General declared in 1964 that smoking caused serious health problems, and companies were required to place health warnings on cigarette packs in 1965. Not until 1972 did Japan require even a mild warning. Today, cigarette packs carry a statement that says: "Smoking by minors is prohibited. Please beware of over-smoking because there is a danger of harming your health. Please observe smoking etiquette."
And while the United States banned cigarette advertising on television in 1971 and many other countries have followed, Japan still permits it, though only between 10:54 P.M. and 5 A.M. (The odd starting time allows advertisements just before the 11 P.M. news.) The ads here are supposed to include a health warning, but this is flashed for only a second.
Most spots depict smoking as the ticket to beauty and adventure, with scenes in spectacular natural settings. Some of the biggest users of television are the American tobacco companies, like Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds, which leaped into the market after American trade negotiators wedged it open in 1985. They have aggressively built market share since then with heavy advertising and promotions. Foreign cigarettes now hold 17 percent of the $28 billion tobacco market here, with Japan Tobacco holding the remainder.
 
Glowing Ads
 Newspaper ads also depict smoking in dreamy terms that would probably be prohibited elsewhere because of their claims. For instance, a recent newspaper ad quoted an actor saying, "Cigarettes are indispensable to creativity for me."
But most advertising is actually done through Japan's almost ubiquitous vending machines. The nation has some 5.5 million of them, the highest concentration in the world, and 500,000 dispense cigarettes.
Most important, much of the $14 billion a year worth of cigarettes sold through vending machines are sold to people under 20, according to various studies, even though smoking by minors is illegal. (The one group whose smoking rate is still increasing is young women.) The Government has repeatedly insisted that this law be enforced strictly, and the Finance Ministry says it requires vending-machine operators to monitor the machines closely. But an official said the ministry had never revoked a license for sales to minors.
In addition, many companies that for sound business reasons are involved in the antismoking movement in the West are passive here. American life insurers, for instance, have offered nonsmoking discounts to customers for years, citing statistical evidence that nonsmokers live longer. But Japanese life insurers do not.
Officials of this industry, which is tightly regulated by the Finance Ministry, say they have thought about studying the health consequences of smoking, but have yet to do so.
But it is life and health insurers who could be hit hardest by the prosmoking policies.
The Finance Ministry and Japan Tobacco argue that if smoking were such a problem, the Japanese would not be so healthy. The Japanese, in fact, enjoy the greatest life expectancy of any people, 75.9 years for men and 81.8 years for women. In the United States, it is 72 for men, 78.9 for women.
"Why do you think Japan has such great longevity?" said Yukio Akiyama, the head of Japan Tobacco's Scientific Information Department. He argued that smoking was just one of many "risk factors," and that the long life spans proved it may not be the decisive one.
He was also quick with a response to the question of why American lung cancer rates are higher than those in Japan. "My personal opinion is that the intake of fats in the United States diet probably is a lot higher," Mr. Akiyama said. "I'm also wondering if the nuclear weapons testing there has some effects."
Some Japanese also bristle over comparisons between Japan's and America's policies on smoking, because of a glaring conflict in the United States approach. While Washington has sought to warn Americans about tobacco, it has also aggressively pried open foreign markets for American tobacco companies and encouraged exports of cigarettes, paying no attention to the health of the smokers in those other countries.
As for the antismoking activists here, Dr. Hirayama said epidemiological studies have shown that the relatively low rates of smoking-related illnesses until recent years were a product of the unusually low smoking rates during and after World War II, when cigarettes were largely unavailable. "But the effects are about over," he said. "By the end of the century, the shortening of the life expectancy of Japanese males will be very visible."
 
 
 
TOBACCO, SALT AND BIG MONEY
 FOR decades, smoking has been regarded by most Japanese men almost as a patriotic duty. (As in most of Asia, it is considered disreputable for women to smoke here, although aggressive advertising is eroding that taboo. Enter any fast-food restaurant and find thick fog banks of cigarette smoke drifting from tables of young women.)
In fact, the Government monopoly was born of nationalism. Near the turn of the century, the Government created the tobacco monopoly to finance imperialistic wars with China and then Russia. A salt monopoly was established for the same purpose. The two were eventually combined into the Finance Ministry's Tobacco and Salt Business Division. Japan Tobacco retains its monopoly on the salt business to this day.
Since World War II, the tobacco monopoly has become a crucial source of revenues to support economic development. Individuals did not question the strategy because it was regarded as so important.
With the end of nearly four decades of one-party rule by the Liberal Democrats, those days may be ending. The Government of Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa has vowed to give the long-suffering consumer a share of Japan's wealth, a higher standard of living and a larger say in government affairs.
If he delivers -- which many doubt -- it would mark something of a revolution. At the least, the new environment engendered by Mr. Hosokawa has raised questions about how out of step Japan's policies on smoking are compared with the West's.
 
 
 
THE OFFICIAL WALL PROTECTING JAPAN TOBACCO
 JAPAN TOBACCO INC. is one of the world's largest cigarette companies and a business powerhouse, but if there were any question about the source of its success the answer is hinted at in a simple sentence on page 31 of the company's latest annual report.
The line states that at the end of the fiscal year on March 31, 1993, "the company had no material litigation or claims outstanding, pending or threatened against it."
While American tobacco companies face a steady flow of smoking-related legal claims from consumers, the Japanese legal system has traditionally been hostile to lawsuits, and especially hostile to those by private individuals against the Government. Nor has there been substantial research on how tobacco affects health, research that might form the basis for legal action.
That is just one aspect of how the Government has insured the sound health of Japan Tobacco ahead of its first offering of shares to the public, scheduled for early next year. The Government fixes the price of cigarettes, currently more than $2 a pack, of which about 60 percent is taxes. And it controls distribution.
Some critics even say it influences the way the media report on health issues because of its huge advertising and promotion budget -- about $750 million a year. Last year Nippon Television, a major network, refused to broadcast a documentary claiming that the Government pushes smoking because of its stake in the business.
The network's union went public, charging that the company's advertising executives killed the project, even though there was no direct pressure from Japan Tobacco. After the uproar, the film finally ran, but without a portion mentioning that Japan was one of the few countries that permit cigarette ads on television.
Japan Tobacco remains a fount of cash, even as smoking rates decline. It had net sales of $23.8 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31, and provided a massive $15 billion to the Finance Ministry in taxes.
That left the company with $494 million in net income. It also had a balance sheet swimming with money. Japan Tobacco reported cash and short-term securities holdings of $3.7 billion. In fact, a substantial portion of its profits -- $143 million -- came simply in the form of net interest income.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Strategies for Style Index Funds

SERIES: Second of two articles on growth and value investing

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
TWO sets of "style" index funds set up last year -- one by Vanguard and the other by Dreyfus -- have made it easier for mutual fund investors to use growth and value stockpicking strategies in building their portfolios, much as mutual fund managers use them in shaping their funds. These index funds can serve as handy benchmarks for investors, or be used as tools themselves to implement a variety of growth- and value-related investing tactics.
Mutual fund managers using a value approach look for shares priced at less than what they think the company is worth, often in mature, dividend-paying companies with cyclical businesses dependent on the overall economy. By contrast, those after growth prefer shares in companies with strong earnings or sales prospects; they may be relatively expensive but are less dependent on economic conditions. 
 The Vanguard Group, of Valley Forge, Pa., captured these diverse approaches via the Standard & Poor's/Barra Growth and Value indexes. Vanguard's value index comprises 320 of the S.&P. 500 stocks with the lowest price-to-book ratios; the rest of the S.&P. 500 make up the growth index. The funds' annual expenses are a low 0.2 percent.
The Dreyfus-Wilshire Target funds, part of the New York-based Dreyfus Corporation, were constructed by splitting the 2,500 largest stocks in the Wilshire 5000 index into four parts. They were first separated by size, with the largest 750 (assets of $900 million to $80 billion) in the large-capitalization fund, and the next group, 1,750 stocks (assets of $90 million to $900 million), in the small-cap fund. Each group was then divided into growth and value camps based on price/earnings and price-to-book ratios, yield and so on.
The four funds each hold between 150 and 550 issues. Annual expenses range from 0.59 to 0.91 percent, and a 1 percent redemption fee applies to sales within six months.
For many investors, these indexes can be useful largely as benchmarks in evaluating the performance of their own value- and growth stock funds. The index funds provide a ready reference as to how much of another fund's performance reflects its stockpicking style as opposed to its manager's skill.
The funds also provide an easy way for investors to bet on shifts in the economy that would favor the growth or value approach. While Vanguard's funds are the cheaper way to do so, Dreyfus's funds permit more refined bets by taking into account the cycles favoring large- and small-capitalization stocks.
Second of two articles on growth
 and value investing.
 For long-term investors, the funds are best used with a simple rebalancing strategy, say fund experts. Don Phillips, publisher of Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago, advises putting equal dollar amounts into both Vanguard funds and then rebalancing the accounts each year, adding more money to whichever fund performed less well that year.
Daniel P. Wiener, editor of the Vanguard Adviser, a Boston-based independent newsletter for Vanguard investors, developed a similar strategy, which he calls "contrarian style cycling." In a study, he found that in 43 of the 74 quarterly periods from 1975 through June 1993, value investors outperformed growth investors; growth won in the remaining time -- and each style often won by wide margins. Mr. Wiener recommends that investors who add continually to their holdings buy shares in whichever type of fund underperformed in the previous quarter.
He suggests that investors with fixed amounts of money switch back and forth between the value and growth index funds using the same methodology. Doing so would have produced an average annual compound return of 17 percent, 1 percentage point higher than leaving the money in the Vanguard S.&P. 500 index fund, based on quarterly results over 31 rolling 10-year periods, he said. Taxes can cut the gains, so this works best in tax-deferred retirement accounts.
Do the style index funds outperform actively managed funds? In most cases, no, according to a study by Kenneth E. Gregory, editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst, in San Francisco.
Using a hypothetical track record created by Dreyfus, Mr. Gregory compared the performance of Dreyfus's small-cap growth index fund to 25 small-cap growth funds tracked by his newsletter over 10 years ended October 1992. The index lagged all of them, as well as all of the 75 United States equity funds Mr. Gregory tracks. On the other hand, the small-cap value index mostly beat the 7 actively managed small-cap value funds.
Among larger-cap stocks, the Vanguard and Dreyfus growth index funds both turned in middle-of-the-road performances, the study found.
Mr. Gregory concludes that actively managed funds are preferable among small stocks, where manager skill can uncover market inefficiencies.
Some experts say the style index funds are a good idea taken too far. While investors can use the style funds to target leading market segments, doing so requires making judgments -- and that defeats the purposes of indexing, said Sheldon Jacobs, who edits the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y. Stick with index funds that cover the whole market, he advised.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Bags, Belts and the Safety Factor

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
"Y'KNOW," a friend said recently, "I've been hearing bad things about air bags. I think you ought to check it out."
Uh-huh. Like what kind of things? 
 "Well," he said, "that people have been getting hurt by air bags. Sometimes even killed."
Actually, I had been hearing the same things, although some of the rumors had come from people who work for automobile companies that have been slow to implement what most manufacturers have recognized as one of the better safety devices to come along.
"Another thing," my friend said, "air bags are really dangerous when a guy is smoking a pipe."
I hadn't thought of that. But then my mother always told me not to run with a stick in my mouth.
In fact, this is a propitious time to talk about air bags. The 1994 models are rolling into the showrooms and about 90 percent of them have air bags, at least for the driver.
Not only that, but the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has just completed a major study of bags and belts and published the results in its newsletter, the Status Report. And while the study finds that air bags do indeed cause some injuries, it also concludes that they are minor in comparison to the major injuries they prevent.
Understand, of course, that the institute represents the insurance companies of America and, as such, has a vested interest in getting all of us to buckle up and be safe. But the study does stand on its own, and it acknowledges that air bags are not perfect.
"Air-bag-induced injuries happen while the bags are still inflating," the report says. "People injured this way often aren't using belts, so they've moved forward enough to contact the air bag early in its inflation. Another problem involves people who sit very close to the steering wheel."
Determining whether minor injuries are caused by the bags is easy, the study says, but it is harder to figure the cause of more serious injuries because the steering wheel and dashboard may be involved. Most injuries from air bags have been abrasions, cuts and bruises, although some crash victims have suffered minor burns from the gas that inflates the bag.
The air bags in today's cars fill in a fraction of a second to restrain occupants, and they deflate just as quickly to further the cushioning effect.
The hot gas that inflates them is disspelled through vents, and the location of those holes has been altered over the years to prevent burns. The inflation is activated by electronic or electromechanical sensors in a vehicle's front end, and the sensitivity to impact depends on the manufacturer's system.
The bags are designed to deploy after a crash that is the equivalent of hitting a solid barrier at 10 to 15 miles an hour. The number and location of sensors vary from model to model, and some systems -- notably those on Mercedes and BMW -- have "adjusted deployment thresholds" that depend on whether the occupants are using seatbelts.
Belts, of course, are crucial in preventing injury, since air bags are designed solely to protect occupants in a head-on or front-angle crash. Belts hold passengers in place so the bags can do their stuff, and they also protect a car's occupants in side and rear accidents.
With more cars now equipped with air bags, the institute's database has grown, and researchers have been able to compare driver deaths per 10,000 registered vehicles in new cars during their first year with bags and belts and their last year with belts alone. What they have found, according to the Status Report, is a death rate of .96 in cars with bags compared with 1.15 in other vehicles.
About 24 percent fewer driver deaths are occurring in front and front-angle crashes of cars with air bags, the institute reports.
All the same, the newsletter cautions, bags and belts can cause injuries as they restrain occupants and keep them from more serious harm. Belt injuries are mostly to people's chests, abdomens, shoulders and necks, while bags more often injure arms, hands or faces.
And, as with bags, injuries from belts can be reduced by proper positioning of the car's occupants. Drivers should sit as far from the steering wheel as is comfortable because, even with a seatbelt, there is some "give" and the person can move forward to hit a hard interior surface.
Lap belts should be positioned low over an occupant's hips, not the abdomen, the newsletter says. And people in cars with air bags should follow the same advice on seating to minimize contact with an inflating bag.
No matter the car's equipment, though, the institute points out in a new pamphlet that a large car is safer than a small one. The booklet, "Shopping for a Safer Car," notes that small vehicles account for more than twice as many occupant deaths as large vehicles.
"The fact that people traveling in small vehicles fare worse when they're in crashes than those in large vehicles isn't surprising," the pamphlet notes. "It's a direct consequence of the laws of physics, which dictate that, everything else being equal, the larger the vehicle the safer the people inside."
The booklet offers model-by-model lists of safety features in 1994 vehicles, including air-bag and antilock-brake availability. In addition, there are discussions of head restraints, built-in child seats and advances in side-impact technology.
"Enhancing crash protection in side impacts is an important new development in vehicle safety," the booklet says. "A Federal standard that goes into effect this year requires passenger cars to meet improved side impact performance requirements as demonstrated in full-scale crash tests."
Manufacturers have the option of phasing in the protective beams in doors, beginning with 10 percent of 1994 models and reaching 100 percent by the 1997 model year. Or an auto maker may defer meeting the requirement until the '95 model year, but then all its new cars must comply.
The edict doesn't apply to utility vehicles, passenger vans or pickups, although some of those do offer the new protection. The pamphlet lists the '94 models that already meet the standard.
Antilock brakes, of course, are an important feature for preventing accidents in the first place. The system uses sensors that determine imminent lockup, and it pumps the brakes many times per second to prevent a skid and to retain the driver's ability to steer.
"Because a car equipped with antilocks handles differently in an emergency stop," the pamphlet says, "drivers need to adjust their braking style. Unlike regular brakes, which require gentle pressure when stopping on wet and slippery surfaces, heavy braking pressure is required to activate the antilock feature. Drivers shouldn't try to pump antilock brakes because pumping prevents effective operation."
The booklet is useful and free. You can get it by sending a stamped self-addressed envelope to Car List, Box 1420, Arlington, Va. 22210.
