SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Styles of The Times

LENGTH: 2424 words

HEADLINE: Have A #%!& Day

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
IT'S rude out there. Rude all over the place. In the country that invented "Have a Nice Day," citizens now wear sweatshirts that scream "Back Off," or worse. On the football field and on the basketball court, the old ideal of sportsmanlike conduct has degenerated into a fiesta of trash talk and aggressive taunting.
Since the 1940's, the Salvation Army has put out drop-off bins so that kindhearted citizens could donate old clothes and furniture. Last month, it announced that it would retire the bins in eight Midwestern states because people were using them as Dumpsters. 
 There's a problem here.
At the height of the riots two years ago in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Mayor David N. Dinkins, an icon of restraint and politeness, traveled to the neighborhood to make a heartfelt appeal for calm, reason and the rule of law. He beat a hasty retreat while being pelted with rocks and bottles.
Rude, rude, rude.
President Clinton has noticed. In late July, a heckler interrupted a speech he was giving in Chicago and blamed the Democrats for Congressional deadlock. The President bristled, then delivered an off-the-cuff policy statement. "I might say this is another thing wrong with this country," he said. "There's not enough civility in how we treat each other."
This is a bipartisan issue. In an address he delivered in May at a Mercer University in Macon, Ga., Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court meditated on the tormented history of racism in America, and on his own trial by fire before the Senate Judiciary Committee.
"I am here today to share my thoughts about a principle that seems to be falling out of fashion these days," he said. "Civility."
A civility deficit? "It may be the problem," said Richard J. Mouw, the president of Fuller Theological Seminary in Pasadena, Calif., and the author of "Uncommon Decency: Christian Civility in an Uncivil World."
"Unless we can find a way to live with diversity without screaming at each other or shooting at each other," he said, "it's all over."
Or as Rodney King put it, with Los Angeles burning in the background, "People, I just want to say, can't we all get along?"
The notion of civility is ancient. It derives from the same Latin root, "civilis," as do words like "city," "civil" and "civilization." It links such seemingly disparate ideas as keeping a civil tongue and fighting for civil rights. "Civility is public politeness, showing courtesy in the public square," Mr. Mouw said. Over time, civility broadened to take in all sorts of territory, from teatime manners to behavior on the football field, but it began as a political idea.
For most of human history, civility could be described as the style of behavior peculiar to the ruling class, and as an entrance exam for those who hoped to rise in social status. Consult the works of Edith Wharton for clarification. One thing was clear: social values and style came from the top down.
Those days are gone. The have-nots are no longer as docile as they once were, for one thing. Critics of the culture have devoted much energy to exposing dominant social codes as tools of oppression and social control, for another.
"I believe very much in civility, but sometimes manner and class can be used as a means of excluding other people," said A. R. Gurney, whose most recent play, "Later Life," explores the limitations of the haut-WASP code. "My father said, 'Gentlemen say trousers, gents say pants.' Or if you said 'excuse me,' that was fine, but 'pardon me' was slightly gauche. He used it as a way of excluding people from his world, I thought."
Mr. Gurney also suggested that civility could be used to dampen useful confrontation. "I was brought up to feel that argument, or what we called contradiction, was wrong," he said. "You agreed and in private said something else. I think that's wrong, because those coals can smolder underneath; an insight may not be arrived at."
No worry about unexpressed insights on "The Simpsons" or "Married With Children," television shows devoted to rudeness as a blue-collar art form. Week after week, the title character on "Roseanne" gives a Bronx cheer in the direction of her natural enemies: middle-management weenies, bankers, lawyers and the phony, dim-witted jerks who hand out layoff slips and bottom-line explanations to union workers.
"People are not feeling powerful these days," said Will Miller, a psychiatrist, Baptist minister and stand-up comedian who psychoanalyzes old television shows on "Nick at Night" under the name Dr. Will. "I believe that TV has tapped into a strong chord of recognition by millions of people that the smart people, the people running the show, are guilty, not of hotblooded rudeness, but of cold-blooded cruelty."
Back in the 1980's there was a fair amount of hotblooded rudeness, too, as the swaggering nouveaux riches pushed and bullied their way to the head of the line. The economic downturn put a damper on that, but the sour taste lingers. And the working class is getting its chance to fight back, at least on television.
In a curious reversal of values, the new blue-collar rudeness stands for honesty, simplicity and sincerity, as opposed to the sneaky, passive-aggressive style that goes under the name of politeness. To the bosses, it says, "You may have the power to get away with this, but don't think for a minute that I don't know what's going on."
Descend one level from the working class to the underclass, and the temperature rises. Skepticism shades into outright rejection. Part of the appeal of rap is that it refuses to buy into the civility model. After Rodney King made his televised appeal, the rap artist Willie D. threw it back in his face with a vulgarly titled record that in essence said, "No, Rodney, we can't get along."
"Rap artists reject what they see as a too-polite civil rights movement," said James Bernard, a senior editor of The Source, a hip-hop magazine. "People feel that being polite doesn't get you anywhere -- it's weak."
All along the political front lines, anger and excess tend to be seen as signs of virtue. Anti-abortion protesters throw out reasoned argument and use words like "murder" and "genocide." Act Up members, protesting the Catholic Church's stand on contraception, disrupt a service at St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Already, the Mayor has had to temper the language of some of his supporters, who have been spicing up their descriptions of Rudolph W. Giuliani with terms like "fascist" and suggestions that his candidacy promotes Ku Klux Klan values.
It feels good to dish out abuse. Besides, the enemy has sacrificed his right to be treated like a fellow human being -- to be treated civilly, that is. There can be no civility, no discussion, no compromise, for "fascists" and murderers.
This style is sometimes called "in your face." Originally a basketball term, it refers to the very fast, very physical, very vocal playground game that came out of the ghettos and now dominates the National Basketball Association.
In-your-face does not subscribe to the old gentlemanly rules. It is loud. It is boastful. In playground ball, half the game lies in the art of mercilessly taunting one's opponent during the game, then rubbing his face in the ashes of defeat afterward.
"Victory is not enough; you have to humiliate," said Frank Deford, who devoted his weekly sports commentary on National Public Radio recently to the decline in civility. His remarks came after a wild Saturday of college football marked by free-for-alls that involved not only players, but also coaches. To older fans, it seemed like the end of civilization as we know it.
New Yorkers are old hands at contemplating the demise of civilization. In this, as in so many other areas, the city is in the vanguard.
Fred Siegel, a professor of humanities at Cooper Union in New York, spends most of his time analyzing what he calls "the collapse of public space in New York."
It's a depressing business. A combination of bulldozers and quasi-martial law has restored order to Tompkins Square Park on the Lower East Side. But in dozens of pocket-size parks and playgrounds, Mr. Siegel sees tribal warfare and turf battles, battling boom boxes and an unhealthy atmosphere of menace. Civility, like a toy poodle on a leash, shivers in the corner.
"New Yorkers have never been terribly civil, but it never had an ideological edge, which it now has," Mr. Siegel said.
This edge comes in part from "a loss of shared assumptions, which is the underside of multiculturalism," he said.
"We don't feel we can criticize behavior different from our own, because that would mean imposing a narrow middle-class point of view," he added.
In recent months, however, timorous New Yorkers have begun to whine out loud about the myriad of petty offenses known as quality-of-life crimes: the broken bottle on the sidewalk, the use of convenient nooks and crannies as public urinals. Middle-class New York is suffering death by a thousand life-style cuts. It hurts.
Suddenly, the quality-of-life issue has taken on new urgency. And Mayor Dinkins has received the message. In an aggressive speech last month, he said, "I believe that by creating a climate of civility and decency and order in our neighborhoods, we'll let the pushers and the criminals know that this city is ours to enjoy -- not theirs to destroy."
The standoff is not just between drug pushers and mothers pushing baby carriages, however. Civility breakdown seems to occur whenever two cultures come into contact. The boycott of a Korean grocery store in Brooklyn by black neighborhood residents in 1988 presented two groups whose sense of civility had been outraged.
Black customers complained that the store owners showed disrespect by, among other things, not making eye contact with them at the cash register. Apparently, they did not realize that for Koreans, bowing the head shows politeness toward a customer. The Koreans interpreted loud talking or displays of high spirits as threatening.
Both sides felt aggrieved. Neither side showed much interest in trying to tune in to the other's cultural frequencies.
Mr. Siegel calls this the new tribalism. "If we have fundamentally different values and assumptions, there's no reason to believe we can transcend them in the political arena," he said. "Multiculturalism argues that persuasion is irrelevant."
Civility is a hard sell, particularly in a city like New York, which cherishes its own brand of rudeness like a pungent cheese, repellent to outsiders, perhaps, but prized by the locals. The city that never sleeps is also the city that never says, "Excuse me," "I'm sorry," or "You know, you could be right."
Civility can seem weak and ineffectual even in a normal environment. In New York, it can look like a personality disorder. I'm O.K., you're not O.K. In fact, you're a jerk. And no, we can't get along.
"There may be points at which we can't compromise, but we'd better be very sure we're at this point," Mr. Mouw said. "There's just too much hostility in the air."
 
MOMENTS (ABUNDANT) OF NASTINESS

* Dennis Leary, a chain-smoking, tough-talking comedian, made his debut on MTV in 1987. His trademark, delivered with his face looming into the camera: "I think you hear me knockin' and I think I'm comin' in."
* During the 1991-92 basketball season, Charles Barkley, a forward for the Philadelphia 76ers at the time, spat at heckling fans, hitting an 8-year-old girl. He was fined $10,000, suspended for one game and was subsequently traded to the Phoenix Suns. With him the Suns, talent-rich but considered "soft," aggressed their way into the 1993 National Basketball Association Finals.
* In December 1992, "The Chronic," an album by Dr. Dre, made its debut and featured the rapper Snoop Doggy Dogg. One number profanely suggested, in title and in detail, that women are worthless. "The Chronic" became the biggest-selling hardcore rap album (more than two million sold) and that track's sentiment was emblazoned on a popular T-shirt. Soon after, Onyx, a hip-hop group, released an album with an indelicate title meaning, essentially, "back off." The album sold more than 500,000 copies.
* Beavis and Butthead, cartoon metal-heads, got their own show on MTV in March. Their mixture of adolescent idiocy and cruelty -- blowing up lizards, for example -- made the show one of the music network's biggest hits.
* Vince Coleman of the Mets threw a firecracker at a group of fans outside Dodger Stadium in July, injuring three people, including a 2-year-old girl.
* A duo calling itself the Jerky Boys created an album of its prank phone calls to New Yorkers. The album sold nearly 500,000 copies.
* Ru Paul, the drag performer, insulted Milton Berle onstage at the MTV Awards in September, suggesting that the elderly comedian needed to wear adult diapers. The outburst earned him the nickname Rudepaul.
* This month, Howard Stern, the shock radio disk jockey, published "Private Parts" (Simon & Schuster), which includes this thought on Rodney King: "They didn't beat this idiot enough."
 
MOMENTS (RARE) OF CIVILITY
 * The New York City Transit Authority announced on May 12, 1989, that its trains were 100 percent graffiti-free. Rude culture was tagged back.
* The author M. Scott Peck issued "A World Waiting to Be Born: Civility Rediscovered" (Bantam, 1993). In it he says America is in need of healing. The book stayed on the New York Times best-seller list for 14 weeks.
* The Handshake: Yitzhak Rabin and Yassir Arafat clasped five on the White House lawn on Sept. 13, symbolizing the peace agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Mr. Rabin also gave secondary but symbolic skin to other startled Arab representatives. "Nobody told us this was going to happen," said the Ambassador from Jordan, Fayez Tarawneh. "But we are gentlemen, after all."
* "The Age of Innocence," Martin Scorsese's rendering of an Edith Wharton novel, opened on Sept. 17. Audiences were fascinated by its depiction of life in New York in the 1870's and of a society so civil that you could insult someone without opening your mouth.
* In July, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo came to the aid of Mayor David N. Dinkins's re-election campaign, calling him "the essence of civility." In September, however, the Governor and Mayor were forced to acknowledge the limitations of that style. LENGTH: 530 words

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS;
Janet Wickenhaver and Tom Allon

BYLINE: By Lois Smith Brady

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, Janet Wickenhaver was working as a freelance crime reporter and living alone in a railroad flat in Hoboken, N.J. She jokingly called her apartment "the penthouse exercise suite" because you had to climb four flights of stairs to get to it.
When she wasn't covering murders or drug busts, her night life consisted mainly of playing poker with a close-knit group of other female journalists. "I was militantly pursuing my singlehood," Ms. Wickenhaver said. "But it was beginning to crack." 
 She met Tom Allon, then the editor of The Manhattan Spirit, a weekly newspaper, when she called him with a story idea: a single woman's survival guide to Valentine's Day. (Advice from the guide: "Do not let any question resembling 'What's wrong with me?' stick in your head. Do not call any ex-boyfriends and ask them that question. Do not call your mother and ask her that question.")
Mr. Allon not only bought the story but he also hired her as an associate editor, and they essentially put out the small West Side paper together. For a year, they were friends and colleagues, critiquing each other's headlines, drinking beers after late nights in the office and talking about their love lives.
His love life was, he said, overactive. "One week, I had seven blind dates in six days," he recalled. "I had two in one day -- lunch and dinner. I used to meet them at Caffe Dante on MacDougal Street between Bleecker and Houston. I remember I was there six consecutive nights and I was getting weird looks from the waitresses."
After a year, what was clear to almost everyone who knew the pair became clear to them: they were falling in love.
Now they live together (in a building with an elevator) but work separately. Mr. Allon, 31, is the publisher and editor of both The Manhattan Spirit and Our Town, a neighborhood newspaper for the East Side. Ms. Wickenhaver, 33, is the editor of Street News, a biweekly paper that focuses on homeless issues in New York and has included features on everything from sidewalk musicians to President Clinton's antipoverty legislation. The paper is distributed mainly in the subway by jobless and homeless people.
"It is true that a lot of street people have ancillary mental, drug and other problems," she said. "But they still have stuff to offer, and we shouldn't give up on them."
Mr. Allon and Ms. Wickenhaver were married on Oct. 10 in the grand ballroom of the Puck Building in SoHo. Gauzy curtains covered the windows, Christmas lights were wrapped around the room's many columns and the couple stood under a large white tentlike chuppa surrounded by ficus trees and flowers; it looked like an elaborate Victorian gazebo in the woods.
During the ceremony, Rabbi Avi Winokur sang Hebrew prayers, quoted George Bernard Shaw, recounted the couple's love story and commented that between husband and wife, it's as important to have a down-to-earth friendship as it is to have a love affair.
"Tom and Janet became good friends long before they made this serious decision and I think that bodes well," he said after the ceremony. "I think passion remains with couples who have more than passion to begin with."

GRAPHIC: Photos of ceremony at the Puck Building, Manhattan, Oct. 10. (Photographs by Edward Keating/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 390 words

HEADLINE: Child Maltreatment Affects the Poor More

 BODY:
Myths die hard, and few myths seem to have as much staying power as the myth that "child abuse cuts across all social and economic lines" but, as the District Attorney candidate Jeanine Pirro puts it, "we see it more in poorer families only because they have more contact with government services" ["Child Abuse Drawing Closer Public Scrutiny," Sept. 12].
Of course, there are some middle-class child abusers, but the evidence is overwhelming that poverty is by far the most important cause of child maltreatment. The Federal Government's second Study of National Incidence and Prevalence of Child Abuse and Neglect found that physical abuse was at least five times more common among poor families and neglect was nearly 12 times more common among the poor. Many other studies have produced similar results. 
 That's not surprising. We know that child abuse is linked to stress and that poverty increases stress. More important, the mere act of being poor is enough to fit the definition of "neglect." And as the article notes, 93 percent of all allegations of child maltreatment in New York State involve neglect.
The overwhelming majority of these cases are nothing like those cited in your article, in which children were starved, drowned and thrown out a window. Far more common are cases in which a family's poverty is confused with neglect.
If not giving enough food to a child is neglect, that includes the wealthy parent who deliberately starves a child and the poor parent whose food stamps run out. But who is likely to turn up more often? If neglect is "lack of supervision," it includes wealthy parents who leave a child alone so they can party all night and the poor, single mother trying to hold a job and stay off welfare whose baby-sitting arrangements are inadequate. But who is likely to turn up more often?
This does not mean we have to eliminate poverty to eliminate child abuse. Simply ameliorating the worst effects of poverty by providing day care or rent subsidies, for example, would dramatically reduce the rate of abuse and neglect. Not only would that allow more children to remain safely in their own homes, it also would free up scarce resources for cases like those described in your article.
 
ELIZABETH VORENBERG
President
National Coalition for
Child Protection Reform
Cambridge, Mass.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: Haiti's Curse;
Power Means Brutality; Practice Makes Perfect

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
FOR most of Haiti's history, the formula insuring its misery has been depressingly simple: a mulatto elite leaves politics to a professional class of brutal demagogues free to do what they will with the country as long as the elite's monopolies are untouched by the hand of government.
"Leave the rich alone to do what they've always done," says a disgruntled army officer in the recent novel of Haiti, "No Other Life," by Brian Moore, explaining the system perfected by the bloody, 29-year Duvalier family dictatorship. "In turn, they're grateful for being spared and so they render unto Caesar." 
 But since the military coup two years ago against this country's first democratically elected President, Haiti's power equation has become even more brutally elementary. The military has muscled out the elite -- a perverse result of repeated international attempts to isolate the country through embargoes and diplomatic pressure meant to secure the return from exile of the ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
That result was starkly illustrated last week as the military repudiated a United Nations agreement that it had signed allowing for President Aristide's return -- an accord supported by prominent members of the elite along with vast numbers of the nation's poor as a way of restoring political and economic order to the country.
The military instead orchestrated a demonstration by armed thugs that forced the humiliating retreat from Port-au-Prince of an American ship carrying more than 200 American and Canadian troops sent to help implement the settlement. Two days later, after the United Nations reimposed economic sanctions to force the military to comply, the Justice Minister in Mr. Aristide's transitional Government was cut down by a hail of assassins' bullets on a Port-au-Prince street, along with two aides. By the end of the week, even the menace of warships dispatched by President Clinton to enforce the embargo had not changed the mind of the army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, who reneged on a promise to step down. With threats against foreigners mounting in a climate of intense hostility, hundreds of United Nations personnel hastily left the country.
Thus have those who imagined that this country could fall no lower than it did under the Duvaliers been awakened to a much more frightening nightmare.
Fed by its control of the country's ports and landing strips, and emboldened by an unfettered ability to cow a population with bullets, the Haitian military has become at once the new elite, the traditional nationalist dictatorship and even the Tontons Macoute -- the Duvaliers' fearsome private militia -- all wrapped into one.
The leaders of the army and the police have learned well the lessons of raw power. General Cedras; his chief of staff, Gen. Philippe Biamby, and the 36-year-old police chief of Port-au-Prince, Col. Joseph Michel Francois -- widely thought to be the military's most powerful officer -- all are descendants of prominent Duvalierists and were raised with a disdain of democracy.
Their economic portfolios are strikingly well-balanced. They earn their livelihood from the lucrative transshipment of illicit drugs from South America to the United States as well as through control of state monopolies like the telephone company. Skimming profits from tariffs and electricity bills alike, their wallets are constantly being fattened in ways that could prove stubbornly resistant to isolation.
Colonel Francois, for example, has become the new czar of the elite's old monopolies: flour, sugar, rice and cement. Through sheer intimidation, he controls enterprises once held by old-line families or more recent Middle Eastern immigrants -- businesses that his downtown police station used to sell "protection" to.
A potentially modernizing influence, a small entrepreneurial class that built its wealth on low-cost, light-assembly industries, has been hurt by an oil embargo, slapped on the country last week for the second time this year.
The entrenchment of the military in Haitian society has long historical roots. Haiti won its independence from France in 1804 in the world's only successful slave revolt. Overnight a land of recent arrivals from Africa, disparate in origin, was forced to stand alone against a hostile outside world. France quickly exacted heavy reparations from what had been its richest colony. The United States, afraid of the inspiration a black nation might give its slaves, declined to recognize Haiti until 1862, despite its contribution of soldiers to America's War of Independence.
For all its African origins, Haiti has always seemed to live in a time all its own. "There is something peculiarly Roman in the air of Haiti: Roman in its cruelty, in its corruption and its heroism," wrote Graham Greene, whose novel "The Comedians" is the classic fictional portrait of the Duvalier era. "We are nearer to the Europe of Nero and Tiberius than to the Africa of Nkrumah."
Haiti as Rome comes across repeatedly in its tormented history. In one of the goriest episodes, President Vilbrun Guillaume Sam, having ordered the execution of more than 100 political prisoners, was dragged out of the French Embassy in 1915 by an angry mob, pulled limb from limb through the closed gates. The incident was a factor in the United States intervention in Haiti that followed, although American concerns over German penetration were probably of equal importance.
The ensuing 19-year occupation of Haiti by 3,000 marines, ending in 1934, merely strengthened the Haitian Army along with its determination to be a controlling force in the nation's life. It has gone much the same with subsequent American efforts to influence Haitian affairs.
"The United States is always looking for the good guy, the man that they can trust in the army," said Jocelyn McCalla, an expert in Haitian affairs who directs the National Coalition of Haitian Refugees in New York. "And they are always surprised when things go bad."
Although it could suddenly capitulate in the current confrontation, the army has the ability to hold out for at least months while conditions deteriorate rapidly for the vast majority of Haitians. That could result in a renewed exodus of boat people toward the United States, as well as an incalculable toll of victims of violent repression.
Even if the military can be brought quickly to its knees, however, a more vexing issue remains: Can an institution that has never long kept itself out of politics be induced to live within the bounds of a true democracy?
Many people knowledgeable about the United Nations settlement intended to end Haiti's agony doubt its viability. The plan calls for lightly armed international experts to separate the police from the army and retrain both forces in perhaps no more than six months. Haiti's forces are intended to emerge as respectably professional entities after crash courses in everything from physical fitness to basic soldiering skills and human rights.
Mr. McCalla and others say that the most important question, one few diplomats or officials wish to confront, is why Haiti, the hemisphere's poorest country and a land without external enemies, needs an army at all.
And as long as Haiti's institutions remain sapped of their vitality by a craven elite and threatened by military power, any outside "solution" is likely to prove transitory. Saying as much in his pessimistic novel, Mr. Moore compared Haiti to a "cheap gramophone record."
"The new tune plays for a while, then the needle sticks in the groove and the player-arm slumps back and slips off the disc."

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Just Say 'Security';
One Clinton Promise Fits All Issues

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A NEATLY dressed 8-year-old boy stood up at at a televised question-and-answer session in Sacramento recently to tell President Clinton that he has been scared to go to school ever since his brother got shot there.
In the White House Rose Garden days before, a young woman told Hillary Rodham Clinton that her sister is dying of AIDS while fighting for the coverage that her insurance company is threatening to cancel. 
 And every day for two weeks, Mr. Clinton has argued for the North American Free Trade Agreement before angry union leaders and dubious members of Congress who fear that it will cost thousands of jobs.
For each of these issues and several others, Mr. Clinton has offered virtually the same response. His administration, he has promised in a series of speeches, will restore security to American life.
Security. The scope of that promise is immense, but the President has tapped into a American craving for certainty at a time when so much of what has gone before is up for grabs. Big corporations and even governments are laying off workers, and health costs and health coverage are slipping out of reach. And, as even the United States' role on the international stage is being rewritten, American optimism is fading.
The President has said he will curb skyrocketing health care costs, flood the streets with police officers and create thousands of new jobs by dropping trade barriers with Mexico and Canada. It is a deep burden for any President to take on.
And if he does not, Mr. Clinton runs the risk of handing his opponents a new version of the formulaic campaign query that Ronald Reagan coined in 1980 to defeat Jimmy Carter and that Mr. Clinton appropriated to defeat George Bush: Do you feel more secure than you did four years ago?
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton also said he would cut taxes on the middle class and devise a national service program that would enable every student to pay for college. Neither of those pledges, which were compromised away after Mr. Clinton took office, lived up to expectations.
Now, with the almost breathtakingly ambitious domestic agenda, the President has constructed a new set of hurdles for himself. The North American Free Trade Agreement is already creaking under the weight of organized opposition. The health care plan is beginning to suffer in public opinion for lack of detail. And the anti-crime package, which has advanced toward near-passage at least twice before in Congress, has yet to win the consensus it will need to push it over the top this time.
All of this could make the promise of security a pretty hard one to keep.
"There's a huge gap between what they say they want to accomplish and the programs and policies they put into effect to accomplish them," said John E. Robson, who was deputy treasury secretary under George Bush. He calls this condition "Clinton's gap."
But the President's closest advisers say that the call for security transcends politics and is Mr. Clinton's way of recognizing the precarious nature of the American condition, both politically and economically.
"It was something evolved by him, not something pasted together by his staff or by his advisers," said David Gergen, a counselor to the President who has helped shape the message. "There has been an evolution in his thinking. He has been trying to piece together in his own mind a way to talk about and think through what we go through as a people."
Sheltering all of the President's domestic initiatives under a single umbrella, Mr. Gergen said, "gives momentum to all of them."
Frank Luntz, a pollster who worked for Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot, agrees.
"It's very easy to sell security, because you're selling a panacea," he said. But the White House, he asserted, is selling a pledge of safety that probably cannot be honored.
"That fear of the future is what's leading Americans to try to put a floor down which they cannot fall below," Mr. Luntz said. "The President is of the belief that people are so desperate and so anxious to create that floor that they will sell the future for the present."
In some cases, the link seems to make perfect sense. In recent speeches, Mr. Clinton has segued from discussing the need for universal health coverage to bemoaning the violence that has burdened city hospitals with uninsured victims of gunshots and gang warfare.
"We have some demographic characteristics that make us a more expensive population than Canada or Great Britain or Germany," a senior White House aide said last week. "And the level of violence is one of those characteristics. And unless you talk about violence and substance abuse as health problems, you don't deal with the whole range of issues that are out there to be confronted."
"It is not just a social problem," the aide said. "It is not just a criminal problem. It is a health problem. And the more we can draw those links, people will begin to understand the relationship."
The link between individual well-being and free trade is a somewhat more difficult case to make, because the Administration lost the march on selling Nafta to labor unions and to Ross Perot, who joined forces to paint the pact as a bad idea.
Some Administration officials sense that they may have handed their Republican opponents a weapon that they can eventually use to attack the President. As a result, they have begun fine-tuning the Clinton message to reflect public distrust in Government.
"If we were to deal seriously and get a serious gun bill through and a serious bill on cops, would that solve the crime problem?" said Mr. Gergen. "No. But would it convince people that the Government is working with them to help reduce violence? I think it would. The trust would go up."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
After 20 Years, America's Foot Is Still On the Gas

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
TWENTY years after the Arab oil embargo, after the gas lines, after the fist fights, after the nation's promise to itself to do better, some things have changed. Mostly they've gotten worse.
The United States today uses almost as much oil as it did then, but imports 44.6 percent of it, up from 37.2 percent in 1973. At the time of the embargo, 5.3 percent of the oil used here came from Arab members of Opec; now it is 11.6 percent. Then our largest supplier was Venezuela, which is geographically and culturally close to the United States; now it is Saudi Arabia, which is neither. 
 Then, we imported oil to help drive our cars and trucks 1.3 trillion miles a year; today we drive 2.2 trillion.
Some of the people most concerned about energy say none of this should come as a surprise. "The only thing we learn from history is we learn nothing from history," said James Schlesinger, a former Defense Secretary and head of the C.I.A., who was the "energy czar" during the second oil crisis, in 1979.
Everyone who thinks about it agrees that some supplies are shaky. Venezuela, now the second-largest supplier to this country, has had two coup attempts this year. Nigeria, No. 5, is also unstable. Saudi Arabia, No. 1 at 1.5 million barrels of the 8.5 million barrels imported each day, faces religious strains.
Production from stable, friendly places, like Texas and Oklahoma, continues to dwindle; domestic production is down by about 2 million barrels a day over the 20-year period, despite tapping the Alaskan fields. The oil industry wants import tariffs or tax incentives, along with access to areas that environmentalists want protected.
Environmentalists like heavier gasoline taxes, and on Oct. 1 the Federal tax rose 4.3 cents a gallon, as much as Congress could stand but not as much in the average motorist's weekly budget as a morning newspaper.
"Our energy policy is to take the cheapest oil in the world, regardless of source, and take our chances that it will continue to be cheap and available," said William K. Tell Jr., senior vice president of Texaco.
On the consumption side, the problem is partly technology but mostly will. A Federal standard established after the embargo sets average mileage at 27.5, and the Environmental Protection Agency said in a recent report that manufacturers have no incentive to do better.
 
Accelerating Acceleration
 While the manufacturers are getting more from a gallon of gasoline these days, they are applying the gains to performance, not mileage. The average time to accelerate from 0 to 60 miles an hour was 14 seconds in 1974, and is now about 11.5 seconds, thanks to multi-valve engines and other technical improvements. If Detroit had interrupted that trend in 1984, when the average time was about 13.4 seconds, and applied all subsequent improvements to fuel economy, average miles per gallon would be about 30 instead of 27.5, the agency believes.
"We have testosterone cars instead of efficient cars," said Daniel F. Becker, an energy expert at the Sierra Club in Washington.
Detroit does, in fact, build some efficient cars. The Coalition for Vehicle Choice, a lobby backed by the auto makers, analyzed the E.P.A. statistics on the 1994 models and pointed out that the 10 models with the highest ratings, 43 miles a gallon to 58 miles a gallon, "represent less than 2 percent of all passenger cars sold." Mr. Becker's response is that Detroit doesn't try very hard to sell the efficient ones.
But the trend to indulge the vehicular equivalent of hormones leads some consumers into vehicles less efficient than cars. "The industry's gone to tremendous efforts to improve the fuel economy of cars, but for the fleet as a whole we're losing it to trucks," said Robert M. Heavenrich, an automotive specialist at the E.P.A., who noted that 4 of 10 vehicles sold are light-duty trucks. Among the top 10 most popular vehicles in the last model year were four pickups and a van.
Intermittent schemes to get people out of cars do not get very far. A recent book on Americans and their cars, "Where the Road and the Sky Collide," by K. T. Berger, (Henry Holt, $22.50) says even the most casual observer would conclude that the car and driver are "the dominant life-form roaming the countryside."
President Clinton recently announced a program to put idle nuclear bomb scientists to work helping the industry make an 80-mile-a-gallon car. A tall order, but maybe more likely than getting drivers to take the bus.
Are there any grounds for optimism? Maybe a few.
For one, the world's largest oil producer, the Soviet Union, collapsed in the early 90's with barely a ripple in the market. For another, some exporting companies are unlikely now to cut off supplies to consuming nations' distributors, because the exporters are the distributors; the Saudis own half of Texaco's eastern retailing system, and the Venezuelans have invested heavily in Citgo.
There is no more Soviet Union to march into the Persian Gulf. At least at the moment, there is no more Arab-Israeli conflict. And there is recent evidence, from the invasion of Kuwait, that war in the oil fields does not mean a catastrophic reduction in supplies.
Charles DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute, said, "Although we're importing a larger fraction, there's also more oil in the world than there was then." It seems unlikely, but world reserves now are nearly 50 times annual consumption, the highest ratio ever.
"The idea that we're running out is getting to be sort of weak," he said. "The idea of weaning yourself off oil with expensive methods makes less sense."
There are reasons to be wary of imports, though, he said, among them the tremendous cost. In 1973, spending on oil imports was $23.9 billion, and total trade deficit was a paltry $3.9 billion; last year, oil imports cost $44.8 billion and total deficit was $84.5 billion.
Eventually, the habit will have to change, said Mr. Becker of the Sierra Club. The deciding factor may not be the stability of distant countries; it may turn out to be pollution or global warming, or the realization that this resource should be shared with future generations. No matter how much oil is found, Mr. Becker said, it is a finite resource: "After all, they're not making new dinosaurs."

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Wanted: Hot Leads on Cold Cases;
Now Bounty Hunters Can Make Out Like Bandits

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE prices on the "Wanted" posters are going up.
Earlier this month, the Federal Government offered $1 million to anyone who helps crack the 15-year-old "Unabom" case -- the hunt for the bomber whose parcels have maimed and killed executives and professors. 
 And last month, the Clinton Administration offered its second $2 million reward in the World Trade Center bombing case. It said the money would go to anyone providing information leading to the capture of Abdul Rahman Yasin, a suspect in the bombing of the World Trade Center who may have fled to Iraq. Over the summer, the Administration made a similar offer for information about another suspect, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef. He is also believed to have escaped to Iraq, although investigators think he may have gone from there to Iran or Afghanistan.
While million-dollar rewards are still rare, the trend toward them seems to be rising much faster than inflation can account for. After United States troops were sent to Panama in 1989, President Bush approved a $1 million bounty for information that would lead to the capture of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, who was hiding in the Vatican diplomatic mission. The money was never paid because Mr. Noriega gave himself up.
Some private groups and other countries have offered seven-figure rewards, including the Colombian Government's bounty earlier this year of more than $6 million for the capture of Pablo Escobar, one of the leaders of the Medellin cocaine cartel. But in the United States, by and large, Federal and state agencies have posted more modest offers -- in the $10,000 to $50,000 range for killers and kidnappers.
And private bounties seem to be getting larger as well. For many years, armored truck companies and art galleries have offered large rewards when they have been the victims of robberies. But a recent offer by the film star Winona Ryder of $200,000 for the safe return of a 12-year-old girl kidnapped at knife-point from her California home has struck some law enforcement officials as unusually generous. Like the girl, Polly Klaas, Ms. Ryder is from Petaluma and began her stage career in a local theater at age 12. She decided to offer the reward after seeing a segment about the case on "America's Most Wanted."
What has changed things?
Officials say that high-profile, high-stakes cases -- like the World Trade Center explosion and the serial mail bomber -- put enormous pressure on investigators. And when the trail starts to grow cold, sometimes the only way to keep an investigation going is to tantalize the public with lottery-sized jackpots.
"A million dollars tends to wonderfully focus the mind," said John C. Killorin, a spokesman for the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. "It's a fair assessment to say that when an agency comes forward with a reward offer, it means that either the leads have run out or there are just too many of them out there."
The firearms agency is one of three Federal agencies, along with anonymous private donors, to jointly offer $1 million for information that leads to the conviction of the serial bomber. Mr. Killorin said it already prompted more than 1,200 calls offering tips, although the case still remains far from being solved. He said the agencies will divvy up the reward if more than one person offers clues that crack the case.
Do bounties work? Sometimes. Of course, governments have offered them since before the founding of the Republic. One of the earliest Federal laws on the subject was adopted in 1899, when Congress authorized the Government to provide rewards to anyone who helped turn in those who failed to pay taxes. And earlier this century, rewards played an important role in the Government's enforcement of Prohibition laws forbidding production or sale of liquor.
Because big rewards are rare and Federal and local agencies account for them in different ways -- most lump them in with their payments to street informants, for example -- it is hard to compare such programs. But officials say the largest is probably the Internal Revenue Service's program that gives informants a portion of what the Government collects (up to a $100,000 maximum). Between 1967 and last year, the I.R.S. paid more than $21 million to recover more than $1 billion in unpaid taxes. Some rewards reached the full $100,000, and officials think those are the largest government bounties collected.
Civil libertarians and defense lawyers say they are generally less troubled by rewards offered to the public than by other kinds of inducements -- like payoffs to informants. Still, they are worried when the awards get so big that they encourage crackpots. They can also taint a trial when a jury begins to consider how much money was paid to help catch the defendant. The large awards, they say, can be big incentives to those tempted to violate civil liberties and privacy rights.
Vivian Berger, an American Civil Liberties Union lawyer who teaches law at Columbia University, said that because the rewards are usually offered to the public at large and paid only after convictions, they are not as problematic as payments to an informant who may have participated in a crime or to someone who can entrap a defendant. She also said that rewards, "to the extent that they are not humongous," are less likely to "skewer the reliability of information."
Still, some rewards encourage abuses anyway. Last year, the Internal Revenue Service received 10,966 claims for prizes. It awarded 671.
"Some of the complainants are people who are disenchanted with their neighbors, spouses or employers," said Johnell Hunter, an I.R.S. spokeswoman. "They don't always work out very well. We don't publicize the program just for that reason. We don't want a rush of unhappy people ratting on their neighbors without cause."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
In a Politician's Eyes, Some Jobs Are Worthier

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HERE is a case where economists and politicians part ways.
Economists say it should make no difference whether a worker was laid off by General Dynamics or by Woolworth -- whether a plant closed because of a specific change in Government policy like cuts in the defense budget or because of corporate mismanagement or the vagaries of the marketplace. All laid-off workers, they say, deserve equal treatment. 
 To politicians, however, some workers are more worthy of Government help. In their view, farmers, lumberjacks and assembly-line workers need retraining more than office workers do. And, they say, when the Government is to blame for layoffs, it is obliged to help.
So when Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, who used to teach economic policy at Harvard, announced last week that the Administration would support new money to retrain workers who lose jobs because of the North American Free Trade Agreement, he did it against his better judgment but out of political necessity.
Shortly before the announcement, he had argued that special programs for particular workers were bad economics. "If you were a supersleuth," he said, "you could trace everything back to some Government policy or other -- to fiscal policy or monetary policy or regulatory policies."
So, he had said, rather than waste money trying to figure out why someone is unemployed or risk treating workers differently, the Government should equally aid everyone out of work, regardless of the reason.
John T. Dunlop, who was Secretary of Labor in the Ford Administration, agreed. "Suppose the Federal Reserve's policy on interest rates leads to a decline in business and people are laid off," he said. "That's just as much a Government policy as new trade rules."
Although a Labor Department audit circulating last week showed that the existing training program for workers hurt by foreign trade has been largely ineffective, Mr. Reich had to bow to political reality. The trade agreement faces do-or-die votes in Congress, and manufacturing workers, who fear Nafta would cost them their jobs, have considerable influence. Without a special retraining program for workers who lose their jobs to Mexicans, the trade measure cannot pass.
Another recent example of how some jobs carry more political weight than others: Last summer, when President Clinton announced plans to restrict logging in the Pacific Northwest, he promised $1.2 billion to help affected communities. That works out to $200,000 for each of the 6,000 jobs the Government thinks will be lost.
But when 30,000 Wall Street workers, most of them secretaries and clerks, were laid off in the late 1980's, the Government offered no special help.
Or consider how differently the jobs of auto workers and computer workers are treated. The policy of the Federal Government and most states and towns is to buy only cars made in the United States. The idea is to protect American jobs.
But walk into any government office and you are likely to see computers made overseas. This, even though International Business Machines is cutting almost 200,000 jobs from its worldwide payroll.
It is easy to understand why the Government spends hundreds of millions of dollars to help workers and towns adjust to the closing of military bases. This is more a question of equity than politics.
But it is less apparent why loggers should get more help than Wall Street clerks or auto workers more than computer programmers.
 
Union Labels
 One explanation is that the workers at computer companies and banks are rarely unionized, while the United Automobile Workers has political muscle and public relations experience.
But Northwest loggers do not owe their political strength to a union. Their case turned on how concentrated the timber industry is. Whole counties in Washington, Oregon and California depend on logging. I.B.M. jobs are spread so widely around the world that no single community is so dependent.
In the counties just north of New York City, where several thousand I.B.M. jobs are being eliminated, the cutback is of more social than economic significance.
"I.B.M. was a symbol of economic growth for this region," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It was high tech, high skill, high pay, high security. Now that symbol has given way. Suddenly the stability is gone."
The most important distinction politicians make about industries seems to be to favor dying ones. Loggers cannot go across town and find new trees to chop down. Workers who lose spots on assembly lines are unlikely to find equivalent pay elsewhere. And lumberjacks and grimy factory workers seem to fit the American myth of the rugged individual, while few good movies have been made about the romance of data processing. The perception is that a computer worker with a pink slip can drive a mile down the road and get hired without missing a paycheck. In fact, that is not always the case. The number of jobs in the industry nationwide -- about 400,000 -- has dropped by 20 percent since 1985. But it is true that computer workers can transfer skills more easily than blue-collar ones can. And companies like I.B.M. make Government intervention less necessary with generous severance pay and early retirement plans.
"The buyout plans are very effective, so people aren't considered victims like the auto workers," said Lenny Siegel, director of the Pacific Studies Center, a research institute in Silicon Valley.
And despite problems at some companies, the industry is not flagging. "I.B.M. is cutting back, and New York loses jobs," Mr. Siegel said. "But things are booming in Austin. The auto business isn't booming anywhere."
James E. Challenger, who heads a job-placement company in Chicago, offered another reason why some workers seem to have more political influence.
"They're the ones who are the most newsworthy," he said. "The picture of the logger versus the spotted owl is simply much more graphic than the picture of someone who sits in front of a computer all day long."

HEADLINE: PACT CALLED KEY TO LOWER IMPORTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton, in his most vigorous promotion of the North American Free Trade Agreement since the formal signing of labor and environmental safeguards in mid-September, warned today that failure to ratify the deal could isolate the United States and flood it with imported goods.
"Without Nafta, one of our best markets, Mexico, could turn to Japan and Europe to make a sweetheart deal for trade," the President said in his weekly radio address. "Without Nafta, Mexico could well become an export platform, allowing more products from Japan and Europe into America. Why would we want that to happen?" 
 Critics of the agreement have repeatedly argued that it would be American companies that would use Mexico as a platform from which to export goods after they move factories there, causing a substantial loss of jobs.
Mr. Clinton's renewed campaign for the agreement, which would gradually remove tariffs and other trade barriers among the United States, Mexico and Canada, was the latest example of a shift in the drive to stress the consequences if it fails.
Other arguments are that a rejection would undermine multinational trade talks now headed for their decisive phase and would jeopardize changes already adopted by Mexico.
 
Vote Set for Nov. 17
 The House is scheduled to vote on the agreement on Nov. 17, with no clear majority for passage yet in sight. The Administration is expected to win approval in the Senate by Thanksgiving.
The President's warnings also followed the outbreak this week of a battle over how to replace $2.4 billion in tariffs that would be lost under the trade agreement and how to pay for $325 million in border cleanup and worker retraining programs. An Administration proposal to levy a tax of at least $5 on international airplane tickets met fierce resistance from airlines and the travel and transportation industries.
The House Ways and Means Committee is to meet Tuesday to consider this issue, among other things, and the Administration is struggling to find a compromise. Mr. Clinton did not refer to the revenue question today.
On Wednesday, representatives of 200 companies with interests in Mexico will display products at the White House in an effort to portray American reliance on trade with Mexico, with which the United States runs a hefty surplus of exports over imports.
Mr. Clinton also used the radio address today to boast that "good things are beginning to happen" with the economy. He cited the savings that homeowners have pocketed as they take advantage of tumbling long-term interest rates to refinance mortgages and passage of a budget intended to cut the Federal deficit. He also said that 1.1 million private-sector jobs were created in his first eight months in office, more than the number generated in all of President George Bush's term.

HEADLINE: At Border, Optimism on Trade Accord

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: McALLEN, Tex., Oct. 12

 BODY:
In this Texas city near the Mexican border, where the unemployment rate is more than twice the national average, Pedro Diaz is acutely aware of the promise and the perils of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Mr. Diaz, a 24-year-old entrepreneur, owns a small but growing business along Highway 83 that sells automobile stereos and alarms. Already, 45 percent of his customers come from Mexico. The trade accord, he says, could be his ticket to rapid expansion into a more affluent Mexican market. But larger retailers might sense the potential, too, he says, and move in to undercut him and drive him out of business. 
 On balance, though, like many people here who somehow seem to be in favor of free trade and a little afraid of it at the same time, Mr. Diaz says he wants Nafta, as the accord is known, to pass when it comes up for a Congressional vote scheduled for next month.
"For me, I might just set up shops in Mexico, hire sales reps, all of that," he said. "But it's going to be a whole new world there, and the one thing I know is that if it passes, I can't just do things the way I'm doing them now. That would be devastating."
 
Fingers-Crossed Optimism
 While the proposed agreement has provoked visceral hostility in many parts of the Northeast and Midwest, a much more common sentiment here and in many cities close to the border is a fingers-crossed optimism about the opportunities Americans might enjoy when and if Mexican consumers have more money to spend. That may help explain why two-thirds of the Texas Congressional delegation is pledged to vote for the accord and several other Texas Representatives are still on the fence.
For many poor cities like McAllen, the support for the pact, which would gradually eliminate all tariffs and other trade barriers between Mexico, the United States and Canada, is bolstered by an undercurrent of fear about what will happen if the accord is defeated.
"Mexico is not going to let us have our cake and eat it too," said Mike Allen, the president of the McAllen Economic Development Corporation, explaining that he feared free trade could be replaced by a trade war. "They may just raise tariffs sky high."
The corporation Mr. Allen heads operates an 80-acre foreign trade zone just three miles north of the international bridge to the neighboring Mexican city of Reynosa. The trade zone, one of several along the border, is an area through which American-made components pass to Mexico, with duties waived, until they are assembled into finished products in Mexico by factory workers in what is known as the maquiladora industry.
The finished products are then shipped back to the United States with a tariff applied only to the amount of the value that is added by the assembly. The trade zones were approved by Congress as a way of spurring economic growth along the border.
About $1.2 billion worth of goods annually move through the trade zone here. The 91 operating maquiladoras in Reynosa put together a combination of goods, including pianos, semiconductors, lingerie and chrome-plated lawn chairs.
 
Fears of Higher Tariffs
 If the trade pact is defeated, some merchants here said they feared a return to the days when Mexican tariffs discouraged Mexicans from crossing the border to buy in Texas. The Mexican tariffs on some goods purchased in the United States could run as high as 50 to 100 percent.
"I talk to people in Reynosa all the time, and I can tell you, it's bordering on a tremendous insult to Mexico if Nafta is voted down," Mr. Allen said.
As in many parts of the country, there are some people here who fervently support the pact, arguing it will stimulate the economies on both sides of the border, create jobs and raise incomes.
And there are people who oppose it because they fear its chief effect will be to drain jobs from this country to Mexico, as industries move their operations south where labor is much cheaper. Some even insist the evident public support for the trade accord is misleading.
"There's not a whole lot of unionizing going on around here," said Jesse Bielefeld, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. representative for the area. "On the other hand, there is a real management push for Nafta. So if you're a worker and you speak out against the trade agreement, it really might affect whether you work the next day."
Still, many people here who favor the pact say they do so not because they completely understand the mechanics of free trade, but because they see tying their futures to the Mexican economy as a gamble worth taking -- or as an inevitability.
The McAllen area is one of the poorest metropolitan areas in the country, and it showed up in Federal statistics a few years ago as having one of the highest percentages of homes without indoor plumbing. But those figures also belie the enormous amount of economic activity here in recent years. Almost all of it, local officials say, is connected one way or another with Mexico.
 
Big Growth and Unemployment
 In fact, if it is possible for a place to be booming and busting all at the same time, McAllen fits the bill. Unemployment for surrounding Hidalgo County stands at 15.1 percent, a figure that almost everybody here says is understated, well above the national rate of 6.5 percent, according to the Texas Employment Commission. But McAllen, which despite being named for a Scottish settler has an unmistakable Latin feel, is also experiencing phenomenal growth. Its population, barely 10,000 a half century ago, swelled to 66,952 10 years ago and then jumped 25 percent in the last decade, to 84,021. The surrounding area is the fastest-growing in Texas and the 13th fastest-growing metropolitan market in the country, according to Federal census statistics.
Annual retail trade more than doubled in McAllen in the last five years, from $800 million in 1987 to $1.7 billion in 1992, said Michael J. Blum, a McAllen business consultant. Next door to the foreign trade zone, a $15 million produce market and storage center is under construction, financed by a large Mexican bank.
Tony Aguirre, who owns several hardware stores and an industrial supply house in the McAllen area, said about two-thirds of his business stems from the other side of the border. "I think we'll grow regardless of what happens," he said. "But we won't grow as fast without Nafta. That's the key."
 
'It Could Be a Nightmare'
 The more complicated question, said both he and Mr. Diaz, the car stereo entrepreneur, is whether their investing in Mexico will be too risky.
"It's not like it will be an automatic gold mine," Mr. Diaz said. "It could be a nightmare. There are all sorts of problems. Mexico has to change its infrastructure, for one thing. You drive to Monterrey, my friend, and you'll see crosses every half-mile on the highway. The roads are horrible."
But, Mr. Diaz added, if the point is to increase Mexicans' investment in their country's highways and bridges, the trade accord will probably be a good catalyst. In any event, given that Reynosa is next door and that people here can get to Monterrey faster than they get to just about any big city in Texas, many people here say they are convinced that their city's prosperity is linked to Mexico's.
"That's the bottom line," said Tommy Joyner, an official with the local Chamber of Commerce. "The people in McAllen, Tex., probably have a lot more in common with Reynosa than they do with Washington, D.C."

Like many people, he seems to favor the trade pact, while remaining a bit afraid of it. He assisted a customer with help from his mother, Sylvia, left, who works in the store. (Hart Van Denburg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Deluge of Foreign Assistance Fails To Revive Egypt's Stricken Economy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO

 BODY:
For nearly two decades, Egypt has been the beneficiary of one of the world's most ambitious assistance program, a multibillion-dollar rescue mission involving the United States' largest overseas aid operation since Vietnam, wealthy Arab neighbors, European creditors and international bankers. All are committed to securing Cairo's political stability.
By any measure, these huge infusions of cash -- more than $35 billion in United States economic and military aid alone since 1975 -- have done much to reshape the Egyptian landscape. The money has provided better roads and telephones, cleaner water and wider access to consumer goods. Birth rates have declined, and life expectancy has risen. 
 But over the same period, Egypt's creaking economy, with its wheezing state-run industries and bloated public sector, has remained virtually intact, forcing economists, bankers and Egyptian Government officials to acknowledge a painful truth. For all the billions pumped into Egypt, including a tripling in overseas assistance the last three years as a reward for Egypt's role in the Persian Gulf war, there has been little real improvement in the daily lives and fortunes of most of the country's 56 million people.
 
Expectations vs. Reality
 For Egyptian officials and overseas policymakers who have invested in Egypt's stability, the gap between expectations and reality continues to cloud the Egyptian Government's future, despite progress over the last two years in beginning to reform Egypt's moribund economy.
While President Hosni Mubarak appears to be firmly in control -- he won overwhelming endorsement to a third six-year term this month, albeit as the only candidate on the ballot -- the poverty, joblessness and lack of opportunity that is endemic here provides fuel for the Islamic militants determined overthrow the Government.
"The biggest challenge we will face over the next two or three years is in getting the economy moving in such a way that ordinary people will feel it, and be convinced things are getting better," said Yousef Boutros-Ghali, the American-educated Minister of State for the economy and nephew of Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Secretary General of the United Nations. "There is no point in pretending otherwise."
All across this teeming, swollen city of more than 10 million, people measure their lives against their hopes, and come up wanting. On the campus of Cairo University, students like 18-year-old Mahmoud el-Kourdy complain that while they are pursuing studies for a degrees, they know their best hope for a job after graduation is to work as a hotel tour guide.
"I speak some English, so I think I have a chance," he said. "Otherwise, I don't know what I will do."
 
Rising Cost of Living
 In the slums of Imbaba, across the Nile from Cairo, a tea shop owner named al-Saify Khodayra said he was hard-pressed to afford the rising costs of electricity, gasoline and sugar, as a result of cutbacks in Government subsidies. "The electrical bill for my shop and my home is now 200 pounds a month," or about $60, he said. "But my income is less than 500 pounds."
Nearly 20 years after Anwar el-Sadat, then the President, said he wanted to open Egypt to Western investors, Egypt has only just begun to implement the sort of basic changes that international bankers say are necessary to restructure Egypt's hugely inefficient, centrally planned economy, attract serious private investment and create the jobs that are key to any hope of real stability.
Under pressure from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the United States, Egypt has made notable progress over the last two years. Bolstered by a huge infusion of aid after the Persian Gulf war -- including a decision by the United States and Arab governments to write off some $13 billion worth of military debt -- Egypt agreed in 1991 to carry out a first round of economic reforms.
In return, some $3 billion in non-military debt owned the Paris Club of creditor nations was forgiven, the first of some $10 billion in promised loan write-offs tied to guarantees of an economic overhaul.
 
Egypt's Fiscal Changes
 As a result, Egypt has now cut its budget deficit from about 20 percent of gross domestic product to below 3 percent, brought inflation below 10 percent, stabilized its currency exchange rate, reduced expensive consumer subsides and removed controls on interest rates, helping bolster cash reserves to an estimated $11 billion.
This summer, the Egyptian Government agreed to a second phase of economic reforms, promising another $3 billion in debt forgiveness in return for promoting private business, liberalizing trade, and overhauling and privatizing state-owned companies.
Egyptian officials say the country's course toward a free-market economy is "irreversible." But this summer's agreement was delayed while Egyptian officials and international bankers wrestled over the pace of economic change, despite warnings it must move quickly to generate some of the 500,000 new jobs a year that the World Bank say are necessary to sustain real growth in the face of a population growing at 2.5 percent a year.
In the meantime, Egypt is vulnerable to domestic unrest. Half of the country is still illiterate; one in every three Egyptian workers lives off an average income of less than $25 a month, and housing remains woefully inadequate. More importantly, there are simply not enough jobs to absorb the 400,000 to 500,000 people who enter the work force each year.
 
Disappointing Example
 If Nasser's 1950's utopian vision of land reform, central planning and nationalization once provided the principal model of economic change for developing nations trying to shuck the remnants of colonial rule, Cairo's nearly two decades of dependence on Western economic assistance stands as an example of quite another sort. It shows the limits of even enormous, long-term financial intervention to achieve fundamental change within developing economies burdened by scarce resources, bloated public sectors and years of mismanagement.
The difficulty in achieving real and sustained economic change in Egypt raises questions for Washington and its Western allies, as they embark on aid and assistance programs intended to revive the moribund economies in the former republics of the Soviet Union, as well as the formerly Communist nations of Eastern Europe.
But in some ways, Egypt has posed difficulties that do not exist in the old Soviet bloc, where the move toward market economies has come abruptly, on the heels of political rebellion. Compared to those in Eastern Europe, Asia or Latin America, the transformation here has been drawn out.
In a recent analysis of the Egyptian economy, Rodney Wilson, a professor at Durham University in Britain, argued, "Egyptian state-sector managers are even more resistant to change than their counterparts in Eastern Europe, and they are highly skeptical about the gains which restructuring or privatization will bring."
 
Fears of Social Problems
 Part of the problem is political. Haunted by memories of widespread rioting that followed the Government's abrupt decision in 1977 to abolish many consumer subsidies, officials of the Mubarak Government are resisting changes that may pose any threat of further social dislocation.
While 17 nations have set up a $613 million fund to help alleviate the impact of privatization, the World Bank has estimated that the sale or liquidation of state-owned companies could more than double unemployment.
Last year, according to the United States Embassy, unemployment here was estimated at about 9 percent, although the number is probably closer to 20 percent because of Egypt's vast shadow subsistence economy of workers, peddlers, vendors and others who never show up in official data.
Partly because Egypt has been slow or reluctant to enforce the kinds of fundamental economic changes already under way in Eastern Europe, few people believe Cairo is prepared to be weaned from its outside cash lifeline, especially considering the continuing threat posed by Muslim militants and the instability in the Middle East.
"If the tubes were disconnected, the patient could die," Mr. Boutros-Ghali said. "We still need to know that we have the financial support, because it is, as much as anything else, a reflection of political support, too."
 
Remarkable Amount of Aid
 In Washington, some members of Congress have already questioned whether the Clinton Administration can afford to continue pouring billions of dollars in Egypt and Israel.
The amount of money funneled into Egypt has been remarkable. According to the United Nations, Cairo last year received more than 10 percent of the $45 billion in overseas assistance distributed among more than 150 nations.
Since 1975, American economic assistance to Cairo has totaled approximately $19 billion, most of it in the form of grants for local development, waste water projects, food aid and energy development. In addition, the United States has given Egypt $16 billion in military assistance since 1979, of which $7 billion consisted of loans that were written off in return for Egypt's help during the Persian Gulf war.
Persian Gulf nations also wrote off $6.2 billion worth of debt in 1991 and began to provide $2.3 billion in economic assistance. Over all, according to data from the United States Embassy, the gross official development assistance to Egypt jumped from $1.6 billion in 1989 to $5.4 billion in 1990 and nearly $5 billion in 1991..
 
Need for Private Investment
 But international bankers say the key to real growth in Egypt is increased private investment and the development of a substantial private sector. According to Mr. Wilson, foreign investment in Egypt since 1974 has totaled just $2.3 billion.
While manufacturing accounts for 16 percent of Egypt's gross domestic product, exports remain weak, and Cairo continues to carry a large trade deficit, aggravated by its continuing need to import some 42 percent of its annual food requirements.
Mohammed Farid Khamis, chairman of Oriental Weavers Group, an Egyptian rug and carpet manufacturer, is one of Egypt's most successful businessmen and a proponent of more Government measures to encourage private investment. His company's sales have grown to $200 million in 1992 from $1.5 million in 1979, with much of that growth coming from overseas.
"We employ 300 people in our factory," said Mr. Khamis, whose plant in the Tenth of Ramadan industrial city outside Cairo uses computer-assisted design and manufacturing processes. "If the public sector was running this company, there would probably be 3,000 employees here."
 
Dependence on Tourism
 Until now, economists say, Egypt has remained far too dependent on its service industries, which in turn means its annual revenue stream can vary widely, from year to year. Receipts from tourism, for example, one of Egypt's principal sources of hard currency earnings, have more than tripled over the last decade, according to the United States Embassy.
But this year, the tourist industry virtually collapsed as a result of fears among travelers about Islamic militants' violence in Egypt.
In addition to foreign aid receipts, tourism is one of the pillars that have anchored the economy since the mid-1970's. The others are Suez Canal revenues, oil exports and remittances from Egyptians working mostly in neighboring Arab countries.
According to current estimates, about 2.5 million Egyptians -- one in every seven people of working age -- leave Egypt to seek their fortune. Last year, according to the United States Embassy, they sent back a record $5.5 billion, taking advantage of high returns on Egyptian bank accounts.

HEADLINE: Congress Eliminates Aid for Production Of Honey and Wool

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Tenacious Federal subsidies for the wool and mohair industry have been cut by Congress.
The subsidies, created in 1954 when wool and mohair were considered strategic materials essential for military uniforms, cost the Government nearly $200 million a year. Cited as an example of Government waste by officials like Vice President Al Gore, the subsidies were given a death sentence by the Senate in July, only to be revived through the efforts of lawmakers from Texas, where many of the sheep and goat ranchers work. 
 In voice votes on Friday, the House and Senate agreed to phase out the subsidies over the next two years. The bill is intended to satisfy critics of the program while easing the economic blow to ranchers.
Congress also eliminated honey support payments, another program criticized as unnecessary.
 
75 Percent Subsidy in 1994
 Under the bill, ranchers will receive 75 percent of their expected subsidies for wool and mohair produced in 1994, half for the 1995 crop and none for 1996. During the two-year phase-out, they may qualify for Government loans so they can hold on to their wool and mohair if prices are too low.
Supporters of the subsidy said it was crucial to the survival of many wool and mohair ranchers. But opponents said the payments were a waste of money that often went to the well-off.
"I would prefer to have the taxpayer checks stop flowing sooner," said Senator Richard Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, who had led the Senate campaign against the subsidies along with Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts. But Mr. Bryan said he was pleased that the program had been killed, saving taxpayers $500 million over the next five years.
The agreement enabled the Senate to give President Clinton an overdue $71 billion spending bill for agricultural programs in the fiscal year 1994, which started Oct. 1.
