HEADLINE: Mechanic's Job: Keep Part of New York Culture From Disappearing

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
Armed with a welding torch and socket wrench, Raffaele Pepe is staving off the extinction of a cherished piece of New York culture: the lovable, lumbering Checker cab.
There are only 10 Checkers still on the road in New York City -- out of more than 11,000 yellow taxis -- and Mr. Pepe's auto shop in Astoria, Queens, is their port of call. The cabs now make up a fraction of his business. But having clocked an average of 500,000 miles each on the city's pockmarked streets, they are his biggest challenge. 
 Like a lifelong family doctor, Mr. Pepe, wearing a grease-splotched blue bandana over his head, knows which cabs had engine transplants, which struggle with rusting rears and which are due for a tuneup.
 
'He's the Checker Czar'
 While there are other mechanics in the area who occasionally service Checkers, Mr. Pepe is generally acknowledged to be the ultimate authority. "He's the Checker czar," said Bernard M. Higgins, publisher of Taxi Talk, a trade newspaper.
Donald E. McKinley, president of the 900-member Checker Car Club of America, said of Mr. Pepe: "He's the last of the old Checker craftsmen. On the East Coast, he's the man. He's it."
Spotting a Checker, which looks something like an overstuffed holiday bird, makes the heart of many city-dwellers beat faster. It conjures up images of a bygone New York, where Pennsylvania Station outshone Grand Central, where couples met under the clock at the Biltmore Hotel and the El rumbled above Third Avenue.
Riding in a Checker can be the day's highlight. With an ocean of leg room, two jaunty jump seats and a back seat that thrusts passengers high above the road, the rotund cab feels more like an airship than a car. It has appeared in frothy movies ("Breakfast at Tiffany's") and sinister ones ("Taxi Driver"). And so identified is the Checker with New York City that even characters in films set in the present have no trouble hailing one, as in the Manhattan scene at the climax of "Sleepless in Seattle."
But for the 56-year-old Mr. Pepe, Checker cabs have meant something different. They established him with a steady income when he came to New York in 1965 from the Italian town of Nusco, outside Naples. They secured him a home in Bayside, Queens, put four children through college and afforded him a country getaway in the form of a mobile home in Germantown, N.Y.
That is not to say he does not appreciate the Checker's singular attributes. "It's like stepping in a house," he said in an Italian accent as viscous as the motor oil that flows in his garage.
 
Makes Some of His Own Parts
 Upon arriving in America, he worked for a service center in Long Island City owned by the Checker Motors Company of Kalamazoo, Mich. The company churned out Checker cabs -- as well as an even larger, "civilian" model called the Marathon -- from the early 1920's until 1982. Production peaked in the 1960's but sagged in the early 1980's, forcing Checker Motors to stop making cars and to start making major assembly parts for Chrysler and General Motors.
In 1976, Mr. Pepe struck out on his own, opening Mira Auto Body Shop. "It was beautiful," he said wistfully. He had eight mechanics under him and serviced hundreds of Checkers. In the 1970's, when there were as many as 5,000 Checkers on New York City roads, Checkers accounted for 80 percent of Mr. Pepe's workload. Today, they account for less than 10 percent, and so he has reached out to the Checkers' sleeker descendants. Hurt by the recent recession, his operation has shrunk, down to three employees.
But on a recent day, Mr. Pepe's shop bustled. His son, Lou, a 25-year-old graduate of St. John's University who is not yet ready to "work behind a desk," drained a transmission contaminated by water. "It should look like rich red wine," his father said. "This looks like a strawberry shake." (Mr. Pepe should know since he makes his own red wine, some of which was used to wash down lunch.)
Toward the back of the garage, dismembered Checkers were stacked according to body part: curvaceous chrome bumpers, Kelly-green and yellow fenders, serpentine grills and a jumble of steering wheels, hoses and belts. Some parts are hard to come by, and Mr. Pepe has no choice but to make them himself.
Even though there are only 10 Checker cabs left on the road in New York, Mr. Pepe will sometimes see most of them in a single week. One recent week was typical.
 
International Reputation
 On a recent Saturday, Fritzgerald Cajuste brought in his 1981 Checker (800,000 miles) to have a spark plug replaced. Victor Acuna came by on Tuesday with a smashed rear after he and his 1980 Checker (715,000 miles) were sandwiched in a multi-car accident. Russell Neville and Earl Johnson both stopped by on Wednesday with their Checker cabs (500,000 miles each) to get a new power steering box and a new brake line, respectively. And on Thursday, Lou Di Maria pulled in with his 1980 Checker (752,000 miles) to have the oil changed and brakes checked.
"They've kept my car running for 13 years," said Mr. Di Maria, 59, who said he was retiring with his cab to South Carolina in two months. "Pepe makes it work, one way or the other."
Mr. Pepe's reputation extends internationally. A few years ago, a woman drove her Checker from Ontario, Canada, to his shop for a restoration, which included a hot-pink paint job. Recently, a man came from Jamaica -- the island, not the neighborhood -- in search of Checker parts.
Mr. Pepe's son, Lou, owns a Checker cab that is so souped up it rarely comes out from under its canvas cover in Mr. Pepe's shop. The car is painted a candied-apple red and boasts a 350-horsepower engine, four-barreled carburetor, sunroof, red leather seats, tinted windows, basket-spoked rims and, in place of a muffler, chrome side pipes. "Everyone thinks I'm crazy," Lou Pepe said, explaining that his peers lean toward the svelter Camaros and Corvettes.
Checker cabs should grace the streets of New York City for at least a few more years. Most likely, their disappearance will be due to their drivers' retirements, not their own deterioration. For a current owner, there is no age limit on a taxi as long it passes inspection every four months. "But if it's a new owner, the car can't be more than 24 months old," said Susan D. Feinstein, a spokeswoman for the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission.
Neither Lou Pepe nor his father seem too sentimental about the Checker cab's fate, however. Lou Pepe says he would sell his Checker tomorrow if the price were right. "What are you going to do?" asked his father. "They're a memory. Maybe it's better that way."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Checker cab, once a cherished piece of New York culture, is nearly extinct, with only 10 remaining on city roads. Raffaele Pepe, above, the "Checker czar," cares for them all at his auto shop in Astoria, Queens. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Shoplifting Arrest Leads to Discovery of Children Locked in Attic, Police Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 16

 BODY:
The two children a 15-year-old girl and her 11-year-old brother -- were caught in a local supermarket last Friday night stuffing bagels, bologna, crackers and candy into book bags and taken, terrified, to the Police Department on shoplifting charges.
"They were frantic, not so much that they were caught shoplifting but that I was going to return them home," Detective Frank C. Jones recalled today. "They were completely hysterical."
Under gentle questioning over the next hour or so, the two children told Detective Jones a story of living for months in isolation with two other children -- like them, in foster care -- in a cramped and often locked attic room with no furniture, no lights, no heat and little food. They pried open the bolt lock last Friday with a coat hanger and went out on their food foray because they were hungry, Detective Jones said. At the time, the couple raising them had gone out for a seafood dinner at a fast-food restaurant in Paramus, the detective said.
"The girl told us more or less they had to go out and steal to get an adequate amount of food," he said.
 
Two Others in Attic
 After the questioning, Detective Jones said he went to the two-story gray house on Howland Avenue and found a 16-year-old girl sleeping on a mattress on the floor in the pitch-black attic room and a 10-year-old boy in diapers asleep on the floor.
Several hours later, the couple, Anthony James, 36, and his wife, Shirley, 39, were arrested on charges of endangering the welfare of the four children. Subsequently they were released on $10,000 bail each after a hearing in State Superior Court. The four children have been placed in the care of New Jersey's Division of Youth and Family Services. They were examined at Englewood Hospital and not found to be suffering from any serious physical ailments, Detective Jones said.
The other two children in the house, a foster daughter, 12, and the Jameses' son, 8, had their own bedrooms, the detective said.
The Englewood Police Department's Youth Bureau has been trying to trace the four children's lives as foster children and learn why the Jameses had them stay in the attic.
 
Not Attending School
 He also said the four children had not attended school for months.
"They were imprisoned, more or less, in the attic," Detective Jones said today. They were allowed out for meals, which consisted of warm cereal in the morning, no lunch, and peanut butter sandwiches, with water, for dinner, he said. The youngsters told the detectives that they had to eat the food in the basement, not upstairs with the others. The two boys also said Mr. James hit them with belts and wires whenever they were caught taking food from the family refrigerator, the detective said.
Whenever the four had to go to the toilet, they had to knock on the locked door of the attic room to be released, the detective said. They were required to use the bathroom in the basement, not the one in the regular living quarters.
"They were more or less rationed out toilet tissue," the detective said.
For the most part, he said, the two boys were allowed out of the attic, aside from meals and toilet trips, only when the Jameses' 8-year-old son wanted to play with them outdoors.
No one answered the door today at the James house. They have no telephone listing.
 
Link to New York State
 A neighbor on Howland Avenue who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the couple, like many on the quiet residential street, kept to themselves. Occasionally, he said, he saw several children in the yard, cleaning it or sharing in barbecues. He said he believed Mrs. James was a Jehovah's Witness and took the children to worship on Sundays at the kingdom hall on Palisades Avenue, about a five-minute walk from their house. Officials at the kingdom hall said today that they knew the Jameses and were aware of the charges against them. But they declined to comment further.
Authorities said they believed the five foster children had been placed with the couple by social services officials in New York and that the Jameses received monthly subsidies of $500 for each, or a total annual stipend of $30,000. Detective Jones said Mr. James was unemployed.
Authorities, he said, were also investigating whether the couple had formally adopted the five children, possibly in New Jersey.
The Bergen County Prosecutor, John J. Fahy, said his staff was trying to learn why New York agencies paid the monthly maintenance stipends for the five children, but apparently did not monitor their living conditions.

HEADLINE: Seeking Help and Enthusiasm in His Home Base, Dinkins Returns to Black Churches

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins has gone home to the black churches in this campaign, wooing the pastors and congregants who have sometimes felt taken for granted by the man they helped elect as New York City's first black Mayor.
In folksy stump speeches and closed-door meetings with hundreds of ministers, Mr. Dinkins is working to convince black churchgoers that he has delivered for them on issues varying from health care to housing to the prevention of police brutality, and they are responding warmly. 
 "It's like you hear from a source that your girlfriend is moving away from you," explained Bill Lynch, the Mayor's campaign manager, "so you buy some flowers and get home earlier."
The enthusiasm of black churches, traditionally rich lodes of Democratic voters, is indispensible to the Mayor in a contest that is still too close to call. In 1989, Mr. Dinkins received about 500,000 black votes, more than half his total tally, and was separated from his opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, by fewer than 50,000 votes.
 
Taking for Granted
 Polls suggest that Mr. Dinkins has lost ground with white voters this year; he may be able to make up some of it with increased black support. But to get that support, he must overcome a perception among some black voters that he has taken their support for granted and failed to sufficiently deliver jobs and services to their neighborhoods.
The wooing of church leaders and their members is part of that push. The ministers are being counted on for a major 'get out the vote' push on Election Day, Nov. 2. In recent weeks, they have begun talking more frequently to their own congregations about the importance of this election, as well as giving Mr. Dinkins a platform to address their members without the filter of the news media, much as President Clinton uses 'town hall' meetings to bypass interviewers.
The normally staid, speech-reading Mayor has thrown away his notes and seems to be having a grand old time. He alternates funny stories about his childhood days with zestful digs at Mr. Giuliani, his Republican-Liberal opponent, and descriptions of how his programs have helped black communities.
At the Thessalonia Baptist Church in the Bronx, the Mayor took to the pulpit to speak to about 200 members of the women's auxiliary of the United Missionary Baptist Association. Afterwards, some of the women, dressed in white suits of satin and silk and white hats of all kinds -- pillboxes, berets, fedoras and derbies -- asked for his autograph and posed for snapshots with him.
 
Parable About Meaning
 When Mr. Dinkins told them that the city had opened primary health care centers in impoverished neighborhoods, he said indignantly, "For many people, the emergency room is the family doctor." The women chorused back: "Yes. That's right. Uh-huh."
He also told them a story that could be a parable for his own difficulties with the black churches. As a boy, he said, he and the other children had to memorize a Biblical quote for Sunday school. Parents, worried their children would forget the words, coached them to say, "Jesus wept."
"One Sunday morning a child got up and said, 'Christ cried,' " the Mayor said, as pews full of church women hooted with laughter. "But everyone knew what he meant."
Some ministers say their congregations have not always known what the Mayor meant. He should have spent more time in the churches, tending his home base and explaining actions of his administration, they said.
 
Waiting at Abyssinian
 The Rev. Calvin O. Butts, pastor of the 5,000-member Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, said the Mayor had stopped by a couple of times, but not for his Sunday services.
"I've offered him the opportunity to come to Abyssinian anytime except Easter and maybe Christmas," Mr. Butts said. "If he walked through the door at 11:15 A.M., I would give him the sermon. But he never came. He's been at St. John the Divine and synagogues and I'm saying, 'Gee whiz, maybe he'll take advantage of it closer to election time.' "
Nonetheless, Mr. Butts said he mentioned the Mayor's accomplishments every Sunday in his sermon. The minister said he believed that the Mayor was now "coming closer to his base." And indeed, Mr. Dinkins is scheduled to appear for Sunday services at Abyssinian on Oct. 24, nine days before the election.
Mr. Dinkins says he has not been ignoring the churches; he's just been busy.
"It's a big city with a lot of problems and constituencies," he said. "My experience is that if you go to a church at 110th Street, some will say you didn't get to 116th Street, and if you go to 116th Street they'll say you weren't at 125th Street."
 
Black Church Is Focal Point
 No one argues the importance of the constituency, however. The black church often has served as a focal point for communities confronted with racial discrimination and economic deprivation, and many black ministers wear several hats, not just as preachers, but also as social workers, neighborhood organizers and political advocates.
The campaign's clergy coordinator, Malcolm Smith, is quick to point out the help the Dinkins administration has given to community development groups formed from black churches to obtain government money for low-income housing and other social programs. He ticked off half a dozen such groups, including a corsortium of churches in Harlem that is involved in a huge effort to redevelop 40 blocks of Bradhurst Avenue.
"The Mayor has actually delivered something for the churches," said Phillip Thompson, an assistant professor of political science at Barnard College, who served as a housing official in the Dinkins administration.
That record has helped Mr. Dinkins attract the support of about 800 black ministers whose churches have over 500,000 members and who will be involved in what the campaign hopes is a big effort on Election Day, Mr. Smith said. The churches will try to muster thousands of volunteers to knock on doors, run phone banks and drive hundreds of church vans loaded with voters to the polls.
 
'Most Disciplined People'
 Mr. Dinkins knows how crucial the success of the churches' efforts is to his own. "The political clubs are not as strong as they once were in terms of bodies," he said recently. "The most disciplined people are trade unions and churches. They turn out in huge numbers."
And black turnout could be the difference between victory and defeat for Mr. Dinkins. "Where the polls are roughly tied, turnout is everything," Mr. Thompson said. "He could more than make up the slippage among white and Latino voters if black turnout is 70 percent. The black vote has room to grow and no one seems to be talking about that."
Political analysts and church leaders say the closeness of the race could spur black turnout, so the Dinkins campaign is trying to head off any signs of overconfidence. At a recent morning pep rally of 250 to 300 ministers, organized by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Rainbow Coalition, the campaign distributed copies of a newspaper article that said the Mayor's support from black voters had eroded and could dampen turnout. It was a warning against apathy.
Ministers say that the increasingly rancorous, racially polarized tone of the election is also energizing black voters. So is the sense that the Mayor, after a long summer of harsh media coverage, is under siege and must be defended.
 
Anger About the Media
 "There's a backlash," said Rev. Timothy Mitchell, pastor of the 500-member Ebenezer Baptist Church in Flushing, Queens. "The quiet, docile, nice, so-called older saints of the church -- the female leadership -- are calling us about what the media and Giuliani have done to Mayor Dinkins."
More than a dozen ministers also said in interviews that there was a growing realization among black people that whatever the Mayor's faults, they did not want Mr. Giuliani to win.
Over and over, ministers pointed to Mr. Giuliani's speech last year to rowdy off-duty police officers at a rally of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association that turned violent. They said it showed Mr. Giuliani's disrespect for Mr. Dinkins and highlighted his own prosecutorial, 'lock em up' approach. The officers were protesting the Mayor's proposal to create a civilian board to review complaints of police brutality -- an issue of special impact in black communities that have historically had strained relations with the police.
"Giuliani's campaign is a threat to the peace and tranquillity of this community," said Wyatt Tee Walker, pastor of the 2,300-member Canaan Baptist Church in Harlem.
 
Awakening a Giant
 The Giuliani campaign's television advertisements attacking the Rev. William A. Jones for associating the word fascism with Mr. Giuliani have also stirred anger.
"If I was the Giuliani campaign, I wouldn't be attacking Bill Jones," said Mr. Thompson, the Barnard professor. "They're not attacking one man; they're attacking a network, a tradition, an organized political base if it wants to be. Why awaken a giant?"
Mr. Jones, pastor of the 1,800-member Bethany Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, is a prominent religious leader revered by many other ministers for his lifelong battle against discrimination. They say Mr. Giuliani has intentionally misinterpreted Mr. Jones's remarks as an anti-Italian slur for political gain. Some do not mute their anger.
"He is in search of a black leader to attack so he can prove to the white community he is their hero -- the great white hope," said the Rev. Preston Washington, pastor of Memorial Baptist Church in Harlem, which has 350 members, and president of Harlem Churches for Community Improvement. "Dr. Jones meant exactly what he said."
 
Pastor's Special Status
 Mr. Dinkins's own ginger handling of Mr. Jones's remarks illustrated his own appreciation for the preacher's status. Mr. Jones's charge that "fascist elements" were flowering around Mr. Giuliani came as he stood beside Mr. Dinkins after a private meeting with 60 ministers. Mr. Dinkins, with no inflection in his voice, simply stated that Mr. Jones's choice of words was not his own. Later, he vigorously disavowed the remarks, but turned aside Mr. Giuliani's suggestion that the Mayor should have refused the support of Mr. Jones and the other pastors he spoke for that day.
"Those clergymen represent thousands of people who support my candidacy," the Mayor said several days after the incident. "Of course, he wishes I would disavow them."
Mr. Jones said of the Mayor: "He's not crazy. He doesn't want to alienate me because that would alienate a whole lot of people whom he really needs."

HEADLINE: New Jersey Is Bellwether To Politicians Across U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
He may fret about the daily developments in Port-au-Prince and Mogadishu, but President Clinton is also keeping a watchful eye on this capital city. "Usually, when I see the President the first thing he says is, 'How's my friend Jim doing?' " said Paul Begala, a White House adviser who is also a strategist for Gov. Jim Florio's re-election campaign in New Jersey.
Although Mr. Begala may have overstated the President's immersion in New Jersey politics, the outcome of the contest between Mr. Florio and Christine Todd Whitman, his Republican challenger, is being watched intently by Republican and Democratic politicians nationally. They are hoping to find signs of the viability of President Clinton's programs, as well as implications for statewide campaigns in 1994 and for Mr. Clinton himself in 1996. 
 While it is in part by default that the New Jersey race is drawing a disproportionate share of attention -- Virginia is the only other state with a gubernatorial election -- it is no accident that Mr. Clinton is so interested in what happens to Mr. Florio or that the national parties are pouring resources into the state.
The President's political position mirrors Mr. Florio's in important ways, the most obvious being the Governor's decision to ram a $2.8 billion tax increase through the State Legislature early in his term after promising in his campaign that there was no need to raise taxes. Likewise, after campaigning on a pledge of middle-class tax relief, Mr. Clinton drove a tax increase through Congress this summer as part of a deficit-reduction package.
 
Tax-and-Mend Politics
 Even as the political parties seek to spin the outcome to their own advantage, a legitimate case can be made that the New Jersey contest will not turn on Mr. Clinton, but on a simpler idea, like which candidate runs the better campaign. Some Republicans are already saying that missteps by the Whitman organization, not any national trends, may cost her the election.
No matter who wins in two weeks, the race has already produced an important political lesson that could be called tax-and-mend: Raising taxes and cutting services may, but does not always, mean political suicide. Polls taken in New Jersey show that the initial furor over Mr. Florio's tax increase has softened.
"I believe, all across the country, from the city council to the state house to the White House, people are looking at this race," Mr. Begala said. "If Florio wins, it says you can be tough and strong and decisive and still win. And if we lose, the do-nothing crowd will have won a victory."
From the rival camp, Edward J. Rollins, Mrs. Whitman's chief strategist, also sees national implications: as a test of the Republican Party's devotion to supply-side economics and, more specifically, his own candidate's proposal to cut the income taxes of most New Jersey residents by 30 percent. The race may also demonstrate whether, in this time of economic uncertainty, voters trust politicians who promise to cut taxes.
 
An Economic Battle
 "If Christie laying out her tax-cut economic plan can win, I think it will give courage to a lot of other people to try, particularly if she succeeds in implementing the policy and it brings the economy back," Mr. Rollins said. "Equally as important, if Florio comes back, it will encourage others who want to raise taxes that you can do it and make the tough decisions, perceived tough decisions, and fight your way back. And the lesson will be: go in early and raise taxes early."
Don Foley, executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said that among his crop of candidates next year he had already detected "a newfound boldness that allows political leaders to do or say what they think is right."
He said, for example, that Senator Chuck Robb of Virginia, who faces tough competition next year, was traveling Virginia praising Mr. Clinton. It is an obvious contrast to Mary Sue Terry, the Democratic candidate for Virginia governor, who has criticized the President and who has found herself in a tight race.
Though he has never wavered from his support for Mr. Clinton, Mr. Florio has been careful not to link his fortunes too closely to him either. And he resists the notion that a vote for or against him is a vote for or against Mr. Clinton. "I don't know if it's a national test, what the national significance is," he said in an interview. "I know I take the responsibility for the hard decisions that I make and have made in the past."
 
Like a Conservative
 A victory by Mr. Florio might also encourage other Democrats to follow his lead of running almost like a conservative by promoting such issues as fighting crime and getting tough on welfare cheats.
As Republican Governors like John Engler of Michigan and William F. Weld of Massachusetts have endorsed major tax cuts in their states, Mrs. Whitman has found herself in the difficult position of distancing herself from their contentious proposals while still insisting that cuts are a viable way to bolster the economy.
"I am not going to become a walking, talking Bill Weld," Mrs. Whitman said at a news conference here the other day, "or a walking, talking John Engler."
Politics, of course, is rooted in perceptions. So most politicians will only ascribe national import to a statewide race when it looks as if they will win.
So three months ago, when Republicans were so confident that they were practically picking their jobs in a Whitman cabinet, Haley Barbour, the national Republican Party chairman, pronounced the race a test of Mr. Clinton and the Democrats. "New Jersey is the prototype state for us," he said.
 
Reading Too Much In
 Now that Mr. Florio is showing more resilience than many political analysts expected, Mr. Barbour has tempered his spin, saying that "governors' races principally are decided by the candidates and the state issues."
Mindful of recent polls, perhaps, John Sears, a Republican political consultant in Washington, also warned against reading too much into the race, saying that voters were not embracing Mr. Florio but repudiating Mrs. Whitman. "I don't think his survival has any great national implications," he said. "She just didn't run a very good race, and she's going to lose."
But while the state has the demographics of a mini-America, the infighting that has plagued Mrs. Whitman's campaign cannot be viewed only through a New Jersey eye. Her difficulties may be a sign of what lies ahead as the Republicans seek to find the best response to the Democratic policies.
In a strategy that may be mimicked if Mr. Florio is re-elected, James Carville, an adviser both to Mr. Clinton and to Mr. Florio, said it was his idea to question not simply Mrs. Whitman's tax-cut pledge, but the credibility of the pledge itself.
 
'Doesn't Even Add Up'
 Mr. Carville said he contemplated two options for television advertisements attacking the Whitman tax cut: "You could have firemen say, 'They're going to cut fire'; you could have homeowners say, 'It's going to raise property taxes'; you could have schoolteachers say, 'It's going to devastate schools.' Or you could say, 'She's got no intention of doing this anyway; her plan doesn't even add up.' "

HEADLINE: On Sunday;
New Rimes For Mariners Not So Ancient

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
OUTSIDE on the water, the city shoreline was a stretch of updated Whitman: bridges and skyscrapers soaring hither and yon, jetliners and ferries coursing past fiery glints of trees that glowed autumnally in the ragged marshes of Queens to the south and the busy parks of Co-op City to the west. Inside the yacht club, Buddy Rice, a retired city firefighter, was having an early beer at the bar and chastising someone who asked him about sailing all his life out of City Island.
"That's a bad word, sailing," Mr. Rice said, friendly in the special way of City Islanders, with an outerborough tinniness of tone and a heartiness worthy of New England. 
 "Me, I like boating the way I like my car," he said, blessing the internal combustion engine as an improvement over canvas. "Boom! goes the ignition, and away I drive around the water."
It's hard to argue with any urban mariner, a breed apart who find an extra dimension in the waters that most New Yorkers ignore. City boaters can snooze nights at their moorings with one ear left open for the same sort of thieving predator who busts wing windows of cars parked overnight on city streets.
"Yeah, there's been a lot more breaking into boats lately," said Charlie Carman, a retired city police officer whose family roots on City Island go all the way back to the 17th century. "But the island stays pretty good. A woman can go out at night, and some people still leave their doors unlocked."
Mr. Carman is at the wheel of the service tender of the Morris Yacht and Beach Club, a seven-acre piece of the city with some history -- Diamond Jim Brady supposedly used its Victorian frame house as a romantic hideaway from Gotham's hectic heart. The membership has a base of officers, firefighters, sanitation workers, telephone workers and other blue-collar guys. Some do competitive sailing out on Long Island Sound on Wednesday evenings, replete with Topsider shoes and other paraphernalia.
Others sit with Buddy Rice, enjoying the camaraderie of the bar, or watch down on the lawn that offers a splendid view of the city, or work on their boats themselves. They help one another with the sanding and patching in a group effort required by the rules to maintain the tradition of a "working club," not heavy with rich members who can hire outside specialists.
The commodore, the club leader chosen by the members, is Jack Mahony, a mechanic with city sanitation, and the big problem is dwindling membership. It is down to 200 members from the normal 350 now that dues are up to $1,000 a year, five times what they used to be. This is because tax rates on the island began soaring in a reassessment sparked by some condominium construction elsewhere on the island, back before the recession hit. The club's taxes are up tenfold to $200,000 a year.
"The city is taxing the club into oblivion," said Wolfgang Ott, working on a beautiful, strange sailboat he built with a curved cement hull. "I'm a truck driver and love this, but I sacrifice for it," he said, gesturing about the boat yard. "We'll belly up eventually."
With the mayoral race narrowing and only a point or two between the candidates, who knows, maybe even urban sailors could become a focus group for the campaign strategists and taxes could return as a big issue. Older members recall when taxes were a hot issue, before race and crime took over the frenzied agenda.
"This is a very American place -- friction and joy together, if you know what I mean," said Ben Fernandez, a club member for 15 years who got his first taste of sailing as a Boy Scout from East Harlem. "On the water, you get a special view of the city and enjoy a different group of people," he said, sitting on the deck of his 30-foot sloop, Ben Siiri, up among autumn foliage at the back of the club's storage yard.
Mr. Fernandez was the club's first Puerto Rican commodore, but more mark him as the "committee commodore," a busy 57-year-old executive always prodding members to get more involved. He is a professional photographer and teacher known for his years of documenting the American protest movement and he is returning now from a Fulbright, looking to get his boat back into New York waters.
"We need boaters, new members," Mr. Fernandez said, staring at the urban seascape drenched in sun and taxes. "Club meetings can be chaotic but they are the essence of what freedom is about," he said appreciatively, envisioning more minority-group yachtsmen coming aboard, the club changing with the city.
He brought a Hispanic friend around for membership the other day. "It went well," Mr. Fernandez said. "One member told me, 'We old-timers have to change with the times if the club is going to make it.' I hope so," said the urban sailor, "because there's nothing so nice as to be on the mooring overnight, the city out there with the water rippling and wind blowing."

HEADLINE: Call That a 'Good' Job, Do You?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I laughed out loud after calculating the annual before-tax income of the holders of the so-called good jobs as described in " 'Good' Jobs in Hard Times" (Oct. 3). 
 A discount retail-store employee making $8 an hour, 35 hours a week, 52 weeks a year, plus a 6 percent profit share, makes $15,435 a year. (I would include an estimated value of the benefits described in the article, but you can't buy food with a health care plan.)
If your reporter had to support his family on $15,435 a year, would he consider himself lucky to have a "good" job? The reality is exploitation of desperate American workers by corporate America. These jobs may be better than nothing, but not by much.
 
MICHELLE C. BILLIES
New York City, Oct. 11

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1018 words

HEADLINE: The Mayoral Campaign -- At Issue: Fiscal Crisis;
Needed: Honesty on the Budget

 BODY:
Crushing budget deficits await the winner of New York City's mayoral election, because city spending will continue to grow faster than revenue until someone makes painful cutbacks -- or pushes through painful tax increases. The budget this year is $31 billion. Projected deficits in the next few years rise to $2 billion a year, not counting new or expanded programs. Band-Aids won't do.
Mayor David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani, his principal challenger, share an aversion to talking about cuts, so much so that neither says much about the need for radical surgery. The Mayor stands on his record -- four balanced budgets in four difficult recession years. Mr. Giuliani stands on a wishful platform of spending cuts and tax cuts. 
 Mayor Dinkins's budget record has less merit than he claims. Yes, it has been a difficult time to balance budgets. Adding to the city's constantly swelling needs, the recession has increased welfare caseloads and other costs of caring for the poor, while Republican Administrations in Washington have stinted on Federal aid.
How Mr. Dinkins will work out the current year remains to be seen. Both the spending and revenue numbers appear to be worse than he projected; he or his successor will have to make fixes before the fiscal year is out, because the books must balance. The State Constitution says so. And state law says if there's a deficit of more than $100 million, city officials must cede budget authority -- the heart of their power -- to the state's Financial Control Board.
The Dinkins administration has gotten by with a combination of spending cuts, a modest reduction in the city work force, tax increases and various one-time gimmicks, while still adding police and schoolteachers. But it did not score essential long-term gains. Most significantly, the Mayor failed to win concessions for greater productivity from city workers who benefit from antiquated work rules.
Last spring Mr. Dinkins commissioned a panel of three budget experts to tell him what must be done. But he gave them until Dec. 1 to report, thus postponing the bad news past Election Day. That was not fair to voters.
Actually, Mr. Dinkins has already proposed some sensible long-term measures -- in his budget messages. He just hasn't gotten them off the page and into practice. Some will doubtless reappear as recommendations from the panel.
One lively prospect for added revenue -- a perennial -- is tolls on the free bridges that link Manhattan with Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. Another is garbage and trash collection fees. Still other ideas would make the police more productive by staffing patrol cars with one officer instead of two in low crime areas and using more civilians for desk work.
These ideas aren't new. Are they more likely to be adopted now than before? Only if the person at the mayor's desk can persuade the objectors who block them that it's time to get serious.
One problem for any mayor is Albany's authority over what he wants to do. Mr. Dinkins wants the state to take over the city's $2 billion share of annual Medicaid costs, as most states do. So does Mr. Giuliani, and Gov. Mario Cuomo has proposed it to the Legislature. There it sits, because suburban and upstate legislators don't want to pay for New York City's poor.
Similarly, despite years of pleading by Mr. Dinkins and others before him, the Legislature refuses to adopt an equitable school aid formula; the current formula favors suburban school systems at the expense of their central cities.
For better or worse, Mr. Giuliani has no record as mayor -- or, for that matter, as an administrator. Thus untested, he can promise pie in the sky a la mode, and no one can prove he can't deliver.
His pledge to cut $2 billion of city taxes is in that category. He would like to phase out the commercial rent tax, the unincorporated business tax and the surtaxes on personal income, and reduce the hotel occupancy tax.
Who wouldn't?
But with annual $2 billion deficits already in store, his tax proposals would require unthinkable slash-and-burn spending cuts. These would be difficult anytime, because most city outlays are mandated by Albany or Washington, and more difficult now because some cuttable programs have already been reduced by the Dinkins administration.
City services must be improved, not curtailed. The streets are unsafe; bridges need repair; schools need better teachers and smaller classes. Even so Mr. Giuliani wants less spending. His promises ring hollow. He doesn't say how he'd clear away bureaucratic roadblocks, union contracts or Albany's opposition.
Mr. Giuliani says he would eliminate 35,000 city jobs in six years. The payroll is now 211,000. It would be reduced by 15 percent, back to where it was in the early 1980's when go-go spending was just beginning. He doesn't say where he would cut, though -- only that he'd try to spare programs that have already taken heavy hits. More realistically, Mr. Dinkins anticipates trimming 8,000 jobs in the next three years, in addition to 15,000 he has cut so far. Both men say they will rely on attrition, which is no guarantee of anything.
Mr. Giuliani also says he can get savings that Mayor Dinkins has been unable to get from increased productivity of city employees. But how much better he would do against strong unions that can paralyze the city with strikes or slowdowns is problematic.
Mr. Giuliani talks about more privatization, too -- turning more city functions, even hospitals, over to private contractors. Within limits, that can make sense, but responsive service to the public must be paramount. Mr. Giuliani would also shut down some city agencies whose functions duplicate state agencies, such as consumer affairs, mental health and human rights. That's a good idea, but hard to get past entrenched bureaucrats, and not a big saver.
Both mayoral candidates owe New York's voters fuller explanation of how they would pack all their promises into the city's diminished resources. If they ever hold the debate they are so strenuously ducking, that would be a good first topic.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

An asterisk indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.
 
ACROSS THE BRIDGE: Stories, by Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $19.) In these 11 lucid urban stories, most of which are set in Paris or Montreal, Mrs. Gallant's wit and exactitude subvert the antiquity of her material.
 
THE CULTURE OF DISBELIEF: How American Law and Politics Trivialize Religious Devotion, by Stephen L. Carter. (Basic Books, $25.) A professor of law at Yale examines what he calls a 20-year-old tendency to ban religion from public discourse, and argues that a just balance of mutually respectful forces should be restored.
 
THE DEBATE ON THE CONSTITUTION: Federalist and Antifederalist Speeches, Articles, and Letters During the Struggle Over Ratification, edited by Bernard Bailyn. (Library of America, 2 vols., $70.) Proof that our founding document came by debate, not divine revelation; we owe much to its opponents, who were no fools.
 
THE ENDANGERED AMERICAN DREAM: How to Stop the United States From Becoming a Third World Country and How to Win the Geo-Economic Struggle for Industrial Supremacy, by Edward N. Luttwak. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) A plea, or more accurately a demand, for an economic diplomacy red in tooth and claw.
 
THE GIRL WHO TROD ON A LOAF, by Kathryn Davis. (Knopf, $23.) A heated, dramatic novel narrated by Francie, an underachieving composer who finds redemption by completing an inherited unfinished opera.
 
THE HOLDER OF THE WORLD, by Bharati Mukherjee. (Knopf, $22.) A woman of today celebrates the life of a woman who lived three centuries ago and across two cultures in this brilliantly conceived and executed novel.
 
LIFE WORK, by Donald Hall. (Beacon, $15.) Donald Hall, a poet and writer who has done many things well and who now, at 65, faces a mortal illness, tells us what he thinks matters about himself in this sort-of-autobiography.
 
THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM: Stories, by Francine Prose. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $20.) Eleven stories, smartly observed and deftly written, present the weird jungle of modern life through the eyes of a wry and mordant writer.
 
TRAVELS WITH LIZBETH, by Lars Eighner. (St. Martin's, $19.95.) A writer who until very recently made homelessness his full-time job has found a strikingly unconventional voice and form to deal with life as the literate don't normally live it.
 
THE WARBURGS: The Twentieth-Century Odyssey of a Remarkable Jewish Family, by Ron Chernow. (Random House, $30.) Mr. Chernow's vast Warburg saga follows the fates of a rich, thoroughly secularized German Jewish family betrayed by the nation and culture they loved.
 
WORKERS: An Archaeology of the Industrial Age, by Sebastiao Salgado. (Aperture, $100.) Pictures by a Brazilian photojournalist of the labors of humanity around the world, especially where hands and backs still do the work; many are beautiful, many appalling, many both.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
An Appeal To Shoppers Is Rewarded

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Adriana's Bazaar, an international cooking store on Broadway between 75th and 76th Streets, has been struggling to survive ever since Rochelle Zabarkes opened it two and a half years ago.
The store, big and airy behind a high teal awning, sells condiments, pottery and spices from around the world, like lemon grass, curries and dried peppers. 
 But the recession stacked the decks against the store, a 1,200-square-foot space in an expensive area.
Ten days ago Adriana's filed for Chapter 11 protection. Ms. Zabarkes still owes several months' rent to the landlord as well as money to other creditors.
But the fight goes on, in the form of a large black-and-gold sign in the window that reads: "Dear Neighbors, if you love us and want us to stay, BUY SOMETHING NOW. (We need an angel or 40,000 little angels.)" And the angels have appeared.
"If we lose our neighborhood stores, we have no neighborhood," said Lisa Picolini, a frequent customer, as she entered the store recently.
Sales have doubled since the sign went up two weeks ago, Ms. Zabarkes said.
"Even without the financial support," she said, "just knowing the neighborhood really cared about us was enough incentive to keep going." E.M.B.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

From Medical Supplies To Hollywood Films
 
How does the owner of a medical supply company in Bensonhurst get involved in the movie business? For Julius Nasso, it began when he landed a job translating Italian for the making of the film "Once Upon a Time in America" in his neighborhood. That led him to think about entering the movie business, and when he was visiting Japan, he arranged to meet Steven Seagal, a distant relative. That led the businessman and the actor to form a company, Seagal-Nasso Productions. 
 The new company shares an office building with Mr. Nasso's other business, Universal Marine Medical Supply. Seagal-Nasso has a deal with Warner Brothers to produce five movies.
 
 
 
A New Community Bank With an Irish Twist
 Manhattan is about to get a new community bank. Peter Hooper, the former president of the Bank of Ireland's New York operations, is setting up a bank catering to Irish and Irish-American depositors.
Mr. Hooper resigned as president when the Bank of Ireland left the retail business in March, and he is negotiating to take with him the bank's $60 million in retail deposits. His partner in the enterprise is Dennis Kelleher, chief executive officer of Wall Street Investor Services, a financial products distributor.
 
 
 
A Toy Store Reopens With New German Wares
 Toy Park, an Upper East Side toy store that closed last summer for remodeling, is back in business. Its new look includes a star-speckled purple carpet and new walls (though the space within the 86th Street store is no larger, it has been rearranged to make room for additional stock, including Gotz dolls and Ravensburger puzzles and games, both from Germany).
 
 
 
Helping Artists Market Their Works
 The Queens Council on the Arts and the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts will sponsor a workshop for artists Saturday on how to show and market their work. Topics will include the development of resumes, and there will be critiques of the participants' exhibitions and slides.
 The workshop will be conducted by a painter, an art critic and the director of Arts Initiatives, a nonprofit arts organization, and will take place in the Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard, from noon to 4 P.M. For information and registration, (718) 463-7700.
 
 
 
Workshops for Women With a Global View
 The New York office of the American Woman's Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization for business women, is conducting a series of workshops for women interested in employment overseas. "How Can I Do International Market Research on a Shoestring" is the topic of Tuesday's free brown-bag session. On Oct. 27, a lawyer and a banker will discuss the writing of letters of credit for international banking, and the Nov. 30 workshop will deal with the financing of export businesses. Fees for the second two workshops are $50, $40 for members. All will be held at the organization's office at Suite 320, 71 Vanderbilt Avenue, between 45th and 46th Streets. For registration, (212) 692-9100.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROCKAWAY;
Bringing Much-Needed Sand to a Storm-Battered Beach

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

 BODY:
Over the last year, erosion worsened by storms has devastated much of the Rockaways shoreline. But with the Army Corps of Engineers expected to approve a $46 million, 10-year restoration plan, repairs may begin early next year.
"It's really a question of the sooner the better," said Joseph Vietri, a planner in the Army Corps of Engineers district office in Manhattan. "We have about 50,000 people living on an island that has been decimated by a series of storms over the last few years, and this project will in essence give the people a measure of protection against the effect of storm damages." 
 The project calls for the replenishment of a 6.2-mile shoreline between Beach 19th and Beach 149th Streets on the Rockaway Peninsula.
About 6.4 million cubic yards of sand would be pumped onto the beach, and additional sand will be laid twice in the next 10 years.
The New York office of the Corps of Engineers recommended the plan after the Corps' 1994 budget had been submitted to Congress, so Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat whose district includes the Rockaways, persuaded a House subcommittee to add $3.2 million to the budget so the work could begin early next summer.
"The beaches are the lifeblood of the Rockaways," Mr. Schumer said. "If they go, so does the economic viability of the whole peninsula, and that's why it's so important to get the Federal Government doing everything they can to fix the beaches."
The Government will pay 65 percent -- $30 million -- of the cost, and the state and city are to split the rest. The work can begin as soon as the State Legislature appropriates the state's share.
"We are in a low-lying area," said Jonathan L. Gaska, district manager of Community Board 14 in Queens. "The beaches are the only thing that's stopping the water." GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROCKAWAY UPDATE;
City Planners Take New Tack On Giant Project: Think Small

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

 BODY:
It stretches for nearly two miles along the oceanfront, block after block of weed-filled, trash-strewn lots, occasionally interrupted by a cluster of buildings. It is the Arverne urban-renewal area in the Rockaways, for a quarter-century the site of a repeatedly thwarted effort to build a "new town" of homes, parks and shopping centers.
The Arverne project suffered its latest blow two years ago when the developer of the most recent plan for the site, Oceanview Associates of Manhattan, pulled out, citing a poor economy in which to market the kind of vast development it was contemplating: a $1.5 billion complex of 7,500 apartments priced to sell or rent to families with annual incomes of $45,000 to $80,000. Stores, movie theaters and a refurbished boardwalk and beach were also part of the package. 
 Previous obstacles to construction on the site had included the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, sharp cutbacks in Federal housing subsidies and local opposition to various schemes.
The result was that although nearly 4,000 deteriorated buildings were demolished in the late 1960's, very little of the envisioned new housing was built to replace them, and the area became one of America's most notorious examples of redevelopment gone nowhere.
But the Dinkins administration insists that the Arverne project is not a nightmare of failure but a dream deferred.
"The project is still alive," Valerie Jo Bradley, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development, said last week.
"We're working on a phasing plan," she said, referring to what other officials have described as a future "series of discrete, smaller projects by separate developers within the urban-renewal area, rather than proceeding with a single master developer."
Kathleen Dunn, the agency's deputy commissioner for development, said that two companies -- Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut and Vollmer Associates -- have been retained as engineering and planning consultants to help determine such issues as where in the vast renewal tract the first such project should go and how much housing to "put out on the market" as part of that phase.
Ms. Dunn could not say how long it might be before the city could move to the next stage -- requesting yet another round of proposals from potential developers in an area where schemes have come and gone like the nearby tides. JOSEPH P. FRIED

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Recreating a Classic Era for a New Generation of Strivers

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
In its heyday, central Harlem drew people from around the world to small, smoky clubs where they could hear the greatest jazz musicians of their day. Now an ambitious development program seeks to recreate that era by bringing new restaurants and clubs to the area around 135th Street.
If the planners win the necessary approvals, the project, called Strivers Center after historic Striver's Row a few blocks north, will mix of middle- and moderate-income housing and upscale businesses, particularly boutiques, and restaurants and jazz clubs. It will stretch from 134th to 136th Street and from Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard to St. Nicholas Avenue, and be financed by public and private loans and city and state grants. 
 Organizers from the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, the project's liaison with the community, the city and the state, said they hoped to make the area a magnet for tourists, as well as for middle-income Harlem residents who, they say, often spend their money downtown.
The first phase, which was finished last month, includes eight five-story brick and stone buildings. Forty-eight units have been filled, and about 12,000 square feet of commercial space is now being completed. The Chamber of Commerce plans to move its office to the block, and there will be a new restaurant, a florist and several social-service-agency offices, said Emmett Causey, the chamber's project director for the center.
Next month, the chamber is to begin construction on $3 million in improvements for 135th Street, including wider sidewalks and new benches and lights. There are plans to add a plaza in St. Nicholas Park behind the subway station at 135th Street, and a new, straight, well-lighted path through the park to link Central Harlem with City College.
The streetscape project will also include a "walk of fame" along the sidewalk of 135th Street, paying tribute to famous residents with tiles made by neighborhood artists.
The second phase of Strivers Center is now in the planning stage. It calls for the renovation of 15 buildings for rental apartments and commercial space, and some major corporations have already begun negotiating for that space, Mr. Causey said. A third phase will offer new condominium apartments.
Strivers Center is financed by a loan from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit coalition of banks and insurance companies. The street improvement money is from the State Economic Development Corporation. E.M.B.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Loan Program Aims at Asians

BYLINE: By VIVIAN LOUIE

 BODY:
A loan program for small businesses on the Lower East Side and in Chinatown has been set up to help Asian owners turn to banks, rather than personal and community resources, for financial needs.
This month, two nonprofit groups, Asian Americans for Equality and Manhattan Neighborhood Renaissance, began administering $175,000 in loans for the State Urban Development Corporation. The loans will benefit minority- and female-owned businesses in lower Manhattan, many run by Asian immigrants. 
 The program is meant to encourage borrowing from banks, according to Christopher Kui, executive director of Asian Americans for Equality and president of Manhattan Neighborhood Renaissance. The fund is intended to provide small-business loans of $15,000 to $20,000.
"The goal of our program is that in 5 to 10 years, the bank takes on these customers," he said.
Mr. Kui, a 33-year-old immigrant from Hong Kong, said that Asian business owners are often reluctant to approach banks because they are used to relying on savings, family loans or borrowing clubs, which pool the resources of dozens of people.
But because those options generally provide only $10,000 to $50,000, they do not help business owners with more costly plans.
The loan program is a continuation of Mr. Kui's efforts to negotiate language barriers and demystify the intricacies of American finance for Asian business owners.
The two groups he runs hold seminars, help owners with business plans and often go with them to banks to get loans.
The population of Chinatown has grown from 41,174 in 1980 to 55,216 in 1990, according to census figures, and many new small businesses have begun, Mr. Kui said. Last year, Mr. Kui was able to help Ellen Chiang get a line of credit after several banks turned her down.
Ms. Chiang and her partner Estrella Chan had started Prestige Care, a Manhattan-based home care service for the Chinese elderly, with a bank loan, money from relatives and from a borrowing club. But they needed more to keep the business going.
Mr. Kui arranged a meeting with officials at Merchants Bank of New York. Its Broadway branch approved a $200,000 line of credit.
"They are doing very well," said Spencer Witty, the chairman. "It was good for the community and good for the bank." VIVIAN LOUIE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA/CLINTON;
At Last, Maybe, a New Beginning

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
City officials have agreed to begin talks with Community Board 4 on the long-stalled development of what is known as the Clinton Urban Renewal Area, a six-block section of tenements west of midtown Manhattan.
Some 2,000 people live or work in buildings on month-to-month leases in this rundown stretch (from 50th to 56th Streets between 10th and 11th Avenues), which was designated for renewal in 1969, nearly a quarter century ago. 
 But economic uncertainties and disagreements between the community and the city over how to develop the area delayed the project virtually from the start.
John Glynn, executive director of the Clinton Preservation Local Development Corporation, a community group, said dozens of buildings were razed and seven apartment buildings constructed with Federal funds. Then the money ran out. Most people moved out of the condemned area, leaving buildings prey to vandals and weather.
In the early 1980's, the Koch administration, seeking to turn Clinton into an area of luxury residential development, offered two blocks on 10th Avenue to developers. The neighborhood group blocked this plan, stopping the demolition of five buildings.
In 1984, the group came up with a rehabilitation plan of its own; it called for retaining most residences and commercial and manufacturing structures and building a set of residential towers in which 80 percent of the units would be designated as low- or moderate-income housing. The goal was to keep small businesses as well as the many artists who make their home in Clinton.
Although the plan was backed by Community Board 4 and won the Urban Design Award of Architectural Digest in 1990, nothing happened. The City Department of Housing Preservation and Development said the proposal was impractical and too costly.
The debate heated up after the demolition last summer of a vacant tenement on 10th Avenue at 52d Street that had been slotted to be restored under the community plan. Residents urged the city to shore up other crumbling buildings until renewal work could start. Then, on Oct. 5, Housing Preservation and Development officials told Community Board 4 that they were willing to consider the board's proposals for Clinton renewal.
"If our space is taken, we can't stay in the city," said Linda Colby, an artist who lives in a threatened building, explaining the need for adoption of the 1984 plan. "Hasn't the city lost enough art?"
Tony Parker, vice president of Brabrook, a flooring manufacturer established in 1927, said: "We won't leave the area. We have an investment to keep the neighborhood intact." MARVINE HOWE

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
South Street Seaport: Just Another Mall?

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
CAPTAIN HOOK'S has a smidgen of everything: a ship in a bottle goes for $9.99. Some wooden ship models fetch in excess of $2,000. A fish scale marketed as a nail file is one way to spend 59 cents. Resembling nothing so much as a dusty, cluttered attic, this old-salt emporium in South Street Seaport is fighting for its life.
Captain Hook's monthly rent has been increased from $2,000 to $19,780.62, and its owner, a lifelong maritime hobbyist turned mall merchant named Joe Hill, is hopping mad, fuming that he can't pay nearly that much. Moreover, he insists that he shouldn't. He is suing the Rouse Company, developer of South Street Seaport Marketplace, claiming that his eviction would violate Rouse's promise to maintain a maritime flavor. 
 "There's a man-eating shark in our midst and the citizenry must be warned," says Mr. Hill. "A shopping mall monster is trying to devour our city's history."
Now, to some people around the seaport, Mr. Hill is at least eccentric. After all, this is a man who habitually wears a pirate hat and a whale tooth around his neck. To others, he is simply going too far. They note that he used to charge customers a quarter just to browse, and they explode at the mere mention of the terms of that $2,000 lease (a relic of his status as an original, indeed the last original, tenant of the market).
Still, if Captain Hook's fails, there will be only two solely maritime shops left at the old seaport. And as the Marketplace turns 10, some admittedly less apocalyptic versions of Mr. Hill's harangue are being heard along the cobblestones of South Street.
Even as it has become one of the city's major tourist attractions, some people are wondering, has Rouse's Marketplace failed in its mission to preserve its original reason for being, the 19th-century character of the city's historic seaport hard by the Brooklyn Bridge? Has it, in short, become just another high-rent shopping mall?
This marriage of seaport and marketplace, history and commerce, was conceived as a way of supporting the South Street Seaport Museum, a museum without walls, set up in 1967, whose holdings range from the four-masted bark Peking to Titanic Memorial Tower on Pearl and Water Streets. The relationship, though, has never really found its way off the rocks.
Part of the problem has been the museum's inability to center itself in a single location. Because of overly optimistic sales projections and the recession, Rouse has never been able to pay more than the minimum required to keep the museum going.
"It didn't work," said Peter Neill, president of the museum. As a result, the institution's exhibits have remained scattered around the seaport, though the city has begun paying some of the museum's expenses and will soon unveil plans to house part of the collection in a 60,000-square-foot space along Schermerhorn Row.
To help maintain the area's character, another strategy was devised: lower rents for original tenants, like Captain Hook's $2,000 a month. But most of them, a half-dozen or so, have gone out of business (Sweets restaurant, established in 1842, closed last December). They have been replaced by upscale newcomers like Country Road Australia, with its stylish wear from Down Under, and Structure, which sells men's sportswear. Last month, Liz Claiborne opened its first New York City store, a sleek two-story space in the seaport, joining other chain stores like Ann Taylor and Coach Leatherware.
Some community advocates and history buffs say that the seaport's character is threatened. They say the shopping-mall ambiance shows a lack of regard for its history and inattention to its cultural potential. "They don't protect the place the way they should," said Anne Compoccia, chairwoman of the local community board. "They're just looking for money." She and other Rouse detractors would have emphasized the museum and antique buildings as the principal attractions.
Others find it an unusual, and sufficiently maritime, attraction. "A mall in New Jersey is the same as a mall in Los Angeles," said Blades Williamson, an investment banker from Wall Street eating lunch recently at the Yankee Clipper, in the seaport historic area. "But a mall where you can see the Statue of Liberty is different."
Joseph E. Ochs, a Rouse vice president and Seaport Marketplace manager, defends Rouse's commitment to maritime promotions and merchandising. "Guess what? His 10 years are up," he said about Captain Hook's lease. Added Glen Wielgus, the marketplace's marketing director: "Our intent is to preserve the integrity and feeling of 19th-century New York. But our audience is very much part of the 20th century."
In many people's minds, the seaport, one of New York's top five attractions, remains a warm-weather tourist destination. But with annual sales exceeding $100 million, it is rivaled as a downtown shopping center only by the World Financial Center. Data that the seaport distributes to prospective tenants is impressive. The average visitor, with a household income of $56,392, spends two hours at the seaport. Downtown workers visit three times a month; city residents visit six times a year.
The scene shifts with the time of day and the day of the week. Wall Street workers congregate at lunchtime, brightly attired day-trippers dominate on weekends, and on Friday nights, the seaport becomes one vast, rambunctious singles bar -- though less so than in previous years.
But like malls everywhere, the seaport has had problems. The original flagship, the blocklong Fulton Market Building, waned after the glitzier Pier 17 opened in 1985. People walk right by on their way to the water; many long-time businesses say they are struggling. "The sales don't warrant us staying there," said Fred Bass, owner of the Strand Book Store. He may close.
But Rouse is actively recruiting. It recently attracted Ferrara Foods from Little Italy, which now sells espresso at the Fulton Market Building. Officials have also talked to movie studios about opening the kind of super entertainment store that Time-Warner will soon open at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street.
Mr. Neill is unenthusiastic. "A Disney-like experience in the South Street Seaport would be a travesty, both culturally and commercially," he said. His distaste for a miniature golf course, a temporary attraction in the Fulton Market Building, is apparent. "That's the level of trivialization that concerns me," he said. "It ain't maritime, is it?"
Meanwhile, Mr. Hill at Captain Hook's lectures customers about his plight and fights to stay on the terms of his original lease. Never mind, he says, that he owns a $2 million house in Sands Point, L.I., and vacations for four months a year in Florida. It is the principle that matters.
"If I go," he says, "the flavor of the Seaport will be completely lost."
