HEADLINE: Will U.S. Be Healthier? Maybe Not, Experts Say

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Suppose President Clinton's health plan is adopted. Suppose every American gets a health insurance card and no one need worry again about being uninsured. Will the nation be healthier?
The answer might seem obvious. After all, 37 million Americans are uninsured. How could the plan do anything but improve the overall health of the country? 
 Oddly, medical and public health experts say that although the system may increase access to health care and although it may be more equitable than the current system, it will not necessarily make Americans healthier, at least by the broad measures generally used to gauge public health.
The problem, health experts say, is that the proposal for overhauling health care is not really a health program. Instead, it is a plan to pay for doctor visits, prescriptions and hospitalizations. It is a plan to insure that no one is bankrupted by medical bills. But sickness and death are often caused by poverty and dangerous habits like smoking, which will not necessarily be affected. Many people who disregard advice to have children vaccinated or to have a Pap smear or exercise or eat less fat or drink less alcohol will not change their ways because they have health insurance.
To be sure, President Clinton has always promoted the plan as what it is: a way to address gross inequities in health care and to get medical costs under control. In his address to the nation on Sept. 23, he said the urgent priority was "giving every American health security, health care that can never be taken away."
 
Benefits for Many People
 And many people are expected to gain enormous benefits. For example, Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, said: "Uninsured people now think twice before they go to a doctor for a headache or even a lump in the breast. Every contact is so, so expensive."
And Dr. Alan Garber, an internist and a health economist at Stanford University, said some people who are now uninsured would undoubtedly benefit from the plan. Others said that poor people now receiving spotty care on Medicaid might do better with a family doctor in a health plan.
But "you have to ask how much difference the health care system can make," Dr. Garber said.
Dr. Reinhardt noted that the Clinton plan was a financial security plan. In fact, it is called a health security plan. Instead of promising good health outright, the American Health Security Act promises that all Americans will have health insurance, with access to plans that meet national standards on benefits, quality and access to care.
"That is very important," Dr. Reinhardt added. "But if you want to make them healthy, get them out of poverty."
One problem in trying to decide how the health plan will affect the nation's health is deciding how to measure health. Public health officials often look at two measures, infant mortality and life expectancy. Neither statistic is likely to be altered perceptibly by the Clinton health plan, experts say.
Infant mortality is highest in the inner cities, where pregnant women often suffer from more than lack of health insurance and where they often have Medicaid. They may be teen-agers, they may smoke heavily, or use cocaine or heroin, and they may have a very poor diet.
Dr. Reinhardt noted that in Britain women had prenatal care through the national health service for more than 30 years. Yet, he said, infant mortality among people in the lower social classes is still triple the rate among people in the higher classes.
Dr. Garber said infant mortality was particularly troubling because "it is heavily influenced by factors outside the medical care system."
Nor is longevity likely to change, experts said. Dr. James W. Vaupel, a medical demographer at Duke University and Odenske University Medical School in Denmark, said there was little relationship between a nation's health care delivery system and its average life span. The United States has an average life span of 75 years, a figure comparable to that of European countries, where health care is readily available to all. But it is also comparable to China and Costa Rica, poor countries where "the level of care is very very low," Dr. Vaupel said. "There may not be a lot of connection between the quality or level of care and life expectancy."
"Medical care sometimes saves our lives," Dr. Vaupel said. "But the main purpose of medical care is to help us get over an acute illness." And that, he said, does not measurably change a nation's average life expectancy.
"Even if you saved 100,000 lives, it wouldn't show up in the life expectancy figures," Dr. Reinhardt said. "If you write down the equations, you realize what unbelievably dramatic changes have to happen" for life expectancy to budge.
So, Dr. Reinhardt said, "if you want to judge health reform by measurable health status indicators, you'll be sorely disappointed."
While the Clinton plan's focus on preventive medicine is generally a good thing, Dr. Garber said, "we shouldn't be surprised if the effects are small" -- even in looking at specific diseases.
One reason is that many people are already receiving preventive care, like vaccines for their children, screening to detect diseases early or blood pressure checks, even if they have to pay for it themselves. So for a noticeable difference to occur, there would have to be a substantial change in the health of those who would suddenly have health insurance.
 
Hard Populations to Reach
 But many people who do not get such care are among the most difficult to reach. They often are poor and poorly educated. Dr. Robert Blendon, a professor of health policy at the Harvard School of Public Health, said: "If you remove the financial barrier, some will come in, but not all. Another group comes in after an educational effort." As for the third group, the most recalcitrant, "you literally have to send the vans out to get them," he said.
A second reason that gains will be limited is that doctors have only a limited arsenal of preventive and early detection measures. These include childhood vaccinations, screening for high blood pressure, Pap smears and mammograms. Many conditions cannot be prevented: most cancer, birth defects, many cases of heart attacks. Others could be partly alleviated by changes in personal habits, like stopping smoking or eating a low-fat diet.
A decade ago, the Rand Corporation conducted a huge study of free medical care, including preventive services.The only improvements the study found were among the poor people in the group: more of them got glasses and their blood pressure levels were slightly decreased. The study, which involved 3,958 people, aged 14 to 61, concluded that "free health care did not improve health status." It also said the people who received free medical care visited doctors more often, spent more time in the hospital and perceived themselves as sicker than those who had to pay.
And in places that stress preventive services, like Hawaii, very few people take advantage of them. "Whenever we offer preventive services, like mammograms or Pap smears or cholesterol screening," said Robert Mytinger, who is vice president for community relations at the Hawaii Medical Services Association, "we never get more than 25 percent of the eligible population."
 
Little Interest in Checkups
 Dr. Mytinger added that about half the insurer's subscribers, or 300,000 people, participate in a program called Healthpass that aggressively encourages the use of preventive services. Each subscriber is invited on his birthday to come in for a general checkup and counseling on his health and how to reduce his risk of disease. But, Mr. Mytinger said, no more than 8 percent of them do.
Of course, Dr. Blendon said, there are aspects of health care that are not captured by health statistics but that do improve people's lives. "Medical care will affect pain and disability, but when you talk of mortality or life expectancy, that doesn't show up," he said. "My mother is convinced that if she has her cataract out, she's healthier. But that won't affect her life expectancy."
In fact, national surveys repeatedly showed that people did not become healthier because they went to doctors. "You go to a doctor when you're born, when you have babies, when you get really sick, and just before you die," said Dr. Donald Patrick, a professor of health services at the University of Washington in Seattle. "Otherwise, if you're lucky, you stay out of the medical system."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A chart last Sunday with the heading "Health Care: Clinton's Plan and the Alternatives," misstated aspects of the proposal by Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington. His plan would impose a payroll tax on individuals as well as employers, and would require individuals to pay "sin taxes." The measure's health security board would also have the authority to revise benefits; it would not be able to establish them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Uwe Reinhardt, of Princeton University, sees the Clinton plan as a financial security plan. If healthier people are the goal, he adds, "get them out of poverty." (Princeton University) (pg. 22)
 
Chart: "Health Care: Clinton's Plan and the Alternatives"
 
COVERAGE
A: McDermott (Single Payer): All legal residents would have access to a standard medical benefits package, administered by the states, with the government paying the bills. Covers all medically necessary procedures. Excludes costs of private hospital rooms and cosmetic surgery.
B: Clinton: All legal residents would be required to be insured, choosing among at least three plans providing a standard benefits package:a Health Maintenance Organization, fee for service or a combination plan. Plans would be administered by large corporate employers or by regional purchasing alliances.
C: Chafee: Individuals would be required to obtain insurance for a standard benefits package. Employers would be required to offer it. Individuals could also buy insurance through purchasing alliances. Vouchers to subsidize the poor would become available as the system produced savings.
D. Cooper-Grandy: Purchasing cooperatives would reduce insurance cost and make it more affordable. The federal government would pay insurance premiums for individuals below the poverty level, and subsidize them for people up to twice the poverty level.
E. Gramm: Employers would be required to offer workers at least three choices, including their existing health insurance arrangements, membership in an HMO or other provider and a tax-free savings account to cover medical expenses that exceed $3,000 in a year.
F. Michel: Employers would be required to offer workers at least one insurance plan and a tax-free Medical Savings account. Insurance companies that sell to small employers would be required to offer both kinds.. Expansion of Community and Migrant Health care centers would expand access to health care.
 
Benefits
A. McDermott (Single payer). Complete payment for doctors' and hospital bills, prescription drugs, mental health care, substance abuse and other "medically necessary" treatment.
B. Clinton. Complete coverage of doctors' and hospital bills and prescription drugs. Limited coverage for mental health and substance abuse. Prescription drug and limited long-term care added to current Medicare benefits.
C. Chafee. Complete coverage of doctors' and hospital bills, prescription drugs, substance abuse, limited mental health coverage. Customers could choose a catastrophic plan instead.
D. Cooper. To be set by a National Health Board.
E. Gramm. Unspecified.
F. Michel. To be established by National Association of Insurnace Commissioners.
 
Payments
A. McDermott (Single payer). Substantial payroll taxes would be imposed on employers, replacing insurance payments most employers now pay. Individuals would pay nothing.
B. Clinton. Employers would have to pay 80 percent of the cost of the average insurance plan, but not more than of 7.9 percent of payroll. Subsidies for small, low-wage employers. Individuals would pay up to 20 percent of premiums. Subsidies for the poor. Co-payments, deductibles and $3,000 family limit in fee-for-service plants. None for preventive care. Would bar penalties for pre-existing conditions.
C. Chafee. No employer payments required. No controls on premium payments. Benefits commission could set standards for co-payments and deductibles, subject to Congressional approval. Would limit higher insurance rates for those with pre-exisiting conditions.
D. Cooper-Grandy. No employer payments required. No controls of premium payments, co-payments or deductibles, except no deductibles or co-payments allowed for preventive care. Would prohibit cancellations and higher payments for pre-existing conditions.
E. Gramm. No employer payments required. No control of premim payments, co-payments or deductibles. Would limit and subsidize higher, rates for those with pre-existing conditions, except those caused by individual behavior like smoking.
F. Michel. No employer payments required. No control of premium payments, co-payments and deductibles. Would limit higher insurance rates for those with pre-existing condistions.
 
MAJOR ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROVISIONS
A. McDermott (Single payer): Being developed.
B. Clinton: New taxes of $105 billion on tobacco and on large corporate employers that stay out of regional purchasing alliances. Reductions of $238 billion in anticipated growth of Medicare and Medicaid between 1995 and 2000.
C. Chafee: Cuts $213 billion in growth of Medicare and Medicaid between 1995 and 2000. Limits tax deductibility of generous employer-paid insurance plans. Allows self-employed to deduct full cost of standard health insurance.
D. Cooper: Would raise $16 billion by preventing employers from deducting costs of insurance beyond the cost of basic plans and $6.5 billion in slowing Medicare increases. Allows self-employed to deduct full cost of standard health insurance.
E. Gramm: Slow Medicaid growth by $113 billion and Medicare growth by $62 billion between 1994 and 1998; gain $16 billion in additional taxes because of lower business expenses. Allows self-employed to deduct health insurance costs up to the national average.
F. Michel: Saves $17 billion by reducing Medicare subsidies, and altering federal retirement rules.
 
ADDITIONAL COST CONTAINMENT: All plans would save by standardizing medical claim forms.
1. McDermott (Single payer). Would establishes annual national health budgets. National Health Board sets standards for pricing all covered services.
2. Clinton. National Health Board establishes national and regional budgets. Insurance premium increases will be limited by the National Health Board.
3. Chafee: Expects competition to produce savings.
4. Cooper: Expects competition to produce savings.
5. Gramm: Expects competition to produce savings.
6. Michel: Expects competition and preemption of state rules on basic coverage to produce savings.
 
MALPRACTICE REFORM
1. McDermott (Single payer). None.
2. Clinton. Plans would have to establish mediation or arbitration systems as alternatives to going to court. If a claimant is dissatisfied, he or she must get a certificate that the claim has merit from independent physicians before going to court. Limit lawyer's fees to 33 1/3 percent of awards, which is the current practice.
3. Chafee: Requires mediation, then alternative dispute resolution. If case is appealed to the courts, loser pays winner's costs and lawyer's fees. "Pain and suffering" damages limited to $250,000. Limit lawyer's fees to 20 percent of award.
4. Cooper: Would require alternative dispute resolution initially. If decision is appealed to court, the loser pays the winner's costs and attroney's fees. "Pain and suffering" damages limited to $250,000. Lawyer's fees limited to 25 percent of first $150,000, and 10 percent of remainder of award.
5. Gramm: Would require loser in court to pay the winner's costs and attorney's fees. "Pain and suffering" damages limited to $250,000. Lawyer's fees limited to 25 percent of awards.
6. Michel: Would require alternative dispute resolution initially. If decision is appealed to court, the loser pays the winner's costs and lawyer's fees. "Pain and suffering" damages limited to $250,000. Would limit lawyer's fees to 20 percent of of award.
 
ADMINISTRATION
1. McDermott (Single payer): Benefits would be established by an American Health Security Board, which would also set pricing standards. The states would provide and structure their individual plans for providng service.
2. Clinton: A national commission could revise benefits. It would have to establish budgets and approve operations of regional and corporate insurance purchasing alliances. The alliances contract with health plans, distribute information to consumers and collect premiums. Corporate alliances allowed for employers of 5,000 or more.
3. Chafee. A national commission would set benefits. States would be required to establish health insurance purchasing cooperatives for small businesses, size to be determined, and individuals. There could be more than one in a geographic area, and they could operate across state lines. Multi-state employer plans would be regulated by the Department of Health and Human Services.
4. Cooper. A national health board would establish benefits. States would create Health Plan Purchasing Cooperatives, excluding large employers, size to be determined, would make insurance available at reduced cost to small business.
5. Gramm: None.
6. Michel: States could establish voluntary insurance purchasing cooperatives. (pg. 22)

HEADLINE: Unmasking Roots of Washington Heights Violence;
Residents Point to Overcrowding, Distrust of Police, Poverty and Thriving Drug Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
After last summer's disturbances, a firebombing that injured two firefighters and the recent killing of a housing police officer, Moises Perez has a blunt reply to those who wonder just what is happening in Washington Heights.
"You think they're getting the message?" said Mr. Perez, the executive director of Alianza Dominicana, a social service group in Washington Heights. "They can't ignore us anymore. We need people to come here with real responses to these problems." 
 Although Mr. Perez and others active in the teeming upper Manhattan community roundly condemned the violence, they emphasized that it was symptomatic of long-simmering problems like overcrowded schools and apartments, distrust of the police, high unemployment and overburdened social service groups like his own.
 
Youths Idle on Street Corners
 The potential for conflict increases when coupled with another factor: a thriving drug trade. Washington Heights, after all, is set amid a narrow stretch of land whose easily accessible highways and bridges make it a natural locale for selling drugs, which offers the promise of quick money to youths who find themselves idle on street corners day after day.
From the narrow streets clogged with double-parked cars outside buildings where some families double and triple up in cramped apartments, to the sun-drenched avenues thick with street peddlers, the area is one of the most densely populated in the city.
"You just have people stacked on top of people," said the Rev. Earl Kooperkamp, assistant minister at the Church of the Intercession at Broadway and West 155th Street. "Those kinds of things lead to a deterioration in the quality of life and lead to the kind of irrational acts and violent acts that we have been seeing."
Although the police have been the targets of violence in other neighborhoods, in Washington Heights the tensions seem more pronounced due to a variety of factors: intense crowding, a traditional distrust toward the police among some immigrants and a sizable drug trade that puts the police constantly on guard.
At the same time, the overcrowding distorts the public's perception of crime, said Deputy Inspector Joseph Esposito, the commanding officer of the 34th Precinct, which in recent months has cultivated better relations with the community. He said while the area had always had a high homicide rate, the number of killings was actually down this year.
"If you compare us per capita to the rest of the city, we're probably well to the middle of the pack," he said. "Everything seems so dense because of the population, the perception appears to be more serious than it actually is."
According to the 1990 Census, 146,416 people, 40 percent of them Dominican, inhabited the heart of Washington Heights, which stretches from 155th to 190th Streets between the Hudson and Harlem Rivers. But community leaders say the larger area, reaching north to Inwood and south into Manhattanville, packs some 300,000 people -- a fifth of them under 18 years old -- into a three-square-mile area.
These leaders note the actual number of Dominicans may be higher than officially reported, when illegal immigrants and others not counted in the census are considered.
 
Poverty Sets Stage For High Crime Rate
 According to the City Planning Department, Dominicans represented the city's largest group of new immigrants last year, with their numbers growing 20 percent faster than in previous years, and many of them have settled in Washington Heights.
Yet in an area where nearly one in three people lives under the poverty line, and by some estimates one out of every five Dominicans is unemployed, advocates said services like job training, education and family assistance have been stretched thin, setting the stage for problems like crime.
"I hope that the message is clear," Mr. Perez said. "Something needs to happen in this community. Young people need to be supported and families need to be helped and reinforced. Unfortunately, in the United States we function under a crisis mode, which means that we only deal with issues once it's at the crisis level."
Each morning, Amaurice Bautista leaves the apartment he shares with another family to hawk batteries, umbrellas and trinkets alongside the vendors who sell food, cassettes and T-shirts in the swirling sidewalk bazaar on St. Nicholas Avenue and 181st Street. The unlicensed peddler sometimes ends his day with little to show for his day's work, especially when the police sweep through and confiscate his goods.
"This is a very hard place to make a living," he said one recent afternoon as he swiftly gathered his goods before a police car passed by. "Every day the economy gets worse and people sometimes feel there is no way to get ahead."
Some trace the social and economic problems in the community back to the 1970's, when large numbers of Dominican immigrants began arriving. It was a time when the city's economy was hurting and the factory jobs that once provided economic opportunity for new immigrants began disappearing.
Rafael Lantigua, a doctor who is active in Dominican social and political issues, said many families had yet to establish themselves economically, while others were hampered by language.
"Most of the community is hard working, and came to establish themselves and help this nation and city," Dr. Lantigua said. "But unfortunately, due to dramatic urban changes in the United States in the last decade, we have not been allowed to reach those dreams."
 
Dreams of Better Life For Their Children
 Gina Martinez and her husband, Ramon, have placed their dreams with their three children, for whom they scrimp and save to come up with tuition to send them to parochial school. They do not want to take their chances with the public schools, which they feel are too crowded and impersonal.
In the Dominican Republic, Mrs. Martinez was an executive secretary and her husband a lawyer, but now he works as a maintenance worker and she takes odd jobs as a housekeeper and baby sitter while taking courses toward a college degree in education.
"My husband says it's been very hard to come here and work as a laborer when you've been a lawyer all your life," she said.
Nevertheless, their efforts are born of a simple desire. "We are sacrificing ourselves for our children," Mrs. Martinez explained.
Others have had a tougher time. Julio Lora, a teen-ager, remembers his years at an overcrowded public junior high school, where he says substitute teachers did little more than baby-sit. When he entered high school, he was a year behind in math.
"There were too many kids," he said. "Sometimes it's too crowded to get a normal education. I mean, sometimes kids get lost and there aren't enough teachers to get them back on track."
Maria Luna, the chairwoman of Community Board 12 in upper Manhattan, noted that youths had often been at the center of the various disturbances that have rocked Washington Heights. Part of the problem, she said, is a high dropout rate and a lack of vocational training that do not give many a chance at competing in the job market.
While five new schools are being built and there are some youth programs in the area, most notably a beacon school program at I.S. 143, Ms. Luna says more are needed.
"We have a subculture of young people who hang out on the street because there is nothing for them to do," she said.
Yvonee Stennett, assistant to the director of the Community League of West 159th Street, said that cutbacks had limited the efforts of groups like hers that have after-school and other youth programs.
"We often tell them to get off the corner," she said. "But we don't tell them where to go."
Some teen-agers end up drifting into the drug trade, lured by the elusive promise of a fast fortune that more often than not results in shortened lives and broken families.
Msgr. Gerald T. Walsh, the pastor of Incarnation Roman Catholic Church, said that while only a small percentage of the area's residents are involved in the drug trade, these people are responsible for much of the trouble in the area.
 
Youth Suspicious And Defiant of Police
 Compounding the problem among the youth is a defiance and suspicion toward the police that has been evident in past confrontations. Rolando Acosta, first deputy commissioner at the Commission on Human Rights, said some of that suspicion could be traced to a troubled relationship between citizens and the authorities back in the Dominican Republic.
"We come from a society where the police are viewed as one of the institutions that are there to oppress us and prevent us from engaging in the democratic process," he said. "Parents say to their children, 'Be careful with the police.' They have this folklore about what the police do with people."
Some young people insist the police do not respect them and are prejudiced against Dominicans. Robin Soriano, 18, said that after Officer John Williamson was killed on Oct. 8 by a bucket thrown from a roof, he and his friends were brought in for questioning and badgered by the police. A few days later, he said, he watched police officers laugh as they drove away after confiscating the goods of an unlicensed street vendor.
"There are policemen who shouldn't be policemen because of the way they treat you," Mr. Soriano said.
But others fault the families of these youths for their behavior. Rosario Bruno, 45, a single mother of three who is enrolled in a clerical skills course in Washington Heights, said she reared her children to be respectful of teachers and the police.
"How you raise your children has a lot to do with it," she said. "But there are women who either do not have the time, inclination or ability to correct their children."
Respect, she said, starts from within.
"If you respect the authorities, they will respect you," she said.
Since last summer's disturbances, elected officials and community leaders have been working to increase that respect, with the police becoming more active in reaching out to residents with programs aimed at young people and forums where residents meet their local beat cop.
"The 34th Precinct has been making an incredible effort to reach out to the community," Mr. Acosta said. "That kind of interaction is necessary. People see with their own eyes that the police are not what they've been led to believe."
In fact, a few days before Officer Williamson was killed, City Councilman Guillermo Linares helped sponsor a meeting with officers involved in the community policing program and 500 Washington Heights residents. The officers, he said, helped people to understand how they could report information to the police without fearing for their safety, and encouraged a continuing dialogue and partnership.
"The officers don't feel alone and they are welcome, respected and appreciated for what they do, as is the community," Mr. Linares said. "It is then the community that challenges anyone that dares violate the community itself."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
Toronto

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH; CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH is Toronto bureau chief of The Times.

 BODY:
Walt Whitman, visiting Toronto in 1880, called the city "a lively, dashing place." In 1993, it is infinitely more so, pulsing with theaters, jazz and comedy clubs, restaurants and flea markets. Unesco recently counted more than 100 languages and dialects spoken here. One-third of the city's residents identify a language other than English or French as their mother tongue.
Chinese, Greeks, Portuguese, Ukrainians, Russians, Koreans, Indians and West Indians all have their own neighborhoods. In fact, there are three Chinatowns, reflecting different periods of immigration, starting with last century's railroad builders. 
 The liveliest places are where the nationalities spill into one another, such as on Bloor Street West, between Spadina Avenue and Bathurst Street. Haider Khan, born in Simla, India, in the foothills of the Himalayas, and raised in Karachi, Pakistan, runs the newly renovated Rajput Dining Room at 388 Bloor Street West, named after a princely Hindu caste famous for its cuisine. Lebanese, Hungarian, Russian, Korean, Italian, Mexican and Chinese restaurants are all within a stone's throw of Rajput.
Despite the proximity of so many peoples, ethnic strife is almost nonexistent, and crime is relatively low.
Public transportation is swift and moderately priced ($1 a ride if you buy five tokens, $1.50 if you buy only one, calculated at 75 United States cents to the Canadian dollar).
 
Events
 With its 44 theaters and more than 26,000 seats, Toronto is the most important theater city in the English-speaking world after New York and London. In a stunning display of optimism, nearly a fifth of the seats were added this year by Canada's largest impresarios, Garth Drabinsky and the father-son team of Ed and David Mirvish.
The biggest event of the fall season is the scheduled opening today of the North York Performing Arts Center, 5040 Yonge Street, which is about a 20-minute subway ride from downtown Union Station (take the Yonge Street Line to the North York stop). The center has three theaters (3,132 seats in all), including one with treelike pillars merging with a gold-domed ceiling and another modeled after the Concertgebouw in Amsterdam. Together with a 5,000-square-foot art gallery, they make the arts complex, the first to be built in Canada since the 1960's, one of the largest in North America.
The 1,850-seat Main Stage Theater, which has the treelike pillars, is now the home of the musical "Show Boat," directed by Harold Prince, which opened for previews this month. Tickets range from $38 to $62. The 1,032-seat Recital Hall, modeled after the Concertgebouw, has scheduled Itzhak Perlman, Kathleen Battle, Yo-Yo Ma, James Galway and Alicia de Larrocha, among others, for its inaugural season, which begins Nov. 23. Tickets are $14 to $70. Call (416) 872-2222 for tickets to "Show Boat" and the Recital Hall.
The Mirvishes' 2,000-seat Princess of Wales Theater in downtown Toronto, at 300 King Street West, (416) 872-1212 or (800) 461-3333, opened in May with an indefinite run of "Miss Saigon." Rollicking murals painted by Frank Stella grace the walls of this new theater. Tickets are $19 to $68.
The performing arts calendar includes plentiful helpings of opera, ballet and symphonic music. The Canadian Opera Company will present "The Marriage of Figaro" from Nov. 4 to 28 and "The Magic Flute" from Nov. 12 to Dec. 5 at the Elgin Theater, 189 Yonge Street, (416) 872-5555. Tickets range from $19 to $65.
The National Ballet of Canada will offer "The Taming of the Shrew," "The Rite of Spring" and "La Sylphide" in November at the O'Keefe Center, 1 Front Street East, (416) 872-2262. Tickets cost $10.50 to $52. Sixty to 90 minutes before the curtain goes up at designated performances, the audience can hear talks by artists about what happens on stage and behind the scenes. For further information, call (416) 362-1041. The cost is $5.
The Toronto Symphony, in addition to its regular programming, began a new series called Casual Concerts this month -- 75 minutes without intermission, with introductions of the program from the podium and the orchestra in casual attire. Musicians will stay afterward to talk with the audience. The next of the season's four Casual Concerts, to include works by Ravel and Stravinsky, is scheduled for Nov. 27. The concerts are at Roy Thomson Hall, 60 Simcoe Street, (416) 593-4828. Tickets are $14 to $34.50.
 
Sightseeing
 Possibly encouraged by the Blue Jays' performance this season, visitors can explore the titanic $450 million Skydome, the domed stadium completed in 1989 at 1 Blue Jays Way, smack in the downtown center (the subway stop is Union Station). The 40,000-seat stadium features a retractable roof, sensing devices that monitor internal movement and a huge Jumbotron video screen. Daily walking tours are given from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Visitors can see the field the way the players do, step into the dugouts, tramp through the media center and see some of the building's inner workings. The tours take an hour, including a 15-minute film; they are not given when daytime events are scheduled. Tours are $6; $4 for children and the elderly; (416) 341-2770.
After a $44 million facelift, the Art Gallery of Ontario, at 317 Dundas Street West (the St. Patrick stop on the University Subway Line), (416) 977-0414, is well worth a visit. Its 16,000 works cover the last 600 years of human creative endeavor and are tastefully presented. Besides clusters of Dutch, English, French, Impressionist, Surrealist and other paintings, the gallery boasts the largest public collection of Henry Moores in the world and one of the world's most important assemblages of Inuit art. Admission: $5.50; $3 for students and the elderly, and free on Wednesdays after 5 P.M. The gallery is open Wednesday and Friday 10 A.M. to 10 P.M. and Thursday, Saturday and Sunday 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.
The Canadian novelist Margaret Atwood observed several years ago that Toronto was becoming a literary city on the model of London. A Writer's Map of Toronto ($3.75 from Colombo & Company, 42 Dell Park Avenue, Toronto, Ontario, M6B 2T6, Canada) is a handy guide to places of literary interest. The Russian-American novelist Vladimir Nabokov hunted butterflies in Queen's Park, home of the Ontario provincial government. And the Ontario Parliament buildings were the inspiration for the red stone buildings in one of John Updike's stories in "Bech Is Back."
 
Where to Eeat
 Toronto is an excellent city for dining out. One of the more exciting restaurants, Joso's, is set among interior design businesses at 202 Davenport Road, (416) 925-1903. The owner is from the Dalmatian coast of the former Yugoslavia, and the seafood is Mediterranean. Among the specialties are risotto nero, made with cuttlefish and its ink, and octopus steamed with garlic, capers and olive oil. Dinner for two, with a modest wine, is $65 to $75.
More than 4,000 people a day eat at Marche, a new restaurant of the Swiss Movenpick chain, at B.C.E. Place, 42 Yonge Street, (416) 366-8986. Diners line up at stalls where the food is prepared, pick out what they want, and watch it being made. Toronto represents a trial run for this concept. Among diners' choices are rosti, which are Swiss hash browns, and a daily pasta. Dinner for two, with wine, is less than $30.
For those who wish to enjoy Toronto's spectacular skyline in elegant surroundings, and eat well besides, there is the Roof Restaurant on the 18th floor of one of two towers at the Park Plaza Hotel, 4 Avenue Road, (416) 924-5471. The view to the south is of the CN Tower and Lake Ontario; specialties include lobster and truffle ravioli and seared chicken breast with spicy goat cheese. With a modest wine, dinner for two is $60 to $75.
Brownes Bistro at 4 Woodlawn Avenue East, (416) 924-8132, near the Summerhill subway stop is a friendly neighborhood restaurant run by a former cooking teacher from Wellington, New Zealand, named Beverley Burge. Some of the best dishes have a New Zealand signature; lamb shank stew or lamb sausage with mashed potatoes are especially good for cold winter nights. With a modest wine, dinner for two is $50.
Peter's Chungking Restaurant, at 281 College Street East, (416) 928-2936, specializes in Sichuan, Mandarin and Hunan dishes like spiced chicken with garlic-peanut sauce ($4.85) and Sichuan shredded beef ($6). Dinner for two, with beer, can cost less than $25.
For dim sum in Chinatown there is the Chiu Yuen restaurant at 2A Kensington Avenue, (416) 598-1573, on the outskirts of the Kensington Market. It is open seven days a week from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. Fried yam spring rolls and shredded taro bean curd rolls are among the specialties. A large meal for two costs about $12, without drinks.
Another wholesome, inexpensive place is the vegetarian Capers Cafe at 372 Bloor Street West, (416) 323-9955, where the fare includes a vegetable stew and ratatouille served with brown rice. Dinner for two, with a modest wine, costs well under $25.
 
Where to Stay
 Adjacent to the Skydome is the Skydome Hotel, at 1 Blue Jays Way; (416) 360-7100 or (800) 441-1414, fax (416) 341-5026. The hotel has 346 rooms, of which 70 overlook the field. The four-year-old hotel has a gymnasium and squash courts. A double room is $100 to $160 until Oct. 31. From Nov. 1 to Dec. 31 they will drop to $85 to $128.
The Westin Harbour Castle, 1 Harbour Square, is on Lake Ontario and only a 10-minute walk to Union Station. All of its 980 rooms have at least a partial lake view. There is a revolving restaurant on the 37th floor and a tennis court on a fifth-floor deck. Until Oct. 31, a standard double room is $104 to $140. A promotional rate of $75, including a $22 food and beverage credit, for a double is sometimes available. In November, the rates for a double are to drop to $75 to $112. Call (416) 869-1600 or (800) 228-3000; fax (416) 361-7448.
Near theaters and Eaton Center, Toronto's biggest indoor shopping mall, is the largest hotel in Canada, the Delta Chelsea Inn at 33 Gerrard Street West, (800) 243-5732 or fax (416) 585-4302, with 1,586 rooms. On the 27th floor are a swimming pool and an exercise room overlooking Bay Street. Double rooms are $72 to $82.50.
Budget: Also near Eaton Center and theaters, at 65 Dundas Street East, is the 286-room Bond Place Hotel, newly renovated with warm pastel colors, (800) 268-9390; fax (416) 360-6406. A double is $52.
The Downtown Toronto Association of Bed and Breakfast Guest Houses, (416) 690-1724, fax (416) 690-5730, offers accommodations in private homes. Doubles are $37.50 to $56. Post Office Box 190, Station B, Toronto, Ontario, M5T 2W1, Canada.
Luxury: The Four Seasons Hotel, at 21 Avenue Road, (416) 964-0411 or (800) 332-3442, fax (416) 964-2301, in the chic Yorkville section, is near boutiques, art galleries and bistros. There are 380 rooms. A standard double is $185 to $230.
We have been looking through proofs of his fall catalogue featuring the model Kristen McMenamy, whose cropped hair and big features are anything but classic. Lagerfeld did the photography, as he does for most of his catalogue and ad material, preferring to keep his vision out of the hands of star photographers, stylists and Madison Avenue types. He says he doesn't need a translator:
"I am the most informed person I know. I like magazines, newspapers, books. I can read in German, French, Italian, English."
In casting his net wide, with a network of what he laughingly calls sociocultural "spies," from Gutfreund to the Chanel phone operators, he hopes to avoid the gilded-cage atrophy that has stunted much of traditional couture.
"I have the feeling that a lot of designers only want the lives of the clients," he says. "MY LADIES. That's very demode. If you do only what you think will flatter her taste, soon your lady will go somewhere else. You have to force people to break with things."
Like offering his ladies rap styles with four-figure price tags?
Lagerfeld smiles. "Look, the subculture is here," he says, pointing to one side of a piece of paper. "Here is the very high established look. And we have to be walking the edge of both of them. This is the secret of couture and expensive ready-to-wear. On the edge. You have to show the people that the world is changing. Because nothing is worse for a woman than having the feeling that she is dated."
He may eschew the worship of tradition but he does not dismiss the impact of his metier on history. "How can you imagine the 20's without the short dress, the 18th century without the corset? No, I think fashion is not just stupid. Millions of people live from it, in it. And it is, as a short note, the most typical expression of a moment."
It has grown very late. Once the last taille has swished down the corridor, only Susan Gutfreund remains. Ask which of the $30,000 visions we've seen are selling and Lagerfeld insists it's the edgier stuff, rather than the "old stiff couture dresses," which he's still obliged to make in small numbers.
"What are we doing still making such things?" The couturier laughs. "Are we all QUITE MAD?"
 
'WHAT'S A SUPERMODEL?'
Shimmering in the heat, ringing with the sounds of the Icelandic rocker Bjork, a limousine is shooting west, toward a spectacular desert sunset. It bears a weary Cindy Crawford, MTV producer Alisa Bellettini, plus hair and makeup stylists. We are headed back to Los Angeles after a day's shoot in Two Bunches Palms, during which a game Crawford wore Alaia and Calvin Klein, stood in hot springs and on a sizzling 110-degree mesa until she nailed her lines.
"It's O.K., honey," Bellettini assured her talent. "A little sweat is very 'Thelma and Louise.' "
Crawford works hard for the money. And, honey, she is always working; men in suits are still lining up to toss money at Cindy Crawford for being the stunner no one's afraid to talk to. Bellettini, who created "House of Style" four years ago, says she fought the network's desire to use a v-jay for the host.
"I wanted a model and I wanted her to be famous," she says. "Because I knew that if I didn't get good ratings, it would be easy to cancel . . . a fashion show."
Crawford was well known at the time, but not so much as now, since she's married a famous actor and been on TV. She thinks that supermodeldom, like the pouf, was very much a creation of the 80's. Recently she had a talk with Lauren Hutton, who, in 1973, became the highest paid model in history when she signed with Revlon. As they compared notes, Crawford realized that "even with inflation, they weren't making the kind of money we make now. And the power."
The swimsuit calendars. Exercise videos. Crawford does Pepsi ads, has a reported $2 million Revlon contract. Much of it came to her back in those limo gridlock days when Nancy Reagan was accepting all those couture "gifts" and the Donald and Ivana were still a fun couple.
"That was a very special time, the Christy-Cindy-Linda-Naomi group of girls," Crawford says. "I don't know if it's going to happen again soon, because I don't know if that necessarily was a good thing for the business."
Nonetheless, she has little patience for the product managers, designers and ad directors moaning about the size of the models' checks. "They made us really important," she says. "Then they didn't like it when we became more important than the clothes."
Now that everyone's sobered up, now that they've had to trade in their car-jackable Range Rovers for less-enticing Accords, she's noticed that their attitudes have changed. She figures that modeling fees and their attendant media fuss might get more "minimal," just like the clothes.
"What's a SUPERMODEL? I always feel like I'm going into a phone booth to change."
The sun has gone down behind the tinted windows, the two-hour drive is nearly over and, as she has quite often this long day, Crawford is telling a Richard story. Seems they were at a dinner party when another well-known beauty entered. Gere leaned over to his wife and whispered, "You know, you're still the most beautiful woman in this room."
Crawford is smiling, declares that, of course, she loves him for saying it, whether it was true or not. But oh, men. Husbands. Boyfriends. Photographers. And Designers. Yes, them too. They can't always catch up to where Beauty has gone, can't help being so retro in the sweetest of nothings.
"Don't they get it yet?" she says. "They just don't seem to understand. We don't need to hear that anymore."

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Oct. 17, with the What's Doing column about Toronto, misstated average temperatures for October. The average high is 56 degrees, the average low is 40 and rainfall averages 11 days; the figures given were for September.
An article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about the role of fashion in society reversed the names of the art director of Club Monaco, a Canadian clothing manufacturer. He is Douglas Lloyd.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 17, 1993

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 980 words

HEADLINE: No One Communes Anymore

BYLINE: By Charles E. Little; Charles E. Little's most recent book is "Hope for the Land," a collection of essays about conservation of land and community.

 BODY:

SEX, ECONOMY, FREEDOM AND COMMUNITY
Eight Essays.
By Wendell Berry.
192 pp. New York:
Pantheon. $20. 
 WHEN Clarence Thomas, Anita Hill and 14 Senators presented their prurient drama on television two years ago, most of us believed that that confirmation hearing for a Supreme Court Justice dealt with sexual harassment, personal integrity and political probity -- or, perhaps better put, the lack of probity. But Wendell Berry, in the title essay of his most recent collection, will have none of this kind of superficial analysis. The event, he writes, had to do with community, and what happens when community disintegrates in a society. In his view, unwhole community is, perforce, unwholesome. Because we have destroyed community, the Senate Judiciary Committee attempted to "deal publicly with a problem for which there is no public solution."
It is essential to know that the author is defining community here as intimately connected to a place, not just an abstract concept. Most particularly he means a rural place, for Mr. Berry is our foremost living literary exponent of the values of rural life and livelihood. His province, as Wallace Stegner, his teacher and friend, has written, is "the farm, the neighborhood, the community, the town, the memory of the past and the hope of the future -- everything that is subsumed . . . under the word 'place.' " Place creates community, but when the place and its natural environment are destroyed -- as rural places inevitably are by ruthless economic exploiters who, in effect, live nowhere -- then the capacity of community to provide a useful moral context and a restraining "mutuality of interests" is lost. And so, says Wendell Berry, are we.
"Sex, Economy, Freedom and Community" is Wendell Berry's 11th collection of essays (he also has written 7 novels and 10 books of poetry), and it is perhaps the most demanding intellectually. Unlike some earlier work, it deals not with rural anecdote, parable and reporting, but in its eight essays distills the author's radically conservative views (in the good senses of both words) that have sprung from land and community in Kentucky's tobacco-farm country, a place -- the Berry "homeplace" -- chosen deliberately by the writer.
Through the lens of this countryman-writer, then, we find that the Persian Gulf war was a tragedy, not a triumph. In "Peaceableness Toward Enemies," Mr. Berry calls it a war to defend an oil-based national economy that "is not at all related to the prosperity of American localities and communities." In an essay on "global thinking and the sustainability of cities" ("Out of Your Car, Off Your Horse"), he challenges the bumper-sticker apothegm "Think Globally, Act Locally" as being facile, hopeless and perilous.
"Local life," he writes, "may be as much endangered by those who would 'save the planet' as by those would 'conquer the world.' " For saving the planet calls for abstract purposes and central powers that cannot know -- and thus will destroy -- the integrity of local nature and local community.
Mr. Berry also takes up, in "Christianity and the Survival of Creation," a point forcefully raised in the historian Lynn White's troubling 1967 article in Science magazine, "The Historic Roots of Our Ecologic Crisis." Though not the first to do so, White most persuasively laid our environmental catastrophes at the feet of a Christianity possessed by a fatal "arrogance toward nature," an attitude "deeply grounded in Christian dogma." Mr. Berry berates what he calls the "anti-Christian environmentalists," who have borrowed White's thesis for their own purposes but have not "mastered the first rule of the criticism of books: you have to read them before you criticize them." In the book in question, the Bible, he finds much support for a reverence for nature, although he excoriates organized Christianity for ignoring its own sacred text. "I don't think," he observes archly, "it is enough appreciated how much an outdoor book the Bible is."
The first essay, "Conservation and the Local Economy," contains a pithy statement that provides the theme for this book, if not for all of Mr. Berry's work: "The great, greedy, indifferent national and international economy is killing rural America, just as it is killing American cities. . . . Experience has shown that there is no use in appealing to this economy for mercy toward the earth or toward any human community. All true patriots must find ways of opposing it."
If you believe in land and community, Mr. Berry argues in "A Bad Big Idea," then you cannot believe in GATT (the General Agreement on
Tariffs and Trade), which in his view will empower the "supranational" corporations even further to demand that farmers adopt industrial farming practices that are destructive to land and community. Moreover, you cannot even be against the Government's tobacco allotment program for small farmers. In an essay that first appeared in The Progressive, and that drew heavy mail from anti-smokers, Mr. Berry, himself a sometime tobacco farmer, insisted that he and his neighbors not be condemned out of hand and not be deprived of a program that operates at no net cost to taxpayers and helps to protect the rural, community values that otherwise most of us subscribe to. The critics, he says, "will sit in their large automobiles, spewing a miasma of toxic gas into the atmosphere, and they will thank you for not smoking a cigarette."
Such are the challenges and joys of reading Wendell Berry. If "Sex, Economy, Freedom and Community" seems too rarefied, a bit dry, unleavened by the telling imagery and stories of rural life in Mr. Berry's other collections, nevertheless it presents him at his aphoristic best. Read it with pencil in hand, make notes and hope that somehow our country and the world will soon come to see the truth that is told here.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

PUB-DATE: October 17, 1993

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2211 words

HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
An Appalachian Trail for Carolina Crafts Seekers

BYLINE: By SUZANNE CARMICHAEL; SUZANNE CARMICHAEL is the author of "The Traveler's Guide to American Crafts" (E. P. Dutton).

 BODY:
AT the beginning of this century, North Carolina mountain crafts were the whooping cranes of the craft world, a seriously endangered species in a changing environment with few protectors. Even in isolated hamlets throughout the Appalachian Mountains along the state's western border, manufactured goods were gradually replacing handcrafts, the lively barter economy was declining, and the craft-dependent mountain way of life had begun to fade as families took jobs outside of their communities.
Fortunately, during the 1920's and 30's, several cultural missionaries began to organize local cottage industries, establish regional markets and found craft schools. Besides assuring the continuation of traditional crafts -- from elaborate Cherokee basketry and hand-spun wool coverlets to whimsical folk toys -- they inspired what today is a burgeoning contemporary crafts scene. 
 I recently made a whirlwind three-day tour of North Carolina's mountain craft caches to see some of the best work being done in the region. The first stop was in Cherokee, 48 miles south of Asheville, the home of Qualla Arts and Crafts Mutual, an Indian cooperative founded in 1946 to nurture and market native Cherokee crafts.
Traditional baskets, pottery, masks and carvings fill Qualla's spacious quarters, providing a glimpse of tribal craftsmanship developed centuries before European contact. A small museum illustrates these techniques with step-by-step exhibits and videos of artisans.
Qualla's most impressive items are double-weave, river-cane baskets once used to transport water ($100 for small ones to $2,000 for large, intricate versions). Essentially two nesting baskets woven as one continuous piece, the containers have handsome geometric designs made with dyes derived from dark brown walnut, rusty red bloodroot and sunny yellowroot.
Traditional pottery includes bear-grease oil lamps with serpent-head handles ($60) and "seven clan" peace pipes that resemble small hollow tree trunks studded with seven stubby branches ($25 to $60). The pottery is made from continuous clay coils smoothed with river stones, then decorated by pressing rope, fabric or carved wood paddles against the clay. Finished surface hues range from solid black to softly mottled coral and gray, the precise color determined by the type of wood used in firing. Buckeye, gourd and fur masks ($75 to $300) that were once used in ceremonies or worn as decoys during hunts are another Cherokee craft specialty.
Perennial favorites include eerie "Booger" masks, stark faces with grimacing mouths and startled eyes, which mocked people considered of questionable character -- generally white men and Indians from other tribes.
From Cherokee, the craft route winds south 58 miles through gentle, smoky mountainscapes to Murphy, then eight miles east to the small village of Brasstown, home of the John C. Campbell Folk School. Founded in 1925, the school promotes traditional mountain crafts, music and dance through three-day to two-week courses. Visitors are encouraged to take a self-guided walking tour through Campbell's 365 wooded acres, a National Historic District, stopping at rustic studio cabins to watch students handle sizzling iron, weave brightly colored textiles or carve wood amid fragrant shavings.
The school's cozy stone craft shop sells a variety of traditional work, including a menagerie of winsome wood animals by the renowned Brasstown carvers, who constitute a cottage industry developed by the school in the 1930's. For over 60 years, local carvers have come to the shop each Friday to pick up blocks of wood, returning a week later with finely detailed carved animals.
Using pale basswood, warm-hued butternut and buckeye streaked with black grain, Brasstown carvers recreate mountain creatures, from fluttery hummingbirds ($10) to stately miniature deer ($58). Shelves, windows and table tops teem with critters: doleful hound dogs ($16 to $20) and dozing cats ($6.50 to $60), inch-high beavers and bears ($8) and foot-tall geese ($60).
From Brasstown, the road passes 52 miles northeast through valley farmland and low mountains to the industrial town of Franklin, the home of Maco Crafts. This mountain co-op represents 200 artisans and offers traditional textiles as well as sweet-toned dulcimers ($245), starchy cornhusk dolls ($6.75 to $14.95) and intricately crocheted doilies ($35). The most irresistible items are Robert and Judy Abel's innovative carved or painted gourds, a potpourri of natural shapes including dark, glossy ones covered with finely carved birds ($36), or transformed into elaborately carved world globes ($145). Other gourds, embellished with paint, become birdhouses ($30) or black and white potbellied cows ($21).
At the Riverwood Pewter Shop in picturesque Dillsboro, 26 miles north of Franklin, artisans wielding leather-wrapped hammers pound pewter on wood forms to create a variety of Colonial-style items, from plain-rimmed nut dishes ($40) to elegantly simple punch bowls ($200). Other artisans use delicate jeweler's saws to pierce pewter rims, fashioning stylized dogwood-blossom edges on shallow plates ($25 to $85) and long oval platters ($65 to $95).
Riverwood pewter, like many other traditional North Carolina crafts, owes its existence to the Penland School of Crafts, the next stop on my trek. A pleasantly remote, almost monastic aura surrounds Penland's 480-acre campus, an artistic retreat framed by mountain backdrops, lush meadows and forested hillsides, 55 miles northeast of Asheville.
Established in 1923 by Lucy Morgan, a weaver and Appalachian enthusiast, Penland first taught classes in weaving, which Miss Morgan hoped would resurrect textile crafts while providing local families with an economic incentive to preserve their traditional mountain life styles. Eventually other endangered crafts were added to the curriculum, including pottery and pewter arts. Today, about 75 students study a variety of crafts during eight-week fall and spring sessions; over 180 students attend two-week summer courses.
Since the 1960's, Penland's mission has shifted from preserving mountain crafts to encouraging serious craft artists to produce fine contemporary work. Penland's sales gallery reflects this change, showcasing imaginative pieces in a variety of media by instructors and students.
During a recent visit, the collection included colorful ceramic teapots with deliberately skewed perspectives by Deborah Groover ($400); Ken Sedberry's oval ceramic plates swimming with speckled frogs ($35), and David Wilson's intriguing glass globes, which resemble small nightmarish caves filled with smoky three-dimensional forms ($300). Another glassy standout was "Bag Explosion," a sculpture by Kate Bogel and John Littleton, the son of the master glass artist Harvey Littleton. This whimsical piece consists of a large, amethyst-colored glass "bag" with two small bags, rose and turquoise, bursting from each side ($2,000).
In recent years, Penland has spawned scores of studio artists, more than 175 of whom have moved permanently to the surrounding countryside. Maps available at the Penland Gallery and local bed-and-breakfasts direct craft connoisseurs to over two dozen of these artists. One is the potter Jane Peiser, whose studio sits at the bottom of a twisty dirt road near the Penland campus.
Inside Ms. Peiser's studio, piles of gaily colored porcelain sit near shelves lined with innovative pottery, from soap dishes ($40) and tapered vases ($80 to $200) to ornate planters (up to $2,000). Ms. Peiser, a former Penland instructor, creates her signature ceramics from thin layers of colored porcelain that are rolled, layered, sliced, relayered, chopped, then rolled again before being shaped into vessels featuring fey female figures robed in vivid complexity or surrounded by mazes of color.
Arval Woody, a fifth-generation chairmaker in nearby Spruce Pine, also has a Penland connection: his grandfather once taught woodworking at the school. Today, the 73-year-old artisan continues the family tradition, making Colonial-style chairs, from fine hardwood rockers ($275 to $475) to "slipper" chairs ($110 to $120). True to their name, the latter are close to the ground, perfect for bending over to put on one's slippers.
All chairs are assembled without nails or glue, depending upon the wood's natural shrinkage as it dries to assure a tight, lasting construction. To prove the sturdiness of his wares, Mr. Woody uses his favorite sales gimmick: balancing a chair on one of its legs, he jumps up on a rung. Neither the chair nor Mr. Woody collapses.
From Spruce Pine, the Blue Ridge Parkway wends south 47 miles, skimming the forested ridges that lead to Asheville and my final destination, the Southern Highland Handicraft Guild's Folk Art Center. This massive 30,000-square-foot stone and wood establishment houses three galleries, a spacious gift shop and, from April through December, a trio of artisans demonstrating their techniques. One frequent demonstrator is Ralph Gates, a garrulous, white-bearded broom maker, whose fanciful yet practical creations include a double broom with two joined sweeping heads ($60), a "cobweb" broom mounted on a twisted honeysuckle vine handle ($18) and an elaborate hearth sweeper with a colorful braided grip ($84).
Beyond the demonstration area, a sloped walkway leads past walls of elaborate quilts ($850 to $895) to balcony galleries. Recent exhibitions have featured intriguing pieces, including a sextuplet of robed black gospel singers carved in wood by Sarah Haines ($4,000).
Below, in the cheerful hubbub of the Allanstand Craft Shop, 275 guild artisans display work that ranges from rustic pine-bark berry baskets ($30) and colorful rag rugs ($40 to $120) to soft-sculpture cows dressed in gingham ($28 to $32) and a shy, bearded folk doll holding a miniature dulcimer ($400). For $2, you can buy a gee-haw whimmy diddle, a traditional folk toy made from a wood propeller mounted on a notched rhododendron twig. By rubbing another twig along the notches, you make the propeller spin right (gee) or left (haw).

Places to Stay
 About six miles from the John C. Campbell Folk School is Huntington Hall Bed and Breakfast, 500 Valley River Avenue, Murphy, N.C. 28906; (800) 824-6189 or (704) 837-9567. This Queen Anne-style house, built in 1881, offers five guest rooms with private baths. Singles are $49; doubles, $65. Rates include a full breakfast.
Chinquapin Inn is a small bed-and-breakfast a quarter-mile from the Penland School of Crafts; the owners are knowledgeable Penland School docents. The address is Post Office Box 145 (Penland School Road), Penland, N.C. 28765; (704) 765-0064. This shingled mountain house has four rooms, one single and three double, with shared baths. The single room is $35; doubles are $45. Rates include breakfast.
The Richmond Inn is in Spruce Pine, near Woody's Chair Shop and the Penland School, as well as many other craft studios. The rambling house with a stone terrace is decorated with local crafts, sells work by several local artisans and offers guests free maps that locate the area's studio artists. The inn, at 101 Pine Avenue, Spruce Pine, N.C. 28777; (704) 765-6993, has seven rooms, each with private bath. Doubles are $45 to $55.

HEADLINE: Malls Add Services to Keep Customers

BYLINE: By NANCY KENNEDY

 BODY:
HOLD on to your credit cards. New Jersey shopping malls, trying to cope with challenges ranging from warehouse clubs to television home-shopping channels, are scrambling to keep their status as consumer icons.
As any serious consumer can attest, the number of places to spend an allowance, a paycheck or an inheritance seems to have risen sharply. Warehouse clubs and large specialty stores like Ikea, with its home furnishings, and Staples, which sells office supplies, are moving into existing retail space along the state's busiest corridors. Discounters and outlet stores have taken a firm hold as well. Easy-access strip centers are enjoying a resurgence with time-starved New Jerseyans. 
 To lure shoppers back into their climate-controlled environs, many malls -- some dating to the 1950's -- are expanding and renovating. Others are trying to be more savvy by luring hot tenants like Nordstrom and the Disney Store.
Still others are finally becoming aware that many customers want more service and better security as much as selection and bargains. The Menlo Park Mall, for example, has wheelchairs and strollers, emergency diaper kits and a mall-walkers' club, whose members exercise by circling the interior of a mall before the stores open.
When customers asked for recycling bins in the food court, they got them, said Alice Rosen, Menlo Park's marketing manager. Menlo Park, one of the earliest malls at 30 years old, is in its second year of operation after an 18-month shutdown for rebuilding.
Last month, the Quakerbridge Mall, in Lawrence Township, began offering year-round valet parking after the service proved popular during the holidays, said its marketing manager, Lisa Stezzi. And earlier this year, Bridgewater Commons instituted a smoke-free environment -- a bold move that other malls have adopted.
For enhanced safety, Menlo Park brightened lighting to eliminate dark corners. A Lawrence Township police officer is now stationed at the Quakerbridge Mall, which executives say played a part in reducing auto theft at the mall by 80 percent compared with a year ago.
Hit by recession and an accompanying real estate decline, new shopping-center construction starts in New Jersey declined to just eight in 1992, from 56 in 1989, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers.
New Jersey is home to about 978 shopping centers -- groupings of stores that have central management -- and generally the largest shopping centers are considered malls. Of the total shopping centers in the state, 35 are enclosed malls, putting most residents within a half-hour's drive of at least one mall, if not several. There hasn't been a new mall constructed in the state since 1990, when the Freehold Raceway Mall opened its doors on the site of a former race track.
Many retail analysts argue that the state has all the malls it can support. The decline of mall development as a profitable venture might be the biggest constraint. "The retail market used to be more development driven; today, the money is in management," said Keith Foxe, the spokesman for the shopping-center council. Shopping-center management companies receive not only rent but also a percentage of their tenants' profits.
Some experts trace the malls' extra efforts at luring shoppers to 1988, when Bridgewater Commons, the second-to-last mall to open in the state, had its debut in central New Jersey.
"Bridgewater Commons made all the other malls in the state look tired," said Prof. James W. Hughes, associate dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
"Malls began to see that new players could come on the scene and take business away."
 
'Siren Call' of Affluence
 Retail developers have long heeded New Jersey's siren call. Residents' personal annual income, at $26,457 per capita in 1992, continually outshines the national average of $19,841. The state is home to four of the country's 10 highest income areas, said Tom Brown, an economist with the State Office of Economic Research.
Developers tend to place their malls in these strategic trade areas of high household income. The average household income of an Echelon Mall shopper is about $50,200, said Monica Carassa, the marketing manager at Echelon, which is in Voorhees. In Somerset County, home to Bridgewater Commons, average household income tops $58,000.
Low vacancy rates among retail properties attest to the fact that retailing is still a viable business. Overall retail vacancy rates today stand at just 10 percent, according to the shopping-center council.
"An office-building developer would think he'd died and gone to heaven to see just 10 percent vacancies in his buildings," said John M. Gilchrist Jr., the chief executive of the Hahn Company, the San Diego-based developer of Bridgewater Commons.
Vacancy rates at malls, at about 5 percent, are the lowest in the retail industry. "Malls tend to be more stable because of their size," Mr. Foxe said. "If two out of 100 stores leave, it doesn't discourage potential tenants."
 
The Profit Potential
 The average mall pulls in about $225 in sales per square foot of the gross leasable area, according to the shopping-center council. In New Jersey, sales figures can be much higher. The Mall at Short Hills, for example, has sales of about $380 a square foot, said the mall's manager, Craig Perry. That puts Short Hills near the top in terms of mall sales: only 1 percent of malls do $400 or more a square foot in business. Bridgewater Commons is said to be in that top 1 percent, although officials there wouldn't discuss sales figures.
For many malls, renovation has indeed been the catalyst to greater profits. The Quakerbridge Mall, which was built in 1975 in Lawrence Township, spent $6 million on renovation this year, replacing about a third of its gross leasable area of 1.2 million square feet. Robert Hart, the mall manager at Quakerbridge, said sales increases are in the double digits this year.
"Same-store sales are up moderately, about 2 to 3 percent, but the new stores are experiencing tremendous increases," Mr. Hart said.
At the Menlo Park Mall, Nordstrom and Macy's are big draws. "Our customers are primarily suburban, dual-income households," Ms. Rosen said. "They have no problem spending money as long as they feel they are being treated as though their dollars matter, and that they are getting good value for the money spent."
 
Establishing an Identity
 Malls try all kinds of moves to establish an identity in the minds of shoppers. Quakerbridge, for example, with 36 clothing stores and 4 major department stores, wants to be known as the "fashion mall," Mr. Hart said.
Just up Route 1 from Quakerbridge, Forrestal Village is hitting its stride as an outlet center, reinventing itself after failing as a tony shopping enclave. At Freehold Raceway, with its double-decker carousel, "everything pivots around children," the mall's manager, Paul Comorado, said, apparently intending no pun.
Menlo Park likes to say it has something for everyone, but it caters to its upper-middle-class suburban community of business professionals with stores like Ann Taylor and Talbots. But even a few miles can make a difference in the target market a mall strives to shape itself around.
"The fashion attitude of our shoppers runs to classic traditional," said Menlo Park's manager, John Carpenter, who until August was the manager of Woodbridge Center. "Just two miles up the road at Woodbridge, the customer could be more accurately described as fashion forward, and closer to the city, at Bergen Mall, say, the customer is a trendsetter."
With their comfortable, controlled environment, malls can entice shoppers to spend money even when they haven't got a specific purchase in mind. "As much as 30 percent of purchases are the result of impulse shopping," Mr. Gilchrist, of the Hahn Company, said. "The customer goes shopping without an idea of what he or she wants to purchase."
 
Happy Shoppers Spend More
 Even average customers will spend 20 percent more if they are enjoying shopping, said Murray Raphel, an Atlantic City-based marketing consultant.
The success of the mall in the 1990's, Mr. Raphel said, depends not only on what the mall as an entity does to attract shoppers, but also on individual mall merchants and their relationship with their loyal customers.
"The rule of thumb is that 80 percent of your business can be traced to 20 percent of your customers," Mr. Raphel said. "Merchants need to reward these customers, give them something they pay nothing for, something they'll get just by walking in the door."
Most malls express confidence in their ability to retain their place in shoppers' hearts. Mr. Hart of Quakerbridge isn't worried. He believes there is room for malls, specialty stores, discounters, warehouse clubs, outlets and strip centers alike on the New Jersey retailing scene.
"Competition merely makes this area more of a retailing hub," Mr. Hart said. "It can only serve to increase customer draw. We're not worried about how big the pie is. We believe the pie is still growing."
