SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 1; Column 6; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2290 words

HEADLINE: Can Schools Curb Rising Bias Incidents?

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
"HOW many of you have ever witnessed a racial, ethnic, religious or sexual slur?" the speaker asked the students. "If you have, stand up."
One by one, students rose, until every student filling the auditorium at Commack High School was standing. 
 The speaker, Joe Giordano, who often addresses students about bias, continued, "How many have heard these remarks from a close friend?"
More than half the students stood.
"How many have heard them from members of your own family?" A majority remained standing.
"We have some work to do, don't we?" Mr. Giordano asked. "When remarks are made that put you down, we often say it doesn't matter. But it really does. These comments are about you and your family -- this is your soul. It's who you are."
 
Face the Hate Week
 The recent assembly was part of a Face the Hate Week in the Commack School District, one of a growing number of districts on Long Island that have introduced programs to address increases in bias incidents among youths.
Commack High School was the scene in June of one of the most blatant incidents of anti-Semitism on the Island. On the night before graduation, anti-Semitic graffiti were painted on the school track and football stands. In July, two graduating seniors were arrested after the police questioned a number of students. Last week the two 18-year-olds, Robert Rolsteon and Philip Argiros, were arraigned. They face up to seven years in jail if convicted.
In addition, another Commack student, Richard Sasto, also 18, was indicted on a charge of perjury. He was accused of lying to a grand jury when he denied that a friend never mentioned to him that he was involved in defacing the track.
There have been a number of other incidents of anti-Semitism on the Island recently. Last month the head of a pig was thrown into the living room of a yeshiva teacher in Lake Grove. The Suffolk County police said they were investigating the incident.
In Port Washington, a swastika and anti-Semitic graffiti were found at a park. Anti-Semitic graffiti were also discovered in elementary schools in Levittown and Huntington. Last week, anti-Semitic graffiti, including swastikas and the phrase "Jews Must Die," were spray painted across the back of a P. C. Richards appliance store in Oceanside.
Suffolk has received 100 reports of bias-related incidents this year, according to Detective James Mosby of the police bias unit. He added that 75 percent of the criminals had been youths from 13 to 19. In Nassau County, 67 incidents were reported to the police this year. The bias coordinator, Inspector Ronald Olsen, said 70 percent of those caught were usually teen-agers.
 
New Programs in Curriculums
 The incidents have prompted educators to become more aggressive in dealing with the problem. Some districts have added to their curriculums programs with acronyms like PINK for Prejudice Is Not Kool, STAR for Students Together Against Racism and BUTY for Bring Unity to Youth. Others are introducing programs sponsored by the Anti-Defamation League, the American Jewish Congress, the Americans Civil Liberties Union and other groups.
 
Increase in Ethnic Violence
 While students are becoming familiar with terms like bias-reduction, ethnic sharing and cultural diversity, some educators and others are concerned over why the acts of bias seem to be growing and whether the programs are effective in changing behavior.
Intolerance is not a new problem, but it has become more visible in schools, said Amy Levine, Long Island director of the American Jewish Congress. Incidents of anti-ethnic graffiti have become more prevalent, she said, along with a general increase in violence.
"We've got to give kids tools to combat hate, to respond to their parents when they hear them making derogatory remarks," Ms. Levine said. "We don't want people to be tolerated, but honored for their diversity."
Racism is no longer just a black-and-white issue, said Louise Simpson, Long Island regional director of the N.A.A.C.P. The tendency to look for scapegoats is an attitude that comes from the home, she added.
An assistant school superintendent in Commack, Robert Davis, said the weeklong program in his district was scheduled early in the school year in response to the vandalism in the spring. "Our students need to know that such ugly incidents will not be accepted or tolerated," he said.
After the first day the events at the high school continued with sensitivity groups to discuss discrimination and stereotypes; the viewing and discussion of a film, "Crimes of Hate," and a crossculture festival. The principal, Ron Vale, said:
"In one week we can't change the behavior of kids. But it's an attempt, and we've got to keep chipping away at it. We're hoping that this will stimulate thinking among the kids and lead to other follow-up activities."
 
Role of Economics
 One widely held theory explaining the rise of bias-related incidents cites economics. The community relations director of the South Huntington School District, Dr. Joan Wilson, said:
"The growing incidence of bias and racism among youth is embedded in the economic conditions of our country. We're seeing the result of the frustration on the part of families unable to live in the manner that they would like to or that they were accustomed to. Children are registering their reactions to the anger and frustrations of their parents."
 
'All Kinds of Fantasies'
 Most experts emphasize early intervention. Dr. Mary Rose Paster, a psychologist in Glen Cove, said that by 12 children are set in their ideas and attitudes. "The earlier we can intervene and teach respect for individuals of different cultures, religions and races, the easier it is for them to take these values and make them part of their own value systems," Dr. Paster said. "If members of minority groups are not part of the broader community, kids can project all kinds of fantasies onto members of these minorities without having the opportunity to check out their perceptions."
Experts also agree that for programs on prejudice to be effective, they should involve parents. A psychologist in Roslyn, Dr. Robert Byalick, said parent education was critical and added:
"It is the attitudes of their parents that kids identify with and imitate at an early age. Their perceptions are often based on fear and ignorance rather than reality. School programs are important to make students more aware of these issues. But unless the schools include the parents on an ongoing basis the programs won't change the behaviors among the kids."
A conference for educators on prejudice was held in May by the American Jewish Congress and the Suffolk Association of Jewish Schools. Its purpose was to exhibit programs that districts have started to help break down stereotypes and reduce prejudice, said Ms. Levine.
The conference was sponsored by more than 30 organizations, including the N.A.A.C.P., the Archdiocese of Rockville Centre, La Union Hispanica, Boces, police departments and other agencies. Workshops demonstrated some of the programs.
 
 'If It's Reinforced Every Day'
 PINK, a counseling program at Rockville Centre Middle School, is one of several anti-bias programs developed by the district, according to Superintendent William Johnson, who is also president of the Nassau County Council of Superintendents.
"This trend is typical of most school districts," Dr. Johnson said. "If they don't already have programs in place they're setting them up. In a multicultural community the process must be on going. The evolution of behavior that allows kids to understand and tolerate one another will happen only if it's reinforced every day."
A national program sponsored by the Anti-Defamation League, a World of Difference, has taken workshops to 87 of the 126 districts on the Island in recent years. The coordinator for Nassau-Suffolk, Robert Ricken, said the workshops started focusing on prejudices about race and religion, but have expanded to include sex, handicaps and other stereotypes.
"We talk to kidsabout how it feels to be picked on, if they're fat, skinny, a Jew, an Indian, a nerd, someone who wears glasses," Mr. Ricken said. "Then we try to give them techniques for dealing with these stereotypes and for appreciating differences among themselves. It's difficult to measure if the workshops have made a difference, but there are indicators that they have been effective in changing the attitudes of some of the kids."
 
Peers as Mediators
 The STAR program at Longwood Middle School features student-led exercises against stereotypes and racism, said an assistant superintendent, Peter Strafaci. "We have a slogan," Mr. Strafaci said, " 'If you educate the young and wait 50 years the old will die out, and racism will die out with it.' We're trying to emphasize that differences are good, not bad."
He said other recent programs in the Longwood district include Bring Unity to Youth, which tries to bring black and white high school students together in an effort to understand differences, and the Diversity Institute, a program in which a group of fourth graders were selected by their peers to become student mediators.
"It's hard to measure if these programs are reaching the kids," Mr. Strafaci said. "But students are more involved than ever before, and kids are talking to other kids. In the long run, hopefully, this will change attitudes."
Districts are introducing programs created for their students. In Bay Shore, whose students are 25 percent black, 20 percent Hispanic and 5 percent Asian, teacher volunteers started a high school program in ethnic sharing several years ago. Last month the district agreed to finance the program, said the coordinator, Pat Ponzi.
 
Pain, Resentment and Anger
 "The beauty of the program is its simplicity," Mrs. Ponzi said. "It's about sharing experiences and opening the lines of communication in a structured three-hour session. Kids can spend time together every day, participate in the same activities and never talk. In an ethnic-sharing session, students of diverse groups talk about bias and stereotypes. We hear about pain, resentment and anger. It touches a lot of nerves.
"When a student hears how another feels about being stereotyped and how it hurts he starts to think more about his own behavior. Has it made a difference? Not an 8 on the Richter scale. But we've seen kids hanging out together who never did before, and we've noticed some reduction in the level of antagonism among groups."
Mrs. Ponzi said teachers in the program had trained other districts to set up programs.
In Herricks a growing Asian population that makes up one-third of the students has mandated increased sensitivity to cultural differences, said Michael Klopfer, coordinator of the community coalition in the district. Recent programs include ethnic sharing, a Korean support group, book talks, a community holiday cookbook and community programs.
"Initially the differences are subtle," Mr. Klopfer said. "The real success will be long range. How will these kids function with their own families when they grow up? We hope that we're educating a generation that will be more tolerant than their parents. The earlier we can reach them and make an impression on their young minds the more effective it will be."
 
Course From New York City
 In Plainview, a district that is half Jewish, a Holocaust and genocide studies center helps students and adults remember those horrors through memorabilia, said a spokesman for the district, Robert Zimmerman. The goal is to focus on what prejudice can lead to and how people can fight back, he said.
Last month, a conference sponsored by the American Civil Liberties Union at Plainview-Old Bethpage John F. Kennedy High School drew 100 educators to preview a course, "Civil Rights and Race Relations," that has been taught in New York City schools.
 
Response to Series of Incidents
 The director of the A.C.L.U. on Long Island, Barbara Bernstein, said the impetus for the conference was the graffiti in Commack, anti-Hispanic incidents in Hicksville and other cases. The six-week course, financed by the New York Civil Rights Coalition, is free to school districts.
Instructors begin discussing the civil rights movement and black pride and lead the group to dialogues on discrimination, prejudice, stereotypes, sexual harassment and other issues. Bringing in outside instructors who are not emotionally attached to the students allows them to be nonjudgmental, Ms. Bernstein said, and makes it easier to have students talk openly.
Ms. Bernstein added that six districts on the Island had requested the course, which is adapted for each district depending on its population. The programs are expected to begin on the Island in December, she said, adding:
"Theoretically, high school is too late, and we should start prejudice reduction when kids are 3 years old. But the fact is that most visual and verbal expressions of hate come at the high school level, and if we want to put our finger in the dike we must start at the high school level."
A health teacher at Syosset High School, Hilda Ward, said that when some students were recently invited to a workshop of the Martin Luther King Club they looked at it as a free period from classes. But they soon found themselves forced to think about issues, she said, and they were surprised and angry to hear what other people thought of them.
"There were many misperceptions," Ms. Ward said. "These kids realized how they too had misjudged others. The message was you don't have to love me, but at least respect me."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 751 words

HEADLINE: We Are What We Do

BYLINE: By Tony Eprile; Tony Eprile is the author of "Temporary Sojourner: And Other South African Stories."

 BODY:

WORKING MEN
Stories.
By Michael Dorris.
286 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95. 
 IT is a cliche about Americans that one of the first things we ask a new acquaintance is "What do you do?" In Europe, the question would be considered unpardonably rude. Michael Dorris taps into this essential aspect of American life, that we are what we do, and most of the stories in "Working Men" center on a moment of self-revelation connected with work.
Mr. Dorris has established a reputation as a novelist ("A Yellow Raft in Blue Water"), nonfiction writer ("The Broken Cord" and essays too numerous to mention) and children's book author ("Morning Girl"). "Working Men" reveals him to be one of the more exciting and gifted American short-story writers as well. These 14 stories demonstrate his skilled and subtle storytelling, roving imagination and embracing humanism.
The stories share a concern with how ripples from the world of work spread into and even define a character's emotional and family lives. Some of the protagonists are inseparable from their labors, their trade the prism through which they view the world: Normand Pasco, in "Qiana," who drives the snowplow in a small New Hampshire town, strays from his comfortable, if unchallenging, marriage into the bed of a woman whose unpredictability "could wake him up like the jolt of a frost heave on an otherwise smooth grade." For others, like Dwayne in "Oui," work is more a matter of happenstance: "I joined the service, re-enlisted twice for lack of a better idea, but when my last two-year hitch in Germany was over, I decided it was time to get on with whatever." Dwayne, who stumbles into a job as a high school French teacher, although he knows only one word in the language (the story's title), is as much defined by his openness to happy accident as others are by professions that fit them like a second skin.
We see that intersection of self and work in "Groom Service" as Bernard, a young American Indian, learns humility, love and the depths of his previously untapped resourcefulness when he is faced with the protracted indifference of his prospective wife's family to his prowess as a hunter. In "Jeopardy," a glib and garrulous traveling salesman discovers -- through the death of his father and the coincidental, unexpected use of one of his products to save a child's life -- that he is lonely and isolated yet connected to "the chain of things . . . a part of the flow, more than I admit, a river that can best be witnessed from very far away."
Collections are rarely even, and there are enough inspired stories in "Working Men" to make the merely well wrought disappointing. (Although "Name Games" pokes witty fun at brand-name fiction and people who mistake designer goods for a life truly lived, the story doesn't rise above its easy target.) There is also a sameness of narrative tone to the stories, although Mr. Dorris is to be lauded for successfully delivering up a wide range of personalities, economic and ethnic backgrounds and historical periods.
The flaws are easily eclipsed by the overall strength of this sensitive and beautifully observed book. The description of pond building by the narrator of "The Benchmark" could equally serve to describe Mr. Dorris's masterly attention to craft: "To start a job, you drive a nail into a peak of ledge, pound it deep, make it your benchmark. . . . Weather patterns can alter, crops grow, houses get built and collapse, but you can return in 50 years and position a tripod, rotate the dials of the spirit until the air bubble precisely crosses the hairline, then aim an alidade at that solitary, centering nail and be in business."
In a lesser writer's hands, this artfulness would be all we would get and the story might offer just another shopworn allegory in which a laborer's craft stands in for the truly arduous work of hauling blocks of words from page to page. A family tragedy has made the narrator of "The Benchmark" aware that the craft he learned from his father won't be passed on to the next generation, that while his "imagination would . . . fill any empty space with water," it is insufficient to fill the gap a favorite son's death has created in his marriage and in his soul. Deeply insightful and generous toward human foibles, this story surprises the reader by veering away from the expected and facing a larger vision that is, on reflection, more accurate. It serves as a fitting bench mark for Mr. Dorris's fine collection.

HEADLINE: Bill, Take a Leaf From J.F.K.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Russell Baker's experience, insight and writing skill combine to cheer his readers when he occasionally turns out a serious column. And so it is with "Make It Bill and Lyndon" (Oct. 9), in which he correctly points out that Bill Clinton's focus on domestic issues matches that of Lyndon Johnson. But Mr. Baker errs when he states that John F. Kennedy "was so absorbed in foreign policy that he seemed to have no domestic policy at all" (until he became active with respect to civil rights). 
 As manifested by a strongly pro-growth tax policy, Kennedy's effective attention to the country's economic needs has been matched by few chief executives, Democrat or Republican. Advised by a splendid economic team (Douglas Dillon, Henry Fowler, Robert Roosa and Paul Volcker at Treasury; Walter Heller, James Tobin and Kermit Gordon at the Council of Economic Advisers), Kennedy moved from day one to promote the saving and investment essential to higher living standards.
(1) In early 1961 J.F.K. called for enactment of an innovative tax credit to promote investment in productive equipment. Congress approved his request (against the lobbying of both Big Labor and Big Business) in 1962.
(2) Secretary Douglas Dillon started his Treasury technicians to work to revise and liberalize business depreciation guidelines. (These two actions alone -- innovative tax credit and depreciation liberalization -- sharply reduced the capital cost of productive investment.)
(3) In January 1963 Kennedy called for a strongly pro-growth general tax cut (what we would now call supply side) on individuals and business. The proposal passed the House before his death and Lyndon Johnson pushed it through the Senate in 1964. The measure cut the top marginal tax rate on individuals from a confiscatory 91 percent to 70 percent, and the rate on the lowest bracket from 20 to 14 percent (shades of Ronald Reagan's Kemp-Roth tax cut in 1981). The corporate rate was cut from 52 to 48 percent, but Kennedy's request to reduce capital gains tax rates was rejected by the Democratic Congress.
The results were an economic policymaker's dream. Saving and productive investment took off, only to be sidetracked in the latter half of the 1960's when, as one observer said, Johnson tried to conquer Vietnam, poverty and space all at once.
The United States did not return to the pro-growth tax track until 1978, when little-known Representatives Jim Jones and Bill Steiger and well-known Senator Russell Long pushed through a bill cutting taxes on saving and investment over Jimmy Carter's objections. Ronald Reagan's massive tax reduction in 1981 may well have gone too far, but it at least temporarily created the most pro-saving and investment tax system in the industrial world. Temporarily because Mr. Reagan blew it all in 1986 by trading the investment tax credit and accelerated depreciation for huge individual tax cuts.
There is an important lesson here for President Clinton. To be sure, his plate is crowded now with health care, trade liberalization and foreign policy problems. But significant tax restructuring for capital formation and fairness should be on the agenda for his first term. If it is not, then his first term may well be his last.
 
CHARLS E. WALKER
Washington, Oct. 12, 1993
 
The writer, former Deputy Treasury Secretary, is chairman of the American Council for Capital Formation.

HEADLINE: MISSION IN SOMALIA;
After Supporting Hunt for Aidid, U.S. Is Blaming U.N. for Losses

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Despite the Administration's attempts to blame the United Nations for the Somalia crisis, the intensifying military operations there were repeatedly endorsed and sometimes driven by top American officials in the months before the disastrous Army raid on a hostile faction two weeks ago.
Last Thursday, 11 days after 18 American soldiers died in the raid, President Clinton sought to shift responsibility to the United Nations, which took over the Somali operation in the spring. 
 Mr. Clinton said the aggressive effort against the faction leader Mohammed Farah Aidid "never should have been allowed to supplant the political process that was ongoing when we were in effective control, up through last May."
Mr. Clinton has gone so far as to say he was not even aware United States forces were still trying to capture General Aidid.
But while officials and critics are hunting for scapegoats, classified messages between Mogadishu and Washington and interviews with United States policymakers and military officers and with United Nations officials show a more complex picture of a policy with wider support in Washington than the Administration has acknowledged.
The premise of the United Nations policy -- to neutralize General Aidid's power -- was shared by top Administration officials throughout most of the summer, though some were uneasy that the strategy relied too heavily on military force. The United States military at first also supported the policy of confronting General Aidid with force, but later came to doubt that it would be possible to capture him.
Even when the Administration began to rethink its approach in September, it did not tell the United States forces in Somalia under Pentagon control to abandon their hunt for General Aidid. It was under the old standing orders that the Army Rangers launched their attack on Oct. 3.
 
Officials at Odds
 A broad range of interviews disclosed these details of United States policymaking:
*As late as Sept. 6 -- two weeks after the Administration agreed to a plea from military commanders in Somalia to send a battalion of Rangers -- the State Department's liaison office in Mogadishu sent a classified message to Washington seeking more troops. The message alarmed Gen. Joseph P. Hoar, head of the United States Central Command, who sent his own message to Washington dismissing the idea as a hopeless crusade.
*In early summer, the Central Intelligence Agency endorsed the view, held by the United Nations and publicly supported by President Clinton at the time, that General Aidid was a disruptive force who would interfere with the rebuilding of Somalia.
*Using his extensive contacts in Washington, Jonathan Howe, the retired United States admiral who is the special United Nations envoy to Somalia, engaged in what an aide to Defense Secretary Les Aspin called "frenetic and obsessive" lobbying for more forces, culminating in the decision to send the Rangers. The mild-mannered Admiral Howe acknowledged the calls but said he never requested any troops without the agreement of the United Nations and United States military commanders in Somalia.
 
What They Wanted
 "I know there are a lot of people trying to put the finger on me," Admiral Howe said. "I have just been one of the many people involved in the policy, which started with the Security Council. A lot of people were involved in it."
"I never asked for anything that American and Turkish leadership did not want," he added, referring to Lieut. Gen. Cevik Bir of Turkey, the commander of the United Nations troops in Somalia, and Maj. Gen. Thomas M. Montgomery, General Bir's deputy and the senior United States military officer there.
 
In the Beginning, A Focus on Food
 President Bush sent 28,000 troops to Somalia last December for what was to be a short mission to help feed starving Somalis. In retrospect, the Bush Administration seems to have underestimated the problems and overestimated the ability of United Nations peacekeepers to take over the mission after United States troops were withdrawn.
The Bush Administration also had its problems with the United Nations: when Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali wanted to disarm the warring clans there, the Bush Administration resisted. Some now say that if disarmament was to be attempted at all, the best time would have been early this year when United States combat strength was at its peak and the United Nations was distributing food, which added to its political leverage.
As the United Nations tried to rebuild Somalia, it sought to reduce the influence of the heavily armed factions. The C.I.A., in an assessment first obtained by Defense Week, a Washington newsletter, seemed to support this track, saying in one unclassified paper that General Aidid was "a threat to peace."
On June 5, forces believed to be under General Aidid's command attacked Pakistani peacekeepers, killing 24 of them.
At the urging of Washington, the Security Council adopted a resolution calling for the arrest of those responsible and for "the disarmament of all Somalia parties." While the resolution did not name General Aidid, Administration officials made it plain that they thought he was responsible.
A week later, United States AC-130 gunships and attack helicopters, supported by other United Nations troops, pounded the clan leader's headquarters and armories. The attacks continued, destroying large amounts of weaponry and a radio station.
When the operation was over, President Clinton proudly declared it a complete success. "The purpose of the operation was to undermine the ability of Aidid to wreak military havoc in Somalia," he said on June 17. "The military back of Aidid has been broken. A warrant has been issued for his arrest."
 
After the Attacks, Calls for Troops
 The military strikes against General Aidid's command center and ammunition caches were not the only steps urged by United Nations and United States field commanders. Admiral Howe and General Montgomery also requested the Delta Force commando unit to hunt for General Aidid.
The Administration initially rebuffed the request, fearing that sending the highly touted commandos would attract too much attention to the effort to capture General Aidid. General Hoar, who supported the attacks on General Aidid's strongholds, opposed a manhunt and told the Pentagon there was only a 1-in-4 chance of catching him, officials said.
Admiral Howe would not take no for an answer. He said in an interview that Washington's initial refusal to approve the request may have made the job more difficult. "Your opportunities change over time," he said. "If we had had the capabilities in June, we would have had a much better chance."
An aide to Mr. Aspin said that beginning in July, Admiral Howe had "adopted Aidid as his Great White Whale" and repeatedly called his contacts in the Administration to request more troops. Admiral Howe acknowledged lobbying for more forces, but said he was merely trying to carry out the Security Council resolution.
Finally, as General Aidid continued his attacks, Admiral Howe's lobbying bore fruit. The Deputies Committee, a panel of sub-Cabinet officials, decided in late August to send the Rangers and a number of Delta commandos.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in a recent interview with The Washington Post that because the policy was being managed by the Deputies Committee, Cabinet-level officials "were not sufficiently attentive."
But senior Administration officials said the decision to send the Rangers was approved by Mr. Clinton, Mr. Aspin, Gen. Colin L. Powell, who was then the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Anthony Lake, the national security adviser.
An aide said that even though General Powell was skeptical about the prospects of capturing General Aidid, he supported the request because his general in Somalia wanted the Rangers.
One day after the Rangers arrived, the Administration began to emphasize a broader political agenda. On Aug. 27, Mr. Aspin called in a speech for more work on the political and economic reconstruction of the country. He also said United States troops would stay in Somalia until violence was quelled, the clans gave up their heavy weapons and a national police was created.
 
Rangers in Place, More Troops Sought
 The Rangers met with mixed success in Somalia: they failed to capture General Aidid but they detained some of his top aides and seized equipment.
To Admiral Howe, who had been saying the United Nations intended to disarm everyone in Mogadishu, it seemed that even more troops were now needed.
He was not alone. On Sept. 6 the Administration received a message from Robert Gosende, the senior United States diplomat in Mogadishu, who wanted more troops to conduct weapons sweeps and urged Washington not to negotiate with General Aidid because he was a terrorist.
An Administration official said another aim behind the request for more troops was to enable United Nations forces to move around the country more freely, demonstrating that General Aidid did not control the country and supporting the political efforts to build a new governing structure.
General Hoar, head of the United States Central Command, was alarmed by the request and sent a strongly worded classified message to Frank G. Wisner, the Under Secretary of Defense for Policy, and to General Powell.
"After four months of operations with extraordinary help from the United States Government, the United Nations' successes have been modest," General Hoar wrote. "A coherent plan which involves the political, humanitarian and security needs for the country has yet to emerge. Control of Mogadishu has been lost."
General Hoar complained that the United Nations favored "facile solutions like, get Aidid and all will be well."
"If the only solution for Mogadishu is large-scale infusion of troops and if the only country available to make this commitment is the United States, then it is time to reassess," he wrote.
By the time General Hoar sent his message, however, senior Administration officials were already reviewing policy toward Somalia with an eye toward encouraging a political solution.
 
Trying to Balance Force and Politics
 But as the Administration sought to move to a political strategy, policy became less clear. Washington was looking for some sort of political settlement but had not yet given up its military approach.
On Sept. 9, United States combat engineers and Pakistani forces were ambushed in Mogadishu and a Pakistani M-48 tank was blown up when it tried to come to the rescue. That day General Montgomery sent a message asking for more firepower -- 4 tanks, 14 armored personnel carriers and a battalion of artillery.
General Hoar supported the request, except for the artillery. So did General Powell. A senior Administration official said General Powell did not argue strongly for the request, but an aide said the general had presented it twice.
Mr. Aspin rejected the request on Sept. 23 because he feared it would emphasize military operations just when Washington was trying to emphasize diplomacy and speed up a withdrawal.
At the same time, Mr. Boutros-Ghali resisted Washington's push for a political strategy, saying establishing security in Somalia was paramount.
Since the Rangers were under United States' command, not United Nations', the Administration could have rescinded their standing orders to try to capture General Aidid. The orders were not rescinded, one senior official said, because Washington had not yet given up the idea of capturing him.
On Oct. 3, the Rangers mounted the raid in which 18 Americans were killed and scores wounded. According to a senior military official, most of the casualties were suffered early in the fighting and could not have been avoided even if Mr. Aspin had approved dispatch of the armor. But military officials agreed that the armor would have improved rescue efforts and limited casualties somewhat.
Of course, if the Rangers had succeeded in capturing General Aidid, the political fallout might have been very different.
"Yes, the United Nations should have focused earlier on political reconciliation in Somalia," one Administration official said. "But all this finger-pointing is unseemly, since no one in the Administration stoutly resisted the main elements of our Somalia policy, including the effort to get Aidid."

HEADLINE: RACES FOR MAYOR FOCUSING ON CRIME

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 14

 BODY:
Pervasive fear of violent crime is dominating mayoral races across the country in a year that is seeing the largest turnover of big-city mayors in more than three decades.
In cities as diverse as Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, Miami and Minneapolis, whether the races pit blacks against blacks, blacks against whites, whites against whites, or involve other ethnic groups, veteran mayors are retiring, and crime is the dominant issue. In cities from New York to Seattle, challengers are using crime as a battering ram to try to unseat incumbents. 
 Political experts say the mayoral races, which are dominating the off-year political landscape, and the rash of retirements both reflect the grim times and diminished expectations in the nation's cities as maintaining order has replaced dreams of minority empowerment or urban innovation.
"There are not a whole lot of subtleties to these races," said David Axelrod, a Chicago-based political consultant whose candidates include Dennis Archer, one of the two candidates bidding to replace Coleman A. Young, who is retiring after 20 years as Detroit's Mayor. "There are fundamental fears, crime being the leading one, among the people who live in cities, and they want someone to address them. Everything else is secondary."
Still, one complication is race, which is an overt issue in the conflict between Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani in New York and a more complex factor in other elections around the nation, including the one in Detroit.
In some cases, the mayoral retirements reflect special circumstances, like Raymond L. Flynn of Boston resigning to become Ambassador to the Vatican. Some decisions, like those of of Mr. Young and Tom Bradley of Los Angeles to give up their jobs after more than two decades in office, reflect age or health concerns. (A conservative businessman, Richard J. Riordan, was elected as mayor of Los Angeles last June.)
But at least as common are the frustrations of running cities in the 1990's, when addressing mounting needs with falling resources is the norm.
 
Jobs Called Greatest Issue
 "The greatest need in our cities is to create jobs, but when you don't get any help from the state or from Washington it's just a very tough time to be a mayor," said John C. Daniels, who is stepping down after four years as Mayor of New Haven. "I think if I had run, I would have won, but I just think the next two years would be some of the same old stuff, just continually fighting and fighting and not really making any accomplishment."
Among other big-city mayors giving up their jobs are Xavier Suarez of Miami, Maynard Jackson of Atlanta, Donald Fraser of Minneapolis, Sophie Masloff of Pittsburgh, James Griffin of Buffalo, James D. Scheibel of St. Paul and Thomas P. Ryan Jr. of Rochester.
Crime is a main issue in the mayoral race in New York, and it is hardly surprising that crime would dominate a race in Detroit, where urban violence has long been prevalent.
Sharon McPhail, a lawyer and administrator in the Wayne County prosecutor's office, who is running with Mr. Young's endorsement, has promised to put an additional 2,000 police officers on the streets, a proposal that many believe will never happen. Mr. Archer calls for a reorganization of the police department that he says would add 380 officers to the streets.
But even in Minneapolis, long a home of sedate, efficient government, voters face an election driven by fears of crime. John Derus, who was voted out last year as Hennepin County Commissioner, came from nowhere to finish second in the primary last month by running a strident law-and-order campaign.
Mr. Derus is in what is judged to be a tight race with the City Council President, Sharon Sayles Belton, in the Nov. 2 election.
"People are interested in being safe in their homes and having their children safe in their schools," said Mr. Derus, who is proposing a 20 percent increase in the number of police officers. "They're really tired of people who want to engineer human behavior by using their tax money."
In most cases, the debate over crime has revolved around who can put the most police on the streets.
In Boston, where a recent spate of highly publicized murders has made crime an especially emotional topic and where a recent front page of The Boston Herald screamed "Gripped by Violence," acting Mayor Thomas M. Menino and State Representative James T. Brett have put forward competing plans to beef up the police.
Mr. Brett, who likes to remind voters that as a state representative he led the fight to ban assault weapons in Boston, has pledged to add 400 new officers. He proposes to pay for them with Federal money and new taxes.
Mr. Menino pledges to add 100 officers to the force every year of his term. He added 45 officers shortly after replacing Mr. Flynn in July and another 65 will join in January. He also wants to consolidate the Boston Police Department, Boston Housing Authority Police and the school police. Both men call for strike forces to go after violent criminals.
Also common are calls for "community-based" policing, which is being advocated by candidates like Ms. McPhail in Detroit and Bill Campbell, the front-runner in Atlanta.
Few doubt that fear of violent crime is a legitimate issue and an overriding fact of life in urban America. But some question whether either the campaign debates or the single-minded focus on law enforcement is likely to be effective in combating it.
 
'Exploit People's Fears'
 "The politicians, and that's going on in our city, too, are trying to exploit people's fears to get elected," said Mr. Fraser, the current Minneapolis Mayor, who is supporting Mr. Derus's opponent. "But everyone in police work knows that's not the long-term answer, and even in the short term it won't have much impact."
Of Mr. Derus, he said, "We've got a guy running here who whether the issue is infant mortality, teen pregnancy, school dropouts or unemployment, his answer is more cops."
In some cities, particularly New York, the crime issue has exacerbated racial ones, and experts say it clearly has the power to hurt black politicians, whether a vulnerable one like Mr. Dinkins in New York or a generally popular one like Norman Rice in Seattle.
But in other cities, the political tie between crime and race is no longer clear. In Atlanta and Detroit, where all the candidates are black, the issue is as potent as in Boston, where the candidates are white. In Detroit, race has been injected into the campaign by Ms. McPhail and her supporters, who have tried to follow in Mr. Young's tradition by painting her as the candidate of urban blacks and her opponent as the candidate favored by suburban whites.
"Voters want a mayor who will shuffle when he's not going anywhere, scratch when he's not itching and grin when he's not tickled," the Rev. Charles Adams said at a prayer breakfast for Ms. McPhail this week. "But I want a tough mayor."
But in a city with problems as desperate as Detroit's it remains to be seen if the strategy, which extends down to Ms. McPhail's "You Go, Girl," a street-slang slogan for "go get 'em," will override more pragmatic judgments.
"Quite frankly, 'You Go, Girl,' gets on my nerves," said Michelle Brown, the business manager of the Michigan Catholic newspaper, who is supporting Mr. Archer. "If I wanted a home girl that's fine, but I want a mayor."
Despite the nation's urban problems, not all incumbent mayors are in trouble. Michael White in Cleveland and Bob Lanier in Houston are among those rated as shoo-ins for re-election. Many of the retirees, like Mr. Jackson in Atlanta, would have been in the same position had they run.
Their relative popularity reflects the fact that despite a high level of frustration, many voters know there are no quick fixes for the cities.
That could mean the tough talk on crime and the promises to radically improve law enforcement will not win elections unless people have reason to believe the claims.
 
 
 
MAYOR'S RACES IN THE BIG CITIES
 BOSTON: Thomas M. Menino, who was appointed to replace Ray Flynn as Mayor when Mr. Flynn resigned to become ambassador to the Vatican, faces State Representative James Brett in contest dominated by crime and education issues.

 MIAMI: Steve Clark, the former Mayor of Dade County; Miriam Alonso, a former City Council member, and Willard Fair, an Urban League leader, are competing in a race dominated by crime issues and personal attacks.

 MINNEAPOLIS: John Derus, a former Hennepin County Commissioner, faces City Council President Sharon Sayles Belton in a race that has been dominated by Mr. Derus' acerbic law and order campaign.

 DETROIT: Dennis Archer, a former Michigan Supreme Court Justice who has strong business backing, faces Sharon McPhail, a lawyer and county prosecutor's office administrator backed by outgoing Mayor Coleman Young, in the race to succeed Mr. Young.

 ATLANTA: Two City Council members, Bill Campbell and Myrtle Davis, and a former County Commission chairman, Michael Lomax, are bidding to succeed Maynard Jackson and preside over the 1996 Olympics in a race dominated by crime issues.

LENGTH: 2093 words

HEADLINE: New Immigrants Test Nation's Heartland

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, Kan.

 BODY:
Its milky white sky sits squat on the plains, a horizon unbroken but for grain elevators and water towers. At a feed yard off Old Highway 83, cowboys gallop into the noonday sun, fringed chaps slapping their thighs. Blond girls practice cheerleading jumps on square lawns adorned by pumpkins. Near a central intersection, a large sign says simply: Have a Nice Day.
That is Garden City at first sight, stereotypical Kansas, wheatlands and cattle pens and rosy cheeks. But before long, a second reality grows apparent. There is a tortilla factory on Main Street, a Laotian market offering Thai videos on Fulton Street. At dawn, hundreds of immigrants and refugees file into Slaughter Employee Parking at a giant meat-packing plant.
 
'A Little New York City'
 At nightfall, while locals head to the Grain Bin for Texas two-step dancing, Mexican immigrants crowd into Saigon, a Vietnamese-run karaoke bar, and Southeast Asians pack the Pho Hoa One Restaurant, where the fish sauce and lemon grass are plentiful. 
 Multiculturalism has come to the heartland, especially to this cow town in the short grass and sand-sage prairie of southwest Kansas. In the direct center of the country -- 1,640 miles from the Atlantic and 1,625 from the Pacific -- Garden City offers an ideal case study of the many forces at work as the latest wave of immigration spills over into the Middle West.
"We've become a little New York City in the land of Dorothy, Toto and Auntie Em," said Roxy Thompson, an elementary school teacher here.
As in New York City, Los Angeles and Miami, immigration into the heartland is a story of conflict and accommodation. But in places that have never known much racial and ethnic diversity, foreignness in and of itself is an issue. Since so many immigrants to the heartland are uncertain whether they are just passing through or will stay, the towns cannot tell if their young, tentative ethnic communities are a temporary challenge or a historic transformation of identity.
In the last 13 years, after the biggest beef-packing plant in the world opened here, Garden City's population has grown by 42 percent to about 25,500. Most of the newcomers -- who work grueling jobs as bleeders, tail rippers, flankers, head droppers, gutters and horn sawers -- are Hispanic and Southeast Asian immigrants and refugees.
The immigrants have made the town worldly while shaking its stability. They have ushered in an era of growth while contributing to an increase in crime and drop-out rates. Privately, ethnic antagonism simmers. But publicly it rarely finds a voice, because newcomers and old-timers live, work and play in worlds that barely intersect.
 
Packing Plants Draw Wave of Immigrants
 Eight years ago, Marcial Cervantes, the Mexican-born son of a migrant miner, met a packing company recruiter at an unemployment office in New Mexico. A day later, with the guarantee of a $6.70-an-hour job in Garden City, he and his newlywed wife crammed their belongings into a 1966 G.M.C. pickup and hit the highway for a place he assumed would be "100 percent guero," -- fair-haired, blue-eyed American.
But in his first day on the kill floor, Mr. Cervantes looked around with amazement.
"I hadn't seen so many mexicanos since I left Mexico in 1976," he said.
Immigrants do not end up in the heartland by chance. They are either plopped here by the Federal Government's refugee resettlement program or lured by jobs in increasingly industrialized rural America. Meat-packing plants, in particular, have cut costs by moving away from unionized cities and closer to the feed yards in areas antagonistic to unions.
When IBP Inc., one of the nation's major food-processing companies, made such a move to just outside Garden City in 1980, the town was typically heartland. About 16 percent of the residents were descendants of the Mexicans who came to work in the early 1900's on the railroads and in the sugar-beet harvest, but only about 2 percent of the residents were foreign-born.
Unemployment stood at about 3 percent as IBP set out to hire 2,850 people and another plant began to double its work force to about 1,400.
"At first, IBP tried to recruit all our people from Nebraska and Iowa," said Duane West, a retired lawyer and former city commissioner. "But the simple fact is that this is hard, tough work, and farm boys just didn't want it."
The Mexicans, Salvadorans, Vietnamese, Cambodians and Laotians who showed up to do the plant's dirty work presented no economic threat. In fact, the town offered IBP a decade's worth of tax breaks, and issued $100 million in bonds to help finance construction. The meat-packing plants were seen as the key to future prosperity, and that set the tone for the polite reception the thousands of new immigrants received.
Garden City is a town that prides itself on civility.
"Basically, there isn't anyone here with the intestinal fortitude to raise heck," Mr. West said. "Sometimes, when you do speak out, people look at you like you're crazier than a pet coon. This really isn't a clash-y kind of community,"
Still, while conflict has been kept to a minimum, so has contact between the old-timers and the newcomers.
"Except for driving down the streets, I don't much notice them immigrants," Greg Ayers, a 37-year-old cowboy, said. "But now, my boy, he's in the second grade and he probably has more Mexican friends than Americans, and they're, well, just buds."
 
Transients Challenge The Staid Heartland
 The Garden City area's past claims to fame were the 1959 murder of the Clutter family in outlying Holcomb (immortalized in Truman Capote's "In Cold Blood") and the nation's largest free concrete municipal swimming pool. Now Garden -- as its residents call it -- is renowned not only as the state's fastest-growing town, but also as its most cosmopolitan one.
Where else in Kansas would a 10-year-old girl born in Laos and raised in a refugee camp in Thailand proudly declare that she, Sopha Bounthasen, loved America and her favorite American food: "Tacos!"
At least 20 percent of the town is now foreign born -- compared with 7.9 percent nationally -- and 40 percent is nonwhite. New immigrants keep arriving, many from California and Texas. Some are recruited by relatives, who are paid a small bounty by the plants. Some come without any job guarantees, gambling that life is easier in Kansas.
Bob Ma, a Vietnamese refugee, and his wife, Elba, a Mexican, met in Los Angeles, where they lived from hand to mouth on their earnings in construction and garment jobs. Now, after six months at IBP here, they own a used van and have made a down payment on the trailer they share with their son, Richard. The trailer is already home, with a new videocassette recorder in one corner, a shrine of apples and incense to Mr. Ma's mother in another.
"Over there, in L.A., it's too wild and expensive," said Mr. Ma, 29."Over here, it's boring but it's better. The kids play outside on the street, and you don't worry about gangs and drugs. And you don't got to stay forever. You can save up and move on."
Indeed, the immigrant population has proved to be a transient one, in part because turnover in the hazard-ridden packing industry is so high, averaging about 7 percent a month, said Donald Stull, a University of Kansas anthropologist.
Tracking new students entering the school system in 1986, a study by Dr. Stull for the Ford Foundation found that only a third remained in town two years later.
A rare few immigrants have made a commitment to Garden City, among them, Donald T. To, the town's first Vietnamese insurance agent, who started in the plants nine years ago. "I'm trying to put down roots in this area," he said.
But many more cannot see their lives here beyond the immediate future. "If they can get out and be their own boss, that's a goal," said Levita Rohlman, refugee services director here for the United States Catholic Conference. "So there is a lot of out-migration to Texas, Hawaii, Louisiana."
The police chief, Roger A. Schroeder holds the newcomers' transience -- especially the movement of young, single males -- partly responsible for the 54 percent increase in violent crimes between 1987 and 1992.
But, paradoxically, the transience has also worked to keep tensions low. Absorbed in their six-day-a-week jobs with no plans for a future here, many immigrants lead a wholly separate life that does not threaten the town's traditional identity.
Indeed, despite all the change, despite the publication of a Spanish-language weekly by The Garden City Telegram, despite the Vietnamese-language mass at St. Dominic's Church, despite the new Buddhist temple, there is surprising constancy.
The town is still perfumed by dung. It is still adorned by a 40-year-old sign advising, "Eat Beef, Stay Slim." It still counts only one Asian police officer, and one Hispanic and one Asian teacher in core courses at the high school. And its power still lies in the hands of an elite of old-timers who mix little with the immigrants who tend to live and work on the edge of town.
And sometimes it is the immigrants themselves who keep things segregated. Recently, 75 Laotians put down $5,000 each toward a 120-acre lot that they intend to convert into a "Laotown" if the city permits.
 
A Gracious Facade Masks Latent Biases
 One recent afternoon, Bountome Pheuahakphay, who swam the Mekong River to escape his homeland in 1984, parked his U-Haul in East Garden Village, a mobile home park built for packing-house workers. Mr. Pheuahakphay had arrived the previous night from Fresno, where, despite an engineering degree, he had lived off public assistance.
One night, in Fresno, he had met a Laotian from Garden City, who was in California to persuade welfare-dependent refugees to start over again in the heartland, moving at taxpayer expense as part of a Federal program.
"We tell them, 'We guarantee that if you listen to us you will save $12,000 to $15,000 a family your first year,' " said Roger Vilaysing, executive director of the Southeast Asian Mutual Assistance Association here. "We tell them, 'It's easy job, meat-packing, if you know how to sharpen your knife.' We tell them, 'In Garden City, the kids see parents work hard, want to please parents, obey parents. Not like in California.' "
Mr. Pheuahakphay had nothing to lose, and neither did Oudom Vongphakdy, another Laotian from Fresno. Mr. Vongphakdy, however, was somewhat unsettled by his first glimpse of East Garden's flat, unwooded acres on the outskirts of town. "This looks just like a refugee camp," he said.
In 1987, several years after East Garden Village opened, a new elementary school was built nearby. Victor Ornelas Elementary was known "with a lot of animosity as that school for those kids," said Ms. Thompson, a teacher there. When the school district proposed busing some white children there, parents rebelled. It was as close as Garden City has come to a public confrontation over the town's changing population.
Now, the 6-year-old school, spacious and modern, has a devoted staff that prides itself on adapting to an America that defies the Norman Rockwell image of their childhood. A kindergarten teacher joked recently about preparing a bulletin board of student self-portraits, where crayon-drawn faces were decorated with colored yarn for hair.
"It's not like the old days," said the teacher, Linda Walker. "I didn't need much yellow yarn, as you can see."
Officially, from the police chief to the grocery store manager who stocks chilies and peanut sauces in staggering varieties, the town sees its cultural diversity as an asset. Townspeople proudly distinguish Garden City from neighboring Dodge City.
Recently, the chairwoman of the Dodge City Commission, Laura Carlson, was quoted in the local paper comparing illegal immigrants to cockroaches: "If you spray for them there, they only end up here." She said she had been misunderstood, but her comment nurtured latent xenophobia, prompting one newspaper letter announcing the formation of a citizen's militia.
Although such public outbursts are not Garden City's style, ethnic animosity does exist -- in muttered remarks behind closed doors about the "wetbacks" and the "gooks," about Wal-Mart turning into "Wal-Mex."
Penney Schwab, Western Kansas director for the United Methodist Care Centers, said: "If you were able to take a secret poll here, you'd find a lot of closet Laura Carlsons who have been careful to keep their mouth shut. Garden is not perfect, just polite."

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: City Seeks to Grow by Disappearing

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEMPHIS

 BODY:
Like other big city mayors, W. W. Herenton of Memphis was concerned that employers were fleeing to the suburbs and that white city residents were fleeing as well. But Mr. Herenton recently took a gamble that few other mayors would take: he proposed that his city merge with the suburbs in surrounding Shelby County.
To be sure, suburban officials are wary about the proposal. For one thing, said the Mayor of one suburban city, Germantown, Charles Salvaggio, no suburban political leaders were included on a committee that Mr. Herenton appointed on Oct. 12 to look into the legal issues in such a merger. 
 In addition, Mr. Salvaggio said, Mr. Herenton was vague about what would happen to the predominantly black city school system and the predominantly white county school system. Two years ago, Mr. Salvaggio said, an effort to merge the two school systems foundered, largely because of opposition from the suburbs.
Mr. Herenton, the first black mayor of Memphis, did find some mild support for his suggestion among business leaders in Memphis, who maintain that a merger would lessen the tax burden they now carry. But many black officials said the suggestion had all the attractiveness of "A Modest Proposal" by Swift, in which he suggests, albeit satirically, that citizens solve their overpopulation problem by eating their young.
 
Opposition in City
 "For me personally, this idea was dead on arrival," said Jerome Rubin, one of six black members of the 13-member Memphis City Council. "This would mean a dilution of the black voting strength here and giving up some of the political control we have fought for for so long."
What was particularly curious to some black political leaders was that the proposal came from a man whose election two years ago came by the slimmest of margins -- 142 votes.
"The black citizens of Memphis have been deprived of political power for so long and there is an understandable jubilation at my election as mayor," Mr. Herenton said, acknowledging in an interview the poor reception his idea of merger has had among blacks. But, he added, "I have an obligation to look down the road to see that we don't end up like other cities have."
Outside Memphis some urban economists and experts on regionalization said they saw Mr. Herenton's proposal as a welcome, but surprising, echo of a kind of thinking that flourished in the early 1960's.
 
Idea Stalled by Realities
 At that time, the talk was of better allocation of resources in metropolitan areas, and such consolidations were seen as magic pills that would cure some ills born of urbanization. Cities like Indianapolis, Nashville and Jacksonville, Fla., embraced a metropolitan form of government.
But the idea ran into the political reality of established government structures, as well as suburban whites jealously guarding their racially and economically homogenous enclaves and urban blacks benefiting from a rising tide of political power.
"The way American politics is set up, it encourages a kind of defensive localism that runs counter to consolidation," said Margaret Weir, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institute. "But this is a bold gamble by Herenton, and if he wins, he is going to mayor of someplace that has resources to work with."
David Rusk, a consultant and author of "Cities Without Suburbs" (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1993), said that while "it is not a sinking ship, Memphis has sprung some leaks" in recent years, much as Detroit, Cleveland and Newark had at one time. An opening to the suburbs, he said, was the only real alternative for such cities.
 
Barriers to Annexation
 In the 40 years from 1940 to 1980, Memphis managed through annexation of suburbs to capture 54 percent of the population growth in its metropolitan area, picking up new taxable properties and middle-income subdivisions. But by 1980, annexation became a more difficult and litigious process, and it virtually stopped.
Consequently, in the last decade Memphis lost 36,000 people, or nearly 6 percent of its 1980 population of 646,000. By contrast, the population of surrounding Shelby County more than doubled to 215,000 people from 1970 to 1990. Total jobs in Memphis declined slightly over the decade while they more than doubled in Shelby County.
These were some of the grim trends that greeted Mayor Herenton when he came into office nearly two years ago and a large part of why he said he had been forced to raise taxes each year. While the city is holding on now, he said, analysts project that the city will face a budget deficit of nearly $50 million in three years.
At the same time, Lakeland, a city of 12,000, moved to annex a mostly white, unincorporated area between it and Memphis, which the larger city sought to annex. Lakeland countered with a lawsuit that was supported by a suit by the more than 10,000 residents of the area to be annexed.
 
Sharp Change of Course
 That was when Mayor Herenton made his proposal to consider consolidation rather than the slow, piecemeal annexation route to expanding the city's tax base.
Mr. Herenton said he did not know what measures the city could legally take in a drive to consolidation, but he named a committee of lawyers, state legislators and others to look at the options, which could include a direct vote in the city and county, the city's surrender of its charter or some entirely new route.
Lest anyone think that he was surrendering politically, Mr. Herenton, who before being elected mayor served as the city's first black school superintendent, made it clear that if the city and county consolidated, he would quickly declare himself a candidate to lead the new municipal entity.
He reasoned that the entire county was 44 percent black, and that that percentage could increase over the next eight years, possibly making Memphis the first area with a metropolitan government to have a black majority. If that did not happen, he said, he believed that he could put together the right combination of black and white support to win.
He noted with some satisfaction that whatever the gaps in his proposals, he had at least started people thinking and talking about the idea and looking at the city's future.
"If we can't employ some sort of consolidation to recapture our tax base, then we will go back to using annexation," he said. "But in the end I believe that the progressive cities of the future will be those that will not allow the growth of the suburbs to strip them of their own potential for growth."
The proposal's supporters are largely white business leaders and white middle-class residents of Memphis, although most have decided to remain on the sidelines for now.
J. R. (Pitt) Hyde, the chairman and chief executive of AutoZone Inc., a Memphis-based chain operating more than 800 auto parts stores in 23 states, said that in many ways the fate of the idea is largely dependent on Mr. Herenton and his perseverance and political standing.
"Herenton has the confidence of a good percentage of the white community and business community," Mr. Hyde said, "and he is perhaps the person who can head off fears among blacks about the dilution of power. It is no small feat, but he may be the unique individual to bring this off."

HEADLINE: STANDOFF IN HAITI;
Terror of Duvalier Years Is Haunting Haiti Again

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 17

 BODY:
When President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier fled in 1986 after a popular uprising, Haitians thought for sure that they had rid themselves of the family dynasty that ruled the country with a tight grip for 29 years.
But the Duvalierists, once operating clandestinely, are now out in the open, in a sort of recurring nightmare. In the last month, several military-backed political organizations have been formed with the common goal of preventing the return of Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President, who was ousted two years ago in a violent coup. 
 Haitian political analysts and foreign diplomats say these groups have mounted a campaign of intimidation and terror, exemplified by the shooting of Justice Minister Guy Malary, who was killed in broad daylight last week, along with his chauffeur and a bodyguard.
But Emmanuel Constant, a leader of the Front for Haitian Advancement and Progress, an organization suspected of being behind some of the killings, denies any involvement.
 
'We Want Peace and Stability'
 "The violence comes from the clashing of the extreme political ideologies," Mr. Constant said. "We want peace and stability. We want to care for our sick and we want to teach our young."
Mr. Constant said his organization had used only traditional means of protest, like strikes and marches, to express opposition to Father Aristide. While Mr. Constant's organization and other groups like it are given police escorts when they call a protest, supporters of Father Aristide are routinely beaten when they try to congregate.
For example, Antoine Izmery, a wealthy businessman and supporter of Father Aristide, was shot and killed at St. Jean Bosco Church, Father Aristide's old parish, after refusing to cancel a church service mourning the anniversary of a massacre.
 
'Mockery of Patriotism'
 On Saturday, when another shadowy group called for a night of "patriotic mourning" and a demonstration at Haiti's largest public square, the Champ Mars, only a lavalas, or torrential rain, dampened the rally, which was sparsely attended.
"They are perpetrating a huge fraud," said Jocelyn McCalla, executive director of the National Coalition for the Haitian Refugees, in New York. "They are not fooling anyone in Haiti. They are making a mockery of patriotism. They're trying to cast themselves as the symbol of democracy."
While leaders of these groups have told foreign journalists in Haiti that they are not Duvalierists, they have given interviews to Haitian journalists welcoming followers of the Duvaliers into their groups.
The Duvalier reign began in 1957 after the election of Francois Duvalier, known as Papa Doc. He proclaimed himself President-for-Life in 1964. After his death, his son, Jean-Claude, called Baby Doc, inherited the title and presided until 1986.
Francois Duvalier's deeply conservative ideology, which he called Duvalierism, began as an effort to uplift Haiti's black masses but quickly reached a social pact with the lighter-skinned elite. It justifies total control over the state by a single party and the use of violence to perpetuate its power.
To carry this out, Mr. Duvalier developed the Tontons Macoute, a paramilitary group using illiterate peasants, responsible only to him and armed them with weapons. Their trademark attire was denim shirt and pants and dark glasses.
 
Sign of Terror: Red Bandanas
 The new group of armed civilians are also illiterate peasants, but they wear civilian clothes and red bandanas around their necks. Called attaches, the carry out terror under the command of the city's police chief, Lieut. Col. Joseph Michel Francois.
An attache who gave his name only as Raymond said he had joined the group because he believed that Father Aristide had sold Haiti to foreigners. Until a month ago, he said, he was unemployed but now he is paid $40 to $50 a week. Raymond, a lanky 29-year-old, said his work was "to protect the sovereignty of the nation."
In a 30-minute interview at a downtown restaurant, Raymond spoke in monotone and gave what seemed to be well-rehearsed responses to questions.
 
With the Aid of Lobbyists
 "Aristide is a criminal," he said when asked why he did not like him. "He wanted to burn people alive."
While Raymond's answers may be simple, the leaders of the political organizations, who control the attaches, are sophisticated and have studied in the United States and Canada.
They have carefully cultivated lobbyists and politicians to feed doubts about Father Aristide.
"He speaks like a sheep, but he acts like a wolf," Reynold Georges, a leader of one organization, the Alliance for the Liberation and Advancement of Haiti, said about the deposed President.

HEADLINE: MISSION IN SOMALIA;
Amid Cheers for Pilot, Tears for Dead

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 17

 BODY:
Along the road leading to the entrance to Fort Campbell, the signs in front of dozens of businesses read "Welcome Home Michael Durant, NSDQ." In this most military of towns, only an outsider and the uninitiated had to ask what NSDQ meant, and when they did, the answer was uttered like some magical incantation.
"N.S.D.Q. are the initials of the motto of the 160th, Mike's unit," said Loretta South, the wife of another member of the unit. "The unit is called the Night Stalkers and the motto is 'Night Stalkers don't quit.' " 
 The joy of Chief Warrant Officer Michael Durant's return home late Saturday from 11 days as a hostage in Somalia was still fresh today, although the mood was more somber and meditative than it was amid the flag waving and cheering of the night before.
 
Mindful of Other Casualties
 Many of the people leaving church services were mindful not only of the Durant family, but of the families of those still stationed in Somalia and the families of eight Fort Campbell soldiers who died in Mogadishu.
"A yellow ribbon is not enough for them," said the wife of one soldier who is still in Somalia as she stood with glistening eyes outside of Bethel United Methodist Church. "President Clinton called the Durants, but he didn't call the families of those who died," said the woman, who asked not to be quoted by name. "A crisis is over for the Durants, but those other families' crisis will go on and on."
Balancing the joy at return and sadness of loss is tricky in places like Clarksville (population 70,000) and Hopkinsville, Ky., (population 27,000), the two communities bordering Fort Campbell. Maj. Gen. John M. Keane, commander of the installation, said having a hero in Michael Durant was important because "it lets us take a burden off our shoulders and feel genuinely good about something."
 
Puts Arms Around a Widow
 But he said he had made it a point during the jubilation on Saturday night to speak to a widow of one of the soldiers who died in the fighting in which Mr. Durant was injured and "put my arms around her and tell her how much I respected her and her courage for being there."
There are more than 25,000 military men and women at Fort Campbell, which is the home of the 101st Air Assault Division, or the Screaming Eagles, as well as Mr. Durant's 160th Special Operations Regiment, many of whose missions are secret. There are also 35,000 relatives as well as 42,000 military retirees, said George Heath, a spokesman for Fort Campbell.
Because there is housing for only 4,200 or so on the base, most of the soldiers and their families live off the base. More than 4,000 children of military personnel attend local public schools. Many of the wives, Lorrie Durant among them, teach in those schools. The base payroll contributes $897 million a year to the local economy.
The euphoria was just too much for some here. Amy Jo Nichols-Redman chose not to go to the welcome home for Mr. Durant, she said, not because he did not deserve it, but rather because it brought back too vividly memories of December 1985, when her husband was among the 248 Fort Campbell troops who died when a plane carrying them home from a Middle East peacekeeping mission crashed near Gander, Newfoundland.
Ms. Nichols-Redman, who is active in military family support programs, recalled going to the airfield then to welcome home others who were not on the plane. She went bravely, caught up in the relief of others, but it all felt awful, she said. She said that during Saturday's events, she kept asking herself, what about the widows?
 
A Memorial Service
 "We had a memorial service for the dead last week while Michael was still a captive, and I remember running into a 12-year-old boy whose father died about eight months ago over there," she said. "He said to me that he hoped Michael Durant got freed, but also said that nobody remembered his dad's name. So I just couldn't go the other night."
It all troubled the Rev. Phil Ross, pastor of New Provident United Methodist Church, where the Durants are members. But today Mr. Ross said he, like General Keane, had found his answer to the problem of sorrow amid celebration late Saturday night at the Durants' home.
He saw some widows of those killed in Somalia stop to visit members of the Durant family. "If they can embrace Lorrie and celebrate even after their loss of loved ones, then we all should be able to," he said.

HEADLINE: Despite U.S. Urging, Arab Lands Hold Firm to Their Israel Boycott

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Diplomats said today that the 43-year-old Arab ban on commercial and financial ties with Israel would not be lifted anytime soon and that the official blacklist of foreign companies that do business with Israel might even be expanded at the urging of hard-line countries.
Arab League officials are to meet in Damascus on Oct. 24 to discuss increasing the blacklist despite appeals from United States officials, who argue that the boycott of 10,000 companies should be lifted soon to add momentum to Middle East peace talks. 
 Assistant Secretary of State Edward P. Djerejian told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Friday in Washington that the Arab blacklist was "totally unacceptable."
 
The Wrong Direction
 He said the Clinton Administration had told several Arab countries, including Syria, that adding companies to the list "would be a step, obviously, in the wrong direction" after the signing of an accord last month by Israel and the Palestinians.
But Arab diplomats in Damascus and Cairo said that hard-line Arab countries like Syria, Iraq and Libya were seeking to widen the boycott, in part because they were unhappy with the accord.
"Any lifting or alteration of the boycott," said a senior Arab diplomat, "would have to be unanimous, and since unanimity is impossible, it will remain in force."
 
States Set Conditions
 Even moderate Arab governments like Saudi Arabia's, which is struggling to contain strong Islamic militant movements, are reluctant to support a repeal because they do not want to give ammunition to their Islamic hard-line critics, the diplomats said. Militant Islamic groups have denounced the pact on self-rule in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip and Jericho as a sellout that compromises Palestinians' interests.
Several Arab officials said they would be reluctant to give up the boycott as long as Israel has nuclear weapons, continues to occupy Gaza, the West Bank, the Golan Heights and southern Lebanon and fails to reach an agreement with its neighbors on sharing scarce water.
The boycott was adopted by Arab countries in 1950 to isolate and cripple Israel. The Arab League operates a Boycott Office in Damascus where Arab representatives are to meet this month to consider adding new companies to the list, the Arab diplomats in Cairo and Damascus said. During its last meeting, on May 1, the Boycott Office added 13 new companies to the list, including Rubbermaid and General Dynamics.
"It is too soon to talk about lifting the boycott," Fahem bin Sultan al-Qasimi, the Secretary General of the Gulf Cooperation Council, was quoted today as saying by the Arabic daily Al Hayat.
 
Three Aspects
 The boycott includes a ban on commercial activity with Israel and a "secondary boycott" that blacklists companies doing business in Israel. A tertiary boycott targets companies dealing with blacklisted companies.
The Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce estimates that the boycott has cost the country $20 billion in lost exports and $16 to $32 billion in lost investment. But Arab officials contend that the losses are probably much smaller because of Arab violations of the ban. Saudi Arabia, along with other Arab states, already ignores the boycott when it is commercially convenient, these officials said.
Israel sells agricultural products, furniture and electrical appliances, valued at several hundred million dollars a year, to Arab countries -- including Lebanon, Libya and Iraq -- through third countries, including Greece and Cyprus, Arab diplomats and Israeli officials say.
Most gulf countries buy weapons from American companies that are also Israel's main military suppliers. "When it is in the Arab interest, they turn a blind eye to the sanctions," said Harry Wall, director of the Israeli Office of the Anti-Defamation League, in a telephone interview from Jerusalem.
Ford, General Dynamics, General Electric, Hilton, General Motors, Coca-Cola, Hertz and Avis are among the companies that do business with Israel and some Arab countries. Most major international banks and large financial institutions, however, refuse to do business with Israel because of a fear of Arab restrictions.
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said in 1991 that he would push for an end to the "secondary boycott" or blacklist if the Israeli Government, then led by Yitzhak Shamir, stopped building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
But the proposal was never accepted by other Arab nations.
"It was refused by Shamir at the time," Mr. Mubarak said in a recent interview.
Israel's current Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, has said that he will not link the lifting of the boycott to the current autonomy negotiations with the Palestinians.
"Israel cannot at present demand the lifting of the boycott as a condition for talks with the Palestinians," Mr. Rabin said last week.
 
Seen as an Insult
 But Israeli organizations that have tried to fight the boycott said the move was a slap in the face to Israel.
"The continuation of the boycott, the most tangible symbol of the refusal to recognize Israel's right to exist, is incompatible with the goal of the peace process," Mr. Wall said.
The determination to extend the boycott has stirred anger in many Western nations and in Japan. The leaders of the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations called last summer at a meeting in Tokyo for an end to the boycott.
Some Arab states, including Kuwait, have already officially eased restrictions on companies that do business in Israel.
Even Egypt, which has been at peace with Israel since 1979, has failed to develop significant trade links with its neighbor, despite numerous commercial agreements.

MIDEAST PEACE TALKS DELAYED
 JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The United States has told Israel that the next round of Middle East peace talks will probably be postponed until the end of November, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.
The talks were expected to resume in late October, but an Israeli official said the reason for the delay was a Syrian threat on Saturday not to attend unless Israel was willing to make progress.
