HEADLINE: Turks' War With Kurds Reaches a New Ferocity

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey, Oct. 15

 BODY:
One year after Turkish generals said they had broken the spine of a Kurdish separatist insurgency in these wild and remote uplands, the war has become more violent and more intractable than ever before.
Since the breakdown in May of a cease-fire declared by the rebel movement, the avowedly Marxist Kurdish Workers Party, more than 1,600 people, many of them civilians, have died, the Government says. That toll amounts to the worst wave of killing in a nine-year war that has claimed more than 7,400 lives and raised fundamental questions about the stability of an area central to regional American policy. 
 The fighting in the hidden war is murky, depicted in the mutually exclusive versions of both sides as either a liberation struggle championing Kurdish rights or outright terrorism. Death tolls, battles and guerrilla attacks in the remote southeastern region are difficult to verify, particularly because of glaring discrepancies in the reports.
[In yet another battle, Turkish troops killed 12 Kurdish guerrillas in a shootout Sunday in Lice, in Diyarbakir province, according to a statement from the regional governor's office. No details were disclosed, and there was no announcement from the Kurdish side.]
Nonetheless, the accounts of Government officials, Kurdish nationalists and diplomats in Ankara suggest that the antagonists are locked in an accelerating spiral of violence, from the torching of villages and kidnappings of Westerners to slayings of civilians and street killings.
The ferocity of the attacks has left the United States and other Western allies of Turkey wondering whether the war can ever be ended without political concessions and a major shift from what the Government in Ankara calls "total warfare."
 
A Popular Insurgency
 "The United States point is that this is an approach that can be predicted to fail if you look at it in exclusively military terms," a Western diplomat in Ankara said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "This is now a popular insurgency," the diplomat said.
But Western governments do not press that argument with the American-armed Turks, in part because they agree with Ankara's depiction of the rebels as terrorists. Equally important, Turkey is a NATO ally playing a crucial role in keeping up economic and military pressure on President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
The rebel movement touches an extremely raw nerve for the Turkish Government, which sees the war as an outright challenge to the very cornerstone of the state -- the model of linguistic, cultural and political unity championed by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of the republic.
 
Redefining the Problem
 "No country will shake the hands of those who want to divide the country through killing or terrorism," Foreign Minister Hikmet Cetin said in an interview before he left with Prime Minister Tansu Ciller on her trip to meet with President Clinton and legislators.
"Some of our friends think we have a problem between Turkish and Kurdish citizens," Mr. Cetin said, but "the problem is between the security forces and the killing organization -- the terrorism groups. Turkey is a democratic country and in a democratic country terrorism cannot be tolerated whatever its aim."
Between 10 million and 12 million people, about a fifth of the nation's population, are Kurds. While Turkish leaders permit the publication of Kurdish-language newspapers and acknowledge what they term a "Kurdish reality," the Government does not allow the Kurds to use their own language in schools or in broadcasting, or acknowledge a separate Kurdish national identity. Kurds, who are largely Sunni Muslims, enjoy the same political rights as other Turks but may not express them in a Kurdish linguistic, political or regional context.
For many people in this southeastern region, such restrictions are part of the basic grievance of Kurdish nationalists: while many Kurds probably do not wish to secede from Turkey, as the insurgents do, their identity as a people is denied. The war, though, has brought them neither progress nor hope.
 
Very Bleak Picture

 "The people have had enough," said Fathi Gumus, a Kurdish lawyer and chairman of the bar association here. "The war is bloodier than ever. Both sides are getting rougher and rougher. The picture is very bleak."
The country's Kurds are the largest of the Kurdish populations who live uneasily in Iraq, Iran and Syria, as well as in Turkey.
Up to a half of Turkey's Kurds have emigrated west from their mountainous homelands seeking jobs or peace. But those who have stayed behind have faced the growing violence between some 150,000 Turkish troops, militiamen and the police and an estimated 10,000 guerrillas operating from bases inside Turkey with support from Syria, Iraq, Iran and, according to Turkish officials, Armenia.
The Government in Ankara has long believed that if its armed forces could sever the ties between the rebels and Turkey's hostile neighbors, the battle would be all but won.
 
Rebel Cease-Fire Offered
 A year ago, therefore, Ankara enlisted the tacit support of Kurds in northern Iraq, who have depended on Turkey for their survival since the Persian Gulf war, in a campaign of air strikes and infantry advances against Turkish Kurds who were operating in part from bases just across the border. The Turkish military declared it had dealt the rebels a lethal blow, and when a Syrian-based guerrilla leader, Abdullah Ocalan, offered to stop fighting in March, the move seemed to reinforce Turkey's view.
"The Turkish view was that they had them on the ropes," the diplomat in Ankara said. "If they were on the ropes, then they have rebounded now."
Since the rebels called off the cease-fire on May 24 with an attack in which 33 Turkish soldiers were killed, they have kidnapped and released 26 foreign tourists (and claim to be still holding an American and a New Zealander). They have also dented Turkey's tourism industry with low-level violence in Mediterranean resorts and in Istanbul. Their area of operations has also broadened westward and northward from the Kurdish heartland. On Oct. 5 Kurdish rebels struck in Siirt and Batman provinces, killing 37 civilians.
Strengthened by their own tactics of intimidation and by the resentment caused by the Government's treatment of many Kurdish civilians, the guerrillas cast themselves increasingly as defenders of the Kurdish identity.
Some of the guerrillas say they ultimately hope to establish a Kurdish state in the region. But in offering the cease-fire, the rebels scaled back that demand and told Turkish Kurds they were seeking a negotiated settlement within Turkey that would acknowledge Kurdish rights, said Hatit Dicle, one of 17 Kurds in the 450-seat Parliament.
"As long as Government forces attack not only P.K.K. sympathizers but also those who are living peacefully in their homes, the number of P.K.K. sympathizers will increase," Mr. Gumus said in an interview here, using the Kurdish initials for the Kurdish Workers Party.
"The P.K.K.'s strength lies mostly in the fact that the state has ceased to be a state in this region," he said.
But the rebels themselves have made targets of villages known to be sympathetic to the Government and that are protected by the "village guard" system set up by the Turks to counter the insurgency. Men, women and children in such villages have all been slain without mercy, as they were on Oct. 5.
 
Vulnerable to Both Sides
 Living in small huts and houses with flat roofs, with small herds and farming plots, Kurdish civilians are vulnerable to both sides. Diplomats and Kurdish nationalists say hundreds of villages have been evacuated or torched by Government forces seeking to deprive the guerrillas of help.
In the towns and cities, hundreds of slayings of Kurdish journalists, newspaper vendors and in one case a Kurdish lawmaker remain unexplained.
Yet the Government seems unwilling or unable to consider political overtures or to take control of military decision-making. The killings of Turkish troops in the southeast has deepened the resentment among many Turkish civilians toward the Kurds, so the Government senses it has broad support for its tactics. That does not leave much room for maneuvering.
Prime Minister Ciller found out as much this month when she told a group of Turkish journalists that Turkey might explore a solution similar to the one found by Spain in dealing with Basque separatists, sealing borders to gunmen while offering political incentives. Such was the uproar from the military and powerful politicians like President Suleyman Demirel that she told her followers a few days that she had never said anything of the kind.
"The P.K.K. has been very successful at politicizing and polarizing" Kurdish and Turkish society, said a diplomat in Ankara.
"There's a sense among the Kurds that the Government's focus on a military solution takes away the mask and reveals the antipathy of Turks toward Kurds. So the Kurds are prepared to see P.K.K. as their only voice."

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Even as Top Priority, the Health Plan Bogs Down

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The White House sales pitch for its health care program began to veer off track even as President Clinton was delivering one of the biggest speeches of his career, the address to Congress laying out his goals for the health plan.
By then, Mr. Clinton knew that inflation estimates were creeping upward and that the staff of the health care task force would be forced to revise the financial assumptions. 
 Then, some members of Congress rejected the Administration's offer to draw up a legislative outline that would have given the lawmakers something to work with while the White House gained some breathing room to hash out the final details.
And in spite of persuasive appearances by Hillary Rodham Clinton before several Congressional committees, the momentum that had been building for the health care package began to diminish as foreign policy crises occupied increasing attention. With other matters at center stage, Administration officials began to receive complaints from Congress that health care details were lacking.
 
Clear to Sluggish
 What was supposed to be a clear and simple plan to sell a set of overarching principles to the American people disintegrated into a sluggish uphill effort to keep the message strong and clear.
The President's aides have admitted some tactical errors, one being the public relations vacuum that developed since Mr. Clinton spoke on Sept. 22 and after Mrs. Clinton testified. But they also said attention was siphoned off by events in Russia, Somalia and Haiti.
Administration officials now predict the legislative draft will reach Capitol Hill next week.
"We really didn't think we would be asked, 'Where is the legislation?' when we thought everybody knew we were working as fast as we could to get the legislation up there," a senior White House aide said last week. "We thought more what would be asked would be, 'What's your evidence that this is a good idea?' "
 
Uncharted Territory
 Assuming that members of Congress would follow that game plan, the White House had summoned Gov. John Waihee 3d of Hawaii to Washington to testify about his state's universal health care plan. But Governor Waihee cooled his heels during his time in Washington without being called to testify. Meanwhile, lawmakers took to the floor of the House and Senate, demanded the details about financing and presented their own alternative plans.
White House officials say the Administration has not been given enough credit for attempting to cope with the complexity of putting together a health care plan. When Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, suggested recently that the actual legislation might yet be several weeks away, the howls of complaint from Capitol Hill forced the White House to move up the schedule.
"You are dealing in an area that is kind of new," said Gene Sperling, a White House economic policy deputy. "When we were doing the budget, a lot of the 200 spending cuts we did had been floating around for several years."
Deprived of the opportunity to remain on the high ground and fuss with the details later, Administration officials hope to regain the initiative in coming weeks with a second start to the health care campaign.
 
No Small Test
 The new push will revolve around the release of a revamped version of the plan, which aides said had been changed to reflect some early criticisms about regulation and to include financing mechanisms.
"This is really a question of allocation of time and resources and travel," said Mandy Grunwald, a media consultant who works for the White House.
She added, "Whether health care reform is front and center at any given moment is not going to make or break public support for the health care plan."
The Administration's ability to sell health care is no small test. By linking the prospects for the health care measure to the rest of his domestic initiatives, Mr. Clinton has opened the possibility that if one part fails, the rest will be seriously weakened.
James MacGregor Burns, the political historian, recalled asking Mr. Clinton during the Presidential campaign how he planned to cope with the intractable problems he would face in the White House. "Persistence," the President replied.
Mr. Burns observed: "History shows again and again that if you stick to your guns and don't compromise unduly, your sheer persistence is such that people will come around to you. There is something impressive about someone who is not constantly compromising and retreating."
But now, Mr. Burns added, there had been more compromise than persistence at the White House, and he worried that this would be reflected in the handling of the health care plan.
Some White House aides subscribe to Mr. Burns's theory of persistence and have suggested in recent interviews that compromise on the health care plan can be taken only so far.
Mr. Clinton has concentrated on linking the health care plan to other pressing domestic matters, but it has nevertheless taken a back seat at times. In his weekly radio address on Saturday, he emphasized the importance of passing the North American Free Trade Agreement and did not mention health care.
This does not faze the President's top health care advisers, who say all domestic policy initiatives are interrelated. Their view is that a greater danger, uncontrollable because of its unpredictability, is that foreign policy crises will continue to seize center stage for the indefinite future.
"Everything's been overshadowed," Ms. Grunwald said. "In an ideal world, would you prefer not to have foreign policy issues come up three weeks after the launch of the health plan? Sure. But the world goes on, and the President has to act."

HEADLINE: Republican Leading In Virginia Contest, Voter Survey Shows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Once behind in the polls, the Republican in the race to be Virginia's next governor now has a wide lead over the Democrat less than three weeks before the election, according to a new poll.
The poll, released Saturday by The Richmond Times-Dispatch and WWBT-TV, showed 50 percent of voters surveyed supporting the Republican, George F. Allen, and 33 percent backing Mary Sue Terry, with 17 percent undecided. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points. 
 The two are fighting to succeed L. Douglas Wilder, a Democrat and the nation's first black elected governor, who is prevented by state law from seeking a second consecutive term.
The next governor's race in Louisiana, however, will feature a familiar player: Gov. Edwin W. Edwards, who on Saturday declared his intention to seek a fifth four-year term.
 
Repeat of '91 in Louisiana?
 Despite polls earlier this year that showed his popularity at an all-time low, Mr. Edwards, 66, said a boost in the state's economy from legalized gambling would help him win in 1995.
He also predicted that the 1995 race would mirror that of 1991, ending in a runoff between him and David Duke, the former Klu Klux Klan leader and state representative. Mr. Duke and former Gov. Buddy Roemer have both hinted that they will seek the office.
A major issue in the Virginia race has been gun control. Ms. Terry, a two-term state attorney general, is pressing for a five-day waiting period for handgun purchases. Mr. Allen, a former Congressman who is the son of the late Washington Redskins coach George Allen, opposes additional gun control in Virginia, which requires a computerized background check for gun buyers. He advocates fighting crime by abolishing parole and building more prisons.
Ms. Terry has also worked to distance herself from President Clinton. Virginia supported George Bush in the last Presidential election.
The telephone survey of 554 registered voters was conducted Monday through Thursday by the research division of Media General Inc., The Times-Dispatch's parent company.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

A BARRIER TO HEALTH-CARE PLANS
Two weeks ago, Earn J. Lloyd of Morris Heights, the Bronx, staggered into the emergency room at Montefiore Medical Center nearly comatose, nearly blind and barely able to walk. Doctors discovered he had severe diabetes, which kept him in the hospital for 10 days. But Mr. Lloyd's more serious medical problem was the lack of a decent general doctor, which for him and hundreds of thousands of others in New York's poorer neighborhoods turns treatable outpatient diseases into life-threatening conditions. This severe deficit of doctors in poor urban neighborhoods will make President Clinton's health-care plan, or any alternative, difficult to carry out in the areas that most need the help. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
DIFFERING SHARPLY ON THE ECONOMY
 As New York City struggles to shake itself out of its worst recession in half a century, the mayoral candidates are offering sharply different prescriptions on how to revive the local economy -- a split that mirrors a national debate over economic policy. The Republican-Liberal challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, contends that fiscal conservatism -- keeping a balanced budget, streamlining city agencies and keeping them off the backs of business -- provides the best hope for the economy. But Mayor Dinkins has unveiled proposals that many see as a sort of industrial policy, with the city marshaling resources to aid 12 industries in the hope that they will become centers of economic growth. A1. 

A SPOILER AND A FOIL?
George J. Marlin, the Conservative Party candidate for mayor, could end up costing Mr. Giuliani vital conservative votes in a contest that polls suggest remains too close to call. Though his support has hovered at only a couple of percentage points, that may change after encounters like the one with Mayor Dinkins yesterday on WNBC-TV, and another last Thursday on the cable channel New York 1. B3.
 
THE MAYORAL CAMPAIGN TACKLES RACE
For three and a half years, Mayor Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani bobbed and feinted toward their electoral rematch, the issue of race a mostly unspoken taboo between them, just as it was in their last campaign. But since President Clinton mused aloud three weeks ago that too many New Yorkers were unwilling to back the Mayor because he is black, all boundaries seem to have fallen. News Analysis. B3.
 
RACE AND ETHNICITY: SHIFTS IN POLITICS
In New York, ethnicity has always been shorthand for distinctions in class and in political factions. Race, in a more visible and indelible way, is providing similar symbolism. Metro Matters by Sam Roberts. B3.
 
DINKINS STRESSES RECYCLING PLAN
Speaking before a group of environmentalists at the foot of Pier 26 in lower Manhattan, Mayor Dinkins said that the city would continue an aggressive program to recycle garbage, replace gas-burning city vehicles with those that burn alternative fuels and buy large tracts of land to protect its reservoirs of drinking water in the Catskill Mountains. B3.
 
IMMIGRATION SEEN AS HURTING CITY
With the largest wave of immigration since the turn of the century raising New York City's foreign-born population to 28 percent, most residents say there are too many immigrants in town and add that while most are law-abiding, they have made the city a worse place to live, a new poll has found. B4.
 
BOND FIRMS SEEK BAN ON DONATIONS
Wall Street's major brokerage firms are poised to announce a plan to voluntarily ban political contributions to government officials and candidates who could award them lucrative municipal bond business. D1.
 
REGION
 
SOUND BITES AND FURY
If this year's race for Suffolk County district attorney sometimes has the feel of a street fight, it is largely because of the intense, combative natures of the two major-party candidates vying to head one of the largest and busiest prosecutor's offices in the state. To some, the race between the incumbent, James M. Catterson Jr., and Patrick Kevin Brosnahan Jr. is a perfect matchup, a convergence of two bulls and one china shop. B5.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
For Race and Ethnicity, Shifts in Roles in Politics

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
RUMINATING on the difference between race and ethnicity in American politics, Representative Charles B. Rangel explained the other day why blacks in particular have not had an easy time inheriting the mantle of municipal power.
"The difference between race and ethnicity is that historically when everyone was out competing they knew at one time their name would get on the ballot," he said. "First the Irish had to wait for the white Anglo-Saxons, and the Italians had to wait for the Irish, and the Jews had to wait for the Italians. But you knew that with party tickets, when your time came, you'd get it. Then they threw away the old rule book because who was up next? The blacks. 
 "While Jews could have pride in seeking a Jew, and the Irish could have pride in Kennedy, when the blacks in Chicago had pride and sought Harold Washington, the white Democrats went bananas and found an unknown -- a Jew, I think -- to run against him as a Republican. What does that mean? Is that ethnicity? I don't think so."
Then what is it? And is it fundamentally different from the social and political resistance that punctuated every racial and ethnic succession since New York City's first minority, the Dutch, achieved hegemony over indigenous Indians?
In New York, ethnicity has always been shorthand for distinctions in class and in political factions. Race, in a more visible and indelible way, is providing similar symbolism.
Immigrants were the major ingredient that perpetuated the Democratic political organizations for generations, spanning the 19th and 20th centuries -- beginning with the Irish, whose peasant values of deference and personal dependency, Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote, made them ideal cogs for the party machine. Cogs grew into big wheels, though, only with the indulgence, or the defeat, of earlier immigrants.
When Irish-Americans presumptuously demanded a regular role in New York City politics a century ago, Mayor Abram S. Hewitt angrily declared that "the danger line has been reached when it must be decided whether American or foreign ideas are to rule this city."
Reformers episodically interrupted the regular organization's reign by uniting nervous business interests with newly arrived immigrants who had not been co-opted by the party machine.
The first Irish Catholic Mayor, William R. Grace, was elected in 1880. Fiorello H. La Guardia, who had adopted the Anglicized name Frank when he first settled in New York in 1906, won in 1933 and was re-elected in spite of, and because of, ethnicity. "In exploiting racial and religous prejudices," Robert Moses wrote, "La Guardia could run circles around the bosses he despised and derided."
The first Jewish mayor (La Guardia was half-Jewish and considered himself Episocopalian) was not elected until 1973. The first black, David N. Dinkins, won in 1989, although the first black candidate for countywide office on a regular party ticket, the Republican nominee for Manhattan borough president, was selected in 1953. If elected, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mr. Dinkins's Republican-Liberal challenger, would be the first mayor with two parents of Italian heritage and who had not (like Vincent R. Impelliteri) served as acting mayor first.
"The difference between racial politics and ethnic voting," former Mayor Edward I. Koch wrote in his book, "Politics," "is this: in racial politics, no distinction is made and you vote simply on the basis of race. In ethnic politics, if the candidates are roughly equal, as perceived, an ethnic group will quite naturally vote for someone they identify with."
Nathan Glazer, the Harvard professor who wrote "Beyond the Melting Pot" 30 years ago with Mr. Moynihan, draws a more subtle distinction. "What was the dominant division in people's minds during previous ethnic successions was not ethnic succession: it was the machine versus the progressives," Mr. Glazer said.
"There was always an underground knowledge, but I just don't believe the whole public discussion was in those terms," he said. "It was a reality, but it wasn't treated that way. This became the surrogate for all class and economic factors. The difference today is the degree of public attention -- the almost total concern. The elements are the same, but the conflict is preserved in a different form.
" The participants are more vividly distinguished" -- meaning more visible but still emblematic of class and economic factors associated with race.
"Glazer and I argued," Mr. Moynihan said, "that ethnicity was the organizing unit of New York politics. When you're talking issues of race, you're talking issues of caste. This is ethnic politics. Race has acquired the pattern of an ethnic group interest."
The city, Mr. Moynihan added, managed to survive every other episode of ethnic politics with minimal dislocation, although party tickets, another victim of political reform, no longer prevail to smooth the transition.
"You're not changing the nature of New York society when there's an Italian mayor finally, or when at long last there's a black police commissioner," the Senator said. "It doesn't require the 82d Airborne."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Plan for Japan's Media Lab Is Stalled

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
A bold and much-debated attempt to establish a Japanese version of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's famous Media Laboratory is suffering from financial and organizational problems and faces an uncertain future, many people involved in the project say.
The idea for the laboratory goes back to 1987, when a Japanese university and business executive signed a contract with M.I.T. The goal was to build a research facility in Japan with the creative atmosphere of M.I.T.'s lab, which is known for its free-wheeling style and ground-breaking developments in multimedia technology and other areas. 
 The project became a symbol in the debate about the proliferation of relationships between American universities and foreign companies. Proponents said the laboratory would promote scientific cooperation between the United States and Japan. Critics called it a crass sale of M.I.T.'s expertise that would lead to Japanese innovations and undermine American competitiveness.
But those arguments are becoming moot because the project is floundering. "The truth is, it never got off the ground," Nicholas Negroponte, the director of the M.I.T. Media Lab, said recently.
The travails show that the collaborative research efforts for which Japan is famous are not always successful. They also demonstrate that the current economic slump in Japan is starting to crimp the ability of its industries to spend money on advanced research, even as they acknowledge that they must make their own breakthroughs if they are to continue to prosper.
In fact, the planned laboratory has not attracted the anticipated financial support of Japanese companies. There has also been a culture clash -- not over research styles, but about organizational strategy -- between some Japanese organizers and Mr. Negroponte.
M.I.T.'s five-year contract to help develop the Japanese lab ended in June 1992. Early this year, Mr. Negroponte resigned from the board of directors of the International Media Research Foundation, the Japanese organization that is trying to establish the lab. That ended M.I.T.'s official connection with the project.
"It was just too slow," Mr. Negroponte said. "It's not my speed. They would not move fast enough."
About the same time, Dr. Tadashi Sasaki, the chairman of the media foundation and one of Japan's most prominent engineers, also quit, in part because of criticism from Mr. Negroponte. Six other Japanese directors followed him off the board.
Construction has not yet started on a big laboratory that was to be built outside Tokyo to house 100 researchers. Instead, there is only a temporary laboratory, staffed by five researchers, in the foundation's office in the basement of a small Tokyo office building. They are working on projects including how to make a computer discern musical rhythms and how to make appliances easier to use by analyzing the workings of the human mind.
 
No Pledges From Companies
 Seiichi Koizumi, secretary general of the foundation, said it still plans to build the laboratory by 1996. He conceded that no companies have yet pledged money but said that fund-raising cannot begin in earnest until a building permit is obtained. Mr. Koizumi called it "regrettable" that Mr. Negroponte had resigned.
In the 1987 agreement, M.I.T. received $10 million to help Japanese scientists recreate its laboratory, where researchers have been pioneers in areas like digital high-definition television, interactive entertainment and personalized electronic newspapers.
The debate over the project grew when critics in the United States said M.I.T. was selling expertise to Japan, where research had often focused on making constant small improvements in existing products, and not on the bursts of inspiration that lead to new products.
Supporters, however, said M.I.T. was not transferring any specific technology, only advice on how to achieve the proper creative atmosphere in the laboratory. Moreover, they said, the money received would help support M.I.T.'s own research.
M.I.T.'s contracts were with two Japanese interests -- Nihon University and Chiyoji Misawa, a developer of prefabricated housing and an alumnus of Nihon. Mr. Misawa's company, Misawa Homes, paid the $10 million to M.I.T.
But the project was plagued by bad luck from the start. In 1990, a scandal at Nihon University involved charges that the yakuza, or members of Japanese organized crime groups, had intimidated a candidate for university president into withdrawing from the election.
To avoid tainting the media laboratory project with a public controversy, Nihon University dropped out. Without a university's involvement, Mr. Negroponte said, it was more difficult for M.I.T. to cooperate.
In April 1992, the International Media Research Foundation was formed to attract broader participation from other universities and from industry. Misawa Homes made another contribution, this time an endowment of 2.5 billion yen, or almost $25 million.
The foundation had the official blessing of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Education. Its chairman, Dr. Sasaki, was known as "Dr. Calculator" for his role in developing Japan's electronic calculator industry, and its board included presidents and past presidents of leading Japanese universities. A separate board of advisers included the presidents of 16 big companies, including Toyota, Sony, Sharp and Canon.
But for several reasons, including a downturn in the economy, the foundation did not succeed in raising money, even from companies that had executives on the advisory board.
 
 
Dispute Over Strategy
 Meanwhile, Dr. Sasaki and Mr. Negroponte disagreed on strategies and roles and wound up leaving the project within weeks of each other. Akira Fujii, an assistant to Dr. Sasaki, said that Dr. Sasaki thought Mr. Negroponte was merely trying to get money from the foundation to spend at M.I.T.
Mr. Negroponte said M.I.T. had not asked for money beyond the original $10 million. He did say, though, that he pushed for a chairman who would spend more time on the project than Dr. Sasaki, who is 78 and is involved in other business interests.
Dr. Sasaki would not grant an interview.
Despite the financial uncertainties, efforts to create the lab have continued. And while the official link to M.I.T. has ended, Mr. Koizumi said the foundation was using M.I.T.'s earlier advice in setting a research agenda and style. Three of the foundation's researchers are former graduate students from the M.I.T. lab.
Dr. Edward E. David Jr., who was the science adviser to former President Richard M. Nixon and is a member of the foundation's board, is planning to come to Japan at the end of this month to discuss ways of reviving the project.
"You can't raise money in a vacuum," he said. "So far, we haven't got anything to show and we don't have a good plan."
But Dr. David, who was also head of research and development for the Exxon Corporation, said the project should be able to get back on track.
"I think in the end it will be quite successful," he said. "I don't know when the end will be."

HEADLINE: Researchers Say U.S. Social Well-Being Is 'Awful'

 BODY:
Increases in child abuse and child poverty have driven the nation's social well-being to its lowest point in two decades, according to a study being released today by social scientists at Fordham University.
The scientists also evaluated Americans' confidence in their quality of life, and they said it was strikingly low. 
 The annual report, "The Index of Social Health," attempts to monitor the well-being of American society by examining statistics from reports by the Census Bureau on 16 major social problems, including teen-age suicide, unemployment, drug abuse, the high-school dropout rate and the lack of affordable housing.
 
Highest Rating forin 1972
 Aided by a computer model, the researchers use the statistics from the 16 categories to reach a single figure between 0 and 100, which they call the index of social health.
The report was first produced in 1985, when the scientists measured social health for the year 1970. The index for 1970 was 75, which the researchers said was above average. But in 1991, the most recent year for which complete data was available, the index was 36, down from 42 in 1990 and less than half the highest index rating of 79 for 1972.
The 1991 figure is "awful," said Dr. Marc L. Miringoff, the author of the study and the director of the Fordham University Institute for Innovation in Social Policy in Tarrytown, N.Y.
"These results reveal as much about what is happening to us as the economic indicators that we watch closely every day," he said.
Two major reasons for the drop, Dr. Miringoff said, are that child abuse reached its worst recorded level and that the number of children living in poverty reached its worst level since 1983.
 
Pointing to Decline in Economy
 Also eroding society's health was a decline in average weekly earnings, he said. "The decline in the economy has much to do with the decline in our social health," Dr. Miringoff said. "Especially the economic factors that affect the labor market. Simply, there are a lot fewer jobs now that people can depend on for stable long-term employment."
Two of the indicators used to calculate the social index did improve in 1991: infant mortality and food stamp coverage.
A new feature of the report, the Index of Social Confidence, seeks to show how Americans evaluate national performance in areas that shape the quality of life: education, health care, safety, occupation and living standard. In a national telephone survey, 1,200 randomly selected Americans were asked how confident they felt about those areas.
The result was a confidence index of 34, which Dr. Miringoff called disturbingly low. He said the respondents to the survey saw serious problems in the nation's social well-being and were pessimistic about the future.
Eighty-four percent of those questioned said they believed it was difficult for the average American to provide for his family, while 71 percent said it was difficult for the average person to find a satisfying job.
The telephone survey was conducted with Yankelovich Partners Inc., a research firm based in Westport, Conn., from May 27 to June 7. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.

HEADLINE: Thatcher Tells of '89 Plan With Paris to Rein In Bonn

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Worried that a reunified Germany would dominate Europe, the leaders of Britain and France took tentative steps in December 1989 and January 1990 to create a British-French entente to "check the German juggernaut," Lady Thatcher has written in her memoirs.
But the plan, which she said evolved from three private meetings with President Francois Mitterrand, eventually came to nothing because the French leader believed that the reunification of East and West Germany could not be stopped and sought instead to contain a newly powerful neighbor by promoting a more integrated, federated Europe. 
 "He made the wrong decision for France," she says baldly.
Lady Thatcher's memoirs, "The Downing Street Years," go on sale here and abroad on Monday. Advance copies of the 862-page book, which is published by HarperCollins and costs $37.50, were made available to the press today. Excerpts have appeared in newpapers over the last week.
The book begins with her visit to the Queen in May 1979, anxious about details of protocol when she formed a Conservative Government, and ends in November 1990, when she resigned as Prime Minister and looked back at the residence at 10 Downing Street with tears in her eyes.
 
Cabinet's 'Weasel Words'
 In between -- during the years in which she is convinced she changed the course of British history by facing down the unions, fighting the war over the Falkland Islands and forcing a Conservative agenda past lily-livered ministers and a howling Labor opposition -- she sprinkles observations about politics and world leaders.
Much of her bile is saved for members of her own Cabinet, who drove her to resign when one by one she called them in to canvass their views on her chances of winning a leadership struggle. What really hurt, she says, was the "weasel words" of friends and allies masquerading "their betrayal as frank advice and concern for my fate."
Among those who hesitated to back her, she notes, was the current Prime Minister, John Major. Nevertheless, she pretended to overlook his faint-heartedness and supported him to become her successor once it was clear she could not win.
Many men in politics, she concludes, are vain and indecisive -- "precisely those characteristics which they attribute to women."
 
Mixed Words for Carter
 She dealt with three American Presidents. Jimmy Carter, we are told, was likable but had a loose grip on economics and "no large vision of America's future." Ronald Reagan, of course, was a paragon of virtues -- warm, charming, unaffected and, like herself, high-minded. His election in 1980 was "as much of a watershed in American affairs as my own election victory."
George Bush was "easy to get on with" but became exasperated by her habit of dominating the conversation. She learned, she says, to "defer to him" and "not to stint the praise," for the greater glory of England. "If that was necessary to secure Britain's interests and influence I had no hesitation in eating a little humble pie."
The Bush presidency, looking on Germany as the coming power, initially turned its back on the "special relationship" with Britain. But Washington soon learned, during the Persian Gulf war, the value of having London as its prime ally, she insists. At one point, speaking on the phone to President Bush when sanctions against Iraq needed enforcement, she told him, "This is no time to go wobbly."
Mrs. Thatcher was quick to spot Mikhail S. Gorbachev as the rising figure in the Kremlin and in December 1984, three months before he became the Soviet leader, she invited him to visit her at the Prime Minister's country retreat of Chequers for his first trip to the capitalist West. Though they argued the merits of their respective systems, she found him confident, personable and not at all like "the average Soviet apparatchik." As was widely reported at the time, she became something of an advocate for him at the court of Mr. Reagan.
 
Denigration of Kohl
 Among international leaders, Chancellor Helmut Kohl is denigrated as someone who "has the sure touch of a German provincial politician." But it is perhaps Mr. Mitterrand who comes off the worst. Although Lady Thatcher takes pains to point out that he is cultivated, cosmopolitan and a lively dinner partner, she notes a "tendency to schizophrenia" on the German question, meaning that while publicly endorsing German reunificiation, privately "he is driven by a fear of the consequences of German domination."
She writes that at the French President's suggestion, she met twice with him in private during a meeting of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg in December 1989, at a time when Mr. Kohl had make public a 10-point plan leading to German reunification. Mr. Mitterrand, she writes, "observed that in history the Germans were a people in constant movement and flux."
"At this I produced from my handbag a map showing the various configurations of Germany in the past, which were not altogether reassuring about the future," she recalls. A special concern was over eventual German hegemony over the countries of Eastern Europe.
"He said that at moments of great danger in the past, France had always established special relations with Britain, and he felt that such a time had come again. We must draw together and stay in touch."
 
'The German Giant'
 Despite a subsequent meeting and plans for foreign and defense ministers to confer on the topic, the proposed axis fell away, largely because Mr. Mitterrand "said he was at a loss as to what we could do," she says. Instead of defending French sovereignty and interests through alliances, he chose to "move toward a federal Europe in order to tie down the German giant."
Mrs. Thatcher's jaundiced view of German reunification was well known at the time, but Mr. Mitterrand's private thoughts have not been disclosed before. A spokeswoman for the French President said there would be no public comment on Lady Thatcher's assertions but added that Mr. Mitterrand's positive attitudes toward Germany were well known and a matter of public record.
The memoirs have caused a storm in Germany, where extracts have appeared in Der Spiegel under the headline "Stop the German Monster." The magazine said that Lady Thatcher could be "deemed an incorrigible German-hater and mocked as the last warrior of the cold war" but that such a characterization would probably not even offend her.

HEADLINE: Palmas Journal;
Brazilians Rush West, to Citadel of Self-Reliance

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALMAS, Brazil

 BODY:
Blueprints in hand, Walfredo Antunes de Oliveira Jr. watched officials lay this frontier city's founding stone and wondered nervously: What if we build a capital and no one comes?
Then, looking across the table-flat savanna on that day in May 1989, he noticed dust plumes in the distance. Slowly, they converged on this patch of wilderness on the east bank of the Tocantins River. 
 "There was one family with a bakery tied on the top of their truck; there was another family from Rondonia, where the soil had given out," Mr. Oliveira, an architect, recalled today.
From 130 hardy pioneers less than five years ago, the youngest and smallest of Brazil's 26 state capitals currently counts its swelling population at 85,000.
"The city recalls Brasilia at the end of the 1950's," gushed a reporter from a Brazilian picture magazine who recently trekked here from Brasilia, the federal capital, 400 miles south of here.
 
An Ideological Gulf
 But red dust, a master plan, and dreams of taming Brazil's West are about all that this new city shares with Brasilia, Brazil's planned city of the 1960's. More than a generational gap, the difference is an ideological gulf.
Designed by Oscar Niemeyer, a lifelong member of the Brazilian Communist Party, Brasilia celebrates supremacy of the state. Seeking to use architecture to create a new citizenry, Mr. Niemeyer initially ruled out private property and housed Government employees in Soviet-style apartment blocks.
But in later years Brazil's central Government went broke.
With inflation raging today at 35 percent a month and Government services deteriorating steadily, Brazilians expect less and less from the federal Government, and this new spirit of self-reliance is especially strong here on Brazil's agricultural frontier.
While attention focused in recent years on Brazil's attempts to colonize the Amazon, a thriving farming and ranching region emerged in the midwest savanna states of Mato Grosso, Mato Grosso do Sul and Goias. To promote growth through investment in basic services like roads and electricity, Brazil's Congress in 1988 lopped off the northern half of Goias and created this state, Tocantins.
With about one million people scattered over an area slightly larger than Colorado, Tocantins has an economy based on cattle ranching and on rice cultivation. Rice plantations here rank among the world's largest.
Forging a new relationship between public and private sectors, Palmas, the new state capital, is being built without special federal aid.
"Of the 15,000 buildings that have sprouted here since 1989, I would be surprised if more than 100 were financed by the state," Mr. Oliveira said. His architecture and engineering firm, Grupo Quatro Ltda., drew up a plan for Palmas that covers 519 square miles of urban areas, farming belts and an ecological reserve.
Under a pay-as-you-go system, Tocantins state sells housing and commercial lots to raise money for paving streets, installing electricity and building government buildings. Grandiose projects have to wait. The airstrip is a section of highway used by propeller planes until a macadam strip can be built for jets.
In a raw, orange brick neighborhood called Liberdade, or Freedom, new electricity wires hang from temporary poles and freshly opened trenches line subdivision streets, waiting for plastic pipes from the city water company.
"When I got here, this was just savanna, and now we have electricity," Edilson Pereira Silva, a 24-year-old migrant from southern Brazil, said, proudly surveying the two-room core of a new house he was building. "In a new city, you grow along with the city."
In the center of town, Jair Correa Jr., from Goias state, recalled how his father impulsively decided in 1990 to buy a lot a few yards from where bulldozers broke ground for the state governor's palace.
"We had just sold a ranch and we decided to invest immediately," said Mr. Correa who now runs the Girassois, the city's largest and busiest hotel. "In Brazil, it's very dangerous to keep your money on hand."
As hotel patrons dug into plates of steamed river fish, the diversity of accents in the dining room reflected the boom town atmosphere here -- cattle ranchers from central Brazil, executives from a coastal Brazil department store chain, and Canadian engineers from a cellular telephone company.
 
Some Success Stories
 In a self-confident city where the first baby, born in 1990, was baptized Palmerio, success stories include Divino Jose Pereira, who parlayed money earned as a pizza deliverer in San Francisco into a Palmas bar and clothing boutique. Cosme Neves Barbosa, another entrepreneur, tapped a need for prefabricated swimming pools in a climate where summer temperatures routinely rise over 100 degrees.
At City Hall, a fax machine burps into life at least 20 times a day, delivering requests for information from small and medium investors across Brazil.
"We get a lot of people looking for a fresh start -- civil servants taking early retirement, divorced people," said Mayor Eduardo Siqueira Campos, an optimistic 30-year-old in blue jeans. "People call up and say: 'I have $80,000. What can I do with it in Palmas?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: With high inflation and deteriorating Government services, Brazilians expect less from the federal Government, fostering a spirit of self-reliance on Brazil's agricultural frontier. A family sat at the bus station recently after arriving in Palmas, the youngest and smallest of Brazil's 26 state capitals. (John Maier Jr. for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Heads of H.M.O.'s Have Concerns on Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Because President Clinton's health plan seeks to increase the number of Americans in health maintenance organizations, White House officials expected the directors of H.M.O.'s to be among the plan's most enthusiastic supporters.
But the people who run these organizations, while generally favoring the President's ideas, nevertheless express many concerns and doubts about the proposal. 
 The directors worry about Federal regulation of their premiums, about 50 different sets of state rules, about their ability to handle a surge in membership and the difficulty of bringing poor people into their networks. They doubt that Federal payments and subsidies will cover the costs they expect when they enroll Medicaid recipients, homeless people, drug addicts and people with chronic illnesses like AIDS.
And they worry about losing the expertise that employers have developed over decades of purchasing health care for their employees. They say such employers have given H.M.O.'s the impetus to be more efficient.
 
Staking Out Positions
 Meeting in Washington last week, medical directors of the health maintenance organizations said they strongly supported Mr. Clinton's goals, including medical insurance for all Americans with an emphasis on preventive care. But, like other sectors of the health care industry, they want to shape the President's plan to address their concerns and are staking out positions for the struggles ahead.
Mr. Clinton's proposal would give all Americans a choice of joining an H.M.O. and would create financial incentives for people to do so. Under Mr. Clinton's plan, H.M.O.'s, which provide comprehensive medical care in return for a monthly payment, would need to be certified by the states where they were operating, and states could set widely differing criteria.
For H.M.O.'s operating in more than one state, as most do, "that would be a nightmare," said Dr. Lee N. Newcomer, medical director of the United Healthcare Corporation, whose H.M.O.'s serve 2.4 million people in 14 states, including Illinois, Minnesota, Ohio and Rhode Island.
Mr. Clinton is intent on preserving state power to regulate H.M.O.'s within a Federal framework.
 
Call for National Standards
 But Dr. Don Nielsen, associate medical director of Kaiser Permanente, the nation's largest H.M.O., with 6.6 million members in 16 states, said, "We want a common set of national standards for certifying health plans and for reporting data in all 50 states."
Karen M. Ignagni, president of the Group Health Association of America, a trade group for H.M.O.'s, said, "It is not in the consumer's interest to have multiple conflicting standards." Instead, she said, "there has to be regulatory uniformity," with the Federal Government setting nationwide standards in categories like financial management, the quality of care and the reporting of data.
Membership in health maintenance organizations exploded in the last decade, to 41.4 million in 1992 from 10.8 million in 1982. Doctors who work at these organizations worry about whether they can expand much faster without harming the quality of care.
Dr. Jesse H. Jampol, medical director of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, which has more than a million members, said it would be difficult, though not impossible, to accommodate a surge in membership.
 
'Adds to the Paperwork'
 "We have 47 medical centers in New York City," Dr. Jampol said. "We don't want to dilute the quality of care by putting more people into a center than it was designed for. If we get 100,000 new patients in a year, we'll have to build another three or four centers at a cost of $8 million to $12 million apiece."
Mr. Clinton would require H.M.O. members to pay $10 for each visit to a doctor, and similar amounts for other services. Dr. Jampol's organization does not make such charges, nor does it want to.
"We are not eager to pocket little bits of money and set up a whole new system of billing and accounts," he said. "It adds to the paperwork and the bureaucracy."
Prof. Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton University, said the H.M.O.'s of today provide a model for the way health care will be delivered in the future. "Under the Clinton plan," he said, "there will be more H.M.O.'s, and some of them will be bigger. But their profit margins will be smaller because they will face fiercer competition."
Kathryn Langwell, a health economist at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting and consulting firm, said: "Today's health care reform initiatives are favorable to H.M.O.'s. They should be relatively happy, but their concerns are reasonable."
 
'Rationing of Health Care'
 Commercial and nonprofit H.M.O.'s both criticize Mr. Clinton's proposal calling for the Government to regulate premiums.
Dr. John M. Ludden, medical director of the Harvard Community Health Plan, which serves 547,000 people in New England, said, "Premium caps will drive capital out of this business and will drive us straight to the rationing of health care."
Dr. Newcomer said: "Premium caps will make us get rid of care that has no proven value, and that's good. They may also force us to limit access to care that is effective and valuable but expensive, and that's not good."
As employers prod workers to join H.M.O.'s, doctors across the country are rushing to affiliate with such networks.
For years, the Government has been trying to increase the use of health maintenance organizations by poor people on Medicaid and elderly people on Medicare. But only 2 million of the 30 million Medicaid recipients and fewer than 2.5 million of the 36 million Medicare beneficiaries are in such organizations.
It is unclear whether these patterns will change. Dr. Howard L. Bailit, senior vice president of Aetna Health Plans, said: "Government has underfunded Medicaid for 20 years. I think that's going to continue. It will be a real serious problem for us." Aetna operates 26 H.M.O.'s with 1.2 million members.
 
Little Control for Employers
 Middle-income consumers can be enrolled in large groups through their employers. But Dr. Newcomer said H.M.O.'s needed a different strategy to recruit and serve poor people. "In parts of Chicago," he said, "we have door-knocking sales people to enroll Medicaid recipients one by one."
In addition, he said, large numbers of Medicaid recipients fail to keep their medical appointments, and these patients often need special help with transportation. "We have to find clinics on public bus lines and sometimes buy bus tickets or pay cab fare," Dr. Newcomer said.
Dr. Ludden said the Harvard Community Health Plan had many patients who cannot speak English. The H.M.O. has interpreters in more than 25 languages. If millions of uninsured people get coverage under Mr. Clinton's plan, other H.M.O.'s will need to provide similar services, Dr. Ludden said.
Under the Clinton proposal, employers would have to pay health insurance premiums for their workers, but they would have little control over the cost of care. Insurance purchasing groups, known as regional health alliances, would collect the premiums from employers, negotiate with H.M.O.'s and buy coverage for millions of people.
The H.M.O. directors lamented the loss of the employers' expertise in this transaction. Dr. Ludden said: "Employers are a powerful voice for health care consumers. They have really become sophisticated customers. They know what to ask for and how to ask for it. They set goals for us -- clinical goals, not just cost goals."
Under Mr. Clinton's plan, employers with more than 5,000 workers could still serve as their own health insurers or buy coverage from insurance companies. But most employers would have little or no role in selecting insurers for their workers. That decision would be made by the alliance.

HEADLINE: Only Bills to Be Auctioned By the Treasury This Week

 BODY:
Treasury financing this week is confined to today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.
On Friday, the outstanding three- month bill closed at a rate of 2.99 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 3.08 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Amid upgrades, Greyhound finds profits are behind schedule.

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
GREYHOUND LINES, the venerable bus company, must have some serious engine trouble. How else to explain the fall of its stock from $22 in early August to about $12 in late September, where it has remained since?
One reason: Its problems are exaggerated. 
 The sputtering of the stock was prompted by Greyhound's weak summer, when it faced the inevitable headaches of introducing a computerized reservation system. Heavy calling on the system's new toll-free number created high hopes about summer traffic, despite two warnings by the company of a weakness in short-haul markets.
Still, investor hopes were dashed in late September with an announcement that August traffic had slumped 12.3 percent and earnings would be flat to slightly improved over 1992. The disclosure was botched, with some company analysts receiving the news before others. Wall Street, with its distaste for surprises, punished the stock. And the shares have languished.
Greyhound Lines, after all, is into its slowest period of the year, the fourth and first quarters. And there were few hopeful signs in employment statistics for its many customers with an average annual income of $25,000 or less. While many regions of the country showed jumps in help-wanted ads in the Conference Board's help-wanted index for August, the index showed a decline in West Coast states like California, where Greyhound gets 15 percent of its business.
Throw in the unwelcome surprise of softer-than-expected earnings, and the stock belongs in the low teens, according to some Greyhound watchers like Allan S. Roness of Fahnestock & Company.
"What do you give a stock that really disappoints?" he said. "It should only get 10 to 12 times earnings."
But the turmoil over the summer has clouded Greyhound's hyperkinetic effort to modernize its outdated operations, which is expected to continue to drive down its operating costs and improve profit margins.
"It's been overpenalized here," said Vivian Lee, an analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, who said she thought the stock ought to be in the $17-to-$18 range, representing a multiple of about 17. That is still considerably below the current market multiple of more than 24 for the Standard & Poor's 500.
Indeed, the speed with which Greyhound is overhauling its operations makes some rapidly restructuring airlines look as if they are standing still.
Greyhound is closing garages -- to 12 by year-end from 30 in early 1992 -- to improve economies of scale. The new computer reservation system should help the carrier schedule its fleet more efficiently, and it expects to take delivery of 400 new buses through the first quarter of next year.
The company, based in Dallas, is introducing various levels of fares to grant discounts on advance purchases. In August, it started testing an Easy Riders program that looks in many ways like a frequent-flier mileage program, offering discounted tickets, food and drinks to repeat customers.
The company has also developed a stock-option plan for drivers and mechanics, letting them earn shares based on performance reviews.
Greyhound's troubled summer has basically lost the company a year. Analysts who had been predicting $1.40 in earnings a share this year are now predicting the same for next year, down from the $1.75 or so they had been expecting for 1994. In other words, the stock lost more than 40 percent of its value after its earnings forecasts were lowered about 25 percent.
So attention, passengers: The bus is coming. It's just going to be a little late.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Shifting Perceptions of a Presidency

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
Presidential reputations are protean things, continually revised and annotated by shifting values and historical developments that vindicate or repudiate an individual President's decisions and world view. Among the many factors that both shape and reflect popular perceptions of a President are biographies, memoirs and historical accounts of an administration.
The second volume of Robert A. Caro's biography of Lyndon Johnson ("Means of Ascent," 1990) left readers with an image of Johnson not as an architect of civil rights legislation, but as a politician of "utter ruthlessness" who "stole" his 1948 Senate election. In contrast, David McCullough's affectionate 1992 portrait of Harry S. Truman ("Truman") served as the culmination of an ongoing process of rehabilitation, transforming an unpopular President (who left office with a 31 percent approval rating) into a kind of folk hero. 
 It is probably more than coincidence that the best-selling "Truman" arrived in bookstores in June of 1992, at the height of the Presidential campaign, and that George Bush soon traded in his former role model, Theodore Roosevelt -- who happened to be the subject of an earlier McCullough biography, "Mornings on Horseback" -- and began comparing himself to Harry Truman.
Bill Clinton also invoked the Truman mantle, as well as that of Franklin D. Roosevelt, but as newspaper, magazine and television accounts attest, he has most insistently cultivated comparisons to John F. Kennedy.
The 14-minute Bloodworth-Thomason film screened at the Democratic National Convention last year showed a teen-age Mr. Clinton shaking hands with President Kennedy at a 1963 Boys Nation reception, using the image twice as a kind of symbolic passing of the torch. The day before he was sworn in, Mr. Clinton made a pilgrimage to Arlington National Cemetery to lay roses on the grave of President Kennedy, and in his inaugural address he used self-consciously Kennedyesque language to call for public service and self-restraint. A recent speech on national service invoked Kennedy by name, praising his creation of the Peace Corps for changing "the way a generation of Americans look at themselves and the world."
Although such speeches by Mr. Clinton conjure up an image of the idealistic founder of the New Frontier, Kennedy's actual place in history remains open to debate. While books by former Kennedy associates -- Arthur M. Schlesigner Jr. and Theodore C. Sorensen -- attempted to cement the Camelot myth, later volumes by historians like Garry Wills and Thomas C. Reeves provided decidedly less flattering portraits of Kennedy as a manipulator obsessed with image.
The latest book about Kennedy -- "President Kennedy: Profile of Power" by the political journalist Richard Reeves (Simon & Schuster) -- draws a portrait of him as a highly pragmatic politician who was intelligent, disorganized and careless. It is less a full-fledged biography of Kennedy than a study of his Presidency, and it unwittingly sheds new light on Kennedy's young emulator, William Jefferson Clinton.
Although Mr. Clinton appears only once in the book (and in a footnote, no less), it's hard for anyone who has read about his Presidency or followed it on television to finish "Profile of Power" without drawing comparisons, and comparisons that tend to have less to do with vision than with circumstance, temperament and managerial style. These inadvertent parallels are not always flattering; indeed, they sometimes leave the reader wondering why Mr. Clinton has chosen to make Kennedy such a favorite role model.
To begin with, there are the obvious similarities of youth and qualified popularity. Although both men were highly skilled politicians and both were hailed as avatars of a new generation, they were both elected with less than 50 percent of the vote and no guarantee of a Congressional majority for their legislation.
Kennedy entered office almost totally focused on foreign policy, and found himself forced by circumstance -- namely, the rising civil rights movement -- to deal with domestic issues. Mr. Clinton entered office almost totally focused on domestic issues and has found himself forced -- by developments in Bosnia, Somalia and the former Soviet Union -- to deal with foreign policy.
In the early months of their Presidencies, both Kennedy and Mr. Clinton were needled by the press about the slow pace of their appointments. Both made close family members -- Robert F. Kennedy and Hillary Rodham Clinton, respectively -- trusted Administration confidants. And both got off to a rocky start with the military: Kennedy losing its respect after his embarrassing summit with the Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1961; Mr. Clinton starting off with scepticism because he had not served in Vietnam.
During their first months in office, both Kennedy and Mr. Clinton struggled with disorder resulting from their White House management styles. According to Mr. Reeves's book, President Kennedy described his White House organization as a wheel with many spokes and himself at "the vital center." Nearly the same words were used last January by a Democratic Party official who told Time magazine that the Clinton White House "has been structured as spokes of a wheel leading into the President."
Mr. Reeves writes that Kennedy's love of rambling meetings and hallway conversations had the effect of "a movable feast, a floating bull session." Reporters have similarly noted that Mr. Clinton's open-door policy in the Oval Office has nurtured the seminar atmosphere he loves.
Indeed Presidents Kennedy and Clinton seem to share certain personality traits that incline them toward such a loose work arrangement: a personal mastery of detail, a capacity to thrive on chaos, a distaste for being alone.
Certainly some of the similarities one might discern between the two Presidents are fairly generic to the office or to the successful politician: confidence, verbal facility, an ability to wing it when necessary. Kennedy, Mr. Reeves observes in his book, delivered his famous 1963 civil rights speech with only a partly finished text. Mr. Clinton made it through the first seven minutes of his recent health care address with the wrong speech in front of him on the prompter.
Other similarities are superficial, the stuff of gossip: allergies, a fondness for the telephone, a penchant for watching movies when under stress. Kennedy, Mr. Reeves notes, watched "Roman Holiday" late one night during the height of the Cuban Missile crisis. Mr. Clinton, Newsweek reported, channel-surfed between "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," "Zorba the Greek" and "The Crucifer of Blood" while waiting for the Senate vote on his economic plan.
Other parallels, however, are more revealing and potentially consequential, from the cultivation of image to both men's easy ability to charm those around them.
Kennedy's gift, in Mr. Reeves's words, "for convincing others that, whatever he did or had to do, he was at heart with them" appears to have led to misunderstandings within his own Adminstration, while Mr. Clinton's ability seem to to empathize with assorted constituencies has already led to hurt feelings -- over such matters as homosexuals in the military -- when his actions have failed to live up to perceived intent.
Mr. Reeves argues in "Profile of Power" that Kennedy "had little ideology beyond anti-Communism and faith in active pragmatic government," that he "never made a decision until he had to," that "invariably he chose the most moderate of available options," and that he was "often willing to suspend" what convictions he did have "if that avoided confrontation with Congress or the risk of being called soft." Mr. Clinton, who has tried to avoid having the liberal label pinned on him, has been repeatedly criticized during his first nine months in office for his willingness to compromise and conciliate.
Of course one of the biggest differences between Kennedy and Mr. Clinton is that Kennedy's Presidency is a matter of history now; though open to the revisions of historians, his decisions belong to a closed book. Mr. Clinton's record is still very much a work in progress, though the process of assessing him and his Administration has already begun. "Promises of Change: The Clinton Administration and the Politics of Renewal," by Roger Morris, is due out in February. Also in the works are a biography of the President by David Maraniff, and books on his Administration by Bob Woodward and Elizabeth Drew. And this after just nine months in office.

HEADLINE: PULSE;
Unemployment

 BODY:
The average length of unemployment claims is at an all-time high in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in what state labor department officials say provides one of the most graphic indications of a job market that continues to shrink. The average length of claims gives a picture of the job prospects of the recently unemployed but does not account for those entering the job market or the long-term unemployed. While unemployment rates have fallen, after soaring to their highest levels in a decade last year, employment remains flat in the region largely because jobs are not being created. New York's Labor Department currently estimates the average worker who loses their job will be out of work for more than a year.

HEADLINE: The Mayoral Campaign -- At Issue: The Economy;
Fixing New York's Sick Economy

 BODY:
New York City's economy is limping along, with high unemployment and rising welfare rolls. Voters naturally demand solutions from their leaders. Mayor David Dinkins and his challenger, Rudolph Giuliani, have responded by offering development plans that promise to turn the local economy around.
The plan put forward by Mr. Dinkins promises too much: 185 pages of proposals to channel money into biotechnology, business services, jewelry, apparel and about 10 other high- and low-tech industry clusters that often seem to have no more claim on taxpayer dollars than the fact that they hire lots of voters. Mr. Giuliani promises too little: Cut taxes to make it cheaper for business to operate in the city -- but leave it to some other time to figure out how to cut spending. 
 New York voters have a choice between a challenger who provides no direction and an incumbent who wants to shoot in 14 different directions -- guaranteeing that none of the money would land with clout.
New York's economic fortunes are swept along by national and international forces that are beyond local control. City government didn't cause the real estate bust of the 1970's or the stock market boom of the early 1980's. It didn't cause the telecommunications boom that added jobs, or the manufacturing bust that eliminated jobs. It didn't create the influx of poor families; nor did it tell Congress to abandon its responsibility to take care of America's poor. But even if city policy can't reverse economic tides, it can help make the economy work better for millions.
Mr. Dinkins's plan is motivated by a single idea: By combining private and public money, city policy can propel industry growth. Mr. Dinkins proposes, for example, a venture-capital fund for biotechnology and information technologies, a center to house computer software companies and a so-called business incubator that would develop companies in the fashion and apparel industries.
Some of these ideas are worthy, but they aren't powerful. High-tech venture-capital funds and business incubators are atop the agendas of many big-city mayors, and where they've been tried, there is no pattern of success. And why does a mature industry like fashion need incubation? In special circumstances, private-public partnerships can overcome obstacles that businesses can't overcome themselves. But Mr. Dinkins's strategy aims at too many targets and could easily turn into taxpayer bailout of politically powerful business groups.
Mr. Dinkins's plan does contain useful ideas. He would create a new financing mechanism to rebuild deteriorating infrastructure. And he would build a network of neighborhood facilities to provide primary health care for the poor -- an innovative and humane policy that would also boost employment.
Mr. Giuliani's plan is simpler to describe because of its scantiness. The first half of his 40-page booklet laments the state of the city economy and criticizes Mr. Dinkins's policies. He then proposes a series of tax cuts. That would be a potent idea if Mr. Giuliani had made it more believable by telling voters how he would cut spending -- without eviscerating the quality of city services -- to make way for the tax cuts. But, as described in yesterday's editorial about each candidate's budget policies, Mr. Giuliani didn't step up to this challenge.
He also promises to cut bothersome regulations and bureaucratic waste. But he doesn't provide details or explain how he, unlike all his predecessors, would ram the changes through the City Council, let alone Albany.
Mr. Giuliani offers some of the same platitudes found in the Dinkins plan about investing in infrastructure and improving schools. But he provides no focus, no numbers. He would loosen zoning requirements to spur residential construction and promote enterprise zones. But he does not explain how subsidizing business in one blighted area of the city, which almost certainly would take business away from companies in nearby neighborhoods, amounts to a strategy for citywide growth.
There are limited circumstances in which it is useful to use taxpayer money to support private enterprise. But the best strategy would be for the city to focus on what it uniquely provides. Studies of metropolitan areas show that the most effective plans channel public money into improving infrastructure, such as transportation facilities, and educating a skilled work force. That's what businesses look for when they start up or relocate.
But it's a hard message to sell to voters. The mayoral candidates would have to ask city taxpayers to spend today but wait for at least a decade -- long after the winner leaves office -- to reap the reward. Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani have failed to deliver that message.

HEADLINE: Has France Gone Bonkers?

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is senior columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
It's a molehill threatening to be a mountain. Compared to the economies involved, the European-America -- really French-American -- farm war heading toward a decisive battle is strictly marginal. But the martial music has grown deafening.
The cohesion of the European Community and relations with the U.S. are at stake. Leaders on both sides have proclaimed that they will never surrender, provoking warnings that the whole Western structure of accommodation that won the cold war could be brought down. 
 Absurd as it sounds, it has to be taken seriously. Internal politics -- links established between seemingly unrelated issues such as wheat production and world currency markets -- along with mythic imagery have made the farm issue a serious danger for international relations.
The French feel under mortal attack. Most everybody else feels the French have gone bonkers. Agriculture accounts for 3.6 percent of France's gross national product and involves 6 percent of its labor force and, while it accounts for 16 percent of French exports, most of that goes to Community partners, and only a quarter of those exports are affected by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rules at issue.
Why such a fuss? It has to do with what Charles de Gaulle called "a certain idea of France." In French minds, the picture that evokes la patrie is a steepled church, set in a stone village, surrounded by farmland. That's why miners, stock brokers and researchers agree that survival of the familiar countryside implies the survival of France. France's history, a misty-eyed banker told me, is the story of a thousand years of clearing and cultivating the land. The French see something immoral in leaving good land fallow.
It makes matters worse that pressures to reduce farm production come at the same time as the inexorable necessity to abandon the other part of the "certain idea" -- France as a great power. That's been fading over the years, but the country has been in a particularly bad mood since the unification of Germany, now undeniably bigger and stronger than France.
But partnership with Germany remains essential. Paris can hold out on GATT only if Bonn succumbs to French demands for "loyal" support. So the demon is the U.S., all the more of a threat since George Bush pronounced Germany America's major European partner.
French politicians are aware of the factual weakness of their case. The Community's common agricultural policy, which was de Gaulle's condition for not pulling France out of the Common Market, has led to drastic overproduction, dumped on world markets, thanks to monumental subsidies. Community subsidies add up to eight times as much per hectare as those in the U.S.
"Every advanced country subsidizes farmers," a French agriculture minister said, but nobody here knows how much French taxpayers and consumers pay for it. Nor is it said aloud that rich farmers get most of the benefits and that poor ones, who are being driven off the land, get least.
Nor do Germans know that a Government study showed it would cost the federal budget half as much to end its subsidies and give every farmer the equivalent of a midlevel civil servant's salary.
So the public responds overwhelmingly to the emotional issue of saving the land and its way of life, and the Government gets cheers when Prime Minister Edouard Balladur says if that means a crisis in the Community and the U.S., "so be it."
This small issue can blow up the chances for expanding world trade and even political cooperation. Rural life in industrial countries is worth preserving for the sake of poetry and the environment. But let each country admit what it's doing, and bear its own burden.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed
