HEADLINE: How Pennsylvania Succeeds at Health Care

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The States' Stakes in Clinton's Health Plan" (The Week in Review, Oct. 10) graphically illustrates that Pennsylvania is one of only five states with a rate of uninsured workers of under 10 percent. And Pennsylvania has, by far, the largest population of the five. 
 There are several reasons why Pennsylvania has maintained a low rate of uninsured workers compared with most other states, despite the economic dislocations that have occurred across the state in the last decade.
A system of voluntary purchasing organizations and community-rated insurance pools has been in place in Pennsylvania for many years -- through unions, trade and professional organizations and individuals -- through which small employers, the self-employed and others can purchase health benefits. More than 1.3 million Pennsylvanians, primarily those who are employed at small companies, obtain extensive health benefits through these pooling arrangements.
Children have also received special attention in Pennsylvania. Over the last decade the private and public sectors have worked together to encourage, develop and finance special health care benefit programs for the children of economically disadvantaged families.
Longstanding practices and policies of the private insurance industry have also played an important role. All individuals in Pennsylvania can obtain coverage, regardless of their age, occupation or medical condition, through Pennsylvania's Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans. Coverage is not canceled because of a major illness.
The thrust of your analysis is clear: the emerging national health care policy can't be so rigid as to preclude the states from charting health care policy and from organizing medical delivery systems to meet the needs of their local populations.
 
EUGENE J. BARONE
Chairman and Chief, Executive Officer, Blue Cross of Western Pennsylvania
Pittsburgh, Oct. 14, 1993

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Candidates' Views on Economy Reflect U.S. Debate Over Policy

SERIES: Mayoral Agenda: A periodic report on major issues facing the election winner. -- 4. The Economy

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
As New York City struggles to shake itself out of its worst recession in half a century, the mayoral candidates are offering sharply different prescriptions on how to revive the local economy -- a split that reflects their philosophical differences over the limits of city government and mirrors a national debate over economic policy.
The Republican-Liberal challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, contends that fiscal conservatism -- keeping a balanced budget, streamlining city agencies and keeping them off the backs of business -- provides the best hope for the economy, allowing private enterprise to flourish on its own.
 
Venture Capital Funds
 But Mayor David N. Dinkins has unveiled proposals that many see as a sort of municipal version of an industrial policy, with the city marshaling resources to the aid of 12 specific industries, ranging from garbage recycling to biotechnology research, in the hope that they will become centers of economic growth. 
 Mr. Dinkins would also create two large venture capital funds that would invest city tax money directly in small and risky start-up companies.
His plan differs sharply from the policies of previous mayors who have used tax incentives to lure business to the declining areas of the city but made no attempt to pick out industries with the best potential for growth.
The timing of Mr. Dinkins's distinct change of direction over economic policy seemed clearly calculated to add luster to his re-election campaign. But his advisers say it has been prompted by the fact that the city's economy has only now reached bottom after a deep five-year recession. They say new, innovative city programs are needed to accelerate a period of slow, painful expansion that is expected over the next four years.
Mayor Dinkins's plan, which was announced in late September, appears to be gaining support among some corporate executives, a group that has traditionally been quick to criticize government intrusion into private enterprise. The plan has also been praised by President Clinton, whose support may be critical since the Mayor is seeking infusions of Federal funds.
Still, critics say the Democratic Mayor's proposals embody a high degree of experimentation that the city cannot afford at a time when there is no assurance that its long economic slump has come to an end.
The prospects of increased municipal involvement in business also underscore a wide philosophical difference with Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Giuliani has proposed the creation of small community development banks in poor neighborhoods and says he would use tax incentives to set up business enterprise zones.
But the main tenets of Mr. Giuliani's economic policy call for cutting the city work force and other forms of municipal spending, reducing red tape for small businesses and seeking to lower taxes.
"This administration can't even run city government properly," said Stephen Kagan, who is one of Mr. Giuliani's top economic advisers. "How can we expect it to run the economy?"
Mr. Dinkins, meanwhile, is proposing a program that asserts that City Hall can and should do more than keep its own fiscal house in order and that government incentives can be strategically honed to spur promising industries.
Advisers to Mr. Dinkins condemn Mr. Guiliani's economic platform as "municipal Reaganomics." They say the Republican candidate's proposals are both simplistic and impractical in a city whose diverse population and business community require economic development strategies that are finely tuned to meet widely divergent needs and timed to conform to cycles in the city's economic activity.
"We are proposing a fundamental change" in economic development strategy, said Barry F. Sullivan, the former bank chairman who was hired by Mr. Dinkins as his deputy mayor for finance and economic development in May 1992. Mr. Sullivan has headed a group of economists and policy analysts who have been preparing the Mayor's new economic development plan for more than a year.
Many business leaders "are surprised by the scope, the risk taking and the willingness to be aggressive in the Mayor's plan," said Ronald Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, a business group whose members include the chief executives of more than 150 of the city's largest corporations.
Although neither candidate has a clear lead among executives, he added, "business is supportive of the Mayor's approach because of a conviction that we have to do more now than we normally would to improve the local economy."
 
Unanswered Questions
 To be sure, many experts feel critical questions remain unaddressed by both candidates. One is whether City Hall should rely on huge tax incentives to keep large employers from leaving the city, a practice that was initiated by Mayor Edward I. Koch and employed more often by Mayor Dinkins.
The Mayor says the incentives are necessary and takes credit for saving thousands of corporate jobs that might have otherwise moved to the suburbs, Mr. Giuliani counters that too many companies have left during the Mayor's term despite the incentives.
But neither has responded to criticism from some officials, including Mark Green, the Democratic candidate for public advocate, that the city is doling out far too many tax breaks in a game of bluff with large corporations that simply threaten to leave.
And neither candidate has yet convinced fiscal experts that he has a workable plan to eliminate a huge gap that is expected in the city's budget for the next several years.
"Neither one has addressed the issue of how you eliminate the city's structural deficit," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group. According to the city's own estimates, it will face deficits of at least $1.7 billion a year in each of the three fiscal years beginning next July.
The two candidates' postions on the economy are based on sharply constrasting stategies for dealing with the deficits.
While Mr. Dinkins suggests that City Hall can stimulate business growth -- thereby creating a larger tax base and reducing the need to cut government spending -- Mr. Guiliani maintains that the role of government is to cut its own expenses and reduce taxes so business can expand on its own.
Mr. Guiliani says he would freeze hiring in several city departments and cut the city work force by 34,000, to 180,000 workers, in four years. He has also called for a "private sector working group" composed of business people to advise city agencies on where cuts should be made. The agencies would have to make cuts of 2 percent to 4 percent a year in spending for equipment, rent, vehicles and other non-personnel expenses.
He has also identified four taxes that he wants to reduce or eliminate. They include three levies that have long rankled business leaders: the unincorporated business tax, the commercial rent tax and the hotel occupancy tax. He says he also wants to reduce the surcharge on personal income.
Mr. Guiliani's approach reflects a widespread belief among fiscal experts that cities must put their own financial house in order before creating new ways to spend tax funds.
 
Harsh Criticism
 But there is no assurance that he can deliver on his pledge to cut taxes. And critics of the proposals say any reduction in taxes, even levied on businesses, may be impossible because of the budget deficits that must be closed.
Mayor Dinkins has been criticized through most of his first term for reacting to the threat of fiscal problems, rather than taking preventive measures.
The Mayor encountered harsh criticism within months of taking office in 1990, when some analysts objected to the size of pay raises won by city teachers while the city was grappling with severe economic problems. Complaints mounted weeks later when Mr. Dinkins said fiscal constraints could force him to lay off other city workers.
The Mayor regained support and confidence among many business people in 1992, when he delivered a balanced budget, froze city property tax rates for four years and hired Mr. Sullivan as deputy mayor.
As for the Mayor's plan to assist businesses, advocates of the proposals say they are based on the belief that what is good for New York City business is good for City Hall since expanding business activity will generate more taxes and lessen the need to cut government programs. They say it is being proposed now for reasons that have more to do with economic cycles than the timing of a mayoral campaign.
In an interview, Mr. Sullivan said the Mayor's economic plan is based on forecasts that the city's battered economy is only now beginning a slow expansion. The city would gain 100,000 jobs over the next four years even without incentives from City Hall, according to the Mayor's forecasts. The proposed economic stimulus package would create an additional 110,000 jobs.
In the largest single outlay -- $250 million over five years -- the Mayor's proposal calls for the creation of a Economic Development Bank to finance large city projects, like the renovation of the Staten Island home port for non-military uses and development of an industrial park along the Brooklyn waterfront.
Analysts say the development bank would bear little resemblance to a commercial bank because it would simply pay for public improvements instead of issuing loans. But its creation would mean that huge amounts of city funds would be clearly designated for economic development projects and could not be redirected for schools, highway improvements or other expenses.
The Mayor's sharpest departure from past policy comes in designating 12 industries to be courted by the city. They include biotechnology, computer software, apparel, jewelry, film and television production, recycling, health care, retailing, telecommunications, electricity and gas distribution, tourism and nonprofit groups.
Among the inducements would be real-estate subsidies to establish laboratories and plants.
Mr. Dinkins's plan also calls for two venture capital funds. One would make investments in small high technology companies, primarily in biotechnology and software. The second would have authority to invest in small businesses of any type.
Ultimately, each of the funds would raise $60 million. Although the plan is modeled on programs created by a handful of states, no other large city has tested them, and no government agency in the nation has attempted a venture capital program as large as those proposed by the Dinkins administration.
The proposal's success depends on the city's request for allocations from the Federal Government's Small Business Administration. Advisers to Mayor Dinkins said they expect $700 million in Federal funds to be made available to cities and states over the next four years.
Despite research by Dinkins aides, officials of the Federal small-business agency said last week that his plan for the venture capital funds was flawed when he announced it in September. The plan, which envisions raising $20 million initially for each of the funds, called for half of that to come from the city and half from private investors.
But Federal rules require that at least two-thirds of such funds come from private sources. On Friday, a spokeswoman for Mr. Sullivan, Jeanne Nathan, said the plan had been changed to conform to Federal guidelines.
Once the initial money is raised, the city would seek $40 million More for each fund from the Federal Government.
Mr. Sullivan said the funds would be managed by Wall Street professionals who would be hired by the city, but would be independent of influence from City Hall.
 
 
 
THE SERIES SO FAR
 The Mayoral Agenda series began on Sept. 27 with a report explaining that whoever wins the election will confront a looming budget crisis. An article on Oct. 2 compared the candidates' views on social-services issues, and an Oct. 11 article looked at their different approaches to the crime problem.

ELECTION: THE CANDIDATE'S ECONOMIC PLANS
Mayor David N. Dinkins

* Has identified 12 industries that the city would attract and assist through real estate subsidies and tax incentives.
* Wants to create two venture capital funds to invest $120 million -- largely from the Federal government -- in small business. Would set aside $250 million in city money over five years for large economic development projects.
* Has pledged to eliminate 8,000 city jobs by June 1996.
* Has appointed a three-member panel to recommend ways the city can avert budget deficits, estimated to exceed $1.7 billion in each of next three years. The recommendations will come after the election, on Dec. 1.
 
 Rudolph W. Guliani
* Would freeze hiring in several agencies, and cut city employment by 34,000 over four years. Would have business people monitor agencies, and find ways to to cut non-personnel expenses by two percent to five percent a year.
 *Wants to reduce or eliminate four city taxes: the unincorporated business tax, the commercial rent tax, the surcharge on on the personal income tax and the hotel occupancy tax. But he says spending cuts must come first.
 *Would use city tax incentives to create Enterprise Zones for business. Proposes small Community Development Banks to assist small business in poor neighborhoods.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: Montana's Sky and Its Hopes Are Left Bare After Logging

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MISSOULA, Mont., Oct. 14

 BODY:
Throughout the 1980's, the Champion International Corporation went on a tree-cutting spree in Montana, leveling entire forests at a rate that had not been seen since the cut-and-run logging days of the last century.
Now the hangover has arrived. After liquidating much of its valuable timber in the Big Sky country, Champion is pulling out of Montana, leaving behind hundreds of unemployed mill workers, towns staggered by despair and more than a thousand square miles of heavily logged land. 
 In one of the nation's biggest private land deals, Champion this month is selling all 867,000 acres of its Montana land -- for $300 an acre -- to the Plum Creek Timber Company, based in Seattle. Plum Creek has been called "the Darth Vader" of timber companies by former Representative Rod Chandler of Washington, a Republican, but it now says it is committed to a less destructive type of forestry.
The deal has revived a century-old complaint about large, distant corporations exploiting Montana for its natural resources and then leaving after the land is exhausted. For all the glamour that has been attached to the state in recent years with the arrival of movie stars and the state's celebration on screen and in print, Champion's final chapter in Montana is evidence to many people here that much of the state's economy still resembles that of a third world country.
 
Evidence of Exploitation
 The sell-off of Champion's land and mills, which are expected to close at the end of this month, could not come at worse time for Montana's economy, which has been racked by layoffs by other out-of-state corporations.
"Champion came in here promising they would be here forever, and then just overcut all the trees and left," said Dr. Thomas Power, chairman of the economics department at the University of Montana in Missoula. "We are left paying the piper."
The company speaks of changing goals, not broken promises. Champion, which is based in Stamford, Conn., and had $5 billion in sales last year, says it is getting out of Montana because its best corporate interests lie elsewhere, in pulp and paper mills in the South and the East. It will pay severance for people who lose their jobs, and it will contribute to a community fund.
"For Champion to leave has been very difficult, and we are very sympathetic to those people and very sad," said Tucker Hill, a spokesman for the company. "But I don't think you can hold a company's feet to the fire for everything they did over the last 20 years."
The company will leave behind much anger and pain, evident in everything from the Champion sign outside Missoula over which has been scrawled the words, "No more rape and run," to the merchants in the small mill towns of Bonner, five miles east of here, and Libby, in northwestern Montana, who say they may have to close up shop.
One thing the sale has done is brought environmentalists and timber workers together. When business was good, few complaints about overcutting were heard from timber workers, while environmentalists warned that eventually both the trees and the jobs would disappear. Now they have joined in a common cry of outrage.
"I've been in the timber industry since 1951, and this is the biggest single blow I've seen -- far worse than any cutbacks from environmental restrictions," said James A. Hill, a Missoula native and a leader of the Western Council of Industrial Workers, which represents various timber unions.
 
1,500 Get Layoff Notices
 In ending its operations in Montana, Champion will lay off nearly 1,500 workers at two mills at the end of this month. About half of those workers expect to be hired back, at an undetermined wage with a different company, the Stimson Lumber Company of Portland, Ore., which bought Champion's Montana mills. Plum Creek will buy the land, giving it 2.1 million acres in the Pacific Northwest.
While most of the battle over logging has focused on Federal land, the big private companies have been cutting timber on their own land -- particularly here in Montana -- at a pace that would be against the law if it had happened on public land.
A study made public last month by the University of Montana found that for Plum Creek and Champion had logged their forests in Montana at a rate nearly three times faster than new trees could grow back -- abandoning the industry's frequently stated principle of cutting at a sustained yield. Federal law requires the Forest Service, a branch of the Department of Agriculture, to log at a sustained rate.
As a result, western Montana is a checkerboard with huge, clear-cut tracts where all the trees were cut down during the roaring 1980's. And biologists and some Montanans say that some of the state's premier trout streams, like the Big Blackfoot River, the site of Norman Maclean's fishing memoir, "A River Runs Through It," are in peril from soil erosion.
 
Mountains Without Trees
 "I came here as a war bride, in 1947, and it was just paradise in these mountains," said Maria Fraser of Libby, a timber town of 2,500 people that is facing an exodus because of cutbacks at the Champion mill. "The mountains are still here, but they look like a desert after Champion and Plum Creek cut all the trees down."
Libby is a place "where people were raised to think if they take care of the woods, the woods will take care of you," said Andrew H. Malcolm, a spokesman for Gov. Marc Racicot, a Republican.
"Then along came these pressures from outside the region, changing the rules, and these people are the lost souls," he said.
Most of the clear-cut land has been replanted. But because of Montana's harsh climate and the high elevation of most of its forests, it can take a century to grow trees big enough to be cut.
Champion decided to close its Montana operations as part of its overall strategy to concentrate on paper manufacturing rather than lumbering, corporate officials said. Two years earlier, the company closed a big mill here in Missoula. It says it is doing everything it can to make life easier for the people who will be out of work and for the communities that will lose their only major employer.
 
$1.2 Million in Compensation
 Under pressure from Montana political leaders, Champion, Plum Creek and Stimson have agreed to pay $1.2 million to help the communities that will be hit hard by the land sale and subsequent layoffs. But critics say the overall compensation is a pittance, particularly from a corporation like Champion.
Champion bought most of its Montana land in 1972 from Anaconda Copper, a company that used to control the state's resources and its newspapers with an iron grip. Before that, the land was part of a 40-million-acre parcel that Lincoln, as President, gave to the railroad companies as an incentive to build a rail line across the country. It will now go to Plum Creek, which is a corporate descendant of the original railroad company that got the biggest piece of Federal largess.
The 1864 railroad land grants still haunt much of the West. When the land was given away, the railroads were awarded every other square mile in a corridor. A map of the land resembles a checkerboard, with Forest Service property in Montana interspersed with Champion or Plum Creek land. That pattern on the map looks the same on the ground in some parts of the state after a decade in which the two big private timber companies clear-cut their square mile patches.
"The land has been replanted," said Mr. Hill, the company spokesman. "Not that it's a perfect situation. But it's a well-managed forest. And it will be in production in years to come."
Plum Creek officials say they will cut about 100 million board feet a year on the land they are are buying from Champion. But some environmentalists say there are not enough trees to provide that volume. "What I suspect they will do is cut what they can and then subdivide some of the land into ranchettes," said Michael Scott of the Wilderness Society in Bozeman, Mont.
Rick Holley, who has just been named as Plum Creek's next president and chief executive, said in an interview that "only a very small amount" of land would probably be sold as subdivisions.
The excessive cutting on private land has prompted timber managers in the adjoining Lolo National Forest to place some public land off limits to logging. They say the overall ecology of certain areas is at risk.
"Champion's legacy is a disaster in certain river valleys," said Professor Power. "Environmentalists warned of this, and now it's come to pass."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A study made public last month by the University of Montana found that over the last 10 years two big companies logged their forests in Montana at a rate nearly three times faster than new trees could grow back. As a result, western Montana, including this area near Lolo National Forest, is a checkerboard of huge, clear-cut tracts where timber managers have placed some public land off limits to logging. (Jeff Green for The New York Times) (pg. A26)

HEADLINE: HOUSE REPUBLICANS REBEL OVER TAXES IN FREE TRADE PACT

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
With the fate of the North American Free Trade Agreement turning on a few undecided lawmakers, the Clinton Administration is now threatened with the loss of a group that is central to the White House's legislative strategy: conservative Republicans.
House Republicans have rebelled at the prospect of $2.37 billion in higher taxes over five years to replace tariffs eliminated by the free trade agreement, inflicting a serious blow to the pact's prospects with the vote only a month away. 
 The increases, amounting to $5 a ticket, would be on the international airline and cruise ticket tax for travelers entering the United States by air or sea, and on fees for trucks and trains entering the country.
 
A Get-Tough Letter
 The free trade agreement cannot pass without strong Republican support because a majority of House Democrats oppose it. Twenty-seven House Republicans, including Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip, sent a letter this afternoon to President Clinton threatening to withdraw their support.
"It would be difficult for many of us to support a Nafta which included tax increases," said the letter, which was signed only by Republicans who had endorsed the agreement or had been leaning toward endorsement.
The opposition is to the tax increases, not the agreement itself. The stance is a Republican bargaining position in the struggle over how to raise money, and it reflects resentment at the White House for expecting Republicans to bear most of the burden of voting for an unpopular pact.
 
The Straw and the Camel
 The Administration proposal last week for the higher ticket fees "could be the straw that broke the camel's back," said Representative Thomas W. Ewing, the Illinois Republican who organized the letter.
The letter called for spending cuts to replace the fees on travelers, trucks and trains, an approach that the Administration has rejected so far because it creates many political and procedural problems.
If approved by both houses of Congress, the pact would gradually remove tariffs and other trade barriers between Canada, Mexico and the United States beginning on Jan. 1.
The dispute over paying for the pact is already delaying Congressional consideration of the agreement, members of the House and Senate say.
The House Ways and Means Committee, the lead committee in the House because it handles tax and tariffs issues, is scheduled to vote Tuesday on legislation putting the agreement into law. Representative Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat and committee member who is leading House supporters of the agreement, said this evening that the committee would probably act without having the financing in place.
 
Looking at the Options
 "I think it is serious," he said. "We're going to have to look at a number of different options." Mr. Matsui added that the Administration was almost certain to retreat from forcing transportation industries to bear the full burden.
An Administration official said tonight that Mickey Kantor, the United States Trade Representative, would present the tax increase proposal at the committee hearing but would stress that no final Administration decision had been made.
Mr. Matsui said he was optimistic that a new method of financing the trade pact could be found that would be acceptable to the conservative Republicans. "If we decided to drop Nafta because we couldn't raise $2.4 billion over five years for tariffs, or because we couldn't afford a $100 million retraining program, it would really send a signal throughout the world that this country is not an economic power," Mr. Matsui said.
The pact was negotiated by the Bush Administration and has the support of Republican leaders in both houses. Mr. Kantor said today at a breakfast with reporters that the Administration hoped to win over 100 House Democrats, suggesting that the support of 118 House Republicans would be needed.
Conservative Republicans, who loathe tax increases, have been the bedrock of that support because of their enthusiasm for free markets and free trade.
Critics and supporters of the agreement say that the Senate is more likely to approve the pact. But the House is scheduled to vote first, most likely on Nov. 17.
The problem of financing the trade agreement arises because Congressional budget rules require that tax and tariff cuts be offset by higher taxes or cuts in mandatory spending programs like Medicare.
The pact would reduce American revenues from import tariffs by $2.36 billion over the next five years, a sum that the Administration proposes to raise by doubling customs inspection fees on international travelers, trucks and rail cars and eliminating certain exemptions from the fees.
The proposal has prompted vociferous lobbying by the nation's travel industry, particularly major airlines, because the fees are included in the price of airline and cruise tickets. Because the airlines employ tens of thousands of highly organized workers and because of their history as a regulated industry until the late 1970's, the airlines maintain strong connections to members of Congress.
Mr. Gingrich's district included the headquarters of Delta Air Lines until the district lines were redrawn before last year's election, and he still represents many airline workers.
 
Where Cuts Might Come
 Mr. Ewing suggested that cuts should be made instead in automatic spending programs, notably food stamps. Tony Blankley, the press secretary for Mr. Gingrich, said the Republican leader would like to see an exception made to the House budget rules to allow the use of cuts in discretionary spending programs to offset the lost tariffs.
But while House rules are easily changed, Senate rules in effect since the 1990 budget agreement effectively require that such an exception win the support of 60 senators. Senator Max S. Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's trade panel and supports the agreement, said that 60 votes were too many to find.
Mr. Blankley said Mr. Gingrich still wanted to support Nafta and was confident that a procedural solution could be found.
Mr. Kantor said the free trade agreement would actually increase Federal tax revenues by several billion dollars by stimulating extra economic growth in the United States that could be taxed. But the budget rules forbid the use of such secondary effects in calculating how to offset lost tax revenues.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
Seventeen of Wall Street's leading underwriting firms said they would stop making political contributions to state and local candidates who might determine underwriting assignments for municipal bonds. [Page A1.] 
 Morgan Guaranty Trust reduced its prime lending rate to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent, the first of the nation's largest banks to do so. The first bank to match Morgan was the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, a midsized Chicago bank. [D1.]
 
Companies
John Sculley, who resigned Friday as chairman of Apple Computer, became head of Spectrum Information Technologies, a little-known wireless networking company. [D1.] Spectrum shares soared $3.50 to $11.125 on the news of its new chief executive. [D1.]
Champion International sold nearly 900,000 acres of its timberland in Montana, then closed its mills and packed up to leave. Now it is accused of the worst kind of cut-and-run forestry. [A1.]
 Arbitron left the battlefield of television ratings, unable to trip up the industry Goliath, the A. C. Nielsen Company.[D1.]
Shell Oil and Chemical Bank will offer a joint Mastercard that will let drivers save 3 percent when they buy Shell gasoline. [D1.]
Chase Manhattan's third-quarter earnings rose 52 percent. PNC Financial had record profits, Nationsbank an earnings drop. [D2.]
Profits at Liz Claiborne, the clothing manufacturer, plunged more than 40 percent in the third quarter. [D4.]
Merck and American Home Products reported single-digit growth in third-quarter sales and modest profit gains. [D4.]
A maker of armored limousines for royalty and heads of state says the time is ripe for an armored car for the common man. [D4.]
Bell Atlantic met with Cablevision before Tele-Communications, industry executives said. [D30.]
 
International
With French unemployment at 11.7 percent, more people there are worrying about their handwriting. A number of French companies subject job applicants' letters to graphological tests. [D1.]
To prepare Groupe Bull for privatization, France named a new chairman for the largely state-owned computer giant. [D4.]
The Clinton Administration faces a loss of support from conservative Republicans on the North American Free Trade Agreement. [A1.] President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico said the region would feel cheated if the United States Congress were to vote down the trade pact. [A10.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks scored modest gains as the Dow rose 12.58 points, to 3,642.31. Broader indicators slipped. [D6.]
In what traders talked of as a piece of an overdue correction, the interest rates on long-term Treasury bonds moved higher, settling above Friday's record low rates. [D25.]
The dollar rose against most currencies as investors looked forward to Germany and others cutting interest rates. [D23.]
The price of gold rose to the highest level since the beginning of September. Prices of other precious metals rose as well. [D23.]
Today's Columns
An analyst says that many on Wall Street "just don't get it" by not jumping at shares of Crown Cork and Seal. Market Place. [D6.]
At the annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers, the clamor grew for ways to measure the effectiveness of advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D28.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chase Posts 52% Jump In Third-Quarter Net

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it earned $267 million in the third quarter, up 52 percent from a year earlier on the strength of high trading profits, fewer problems from bad loans and a wide spread between what it pays for deposits and what it charges for loans.
Also yesterday, the PNC Bank Corporation, the holding company for Pittsburgh National Bank, reported record profits, and Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C., posted a drop in earnings. 
 Chase's third-quarter profit was the latest in a long string of reports showing that Chase has rebuilt its business after suffering losses totaling nearly $1 billion in 1989 and 1990. Through the first nine months of this year, profits totaled $653 million, or more than it earned in all of last year.
 
 
Stock Drops
 Despite the strong performance, which was in line with results reported by other large banks recently, Chase stock fell sharply yesterday to $34.125 a share, down $1.75. Investors and traders who have worried for months that bank profits could be undermined by higher interest rates reacted yesterday to the cut in the prime rate by Morgan Guarantee Trust to 5.5 percent from 6 percent -- a move that reduces bank revenues even if there is no increase in the general level of interest rates.
At a meeting with analysts yesterday, E. Michel Kruse, Chase's chief financial officer, told analysts that a drop of half of a percent in the prime rate would reduce Chase's revenues by about $46 million, or 1.25 percent of the $3.7 billion of its interest spread, the difference between the rates it pays on deposits and other borrowed money and the rates it earns on loans and investments.
Nationsbank said yesterday that profits from its basic banking business were at a record level, though special charges kept third-quarter profits slightly lower than a year ago.
The company said its $341 million profit in the quarter ended Sept. 30 was reduced by $30 million for special charges relating to its merger this month with MNC Corporation, a Baltimore-based banking company. The $350 million profit it reported a year earlier was increased, the company said, by a special gain of $55 million from the sale of part of its home mortgage business.
 
 
Diminishing Problems
 Nationsbank, whose acquisitions in recent years have made it the country's fifth-largest banking company, has been pushing hard to increase its business lending in recent quarters. Total loans grew at a rate of more than 10 percent in the second quarter, and diminishing problems with bad loans allowed the company to set aside just $100 million of profit for its loan-loss reserve, down from $150 million a year earlier.
PNC, the 10th-largest banking company in the country, said yesterday that it earned a record $217.7 million in the third quarter, up 64 percent from a year earlier.
The company, which has one of the industry's best records for controlling costs, said noninterest expenses fell to $345.9 million from $362.3 million a year earlier. At the same time, it said, loans grew to $27.4 billion from $24.4 billion.
Costs of troubled loans also continued to decline, as the company put only $50 million into its loan-loss reserve, down from $69.9 million a year earlier.

HEADLINE: In France, It's How You Cross the t's

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 15

 BODY:
Increasingly tormented after six months of unemployment, Michel Malat, a 40-year-old former furniture sales manager, made an unusual decision: he decided to have his handwriting analyzed by an expert.
"I had sent over 250 applications for jobs, all written by hand, and I knew that my writing was being analyzed by companies in order to gauge my character," Mr. Malat explained. "And the more rejections I received, the more I worried my handwriting was suspect." 
 As French unemployment has soared to a rate of 11.7 percent, or 3.2 million people, an increase of more than 10 percent in the last year alone, more and more people here are worrying about their handwriting. Because a growing number of French corporations routinely subject the handwritten letters from job applicants, particularly for management positions, to graphological tests, the loops, slants, margins and flourishes of handwritten letters have assumed considerable importance.
In Mr. Malat's case, the analysis was generally positive. He was judged intelligent, balanced and caring. But, the report noted, "he may lack flexibility and inventiveness because of a tendency to reject what he judges to be over-imaginative or idealistic."
Poppycock? Graphology, or the analysis of handwriting as a means to understand character, has no proven scientific value and is not widely used by American companies. Some German companies have used graphology, but it is among French corporations that a job applicant's script has become a crucial indicator of personal qualities and flaws. As competition for jobs has grown, the technique's use has spread as a way to narrow the field and even to choose between finalists -- prompting some heated debate on its merits.
"Graphology is useless, psychological nonsense," said Bernard Krieff, the owner of a large Parisian recruiting consulting firm that bears his name. "Only if a company really insists will we have an analysis done. I personally sent the same handwriting to a graphologist on two separate occasions, and received two totally different results."
But the majority of companies, including other recruiting consultants, have a different view. "It would be very badly viewed if a job applicant sent a typewritten letter," said Jean-Pierre Verdier, the head of management recruitment for the state-owned cigarette manufacturer Seita. "We would have the impression that the person is trying to hide something."
Seita, which has annual sales exceeding $2 billion, routinely analyzes the penmanship of potential corporate managers. On Mr. Verdier's desk, piles of handwritten letters could be seen. Sometimes the company merely wants a "grapho flash," a quick, two-sentence assessment of a candidate's principal traits based on the letter; at other times, when important positions are to be filled and a handful of applicants remain, a full analysis of the letter is requested.
Mr. Verdier insisted that the method was generally good and reassuring to French managers raised to value instinct and impressions over the sort of rational scrutiny used in American multiple-choice tests. But, he said, handwriting was only one element among many used in making a choice. "Only if the graphology revealed something bizarre would we think again," he added.
Martine Clement, a Seita spokeswoman, said, "You may suddenly find that a person you are about to hire as an accountant has a tendency toward deviousness."
Not all French companies are willing to reveal their reliance on graphology, although almost all advertisements for jobs request a handwritten letter.
An Air France spokeswoman acknowledged that the company used the technique, but said she was unable to talk about it at a time when the money-losing carrier was trying to cut more than 4,000 jobs. At FNAC, a large chain of record and book stores, an official also said graphology was used but declined to elaborate.
Pascale Slama, a spokeswoman for Moulinex, the manufacturer of household appliances, said the company began using graphological analysis for management jobs two years ago.
 
Qualifications Questioned
 In France, there is no official recognition of graphology, which was invented 122 years ago by a French priest named Jean-Hyppolite Michon. The closest thing to a formal qualification is admission to the French Society of Graphologists, which imposes a stringent exam for which at least three years of study and a university degree are required. Only about 300 people, mostly women, have passed the society's exam, but thousands of other self-styled experts are known to practice graphology.
"I am shocked by the people I see calling themselves graphologists these days," said Marie-France Szymanek, who is a member of the Society of Graphologists. "The fact is you need long study to become familiar with the over 270 types of writing -- and unqualified people are bringing our profession into disrepute."
Mrs. Szymanek is a full-time employee of the Lille-based L'Office du Nord, a manager of low-rent housing. She earns her salary doing graphological analysis for all the company's job applicants, but she also does freelance work. Graphology, she concedes, is not a science, but is, she says, 70 percent effective in uncovering character traits.
One candidate for a job at L'Office du Nord was summarized in Mrs. Szymanek's report as "an earthy individual, who likes contact with people; a little disordered, with a lack of perspective, but conviction in his way of getting a message across."
As such reports pour into French companies, which are being urged by Prime Minister Edouard Balladur to stem the rising tide of unemployment, graphology is being widely questioned in a spate of newspaper and magazine articles. Le Nouvel Observateur noted recently that writing leaning at more than 45 degrees to the right was regarded by some experts as a sign of an uncontrollably passionate nature.
Mrs. Szymanek conceded that graphologists were under fire. "I know we cause some anguish," she said, "but the real cause of anguish is the state of the economy."
What seems clear is that French companies have no intention of dropping their graphological inclinations. "Americans use figures," Le Nouvel Observateur concluded, "while we prefer impressions. We like grace, emotion, approximation. Instinct. We are probably not made for the modern world."

HEADLINE: N.Y.U. Opens Research Laboratory for AIDS

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
New York University Medical Center, providing what some experts hope will be a cornerstone for an expanding biomolecular research industry in New York City, yesterday opened a $75 million laboratory devoted entirely to scientists who will seek new treatments for cancer, AIDS and other diseases.
The laboratory, part of a new, 23-story university building on First Avenue off 30th Street, is to employ 70 to 80 scientists in full-time research, university officials said. 
 In a city that is already home to a vast network of hospitals and medical schools, the New York University project is considered important to both scientific research and economic development. Many officials, including Mayor David N. Dinkins, have pointed to biotechnology as a growth industry that should have a larger presence in New York City than it now has.
Recent studies show that the city has been losing out to other parts of the country in the type of laboratory research that leads to new treatments, products and private companies. A report last November by the New York Academy of Medicine found that the city's share of grant money from two of the Federal Government's largest medical research agencies had fallen to 7.3 percent in 1990 from 8.1 percent in 1987.
 
Philanthropic Gifts
 The report said that biomedical research remained a large industry for the city, responsible for 32,600 jobs and $2.3 billion in economic activity. But as measured by the volume of Federal grants from the National Institutes of Health and the Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration, it said New York City had been surpassed by Boston as a research center.
The New York University Medical Center laboratory "is not only a major commitment to the future of medicine, but also a commitment to help New York City retain its position as the nation's leading biomedical research center," said Thomas S. Murphy, chairman of the medical center's board of trustees.
The laboratory, named the Skirball Institute of Biomolecular Medicine, has been financed by philanthropic gifts, mainly from the Tisch family of New York and the Skirball Foundation. It fills four floors of the new building, where the other floors are largely meant for staff and student housing.
Besides the New York University laboratory, another research project, financed at $26 million in a joint venture between the city, state and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, is scheduled to be completed in late 1994. It will provide space for several commercial biotechnology companies at the Columbia-Presbyterian site in upper Manhattan.
Although the New York University laboratory has been built with university money, experts said the research it supports is most likely to attract financing from other sources, including the Federal Government and venture capital funds.
One such fund has been proposed by Mayor Dinkins, who, as part of his re-election campaign, has proposed a new economic strategy in which 12 industries, including biotechnology, would be designated for city assistance. The Mayor wants to channel $120 million, most of it from the Federal Small Business Administration, into a venture capital fund, for investment in high technology concerns.
"Nobody at New York University Medical Center will turn their backs on venture capital," said Martin S. Begun, the center's associate dean. He added that the intent of the new institute was to "get the stuff that comes out of our laboratories to the market."

HEADLINE: Can a Governor Really Save Jobs?;
New Jersey Candidates Debate Role of State's Top Official

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LINDEN, N.J., Oct. 15

 BODY:
Two newly minted pickup trucks in dazzling colors are on display in front of the General Motors assembly plant here, and what they represent depends on who is doing the telling.
To G.M., the new S-line trucks represent the latest entry in the wildly popular sports-utility vehicle market. To Bill Wisk, a 47-year-old assembly line worker, they represent a return, after a long layoff, to a highly paid manufacturing job. 
 And because the state helped G.M. to retrain Mr. Wisk and 2,400 others, state officials regard the trucks as a small but promising part of its effort to keep good jobs from leaving New Jersey.
It is efforts like these -- from worker retraining programs to huge, state-financed construction projects -- that Gov. Jim Florio touts as he seeks a second term. His Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, meanwhile, consistently blames Governor Florio for the loss of tens of thousands of jobs in New Jersey since he took office in January 1990.
Beyond the campaign oratory, there is a broader question: How much can a governor, or any state official, do about a state's economy, especially when market forces operate not only nationally but internationally?
 
Questioning a Governor's Impact
 "If you got elected governor of this state and you went to Maine for four years instead of to Trenton, the economy when you got back would not be very different from what it was when you left," said Bruce Coe, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, a lobbying group. "Governors themselves aren't going to create that many jobs, and they aren't going to lose that many jobs."
But Mr. Coe said that does not let Mr. Florio off the hook.
"I don't think when Governor Florio became Governor that he had the business community and what their needs are very high on his priority list," Mr. Coe said, contrasting Mr. Florio with his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, who consistently declared that a healthy business climate was the foundation for other state economic efforts.
 
Taxes Against Growth
 That is the thrust of Mrs. Whitman's argument when she maintains, in commercials and debates, that Mr. Florio is responsible for the loss of 280,000 jobs in the state. In fact, the decline in nonfarm employment from January 1990 to last August, the most recent figures available, was 205,300 jobs, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"I would argue that the Governor has not used the tax structure of this state to encourage jobs growth, and that in fact he has used it to discourage growth," said Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman. "When you take $2.8 billion out of the economy and send it to Trenton for some not totally specified purpose, that money is not going to be spent in the private sector."
Moreover, Mr. Golden added, it is inconsistent for the Florio administration to blame the recession for the state's punishing job losses while taking credit for the bright spots.
Governor Florio's spokeswoman, Jo Astrid Glading, defended his record.
"No governor can change the course of a national recession that has hit the Northeast particularly hard," she said, "but Jim Florio has in fact made his priority the creation of jobs, whether it be a small business confronting a credit crunch and needing assistance to grow, or a large business who needed help upgrading the skills of its work force."
An official who has served in both the Kean and Florio administrations said that there are things state leaders can do -- within limits.
"States can do a lot, but they clearly can't do it all -- they can be very effective around the edges," said Bob Hughey, who was Mr. Kean's Environmental Protection Commissioner and who spent the last year as head of the Office of Economic Recovery, a program put together by the Governor and the Republican-controlled State Legislature.
Mr. Hughey calculated that the state has laid the groundwork for the creation of 30,000 jobs through its major economic development programs, including the Economic Development Authority's low-cost loan program to small businesses and the Commission on Science and Technology, which provides seed money for high-technology start-up ventures.
 
Workers Are Grateful
 State economic development officials are used to taking credit for "saving" the Linden General Motors plant by helping the company pay for worker retraining. But Richard A. Monkaba, the plant manager, said the money from the state was only a fraction of the hundreds of millions of dollars the company has invested to modify the ancient plant, which once built World War II Grumman fighters, he said. The company spent a total of $16 million in training its 2,400 workers, he said. The $4.5 million from the state was welcome, he added, but not the deciding factor.
"The money from the state allowed us to do the kind of training we wanted to do in the time frame we wanted," Mr. Monkaba said.
Whatever the source of the training money, the workers inside the plant spoke gratefully of being given a chance to view their jobs from a new perspective. And state officials said they hope such efforts will ultimately give the state a better work force, new investment and more jobs.
"Used to be, they'd hand us a part and say, 'It goes on like this,' and sometimes it did, and sometimes it didn't," said Mr. Wisk, who checks the electrical systems of the newly assembled trucks. "In the training sessions, right from the get-go, we were talking to engineers, we were going over training vehicles with them, talking about how to do things. It makes you feel good about the job."
New Jersey spends $50 million a year, partly from the state unemployment insurance fund, to retrain workers through cooperative ventures with companies and grants to individuals. The figure per worker is higher than in all other states but California and Iowa, according to a recent study sponsored by the University of California. In the last year about 45,000 New Jersey residents have undergone retraining.
But as Joseph Capobianco of Roselle Park has found out, being trained for new jobs does not guarantee employment.
Mr. Capobianco, 56, an electrical draftsman with 30 years' experience, was laid off last fall from his $48,000-a-year job at I.T.T. Avionics in Nutley. He took two college courses in computer-aided design last year, with the state paying the $1,274 tuition, but since then has found work for only five months. Now he is looking again.
An audit of the United States Labor Department's $200 million retraining program found that only 20 percent of retrained workers found jobs that paid close to their former salaries. New Jersey, like many other states, is looking to high technology as a way to replace some of the jobs lost as older industries shrink and die.
Since 1985, the Science and Technology Commission program founded by former Governor Kean has given money to start-up companies that develop new products, hoping that new employment will follow. Several years ago, the program awarded a $40,000 grant to Envirogen Inc. of Lawrenceville, a 5-year-old venture to develop new ways to dispose of hazardous waste.
"Large companies are downsizing, they're getting rid of people, not growing, and New Jersey certainly has a large number of large companies," said Roger Colley, the president of Envirogen, which employs 90 people. "So the state's theory is that the small companies like mine will grow to fill the void, and that's where state programs can do the most good."

Jim Florio campaigned yesterday at the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 456, in North Brunswick. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Issues Gain as Most Others Drop

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
After a wobbly start, blue-chip stocks racked up modest gains yesterday, driven by spurts among the pharmaceutical and transportation issues. But broader indicators slipped as uneasiness over interest rates and fears that the market could not sustain its recent highs seemed to take their toll.
Bank stocks suffered after the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reduced its prime lending rate to 5.5 percent from 6 percent. Investors appeared worried that the move would chip away at the growing profits of banks like the Chase Manhattan Corporation, whose stock dropped 1 3/4, to 34 1/8. Citicorp, the most active stock on the Big Board, fell 1 3/4, to 35 5/8. 
 The Signet Banking Corporation, Wells Fargo & Company, the First Chicago Corporation and the Banc One Corporation also declined.
 
Telecommunications Stocks Ease
 Telecommunications stocks, which surged last week on the news of the merger between Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications Inc., lost ground, as did financial-service stocks. Bell Atlantic dropped 2, to 65, and U S West fell 1, to 48 7/8.
Over all, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.58 points, to 3,642.31, led by the Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Company, Allied Signal, and the General Motors Corporation. Because those companies' balance sheets are generally tied to the health of the economy, the gains seemed to reflect some optimism among investors that the pace of the recovery may soon pick up, some analysts said.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 329.6 million shares, down from 366.1 million shares on Friday. Declining stocks led advancing issues, 1,048 to 1,021. Pushed by rises in airline stocks, the Dow Jones transportation average increased 14.96 points, to 1,655.91.
The Amex composite index dropped 2.13 points, to 481.10. After a week of record highs, the Nasdaq index dropped as investors cashed in some of the gains. The Nasdaq composite was off 4.51 points, to 782.91.
"The belief is growing that the market is getting a little overheated," said Harry W. Laubscher, a senior vice president at Tucker Anthony Inc. in New York. "This has been evidenced by the rapid runoff on the Nasdaq stocks. They are off today because of profit taking."
Rao Chalasani, chief investment strategist for Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago, described yesterday's trading as "ho-hum," noting that the long-term bond market, where interest rates rose, dragged the stock market down. The stock and bond markets often move in tandem because the lower yields that come with higher bond prices make stocks more attractive.
"The engine for the most recent rally, interest rates, seems to be absent," Mr. Chalasani said.
Stock in pharmaceutical companies, particularly Merck & Company, the world's largest drug concern, rose yesterday after Merck reported third-quarter profits that exceeded analysts' predictions. Merck shot up 1 1/4, to 32 1/4, while the American Home Products Corporation closed unchanged at 63 1/8.
 
Other Active Stocks
 Among other active stocks, Liz Claiborne dropped 1 1/8, to 20, after it said its income fell for the third quarter. ITT, which said last week that it would trim 1,100 jobs from its executive payroll, declined 2, to 90 7/8.
Unicare Financial Corporation surged 7 7/8, to 27 5/8 after the Wellpoint Health Networks said it would buy Unicare. Wellpoint dipped 1/4, to 26 1/2.
Caremark International was down 1 7/8, to 16 1/8, after The Wall Street Journal reported that a two-year investigation was focusing on the company's dealings with the University of Minnesota Hospital.
In Nasdaq trading, Spectrum Information Technologies soared 3 1/2, to 11 1/8, after the company said that John Sculley, who resigned Friday as chairman of Apple Computer, had been named Spectrum's chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: Shell Joins Chemical on Credit Card

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
The Shell Oil Company and the Chemical Bank will offer a joint Mastercard on Nov. 1 under which drivers will be able to save 3 percent when they buy Shell gasoline or 2 percent on other purchases for rebates of up to $70 a year on Shell gasoline purchases.
After they reach $70 a year in savings, customers could then get only 1 percent off their purchases of Shell gasoline. 
 The move is the largest yet by an oil company, many of which have increasingly been allowing their customers to use what are called "co-branded" bank cards -- that is jointly sponsored cards -- to buy gas.
 
Seeking Brand Awareness
 Robert K. Heady, publisher of the Bank Rate Monitor, of North Palm Beach, Fla., said that sponsors of co-branded credit cards, including General Motors, A.T.& T. and General Electric, "are trying to create more brand awareness and move more products" by offering rebates or other incentives. "The upshot for consumers is that it is putting downward pressure on rates," he said, but it is also adding to saturation and confusion.
With General Motors cards, users can get 10 percent off the purchase of new G.M. cars; with A.T.& T. users can get a 10 percent discount on long-distances calls, and General Electric cards offer rebates at a variety of stores. In addition, G.M. has teamed up with some partners, including Mobil, for additional rebates.
General Motors is expected to announced today that it will allow its card to be used in some foreign countries, but no further enhancements are expected, according to an industry executive who did not want to be identified.
Studies have shown that the average household credit card user buys about $3,000 a year on credit cards. Thus, Shell estimated that the typical user's gasoline rebates could be about $60 to $70 a year, provided the card is used not only for gas but also for most other credit card purchases.
However, Mr. Heady cautioned, consumers should look beyond the rebates and compare cards' annual fees, interest rates and grace periods on purchases in deciding which cards to use. Cards with no annual fees are best for customers who pay off their charges each month, he said, while those with low interest rates are best for people who carry balances.
 
Annual Fee Rules
 With the Shell-Chemical card, there is no annual fee for the first year for those who sign up before April 30, 1994, and the annual fee will be waived thereafter if the card is used at least six times a year. The initial interest rate will be 15 percent -- prime rate plus 9 percent. The grace period is 25 days on gasoline purchases, but interest is charged immediately on other purchases, partly offsetting the 2 percent interest rates.
In comparison, Mr. Heady said, the average rate on credit cards issued by the 100 largest banks and thrift units is 17.95 percent, and most have a grace period of 25 to 30 days. However, he added, much lower rates are available for people with good credit ratings. For example, Arkansas Federal Card Services, Little Rock, Ark., in conjunction with the Wachovia Corporation, Winston-Salem, N.C., offers variable rate cards that are now at 7.75 percent and have a $50 annual fee.
As the oil companies install automatic equipment at their stations where drivers can fuel up and pay by credit card without the need for an attendant, they have expanded the types of cards customers can use to buy gas. This has made most oil company cards, which offer no rebates, less competitive.
Bill Schutzenhofer, the vice president of marketing for Shell, said that "the future of oil company cards hangs in the balance. It's not that people don't like them or use them, but there are so many new potential offerings."
Shell will continue to offer its own card, he said, but he predicted that most people would chose the combination card with the rebates.
Chemical will offer the card to about 9 million customers by direct mail, including about 4 million of the 6 million current holders of a Shell card.
 
Ad Campaign Planned
 Charles R. Walsh, the executive vice president who heads Chemical's retail card servicers group, said that it would be one of the biggest introductions of a credit card, accompanied with a nationwide advertising campaign.
The average consumer buys about 500 to 600 gallons of gasoline a year. Thus, Shell estimated, if the average card user earns rebates of $70 a year, it would amount to a 10 percent reduction of the user's annual gasoline bill.
The rebates would be awarded each month and would be automatically applied to future purchases of Shell gasoline, except in New Jersey.
Shell spent about $1 million in market research on the card. Shell, which has about 8,700 service stations in the United States, is one of the largest gasoline retailers in the country.

HEADLINE: Prime Rate Cut to 5 1/2% By Morgan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Morgan Guaranty Trust Company reduced its prime lending rate to 5 1/2 percent from 6 percent yesterday, the first among the nation's largest banks to take that step.
While the rate cut matters little to Morgan's customers, millions of individuals and small businesses could benefit if other banks follow. Because Morgan's business is concentrated in trading and in advising large companies -- with little consumer or business lending pegged to the prime, other bankers and analysts said the large New York bank was cutting the price of something it does not sell. 
 "It's very bizarre, and can only hurt their brethren at other banks," said George Salem, a banking analyst at Prudential Securities. "Maybe they are looking for some favor from Washington," he added, noting that the Clinton Administration is counting on low interest rates to stimulate the economy.
 
Matched by Harris
 The first bank to match Morgan's 5 1/2 percent rate was the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago, a $10 billion asset bank owned by the Bank of Montreal.
"We want to compete aggressively for new business, and lowering the prime rate is one way to do that," Donald S. Hunt, president of Harris Trust, said. Since Harris broke ranks on Sept. 17 by lowering its prime to 5 3/4 percent, Mr. Hunt said, it has experienced a "strong increase in customer inquires."
Even if the inquiries do not result in enough new loans to compensate immediately for the decline in revenue caused by the lower rate, Mr. Hunt said, the rate-cutting approach is best for the bank because it builds good will among customers. "I sure have not had any customer call me to say 'I wish you hadn't cut the prime,' " he said.
Several large banks, including Chemical in New York, decided yesterday morning to hold their prime rates at 6 percent. But the idea that banks would eventually cut the prime rate and suffer reduced profits as a result was widespread enough to push bank stocks lower. Among the biggest losers, apart from Morgan, which fell $1.625, to $74.50, were Citicorp, down $1.75, to $35.625, and the Chemical Banking Corporation, down $1.5, to $42.
Analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods estimated that a half-point cut in the prime would not be devastating to bank profits. Those profits have been at record levels the last year partly because of an unusually wide spread between the rates banks pay for deposits and the rates they earn on loans and investments. At Citicorp, whose credit card business helps give it more loans linked to the prime than any other bank, they estimated that the cut could cost $75 million after taxes, or about 3 percent of the profits analysts expect next year.
According to Federal Reserve surveys of bank lending, the proportion of business loans tied to the prime has declined in recent years. In August, the Fed's most recent survey period, about 33 percent of loans issued by banks were tied to the prime rate, excluding overnight loans, which are assumed to be for very large companies and tied to other interest rates. In the mid- and late-80's, up to half of the business loans made for longer than overnight were tied to prime.
 
Growing Consumer Impact
 While businesses are shedding ties to the prime, consumers are becoming more closely linked to it, through home equity loans and credit cards. About 38 percent of credit cards issued by banks carry interest rates pegged to the prime, according to Robert McKinley, president of RAM Research.
Richard Mahoney, a spokesman for J. P. Morgan & Company, the holding company for Morgan Guaranty, said the rate cut was based on loan demand, which has been weak; the cost of funds, which has been well below what the bank earns on loans and investments, and the outlook for continued low inflation.
Those conditions have prevailed in the last year, with the exception of inflation, which was higher earlier this year but seems to have subsided. Last week, the Government reported that consumer prices were flat in September.
Morgan, like other large banks, adopted the 6 percent prime in July 1992. At 5 1/2 percent, the prime is at its lowest since 1972.
Mr. Mahoney declined to elaborate on how many loans the bank has pegged to prime, though he noted that "obviously it is not as great as other banks."
Morgan's cut in the prime was not the first time it has made other banks uncomfortable. In 1989, it set aside reserves to cover all its remaining loans to less-developed countries, a move that many other banks could not afford to match because they were not as strong financially as J. P. Morgan.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A First Boston analyst sees great things for Crown Cork and Seal.

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
BOTTLE caps and aluminum cans, on the face of it, are pretty mundane items. But a First Boston analyst says that many on Wall Street "just don't get it" by not jumping at shares of Crown Cork and Seal, the world's No. 2 plastic bottle and aluminum can maker.
Timothy P. Burns has broken ranks with his analyst brethren who have neutral ratings on the Philadelphia-based packaging company. He claims Crown Cork is a "strong buy" based on the company's good showing during difficult times for its industry and because of some strategic decisions that are reshaping the $3.7 billion company. Though his opinion is in the minority, it carries a lot of weight, largely because Mr. Burns snared the No. 1 spot in the latest rankings of packaging analysts by Institutional Investor magazine. 
 "This is absolutely the time to buy," said Mr. Burns, in a telephone interview from Paris, where he was calling on some of Crown Cork's overseas rivals. "This is one of the worst cycles for rigid- packaging companies, and Crown Cork is doing so much better than the others. Wall Street just doesn't get it."
Other analysts such as John Tumazos, a leading analyst in the mining and metals industry at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, are far less enthusiastic. "It's a company for conservative investors," said Mr. Tumazos, who calls the stock moderately attractive. "These aren't markets that fluctuate wildly, like a steel company that can lose millions in a quarter, and this company is aware of changes taking place."
Crown Cork has historically been one of the "crowns" of American investing. Located in industrial North Philadelphia, the company's array of bottle caps, fasteners and cans led to a 19.3 percent annual growth rate in its share price for the 36 years beginning in 1956. Not surprisingly, the company had a cultlike following among investors, including, for a long time, Peter Lynch, the legendary former manager of the Magellan Fund.
But times have changed. The master of Crown Cork's success, John F. Connolly -- also known as the "iron man" for his attention to cost control -- died in 1990 and William J. Avery replaced him. Under Mr. Avery, the company has expanded from a regional player to become the leading supplier of traditional metal packaging and a mover in the new world of plastics. This follows a shift in consumer taste away from imbibing soft drinks in aluminum cans to drinking sparkling water and new "clear" drinks in rigid plastic containers.
To meet this demand, Crown Cork has recently acquired three plastic container manufacturers and has shifted its product mix so that now 22 percent of its sales come from plastic containers, compared with 2 percent in 1990. For this reason, Mr. Burns touts the stock. "They are aware of the new environment and have dramatically altered their product mix at the right time when traditional beverage cans have run out of steam," said Mr. Burns, who estimates that the company will earn $2.05 a share in 1993 and $2.40 in 1994; it earned $1.79 in 1992. Crown Cork's shares closed yesterday at $37.75, 18.4 times his 1993 earnings estimate.
At the same time, Mr. Burns says Crown Cork has weathered industrywide problems better than its global rivals, whose operating profits have declined while Crown Cork's continue to rise. These problems include hold-the-line prices paid by the beverage industry for containers, industry productivity gains that have exceeded growth in product demand and depressed economies in many countries.
Richard Palm, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who tied for third among packaging analysts on the Institutional Investor list, is unconvinced. He sees Crown Cork earning $2.05 in 1993 and $2.30 in 1994, similar to Mr. Burns. But Mr. Palm gives Crown Cork a "neutral" rating and believes it will not outperform the stock market. "Management has an excellent record," he said. "But that's already reasonably reflected in the price of the stock."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Sales Push Up Long-Term Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates moved higher yesterday, settling above the record lows set on Friday.
There was no big news event to prompt the selling, but traders said that after the strong rally late last week the market was due for a correction. 
 "That's all this is," one trader said. "We have had a very large rally, and the market finally got beaten up."
 
 
Market 'Got Carried Away'
 Jay Goldinger, a principal in Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif., said: "The market was smoking something on Friday. People were euphoric beyond belief and got carried away. Today they woke up."
Traders looking to justify a round of profit taking were talking about an article in USA Today yesterday that said George Soros and Michael H. Steinhardt, two of the country's biggest money managers, had turned sour on the bond market.
And the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company's decision to cut its prime lending rate to 5.5 percent -- a move that some economists said was a sign of economic weakness -- was interpreted as a negative by some market participants.
Morgan's decision "could mean they are going to be more aggressive in pricing loans," another Treasury securities trader said, "and that they now think it is more profitable to increase their loan portfolios rather than keep on buying Government paper."
In recent years Morgan has veered away from traditional commercial bank activities like prime-based lending to focus on activities more commonly associated with investment banks, like securities underwriting and trading.
 
 
Concerns About Demand
 Still, with interest rates at such low levels, traders are concerned about whether commercial bank demand for Treasury securities will remain strong.
Purchases of Government bills, notes and bonds by banks, which have faced weak loan demand and financial difficulties of their own, have surged in recent years.
As of August, banks owned $714 billion of Government securities, according to Federal Reserve statistics. That figure is up roughly 13 percent from a year ago, which in turn was up 24 percent from August 1991.
Aside from these factors, traders said coming auctions of new two-year and five-year Treasury notes -- expected to be announced on Wednesday -- created selling pressure on outstanding short-term securities.
"At the rates we were trading at on Friday, there is no way that paper could have been absorbed," another trader said. "The market is getting beaten up to make it a reasonable buy again."
 
 
Treasury Auction
 On Wednesday, the Treasury is expected to announce that it intends to sell $16.5 billion of new two-year notes and $11 billion of new five-year securities.
Interest rates rose slightly at yesterday's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 3.06 percent, up from 3.04 percent a week ago.
Six-month bills were auctioned at an average rate of 3.14 percent, compared with 3.12 percent at last week's auction.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 6 1/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2023 were offered in late trading at a price of 10522/32 , down 27/32 , to yield 5.84 percent, up from Friday's record 25-year low of 5.78 percent.
Among note issues, the Treasury's 5 3/4 percent 10-year issue was offered at 10327/32 , down 19/32 , to yield 5.24 percent. And the 4 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 1/2, down 9/32 , to yield 4.63 percent.
 
 
Corporate Debt
 A number of corporations priced new issues yesterday despite the rise in market interest rates.
The Phillips Petroleum Company and the CIT Group were among the companies selling new debt.
Phillips offered $250 million of 30-year 7.20 percent debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The securities were priced at $100, or par, 1.22 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/8 percent 30-year bond at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is not callable, is rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
CIT offered $200 million of 15-year debentures through Morgan Stanley & Company.
The 5 7/8 percent securities were priced at 99.27 to yield 5.949 percent, 75 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is not callable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by Standard & Poor's.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:
