HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Arbitron Decides to Pull Out Of the TV Ratings Business

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
With yet another pebble in its pouch proving a dud, the Arbitron Company left the battlefield of television ratings yesterday, unable to trip up the industry Goliath, the A. C. Nielsen Company.
Arbitron said that by the end of the year it would lay off 700 employees nationwide -- 58 percent of its staff of 1,200 -- and discontinue its ratings of syndicated programs and cable television in local markets. More than 400 of those layoffs will be in Laurel, Md., where the company's television ratings operations are based. 
 Arbitron has dominated the radio ratings business since the 1970's, but its various attempts to breach the Nielsen stronghold have made little progress.
Many broadcast executives and some advertisers are frequently critical of the accuracy of Nielsen ratings, particularly when their own programs lag, but few have been willing to support a competing service. So the ratings compiled by Nielsen, a division of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, remain the basis of more than $15 billion in advertising decisions a year.
"Much to CBS's frustration, the industry has not supported any innovation in this field," said David F. Poltrack, CBS's senior vice president of planning and research. "I can't believe there's anybody out there foolhardy enough to venture into this area."
Paul Schulman, president of the media buying company that bears his name, commented: "This is unfortunate for the industry, because we'll have only one measure. And without competition, the cost may well escalate. Everybody wants Arbitron to challenge Nielsen, but nobody wants to pay for it."
Announcing the changes, Lawrence Perlman, chairman and chief executive of the Ceridian Corporation, which owns Arbitron, said: "Arbitron has not been achieving acceptable financial results from the service and had no near-term prospects for getting it back on a profitable track. Competition in the local television and cable ratings market has been intense."
 
'Deeper Pockets'
 Stephen B. Morris, the president of Arbitron, said in a telephone interview: "We did well in TV in the 80's. But as the business got squeezed, they went down the path of one service only." Nielsen "was more aggressive and had deeper pockets," he said, adding that the competitor was better able to withstand the price competition that broadcasters had pushed for.
John A. Dimling, the president of Nielsen Media Research, the television ratings division of A. C. Nielsen, said that despite the competition, Nielsen had continued to make money on its local service. He declined to confirm Mr. Schulman's fears that Nielsen's prices would now go up, saying, "We have no specific plans to raise prices."
At a news conference in New York, Mr. Morris of Arbitron also said, "We are abandoning ratings, but we are not abandoning television." He said the company was developing qualitative research into the buying habits of television viewers and radio listeners.
"We are gathering information in five markets, selling it in those markets," he said later in a telephone interview, declining to identify the markets. "By January, we expect to have a demonstrable product, and we expect to roll it out next year."
 
 
'Pocket People Meter'
 A year ago, Arbitron announced that it was ending Scan America, a television ratings and product-buying survey that it began locally in 1987 and nationally in 1991. While CBS backed Scan America, it attracted little support from other networks and large advertisers.
Last December, Arbitron announced that it would develop for use in television ratings a "pocket people meter," to be worn by viewers. The device would record what its wearers watched by "reading" an inaudible code etched into television program sound. Mr. Morris said yesterday that the project was proceeding on schedule and could be introduced in 1995 if Arbitron found demand for it.
Ceridian said it would take a $67 million charge in the fourth quarter because of the Arbitron layoffs.
Also yesterday, the company, which is based in Minneapolis, said third-quarter net income rose 15 percent, to $10.7 million, or 25 cents a share, from $9.3 million, or 22 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue rose 2.8 percent, to $208.9 million.
The company's share price ended the day yesterday down 25 cents, at $19.125, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Expectation Of Lower Rates in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced against most leading currencies yesterday as investors expected Germany and other countries to lower their interest rates.
"The dollar seems to have won on a default basis," said Belal Khan, a senior dealer for the Bank of Tokyo in New York.
 
Money Supply Under Control
 In late New York trading, the dollar was at 1.6395 German marks, up from 1.6165 on Friday. The dollar also rose to 107.45 Japanese yen, from 107.10. 
 Currency traders said the dollar was bolstered by expectations that Germany would ease its tight monetary policy. They expect a drop this week in the repurchase rate, the Bundesbank's main instrument to influence money market rates.
Peter Michaels, an assistant vice president at Fuji Bank in New York, said the market also expected that the latest German money supply figures would fall within targets. The Bundesbank has maintained high interest rates to choke a rise in the money supply and inflation.
David Gilmore of MCM Currencywatch said the change in the repurchase rate was not expected to be large.
"It's more an indication of an easier monetary policy stance having been adopted," he said.
Other European countries were also expected to lower interest rates to stimulate their recession-bound economies. Lower rates overseas make United States rates, and in turn the dollar, more attractive to investors.
"It's not as much strength on the U.S. side of the ratio, it's weakness on the European side" that's benefiting the dollar, Mr. Gilmore said.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, one of the largest banks in the United States, dropped its prime lending rate half a percentage point, to 5 1/2 percent yesterday. The move did not affect the dollar because the prime is considered a lagging rate that responds to established interest rate trends.
In New York trading, the British pound slipped to $1.4860, from $1.5105 on Friday.
Other rates in New York late yesterday, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4465 Swiss francs, up from 1.4263; 5.7965 French francs, up from 5.7265; 1,599.00 Italian lire, up from 1,588.00, and 1.3250 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3315.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
A Bank's Prime-Rate Cut Spurs Another Gain by Gold

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
The price of gold rose yesterday to the highest level since the beginning of September, after Morgan Guaranty Trust Company lowered its prime lending rate, a move that could help increase the demand for gold.
Morgan Guaranty, the nation's fourth-largest bank, cut its rate on loans for its most creditworthy customers, its prime rate, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent. Traders said this aided gold prices, as did speculation that German interest rates would be cut in the next few weeks. 
 Lower interest rates often buoy economic growth, and, traders say, can increase the demand for gold from industrial users and jewelry makers.
Alluding to gold prices, Ronald Spurga, vice president for commodities finance at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. in New York, said yesterday: "The primary reason for the rise was Morgan's cut in the prime rate. Lower interest rates lower the cost of carrying inventories, including gold and precious metals."
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery gained $3.40, to $369.60 an ounce.
The prices of other precious metals rose, too, with December silver picking up 7 cents, to settle at $4.425 an ounce on the Comex. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, January platinum gained $3.50, to $372.90 an ounce, and December palladium increased $1.75, to $132.80 an ounce.
Gold traders remain focused on supply and demand, analysts said. "It's a continuation of what we saw last week," when commodity funds bought gold in the hope of an upturn in the economy, said Michael Martin of Sinclair Group in New York.
The traders assume that a stronger economy would translate to greater demand from jewelry makers. October and November are the months of peak demand for gold, as jewelers prepare for the Christmas season. Jewelry makers account for about 75 percent of demand for delivered gold, according to Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd.
On the oil market, prices for crude oil fell for the fifth consecutive session, as traders dismissed reports of increased confrontation on the Iraq-Kuwait border and instead focused on big supplies and weak demand. Light crude oil for November delivery lost 14 cents, to settle at $18.13 a barrel. Oil prices have fallen roughly 3 percent in the last week, after surging in the wake of an agreement within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to limit production.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Gap Widens

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The high yen and continued demand for Japanese exports helped to increase Japan's trade surplus by 5.4 percent in September, to $12.73 billion, the Finance Ministry announced today.
It was the 33d consecutive month in which Japanese exports exceeded imports by a larger amount than a year earlier. 
 Japan's surplus with the United States rose 17 percent, to $5.67 billion, the ministry said. America's gradual economic recovery has encouraged consumption of Japanese products, while economic sluggishness in Japan has dampened Japanese demand for imports.
The September surplus was larger than expected. Many economists in Japan had predicted it would fall below the $12.08 billion registered in September 1992, ending the long expansion trend.
The ministry said exports rose 6 percent, to $33.52 billion, while imports grew 6.4 percent, to $20.79 billion.
Japan's trade surplus has ballooned in recent years as the nation's domestic economic slowdown has reduced demand for imports and the yen's rapid rise has increased dollar-denominated trade figures.
Exports to the United States rose 13 percent, to $10.19 billion, while imports grew 7.5 percent, to $4.52 billion, the ministry said.
Japan measures trade on a customs-clearance basis, which means that freight and insurance charges are included in imports but not in exports.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL: WORLD SERIES;
Pass the Hoagies And Cheese Steaks

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
When former heavyweight champion Sonny Liston once said that he'd rather be a lamppost in Denver than the mayor of Philadelphia, probably not a lot of people argued. The same probably applied when W. C. Fields said if the choices were either being dead or being in the City of Brotherly Love, then perhaps, all things considered, he'd rather be in Philadelphia.
Unfortunately for the city stuck in the backbone of the country's East Coast corridor, the identity crisis and the fight for respect have always been somewhat losing battles. 
 Well, the battles have ceased, for now. The Philadelphia Phillies, with their anti-Club Med flavor and aversions to conformity and compromise, have shown an entire city the way.
Forget conventional wisdom, white wine and the hair mousse, dude. Pass the cheese steaks and the hoagies and get on with life. That, the National League champion Phillies have let it be known, is what they intend to do as they continue their funny-bone tickling ride through the World Series.
That they fit Philadelphia as well as they contrast with the Toronto Blue Jays, their staid World Series opponents, is obvious. And that they enjoy the differences on the field as much as the blend with their city off the field has made the Philadelphia story all the more special.
"The people care about this team more than any team in my recollection," said Mayor Ed Rendell of Philadelphia. "Because they're hard-working guys who aren't afraid to get dirt on their uniforms, who aren't afraid to be a little unconventional. Because they're so different from the athlete of today. They're something special."
And they have apparently succeeded in making Philadelphia feel special. "Cities operate in great part on feel and perception," Rendell said. "And I think it really helps if people feel real good about themselves and their city. And it also helps in terms of visitors. So this thing has some direct economic benefits for us. But the indirect and the sort of psychic benefits far outweigh it."
So it is that the city, which will be host to its first Series game in 10 years tonight at Veterans Stadium, will celebrate not only the winning of the National League pennant and a possible World Series championship, but also a team that reflects the area's blue-collar, workmanlike approach. A team with a down-to-earth nature that so well reflects a metropolis in many ways more than geographically at arms length from both the cosmopolitan nature of New York to the north and gentility of Baltimore to the south.
The Phillies, with John Kruk and Pete Incaviglia, Mitch Williams and Darren Daulton as poster boys, like Philadelphia, may invite comic critiques at first glance. But respect is usually not too far behind. Atlantans, from the cosmopolitan center of the Deep South, jested about hiding their women and children from the Phillies during the National League Championship Series. But the Phillies did not purge or burn Atlanta. Merely the Braves' pennant hopes.
And Blue Jays' fans participated all week in contests that invited them to find the "Phat Phillie" or complete sentences about how "the Phillies are so ugly . . ." Ultimately, the ugliest development may well be that the Jays allowed the Phillies to return home with a satisfying split of the first two games played in Toronto's Skydome.
Like Atlanta, Toronto failed to keep the Phillies cornered. Now they must deal with the Phillies, in Philadelphia, in Games 3, 4 and 5.
The knocks will still come, of course. Which all seems to delight Philadelphians. Nothing that has unfolded has been too humbling, too close to the bone, too ethnocentric to knock what seems like hundreds of thousands of smiles that went into place the instance the Phillies clinched the pennant.
It's like they all know a wonderful secret. Rendell is convinced that they do. The Phillies are special, he believes, as much for who they are not as for who they are. "It's just that when you watch sports these days it's so disheartening to see athletes who are all blow-dried, who only care about their agents, who all tailor their image to get the maximum endorsements," Rendell said. "They're all sort of like business people. So it's great to see guys who are more like old-time ballplayers."
So it was that Rendell got no arguments, only praise, last week when he allowed the iron workers' union to put a giant red Phillies cap on top of the city's statue of William Penn, which sits atop Philadelphia's nine-story City Hall. Nothing, not even eradicating a $450 million deficit without raising taxes was such a hit, Rendell said.
That the Phillies are beloved cannot be argued. Why it should matter to a public figure should not be ignored. Rendell has read into that love a safety net in which all of Philadelphia benefited. For Rendell, like every mayor knowing his city was sitting on the verge of a big celebration, also wondered what else it was sitting on in terms of anti-social over-exuberance.
"But it was easy for both myself and the city to persuade the citizens of the city not to have any destruction after we won the pennant," he said. "Because we said, 'if you destroy property it's going to detract from the team's win.' And after all the trouble in Montreal, Chicago and Detroit, we went with one arrest and one broken window the entire night. It was awesome. And I'd like to think it was because of the team's feelings for the city."
And the city's feelings for the team.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Those Three Words

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Now here is a Government document with a lot of potential -- including the potential to make the incumbent President and his successors yearn for these safe days of Somalia, Haiti and the gulf war.
The document has to do with three words. Proliferation -- as in third-world nuclear bombs. Dual use -- as in: I sell you a chemical to make fertilizer and you use it to make biological weapons, which, to tell the truth, is what I expected you to do all along, but a dollar is a dollar. 
 Americans don't like to think much about those three words. It certainly is not because they do not bring excitement to our lives. Saddam Hussein had such a fine supply line of nuclear and dual-use items from the West that he was getting close to nuclear weapon production and felt strong enough to take on the U.S. and survive, which he did.
Maybe it's all so frightening that we prefer to push it out of our minds. Anyway, some time ago I decided to become one of those people who make themselves pests about those three words, so to work.
The document consists of replies to questions put by the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs, headed by Senator John Glenn, to R. James Woolsey, the C.I.A. Director.
Question. [Questions compressed by me for space reasons.] Can wars be made less likely by new regional nuclear balances of terror?
Answer. I can think of no example where the introduction of nuclear weapons has enhanced that region's security. . . . Emerging nuclear-capable states lack the strict command and control and doctrine of the superpowers.
Q. From the evidence, how effective is military force as a solution to nuclear proliferation?
A. Military force can slow nuclear weapons development programs in the short term but cannot permanently stop [them]. . . . Without international scrutiny, continued inspections, Iraq probably could rebuild, with available expertise, its nuclear weapons program and manufacture a device in about five to seven years.
Q. After the B.N.L. and B.C.C.I. scandals, will U.S. intelligence concentrate more on the financial and banking aspects of proliferation?
A. Yes. . . . Banks play a key role in facilitating arms-related gray-market deals.
Q. Can nuclear material be smuggled out of the former Soviet Union?
A. If the situation were to deteriorate and since nuclear materials are in so many different places, some of them could fall into the wrong hands and be exported and, potentially, without our knowledge.
Q. Where has the technology for proliferating countries come from?
A (condensed). Some American companies have been involved but by and large to the Mideast it was a "free flow" from Europe. Some European nations have tightened control. Principal concerns now focus on China and North Korea. Beijing has consistently regarded a nuclear-armed Pakistan as a crucial regional ally and vital counterweight to India.
Q. How many nuclear weapons do India and Pakistan have?
A. India and Pakistan have the capability to assemble . . . a small number . . . within a very short period of time. . . . The distinction between whether or not these weapons are in fact assembled or only able to be assembled within a few days is a very small distinction.
Q. About Pakistan, what would be the delivery system -- the F-16's we sold them?
A. Our best judgment right now would be the F-16's.
Q. Does Egypt have a biological weapons capability?
A. Yes, a program.
Q. Are you confident we can detect the use of biological weapons?
A. No. . . .
Q. How far ahead can you predict intentions and capabilities of nations with stockpiles of nuclear materials?
A. Substantial uncertainties could harm our ability to forecast -- especially beyond 10 years.
The U.S. has a list of "special countries" that cannot receive material that they could use or transmit to a third country for nuclear purposes, without special study and clearance.
On Oct. 6, the Administration removed 11 countries from that list. They were Argentina, Bahrain, Brazil, Chile, Kuwait, Malawi, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Africa, Syria and Yemen. No advance notice was given to Congress.

HEADLINE: Linking Exports to Aid

 BODY:
At first glance, the Clinton Administration's new export policy is dismaying. Mr. Clinton wants to reinstitute a practice, known as tied aid, whereby the U.S. would give development aid to poor countries on condition that they purchase U.S. goods. For example, the U.S. would give Paraguay cash to help build a dam; the U.S. would also provide subsidized loans with which Paraguay would be required to buy the needed construction equipment from U.S. companies. The U.S. largely abandoned this practice 20 years ago because linking aid to exports isn't good for recipient countries or fair trade.
At second glance, however, Mr. Clinton's policy is defensible as a means to pressure other donors to cut back the suspect practice. Mr. Clinton hopes that if we play the game just a little, our trading partners will play it a whole lot less. 
 The biggest knock on linking aid to exports is that it encourages donor countries to give underdeveloped countries the wrong type of aid. Rather than paying for projects that generate the most growth, donors are tempted to pay for projects that generate the most exports. And the practice sneaks around trade rules that prohibit countries from unfairly subsidizing exports.
Distinguishing aid from export subsidies isn't easy. A donor that grants a poor country $15 million tied to a requirement that the recipient country spend $10 million on exports from the donor qualifies as substantial aid; but when the required purchase is hiked to $50 or $100 million, the package has more to do with subsidizing the sale of exports than promoting development.
Mr. Clinton is aware of these dangers and does not propose sending U.S. policy careening in the wrong direction. He will leave existing aid programs virtually unchanged so that current recipients won't be threatened by new conditions. But he would also create a small fund, of about $150 million, that the Export-Import Bank would use to match offers of other donor countries that link export sales to aid projects.
The policy would try to recapture export sales for U.S. companies lost to foreign subsidies. The hope is that other donors would then see less advantage in pursuing the policy -- compelling them either to cut back on the practice or at least to pay strict attention to guidelines that the U.S. and Western allies have recently negotiated to limit the use of export-linked aid.
Mr. Clinton proposes using tied aid to discourage its widespread use. That's a reasonable, though dangerous, tactic. The threat is that the U.S. could get carried away; not content merely to match offers by other donors, it would launch a trade war to capture new exports.
Congress should keep a sharp eye on the program to insure it doesn't degenerate into a tit-for-tat competition with U.S. trade rivals. But the threat seems farfetched. Mr. Clinton wants to use the fund prudently to convince fellow donors that there won't be much profit in the worrisome practice.

HEADLINE: Welfare Reform? First Improve Child Care Aid.;
A 'Community School'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You do a tremendous service for children in your report on the neglected health needs of the city's students ("Too Ill to Learn," news article, Oct. 10). In human and in real financial terms, we pay a huge price for these false economies. 
 Two years ago, after five years of planning, the Children's Aid Society, School District 6 in Washington Heights/Inwood and the Board of Education opened a prototype public school, called a "community school," to address these health and family needs that keep children from learning. The problems can be fixed, and not always by spending more or new money. We also need to change the way we think about the school as a public institution.
In Washington Heights, for example, the community school has a health clinic that challenges all the traditional definitions of "school." It is open until 6 in the evening. It is open year round. It primarily serves the 1,300 students in the school, but it also serves their siblings and others who need care. It is staffed by Children's Aid professionals, plus parents who have been trained to give vision and hearing examinations. It uses medical and nursing students from a local hospital to offer additional services, and the hospital in turn uses the clinic as a training center. All of the school's before- and after-school programs, weekend and parent programs rely on similar partnerships and nontraditional approaches.
The result is not only a new model for public school services, but also a new financial model: one that shifts public spending from existing health, clinic and human services programs -- often redundant -- into the school, and uses it more effectively. In a community school, social service agencies become eligible for funding in school-based services, and schools qualify for funding in child protection, job training and health. There is essentially no net increase in public spending, only in child and family benefits.
If we can change the way we think about public education, we can change how we pay for it too. And what better way to manage health care than to have it cost-effective and located in the one facility, the school facility, that is so central to child and family life?
 
PHILIP COLTOFF
Executive Director
The Children's Aid Society
New York, Oct. 12, 1993

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Consumer product companies seek better methods to gauge the effect of marketing on their sales.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

DATELINE: NAPLES, Fla.

 BODY:
THE more strenuously advertisers labor to achieve success in marketing consumer products, the more insistent the clamor grows to find methods to measure the effectiveness of advertising. So the 84th annual meeting and conference of the Association of National Advertisers is trying to offer some solutions.
"Advertising, as a marketing and communications tool, will never command the respect it deserves until correlation between share of voice and profitable growth is firmly established," said DeWitt F. Helm Jr., president of the association, whose members account for more than 80 percent of annual spending on national and regional advertising. 
 Peter H. Coors, vice chairman and chief executive at the Coors Brewing Company of Golden, Colo., explained why.
"With the economic climate as tough as it is, C.E.O.'s, board members and shareholders are looking more and more at bottom-line results," Mr. Coors told the audience at the general session yesterday. "Our marketing and advertising people must explain the short- and long-term benefits of what we're presenting to the public and be prepared to measure results, not only in sales but in profits."
Mr. Coors, who is featured in image-building campaigns for his 120-year-old family-owned brewery, praised the Silver Bullet advertising for his Coors Light brand, created by Foote, Cone & Belding of Chicago. The ads "consistently communicate our product attributes," he said, while simultaneously delivering "consistent brand volume and profit growth."
Gary M. Stibel, founder and principal at the New England Consulting Group, a marketing consulting company in Westport, Conn., shared the initial results of a study of the accountability of advertising.
If the effectiveness of advertising cannot be measured, Mr. Stibel warned, "someone is likely to insist we spend as little as possible on advertising."
"Agencies must and can be held accountable," he added. "The great agencies will welcome this."
Based on data from 1980 to 1990 provided by 15 leading association members including A.T.& T., Coors, General Electric, General Motors and Procter & Gamble, the study concluded that "advertising has a quantitative positive impact" on sales and market share, Mr. Stibel said, and is profitable "at least most of the time."
"On balance, the evidence is reasonably clear," he concluded. "Advertising works; it drives profits."
Lorraine C. Scarpa, senior vice president of marketing services at Kraft General Foods of Rye Brook, N.Y., discussed the role that "market intelligence," as she called marketing research, could play in enhancing advertising performance.
After joking that a marketing research executive's epitaph reads, "He may have helped to sell Jell-O," Ms. Scarpa praised the benefits of the new "high-tech dimension in marketing information," like the analysis of consumer purchase data reported from supermarket scanners.
For instance, scanner data revealed that of the 43 million households that buy the company's Oscar Mayer cold cuts, she said, 20 million also buy Jell-O gelatin, 20 million buy Jell-O pudding, 18 million buy Kraft salad dressings, 16 million buy Stove Top stuffing and 250,000 buy Postum grain beverage.
Ms. Scarpa described how a huge project to analyze the purchase behavior of 12,000 households last year benefited Kraft General Foods tremendously by enabling the company to focus on how it would spend $1.6 billion in advertising and consumer promotions across its 61 categories of products.
The data enabled Kraft General Foods to hone in on households that are heavy users of the products it sells, she said, by identifying that 2 percent of them "account for 50 percent of all our volume." Those households buy an average of $600 worth of Kraft General Foods products a year, she added, more than twice as much as the $250 that an average household buys.
Research from 90 Kroger supermarkets in Columbus, Ohio, found that of the average 23,000 items in a store, Ms. Scarpa said, 6,700 sold in a day, 13,600 sold in a week and 17,500 sold in a month -- leaving 5,500 that sold nothing in that month.
The shudder that swept through the audience, as advertisers pondered the prospect of marketing one of those 5,500 items, was almost palpable.
The conference, at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel here, concludes today.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 21, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of a transmission error, the Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about the effectiveness of advertising for consumer products, misstated data supplied by Lorraine C. Scarpa, senior vice president for marketing services at Kraft General Foods. Based on a survey of 12,000 households, she said, 50 percent of the company's sales volume in 61 product categories came from 20 percent of the nation's households, not from 2 percent.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Achieves Fund-Raising Success

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The last time Rudolph W. Giuliani ran for mayor, he had to struggle hard in the last six weeks of the race to raise even half the amount of money that was flowing to the Democratic nominee, David N. Dinkins. He was forced to borrow $200,000 from the Republican State Committee and he asked President Bush to help coax donations from the Republican faithful.
This time, Mr. Giuliani raised all the money the law would allow him to spend with two weeks to go, even as Mayor Dinkins continued to worry about fund raising. 
 This difference reflects an impression among many of the contributors who support mayoral campaigns that he is a stronger candidate this time around. Four years ago, he trailed badly in the polls, though he ultimately lost by a thin 2 percentage points. Recent polls show a tight race.
Until about 10 months ago, most of Mr. Giuliani's money was still coming from thousands of small contributors. But as his campaign emerged with a serious chance to win, Mr. Giuliani began drawing significant support from New York City's traditional well of large contributors -- lawyers, business owners, contractors and real-estate developers who every four years bear the brunt of the election's cost. Even executives on Wall Street, where Mr. Giuliani made a number of enemies while he was United States Attorney, have contributed significantly to his campaign.
Republican strategists and fund-raisers say Wall Street has been contributing more to Mr. Giuliani's campaign because he is no longer seen as a crusader out to lock up white-collar criminals, but as a politician with whom the financiers and bond traders believe they can do business. In addition, the financial services world, by its nature, tends to back politicians who are seen as having a chance of winning, which Mr. Giuliani does this year.
"They see Giuliani's stock very differently than they saw it in 1989," said Jay Severin, a Republican political consultant. "What they saw as a contribution in 1989, they now see as an investment in someone who can win. That's what these guys live and die by. Making investments."
Mr. Giuliani's sources of money in some cases reflect some of Mr. Dinkins's political difficulties. In the last three weeks of August, for example, while the Mayor was taking a political beating over allegations that his administration steered a parking-ticket contract to a scandal-tainted company, Mr. Giuliani reaped about $852,000 in contributions and saw a surge of support from Wall Street and big business, campaign records indicate.
A group of 62 Korean owners of small businesses has collected $15,075 for Mr. Giuliani because they were angered by the Mayor's hands-off approach to a black-led boycott of a Korean grocer in Brooklyn in 1991. In another example, about 190 electrical contractors who assert that they have been excluded from city contracts have banded together to raise $42,196 for the Republican-Liberal candidate.
Fund raising is not as crucial a battleground in this year's race as in past years because both candidates have agreed to participate in the city's campaign finance program, limiting their overall spending to $8 million -- not including some expenditures that are exempt from the rules -- and agreeing to keep each donation under $6,500 in return for public funds. While the rules of the program are complex, political strategists say candidates can generally expect public funds to cover about a third of their $8 million in spending.
Since neither campaign appears to be in danger of falling short of the $8 million limit, how and when the candidates spend their funds has become a more important question in the last three weeks than who is raising and spending the most.
By Sept. 27, the most recent filing date for campaign finance reports, Mr. Giuliani had raised $6.6 million from about 16,000 contributors, compared with the $2.5 million from 9,300 donors he had raised at this point four years ago. Since July 11, the Republican campaign has outstripped Mr. Dinkins in raising money by almost a 2-to-1 ratio, collecting about $2.7 million to the Mayor's $1.5 million.
Mr. Giuliani had approximately $3.5 million in the bank for the last three weeks of the campaign, said the deputy campaign manager, Tamra Roberts Lhota.
Mr. Dinkins still has approximtely $700,000 left to raise, though his aides predict he will meet that goal with several fund-raisers, including a benefit concert tonight by Bette Midler and an event tomorrow with Vice President Gore.
One reason the Giuliani campaign has been more successful raising money this time around is that the candidate began earlier and has spent far more time going to small fund-raisers, Ms. Lhota said.
The current drive began nearly two years ago, in November 1991, and Mr. Giuliani has so far attended almost 289 events to raise cash, ranging from tiny house parties to large $1,000-a-plate dinners. He made it a habit to hold breakfast meetings with partners at law firms, for instance.
 
Well-Known Contributors
 Ms. Lhota said Republican contributors were heartened by Mr. Giuliani's showing in 1989, and were convinced that he could win this time. "People felt with a little more money sooner in 1989 we could have won," she said.
Mr. Giuliani's largest contributors include some well-known names among Republicans. Members of the Rockefeller family and its foundation have donated a total of $31,100. Robert A. Mosbacher, the former Secretary of Commerce under President Bush, and his wife, Georgette, a cosmetics executive, have given $11,500.
Mr. Giuliani has also garnered strong support from prominent law firms where he has friends and former associates. Partners at Rogers & Wells -- which represents the city in bond negotiations -- have given a total of $20,325, and several lawyers at Leboeuf, Lamb, Leiby & McCrae have funneled $14,200 to the Republican campaign. Members of Mr. Giuliani's own law firm -- Anderson, Kill, Olick & Oshinsky -- have contributed $19,375, and $13,950 came from members of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz & Mendelsohn, where Mr. Giuliani's professional mentor, former Deputy Attorney General Arnold I. Burns, is a partner.
Bond underwriters, investment bankers and other Wall Street executives have channeled heavier financial support to Mr. Giuliani than they did in 1989, though all told the financial-services world appears to be tilting toward the incumbent, records show. Employees of the 30 firms that are in the city's syndicate of bond sellers have given a total of about $344,000 to Mr. Giuliani, including $64,930 from Merrill Lynch & Company employees and $60,338 from traders at Bear Stearns & Company.
Mr. Giuliani also raised a significant amount of money from some Wall Street firms that do little or no city business. The partners in Forstmann, Little & Company and their families, for instance, have given a total of $28,500. In another example, Edward J. Rappa, the founder of R. W. Pressprich, a small, three-year-old bond house, has given $27,960 to Mr. Giuliani through personal contributions, his employees and his wife.
"I got a real stake in this city, an emotional stake, an economic stake, and I really can't stand what's going on," Mr. Rappa said.
A few real-estate developers and management companies have thrown their monetary heft behind Mr. Giuliani, though most of them are also giving to Mr. Dinkins. Among Mr. Giuliani's top contributors are the owners and principals of the Mendik Company, the Mack Company, Fisher Brothers Development and Grace Industries. Donald Trump, though he has yet to contribute himself, has raised more than $19,500 from other people for the Giuliani campaign.
Construction companies and contractors have given in large numbers to Mr. Giuliani as well. By Sept. 20, at least 347 contracting companies or their employees had donated a total of $237,820 to Mr. Giuliani's election effort, records show.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
World Bank Issues Bond in Marks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The World Bank began selling its first global bond issue denominated in German marks yesterday, and officials said demand was very strong.
Kenneth G. Lay, director of the financial operations department at the World Bank, said the lead underwriters for the 3 billion mark ($1.83 billion) 10-year issue, Salomon Brothers and Deutsche Bank, were telling investors that the deal was oversubscribed several times, so they would not get the bonds they had requested. 
 He also said the new issue, which will be formally priced this morning, was likely to be at the bottom of a range of 6 to 8 basis points above the yield on the 10-year German bond, which was at 5.87 percent yesterday. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Traded Globally
 A global bond can be traded in any big markets, from New York to London to Tokyo. Most global issues are denominated in dollars, but the World Bank has also done four of them in Japanese yen.
For the World Bank, which has done 14 global bond issues since 1989, such offerings provide a way to diversify and expand its pool of investors. In addition, Mr. Lay said, a global issue is designed "to bring to bear on a single issue the full range of investor demand." If the bank is successful, then the broader demand will lower its borrowing costs.
But a global bond issue presents challenges as technicians at the World Bank figure out how to hurdle legal and other obstacles that could keep the offering from being successful or make its trading difficult. "Each of these cases present a special set of problems," Mr. Lay said.
The work that Mr. Lay and his staff do is is necessary, he said, "to establish the link that allows bonds to flow from Germany to the United States and to Japan."
This issue has been in the works since the summer of 1992. Mr. Lay said that was partly because of the time it took to work out the differences in laws in the United States and Germany so that investors who buy the bonds here and in Germany can buy them and trade them easily.
Mr. Lay said one benefit of all the technical work is that it is now easier for wealthy individual investors in the United States to hold these bonds. The World Bank has worked out a system that allows investors to pay for the bonds in dollars, which will be converted to marks by an intermediary bank, in this case Citicorp. In addition, all interest payments made in marks are automatically converted into dollars.
The investment, however, is still subject to the gains and losses that can come with fluctuations in the value of the dollar against the mark.
The other American buyers of the this bond, Mr. Lay said, are portfolio managers with large funds that include European and Japanese bonds in addition to American Treasury issues.
Because the yield on the World Bank bond is so close to that of the German 10-year bond and because of the high credit quality of World Bank paper, the new issue will trade very much like a 10-year German bond.
The issue is also expected to be attractive to managers who want to bet on the expected decline in interest rates in Germany, which will push the prices higher on German bonds and bonds denominated in marks. Because the issue is so large and should be relatively easy to trade, it can be simpler to sell than a actual German bond.
Some of these managers are likely to hedge the currency risk by selling marks for dollars when the bonds are bought.
 
Treasury Market
 In the Treasury market, prices and yields were little changed yesterday after three hectic trading sessions in a row. The yield on the 30-year bond finished at 5.84 percent, unchanged from Monday. The price of the bond, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 3/32 .
The only economic news of the day was the report that housing starts rose 2.8 percent in September, which was a much stronger performance than expected. There was selling after the report, but then buyers came in and the bond rebounded. Treasury notes were unchanged on the day, and the discount rates on the three- and six-month bills stayed at 3.04 percent and 3.12 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Flat as Traders Await Activity in European Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished little changed against most leading currencies yesterday as traders awaited news on whether Germany and other European countries would drop interest rates.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6411 German marks, up from 1.6395 marks. But it slipped to 107.16 Japanese yen, from 107.45 yen. 
 Meanwhile, gold prices rose in the United States after falling in Europe. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery closed at $370.30 an ounce, up 70 cents. And the Republic National Bank of New York quoted spot gold at $368.75 an ounce, up 75 cents.
Traders said most currencies moved within narrow trading ranges. "Today is what you might call a calm-down day," said Robert Ryan, a vice president at Bank of New York. "We haven't made any progress up or down."
He said the strength of the dollar resulted from a number of factors. One was the weaknesses in the economies of France and Belgium, which are expected to lead to interest rate cuts in those countries.
Drop in Currencies Likely
Such actions might stimulate the economies, but will probably drive down the value of the currencies in those countries because investors will get lower returns.
Also supporting the dollar, Mr. Ryan said, were the predictions by some economists of stronger United States gross domestic product figures for the fourth quarter.
Other traders said the market was awaiting figures on the German money supply, which indicate the strength of inflation in that country. If the numbers are low, Germany might loosen its tight monetary policy.
Germany could lower its securities repurchase rate or -- a less likely possibility -- cut the key discount rate on Thursday, when the central bank's policy-setting Central Council meets. The lower interest rates would probably cause the mark to fall.
"People are pretty much gearing up for statements from Germany," said John Nelson, the director of foreign exchange at Barclays Bank in New York.
The British pound, meanwhile, was quoted in New York at $1.4897, down from $1.4980 on Monday.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper, Stockpiles Rising, Hits Lowest Level in 6 Years

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Copper fell sharply for the second straight session yesterday, tumbling to its lowest level in six years amid rising stockpiles and weaker-than-expected demand.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, copper for December delivery fell 0.70 cent, to 73.15 cents a pound. Over the last six weeks, prices have fallen about 15 percent. 
 The London Metals Exchange reported yesterday that stockpiles had risen by about 2,500 tons, to 603,700 tons, their highest levels since 1984. The last time copper stockpiles were this high prices were about 10 cents a pound lower, at about 63 cents a pound.
A global recession, particularly in Europe and Japan, has depressed industrial demand for copper, while mine production has held steady.
"We've got a very significant overhang of excess metal on the market," said John Gross at BICC Cables in West Nyack, N.Y. "The market will continue to deteriorate, unless something dramatic happens to increase demand."
 
Counting on a Price Rise
 Copper companies have been counting on a rise in prices as growing economies, especially China's, soak up production.
Placer Dome Inc. said yesterday that it would spend $600 million to develop a copper deposit in Chile.
On other futures markets, lumber prices slipped for the first time in six sessions even though the Government reported unexpected increases in housing starts and construction. November lumber closed $3.50 higher, at $320.50 per 1,000 board feet, on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Lumber had risen almost 7.5 percent since Oct. 7 as mills marked up prices to take advantage of improved demand from builders.
Elsewhere, crude oil fell for the sixth consecutive session. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, light crude for November delivery slipped 7 cents, to $18.06 a barrel.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Los Angeles Times Offers A 3d Buyout

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In its latest effort to cope with a persistent advertising slump, The Los Angeles Times is pursuing yet another voluntary employee buyout program to reduce overhead, Times officials confirmed today.
Under the program, announced internally at the paper on Monday, The Los Angeles Times said it hoped to eliminate at least 100 jobs and save $5 million a year. Newsroom, transportation, mailroom, fleet operations, security, finance and prepress employees are eligible for the program. 
 The Times has undertaken several cost-cutting measures since the recession hit Southern California in 1990. Through attrition and two other buyout programs it has reduced its work force by 23 percent, to 6,700 people, resulting in an annual saving of $105 million, the paper said.
In addition, it closed its San Diego edition last November and is considering selling its downtown Los Angeles headquarters and moving into a high-rise office tower.
The Times, which with a circulation of 1,138,353 is the flagship paper of the Times Mirror Company, also plans to turn its regional sections into tabloids and reduce the frequency of publication for some of them, Times officials disclosed.
 
Less Frequent Publication
 The Times publishes its San Gabriel and Southeast/Long Beach sections twice a week and its South Bay section four times a week. After January they will be weeklies. The Westside section, serving the city's most affluent areas, including Beverly Hills and Westwood, will continue to appear twice a week.
"The Times is fortunate to have been able to reduce staffing levels through voluntary means, unlike so many other United States companies," David Laventhol, publisher and chief executive, said in a statement. "We remain committed to the goal of avoiding layoffs of full-time staff."
It is offering the buyout program to all full-time employees on its regional sections. In a buyout program earlier this year, Times editors said they were surprised by the number of employees -- including about 130 in the newsroom -- who chose to leave. There are now just over 1,000 news employees and the paper expects about 30 to take the new buyout offer.

HEADLINE: Low Mortgage Rates Push Up Housing Starts

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Construction of new housing was at its highest in three and a half years in September as low mortgage rates helped place the sector on solid ground, the Commerce Department said today.
Starts on new single-family homes and apartments rose 2.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.35 million -- the strongest since 1.44 million in February 1990. 
 That followed a 6.7 percent jump in August building activity, revised down from a previously reported 7.8 percent gain.
 
 
Optimistic Outlook

 
 Also, a third consecutive monthly increase in building-permit applications signaled even more construction activity ahead. Permits edged up eight-tenths of a percent in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.25 million, after increases of 6.9 percent in August and 4.2 percent in July.
"We mean jobs," said Roger Blunt, a Pittsburgh-area construction executive and president of the National Association of Home Builders. "Every 100,000 housing starts means 175,000 jobs."
September's construction increase was concentrated entirely in new apartments, which boomed 52 percent to an annual rate of 210,000. They fell 17.9 percent in August.
Construction of single-family homes fell 3 percent last month, down from a 10.5 percent jump in August. This crucial category measures consumers' willingness to take on long-term commitments.
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said the report "gives us confidence that the housing rebound triggered by lower interest rates is being sustained."
Starts increased in every region of the country last month except the South, where they fell from August levels.
 
 
A Boom Sector
 Mark Obrinsky, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, noted that housing starts in the third quarter rose 4 percent from the second quarter, as housing added impetus to the economy's slow recovery from the 1990-91 recession.
"Let's put it this way," he said. "If the rest of the economy in the past two years had recovered at anywhere near the same rate that housing has, we would be experiencing a boom right now."
Financing options remain exceptionally favorable, with mortgage rates at their lowest in a generation. Rates for a 30-year loan were under 7 percent through September and dipped last week to a 25-year low of 6.81 percent, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
The National Association of Home Builders reported Monday that a survey of its members found buoyant expectations for sales over the next six months. Some 62 percent saw sales on the rise, the most upbeat assessment by builders in years, the association said.
The Government said overall starts in September were up 12.3 percent in the Northeast, up 5.3 percent in the Midwest, and up 2.8 percent in the West. They fell five-tenths of a percent in the South.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
O'Hare Airport Refunding

 BODY:
The largest negotiated municipal offering yesterday was a $642.97 million airport bond refunding by the City of Chicago, which was initially priced to yield a maximum 5.30 percent for a bond due in 2016 through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Proceeds from the bond sale of $323.2 million in general airport revenue refunding bonds and $319.8 million in general airport second-lien revenue refunding bonds for O'Hare International Airport in Chicago will be used to redeem bonds that were sold when interest rates were higher and to lower debt-service payments. 
 For investors in a 31 percent tax bracket, the taxable bond equivalent yield for a bond due in 2016 is about 7.68 percent.
The general airport revenue refunding bonds include serials with shorter maturities priced to yield from 4.80 percent in 2004 to 5 percent in 2006, with an issue due in 2013 priced to yield 5.34 percent. Assuming a 31 percent tax bracket, the taxable bond equivalents would be about 6.96 percent in 2004 and 7.25 percent in 2006, with the issue due 2013 at about 7.74 percent.
Underwriters said the general airport second-lien bonds were initially priced to yield 5 percent in 2007 to 5.12 percent in 2011, with an issue due in 2018 at 5.29 percent. The taxable equivalents would yield about 7.25 percent in 2007 to 7.42 percent in 2011, with a taxable equivalent yield for an issue due in 2018 at about 7.67 percent.
The general airport revenue issue carries an A-1 rating from Moody's Investors Service and an A+ rating from Standard & Poor's, while the second-lien revenue issue is rated triple-A because of insurance coverage by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation.

HEADLINE: Yankees Would Create Environmental Nightmare in Midtown

 BODY:
To the Editor:
New York's Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the Urban Development Corporation propose to build a new Yankee Stadium in Manhattan to keep the ball club from moving to New Jersey. But why should New Yorkers give the Yankees even $20 million a year, the cost of financing a new stadium, to congest and pollute Manhattan? 
 The Governor is willing to find the Yankees $500 million to appease their owner, George Steinbrenner, who blackmailed Mayor John V. Lindsay into spending $110 million in taxpayer dollars to refurbish Yankee Stadium two decades ago and who is doing it again to Mayor David N. Dinkins and Governor Cuomo. Enough!
Overlooked is the Clean Air Act. New York and New Jersey are in "severe non-attainment" for ozone pollution. They must show they can meet Federal clean-air standards by 2007. Right now both are in default.
In midtown, a stadium with a parking garage for 7,800 cars would make attainment of standards more difficult. If the states cannot demonstrate compliance, both face severe sanctions. In New York, this means the loss of $1 billion in highway funds annually, including $400 million now transferred to transit. Under these conditions, it is unrealistic to expect that a garage of this size could get a state permit in Manhattan.
What should be done? Make Yankee Stadium work where it is. Build the proposed Metro North access. Promote "subway specials." Provide safe parking. Use new technology to move traffic better on the Major Deegan. Invest in the Bronx to make it inviting. Instead of abandoning cities endowed with transit, we must strengthen them.
The legal hurdles a Manhattan stadium would face demonstrate that for any major new project to go forward, New York must move more effectively to develop and implement clean-air plans. Both New York and New Jersey must cut auto use by 20 percent to meet clean-air standards, not increase it as a new stadium would do.
If the Governor wants to help New York's economy, he should focus on meeting clean-air goals. A new Yankee Stadium will do no more to save New York than circuses did for ancient Rome.
 
BRIAN KETCHAM
Brooklyn, Oct. 12, 1993
The writer is an engineer.

HEADLINE: Yankees Would Create Environmental Nightmare in Midtown;
Cut Stadium Prices

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding the latest proposal to relocate the Yankees in midtown, if you ride the trains when the Yankees are playing, you see a curious thing: the trains to Yankee Stadium coming from Manhattan are packed with fans, while the trains to the stadium coming from the Bronx are empty. Why do so few people from the Bronx come to see the Bronx Bombers play? 
 I think it's economics, pure and simple. Low-income people, which means most of the people living near Yankee Stadium, just can't afford to spend $10.50 for the cheapest reserved seat, let alone the outlandish prices for food and drink.
My solution to the attendance problem at Yankee Stadium is to lower the ticket prices to what you'd pay for a movie, and food prices to what you'd pay in a shopping mall. What George Steinbrenner would lose per seat would more than be made up in volume.
 
ROGER F. REPOHL
Bronx, Oct. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: Florio's Ratings Slipping in Poll, But He's Ahead

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
Gov. Jim Florio's standing with the voters has begun to erode in New Jersey's race for governor, according to the latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll, but he still maintains a commanding lead over Christine Todd Whitman.
With less than two weeks to go before the Nov. 2 election, the poll shows Governor Florio leading Mrs. Whitman 49 to 34 percent among registered voters, a lead that is wider still among those who said they will definitely vote. But his performance rating has slipped, his trust rating has slipped and so has his reputation for honesty and integrity. Nearly two-thirds of the respondents think their taxes would go up if he is re-elected. 
 But even fewer people believed that Mrs. Whitman would have the necessary honesty or could be trusted to make the right decisions in office. And fully two-thirds had concluded that Mrs. Whitman herself did not really believe her tax proposals were feasible.
 
A Cynical Electorate
 The poll results paint a picture of an electorate that is deeply cynical about the candidates' motives, offering only lukewarm support for each, and that is skeptical about the contenders' major policy positions. Campaign experts, when told of the poll results, suggested that negative television advertising has begun to be reflected in a more generally negative view of the race by the voters, a trend that could depress the eventual turnout.
The poll, conducted Saturday through Monday was based on telephone interviews with 1,153 adults throughout the state, of whom 925 said they were registered to vote. The margin of sampling error for voters was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Governor Florio's lead in the trial heat over Mrs. Whitman among all registered voters represents a slight decline from the level of his support in the previous New York Times/ WCBS-TV News poll, which was conducted during the fourth week of September with 804 registered voters out of 1,010 adults. The September poll was conducted during a period that proved to be a bad week in Mrs. Whitman's campaign. The result is consistent with the results of other statewide polls taken this month.
The new survey also shows that the Governor continues to win a good deal of acceptance for his major 1990 tax increase, with the voters splitting evenly on the question of its wisdom, despite Mrs. Whitman's double-pronged charge that the taxes have both depleted the voters' finances and contributed to the loss of tens of thousands of jobs in the state since Mr. Florio took office in 1990.
In last month's poll, 49 percent of the voters had said the tax raises, totaling $2.8 billion annually, had been the right thing for New Jersey, while 42 percent said it had been wrong. In the new poll, 45 percent said it had been the right thing, while 47 percent disagreed.
 
Reaction to Whitman Tax Plan
 Meanwhile, the centerpiece of Mrs. Whitman's economic program, a promise to cut income taxes for most voters by 30 percent over three years, has clearly fallen on barren electoral ground: as many voters said such a cut would be wrong for the state as said it would be right; and 65 percent said the tax cut idea was a promise Mrs. Whitman knew she could not keep, while 24 percent disagreed.
By a ratio of more than 2 to 1, they said they believed Mr. Florio knew he would have to raise taxes during his 1989 campaign, despite his position at the time that he saw no need for new levies.
But perhaps the most telling story of the new poll lies in the evidence that the previous poll's high level of "don't knows" and "no answers" have begun to coalesce into distinct political opinions, and that Governor Florio's standing has suffered, however slightly, on every measure in the new poll compared to the old.
The evidence of rising negativity is exactly why no one should consider today's polling results conclusive for the race, said Lee Seglem, managing editor of New Jersey Reporter, an independent, nonprofit public affairs bimonthly. Flux in public opinion that reveals itself in the final weeks of a campaign, he said, will likely increase in volatility as the days count down to the vote, and as the clangor of the campaign rises in pitch.
"I wouldn't bet on this race even now," Mr. Seglem said. "This is a very volatile campaign, it's really going to tighten in the last 10 days, and I think it's going to be decided by 2 or 3 percentage points when we're all done."
Indeed, opinion-poll leaders have turned into election-day losers several times in New Jersey's turbid political atmosphere. Mr. Florio lost to Thomas H. Kean in 1981 after leading in the opinion surveys for most of the race, and Brendan Byrne staged a come-from-behind upset in his race for governor four years before.
With that background, the Whitman campaign is likely to read the portents of softness in Mr. Florio's armor with particular care.
"We still have two weeks to go," said Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman, when apprised of the latest Times/WCBS-TV News poll. "There's enough time for her to drive home her message about creating new jobs in a healthy economy."
In the new poll, fewer voters had a favorable opinion of the Governor than in the last poll, fewer of them approved of his performance in office, fewer thought that he understood their needs and problems, or that he has offered specific proposals to solve the state's problems.
On the question of Mr. Florio's competence, which the Governor has made a keystone of his campaign against an opponent he characterizes as inexperienced and out of touch, the poll respondents reversed themselves since the last survey. Then, by a ratio of 51 to 40, they said Mr. Florio could be trusted to avoid making serious mistakes in office; this time, 42 percent trusted him to avoid mistakes, and 50 percent did not.
 
Scorn for Ads
 The voters scorned the negative television advertising they said they saw coming from both sides, but they blame Mr. Florio for the negativity more than they do Mrs. Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman's standing in most categories also suffered when compared to the September opinion survey. Where she has improved -- on issues of familiarity with voters' concerns, the voters' general impression of her, trustworthiness and ability to avoid mistakes in office -- the improvements tended to be meager ones on top of already relatively small percentages, leaving her far from striking distance of the Governor in most categories.
It is a political truism that in the absence of an overriding issue, re-election campaigns tend to be referendums on the incumbent, and to that extent Mrs. Whitman clearly benefits from the kind of anti-Florio sentiment that has dotted New Jersey with bumper stickers saying "Dump Florio," and "Florio Free in '93." While only 16 percent of Governor Florio's supporters said they back him because of dislike of Mrs. Whitman, 45 percent of those supporting Mrs. Whitman said they did so not because they favor her, but because they disliked Governor Florio.
Bob Lundin, a printing supplies salesman from Roselle, was a respondent who agreed to be interviewed after the poll. He explained his support for Mrs. Whitman in straight anti-Florio terms.
"Florio has been a disaster for this state," Mr. Lundin declared. "Anybody who has a business will tell you that they're just hanging on with the taxes and the regulations that are coming down, and if we're looking at four more years of this, I don't know how anybody is going to survive -- there won't be anyone left."
In contrast, several Florio supporters who were re-interviewed after the poll pointed to positive changes in the lives of their families or their communities as the basis for their views.
Jackie Kerrigan of the shorefront community of Beechwood, who described herself as being "in the Mom business right now," said her general opinion of politicians is not a good one.
"I'm not hard-core for Florio, but I happen to live on the ocean, and in all my days of living here I find that the shore is much cleaner than it used to be, and that is really important to my friends who depend on the shore business," she said.
 
A Reason to Vote
 If Mrs. Whitman can take heart from the poll's evidence that she has inflicted some damage on Governor Florio, said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider College, she still faces the task in the remaining days to lift her own positive attributes among voters.
In that task, Dr. Rebovich said, the Republican has started late:
"You can attack all you want, but the other half of campaigning is giving voters a reason to vote for you, and I think she has done less than that," he said. "This is the point where you use television to reinforce your message, and if you don't have one at this point, I think you're in trouble."
Both sides are paying close attention to evidence of the firmness of each candidate's support, as well to the level of voter interest, which will drive turnout on election day.
For example, when registered voters who said they would definitely vote were analyzed, Governor Florio's support increased slightly to 52 percent, while Mrs. Whitman's increased by one point to 35 percent.
When this group of voters was reduced to those who also said they were paying at least some attention to the campaign, the Governor's support increased another 2 points to 54 percent, while Mrs. Whitman's support remained unchanged at 35 percent.
 
How Poll of New Jersey Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 16 to 18 with 1,153 adults throughout New Jersey. Of these, 925 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of New Jersey exchanges. The exchanges were chosen in a way to insure that each area of the state was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines in each residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to race, sex, age, and region of the state.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Jersey residents.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 4 percentage points for registered voters who say they will "definitely" vote on Election Day.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.
And in a poll conducted more than two weeks before an election, like this one, there are additional potential difficulties, such as dramatic events, debates, or campaign appeals that occur after the interviewing, unusual patterns of voter turnout, and the ultimate decisions made by those voters who were undecided at the time of the poll or said they might change their mind before Election Day.

HEADLINE: Local Governments May Pay More in Health Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Administration officials disclosed today that President Clinton's health plan would require some state and local governments to pay more than private employers for workers' health insurance.
Private employers would not have to contribute more than 7.9 percent of their payrolls. But no such limit would apply to public employers, the Administration officials said. 
 The President's decision to exempt state and local governments from that limit alienates some of his natural allies, including public employee unions, which strongly supported him in the 1992 campaign and have pleaded for a ceiling on their health insurance costs.
Officials of the United States Conference of Mayors, the National Association of Counties, the National League of Cities, the National Governors' Association and public employee unions all expressed concern about this decision.
 
At Least 10 States Affected
 They said it appeared that at least 10 states would pay more than 7.9 percent of their payrolls to provide the package of health benefits required under Mr. Clinton's plan. The states are New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, Vermont, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan and Pennsylvania.
Medical costs and health insurance premiums tend to be higher in states with high personal income, large numbers of doctors, a large proportion of medical specialists and a high concentration of elderly people.
Administration officials said part of their reason behind the decision not to put a limit on the cost to public employers was that state and local governments could impose taxes to help pay for employee health benefits.
In response to a question last week, Kevin Anderson, a White House spokesman, said: "The 7.9 percent cap does not apply to public employers. Their low-wage employees are eligible for the same kind of assistance on their premiums and copayments as anybody else. But the cap does not apply to them."
Administration officials disclosed details of the financing and subsidies in the President's plan as they rushed to draft legislation for submission to Congress next week.
The officials said there would be some limits on the amount of Federal money available for subsidies to small businesses and their low-wage workers. Low-income families would have a legally enforceable right to such subsidies. But the officials said it was not clear what would happen if demand for such subsidies exceeded the amount available because of a recession, an epidemic or other unforeseen events.
 
'Capped Entitlement'
 Using the jargon of budget analysts in Washington, the officials said Mr. Clinton's subsidies would probably not provide an absolute, open-ended entitlement to benefits as in the case of Social Security or Medicare, but would establish a "capped entitlement." Congress would need to appropriate additional money if claims exceeded the expected amount.
Stan Dorn, who has represented low-income people as a lawyer at the National Health Law Program, said the subsidies should not depend on the vagaries and politics of the annual budget process. "If forced to compete for money with other, better established interest groups, low-income consumers and small businesses may lose out," he said.
There were these other developments today as politicians staked out positions for the coming debate over the future of health care in America:
*A new national survey found that the public is confused and generally uninformed about the nation's health care problems. The survey, designed by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Harvard University School of Public Health, found that people were equally divided on whether the nation spends too much or too little on health care.
*The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said there was "little empirical evidence" of savings from managed care networks. President Clinton is counting on such networks of doctors and hospitals to control health costs.
*The Republican National Committee unveiled a television commercial criticizing Mr. Clinton's health plan on the ground that it would lead to "Government price-fixing, rationing and delays." The Administration denied the accusations.
White House officials said that Mr. Clinton on Monday ruled out any cap on the health insurance costs of the employees of state and local governments.
Douglas D. Peterson, senior policy analyst at the National League of Cities, said tonight: "Municipal employers would like to be treated in the same manner as private employers. We fail to see why private employers would have a cap on their health care costs while public employers would not."
Barbara Shipnuck, a spokeswoman for the National Association of Counties, said: "All employers, public and private, should be treated alike. We should not have to spend more for our employees than private employers spend for theirs."
 
'Fiscal Safety Valve'
 Ms. Shipnuck, who is chairwoman of the Board of Supervisors of Monterey County, Calif., said Mr. Clinton was using counties as "a fiscal safety valve" for his health care plan. She complained that counties were being asked to pay "more than their fair share."
The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees was the first union in the country to endorse Mr. Clinton for President, in January 1992, before all the primaries. But its members say they fear they will be hurt by the President's health plan because they might have to pay higher premiums for health insurance.
Administration officials said it was inappropriate for the Federal Government to subsidize the personnel costs of state and local governments. Moreover, they said it would cost the Federal Government at least $20 billion over five years if it guaranteed state and local authorities that they would not spend more than 7.9 percent of their payrolls on employee health benefits.
Administration officials said Mr. Clinton's proposal would help state and local governments in other ways, by reducing the projected cost of health care for uninsured people, for Medicaid recipients and for retirees who formerly worked for state and local agencies.
 
Pooling Purchasing Power
 Under Mr. Clinton's plan, public employees and most private employees would pool their purchasing power and get insurance coverage through large groups known as regional health alliances. State and local officials and public employee unions said they feared they would bear a disproportionate share because there would be a limit on health insurance costs for private companies, but not for public employers.
Health alliances are a cornerstone of Mr. Clinton's proposal. But the Kaiser survey found that only 22 percent of Americans knew what such entities were.
Similarly, only 31 percent said they knew the meaning of "managed care," and just 20 percent knew the meaning of "managed competition," the blend of market forces and government regulation that Mr. Clinton has embraced.
Many people in the survey said they thought the uninsured were poor, unemployed or elderly. In fact, most of the uninsured are above the official poverty level, are employed and are not elderly.
Forty percent of people in the survey said they thought the United States spends too much on health care, while 41 percent said it spends too little. Only 38 percent said they believed that Federal spending for health care was an important cause of the Federal budget deficit; 54 percent said it was not an important cause.
 
'Public Poorly Informed'
 "The public is still poorly informed and uninvolved," said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation. "Unless that changes, the spin controllers and special interests will dominate the debate."
The poll, based on telephone interviews with 1,200 adults, was conducted Sept. 30 through Oct. 5 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
The survey found large numbers of people were unsure about whether they would be better off under the Clinton plan, Republican proposals or the current health care system.
The Republican National Committee is trying to shape public opinion on this question with its new television commercial.
The advertisement shows pictures of a doctor's office and a nurse with children. An announcer says "there's a way" to provide health care for all "without Bill Clinton's Government-run system, or his 100 new Government bureaucracies, without his Government price fixing, rationing and delays, without his mandates on small business that would cost up to 3 million Americans their jobs."
