HEADLINE: CLINTON ASKS HELP ON POLLUTION GOAL

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton appealed to businesses and individuals today to help prevent global warming as he announced his plan to reduce the nation's emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide.
"In concert with all other nations, we simply must halt global warming," Mr. Clinton said in a White House ceremony. "It is a threat to our health, to our ecology and to our economy." 
 The goal of the Climate Change Action Plan is to reduce the nation's emissions of so-called greenhouse gases to 1990 levels by the year 2000. Mr. Clinton assigned a study group to look at further reductions beyond that.
Some scientists believe that global temperatures will rise because increasing levels of carbon dioxide and other man-made gases will trap and retain heat from the sun in a process similar to what happens in a hreenhouse. Such a warming trend could lead to rising sea levels, cause severe droughts and severely disrupt the earth's biological systems.
 
Reliance on Volunteerism
 The President's plan relies mainly on voluntary cooperation by businesses and industries to undertake energy efficiency measures and curb emissions that are caused in large part by burning fossil fuels.
Some environmental groups have criticized the plan, whose outlines had become known over the last week, as not tough enough.
The plan calls for $1.9 billion in Federal spending, most of it diverted from other areas of the budget, and seeks $60 billion worth of voluntary participation by business and industry. If the companies do not fully embrace the plan, the Administration held out the prospect of tougher regulation.
"If this doesn't get it, we'll go back and find out how to get it through mandates," said Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary. She said, however, "Voluntary is not a dirty word."
The Administration said that 60 companies had already pledged to reduce emissions and that 40 motor industry representatives had agreed to promote use of more efficient electric motors.
 
Ntionwide Cooperation Urged
 Responding to environmental critics, Mr. Clinton called for nationwide cooperation. "We frankly must all take more personal responsibility," he said. "It will take all of us to make it work. So I say to all the American people, if your utility offers you help in conserving energy in your own home, seize it."
Similarly, he called on businesses to take advantage of help offered by the Environmental Protection Agency's expanded effort to encourage more efficient lighting, and by the Department of Energy's new efforts to promote more efficient industrial motors.
"You will save money, and you will help your country and your fellow citizens," Mr. Clinton told the audience on the South Lawn. The audience included many utility and business representatives, who praised the initiative.
Mr. Clinton was joined by Vice President Al Gore, who had criticized former President George Bush for not taking strong action against greenhouse gases.
Mr. Gore called global warming "the highest-risk environmental problem the world faces today," and said the plan "will do the job, effectively protect our environment, establish the United States as the world leader we must be in confronting this problem and at the same time enhance our economic strength."

HEADLINE: Customs Overhaul Offered In Move to Aid Trade Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Administration and Congressional supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement today tied a sweeping revision of Federal customs regulations to the proposed pact after failing to resolve a dispute over how to pay for the agreement.
Today's proposed revision of customs regulations was part of an effort by the pact's supporters to mollify transportation industries. The nation's airlines, cruise lines and trucking companies are vigorously lobbying against an Administration proposal to double customs inspection fees to offset $2.35 billion in tariffs that would be eliminated over five years under the agreement. 
 Some House Republicans who vehemently oppose tax increases are also trying to block the fee proposal. A group of 27 Republicans sent a letter to President Clinton on Monday contending that spending should be cut instead of adding transportation taxes to offset the lost tariffs.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is the ranking minority member on the Ways and Means Committee, said today, "We continue to tell the Administration that the ball is in their court, and they need to come up with some spending cuts if they don't want to lose some votes."
 
Budget Requirement
 The fee increase was proposed because Congressional budget rules require that revenue reductions be offset by higher taxes or cuts in mandatory spending programs.
The Administration proposal called for an increase by $5 in the tax on a ticket for an international flight or cruise. The proposal would also double border-crossing fees, to $10 for trucks and $15 for rail cars.
The revision of customs regulations proposed today would allow customs documents, now required to be typed and hand delivered, to be filed by computer over telephone lines. Trucking and air freight executives have sought such a change for years.
But the initial reaction was unenthusiastic, with trucking and airline industry representatives immediately dismissing the proposal as inadequate and saying it was likely to go through Congress as a separate bill anyway.
Before the fee proposal, the airline industry had been neutral about the trade agreement, while the trucking industry had been lobbying the Administration to change some provisions that affected it. Both groups opposed the fee increase, and James Landry, the president of the Air Transport Association, an industry group based here, has said that the higher fees proposed by the Administration would also violate international air agreements. White House officials deny this, citing State and Transportation Department legal opinions.
 
Carrot and Stick
 The customs revisions were proposed at a Ways and Means Committee meeting this morning. Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, used an amendment to attach the customs revisions to legislation putting the free-trade agreement into law. The Customs Commissioner, George Weiss, endorsed the move in brief testimony to the committee.
Representative Robert T. Matsui, the California Democrat who is leading House backers of the free trade pact, said that if transportation industries did not rally to the agreement's defense then the provision might be dropped.
The Ways and Means Committee also discussed the dispute over how to raise money, but reached no decision. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said the Administration still wanted to raise the transportation fees but would like to discuss new ideas at a closed session with committee members.
At the end of the hearing, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the committee, said that he would probably meet on Wednesday with Leon E. Panetta, the White House budget director, to review a number of budgetary options.
An Administration official said that the White House was now looking at ways to pay for the agreement through improved tax collections, but had only found $700 million so far that it thought could be raised by such a move.
Budgetary squabbles are hurting efforts to build support for the agreement, lawmakers favoring the trade agreement are saying. "It's just another problem the opposition can point to -- the sooner they can resolve these, the sooner they can pick up votes," Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who heads the Finance Committee's trade panel and supports the agreement, said last Thursday in an interview.
 
Tariff as Tax
 President Clinton told reporters this morning that the Administration was still working on how to raise the money to offset tariffs eliminated by the free trade pact. If approved by the House and Senate, the agreement would gradually eliminate tariffs and other trade barriers over the next 15 years.
"We still have to work through the whole issue of how we deal with the fact that if we pass Nafta, we have to reduce tariffs," the President said. He emphasized that the current tariffs on Mexican and Canadian goods represented a tax on Americans now buying these goods.
"That's a $2.5 billion tax on American consumers today," President Clinton said.
Mr. Kantor and House supporters of the free trade pact contend that it will increase overall Federal tax revenue by stimulating economic growth in the United States. "Every $1 billion increase in exports is another 20,000 well-paying jobs here," said Representative Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois."
But Congressional budget rules do not allow economic growth and other secondary effects of legislation to be used to offset revenue losses.

HEADLINE: In Haiti, There Is No Shortage of Fear

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 19

 BODY:
People familiar with Haiti's economy say that the international naval blockade that began today may cause severe damage but that it is uncertain whether the hardships will force the military leaders to restore democracy.
Concerns about the impact of the embargo grew as an international flotilla, including six warships from the United States, gathered on the hazy blue horizon off the coast to prevent fuel and arms from entering Haiti. 
 The sanctions were approved by the United Nations Security Council last week in an effort to force the military to allow the return of the elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
In the first action of the blockade, the United States Navy frigate Klakring stopped the cargo ship San Antonio today, the Defense Department said in Washington. The ship, registered in Belize and bound for Haiti, carried cement, which is not prohibited under the embargo, the Pentagon said.
 
Oil May Last 10 Weeks
 Diplomats and Haitian economists estimate that without rationing, the country's oil supply could last 6 to 10 weeks. During a similar embargo this summer, draconian conservation stretched supplies dramatically.
If many Haitians in the capital are worried about possible violence if the military retaliates against its enemies because of the blockade, development experts and others say the embargo could pose dangers for many in the countryside even without more bloodshed.
"I was talking to a priest in the northwest the other day, and he told me that if they are going to blockade this country he hopes they send a lot of wood," said Chris Conrad, the director of CARE's relief programs in Haiti. "When I asked him, 'Wood?,' he said, 'because that's what you'll need to build all of the coffins.' "
The arid northwest is the poorest region of Haiti, which is the hemisphere's poorest country. Mr. Conrad, whose organization feeds 620,000 people in Haiti at least one meal a day, said that after two years of political turmoil and international isolation, many in the region, particularly women and children, were barely holding on to life.
 
Where Measles Is Fatal
 "Anything that comes down the pike at this point, be it measles or diarrhea or upper respiratory disease," he said, "the kids up there who have very little resistance already are just going to be wiped out."
Like others, Mr. Conrad said provisions in the embargo that allow relief supplies to enter Haiti would be of limited consequence because transportation will soon be frozen as the fuel supply dries up.
Alberto Favilla, a former World Bank economist who led efforts to draw up a recovery program for Haiti that is to begin once President Aristide returns, said: "Because of all this country has been through recently, essential inputs like spare parts, pesticides, fertilizers and drugs have reached the bottom already. This new embargo doesn't have to go very much further to paralyze the whole country. The only remaining question is the power of the Army to suppress opposition by threatening to kill everybody."
During the last two years, he said, Haiti's economy had shrunk by more than 15 percent.
 
The Intimidation Campaign
 Since its September 1991 coup against President Aristide, the Army has proven highly effective at intimidation. Several hundred people are thought to have been killed in the coup, and many more have perished since, either as a direct result of army terror or lost at sea in attempts to flee the country. The violence of the past two years led 40,000 Haitians to flee the country in a chaotic rush.
In recent days the terror campaign has focused on close supporters of President Aristide and on members of the transitional Government of Prime Minister Robert Malval, who was appointed by the President six weeks ago.
With that in mind, Washington dispatched the Assistant Secretary of State for Security, Anthony C. E. Quainton, to Haiti today to consult with the Government on protective measures. Diplomats said the Government would be given armored vehicles and secure radios to communicate with each other.
"If this military leadership knows that it is facing defeat, these people are going to be slaughtering people even as they go down the exit escalator," said a former Haitian official with extensive knowledge of the armed forces.
 
The Promises Unkept
 The former official, like several diplomats here, said he expected the military to bide its time, seeking an exit only if its situation becomes critical. The problem then, he said, becomes one of holding the commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, to whatever bargain he negotiates.
Diplomats portray General Cedras as a deeply dishonest figure who believes he is more clever than any of the foreigners sent to seek his removal. Last Friday, even as the blockade loomed, General Cedras reneged on a commitment to retire to make way for Father Aristide's scheduled return on Oct. 30.
"If strictly enforced, this blockade will definitely bring the Army back to the table," the former official said. "The problem is that there may not be anything to prevent them from reneging again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As the international naval blockade against Haiti went into effect yesterday, people began stocking up on supplies of basic goods. Residents of Port-au-Prince stood in line to buy kerosene for lamps. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Moynihan on Health: Cure Social Ills

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Health care hearings at the Senate Finance Committee under Daniel Patrick Moynihan's chairmanship are unlike any other health care hearings.
The talk today was not of how health care alliances would work under President Clinton's plan, nor whether small business could afford to pay premiums. There were no emotional accounts of children denied treatment, no special pleading for victims of this disease or practitioners of that treatment. 
 Instead, the committee discussed the soaring rates of illegitimate births in the United States, a topic that for more than two decades has concerned Senator Moynihan, Democrat of New York.
He began the hearing by noting that 30 percent of all births now were to unmarried women, 71 percent in Detroit, 66 percent in Washington and 45.2 percent in New York.
Then Lee Rainwater, a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation, said that "by the time we get our health care plan," in the year 2000, "they will be a little over 40 percent."
What does this have to do with health care?
Senator Moynihan tried to make a direct connection when he observed that the increase was occurring, but, he said, "so far as we can tell, no one in the vast health bureaucracy of the Federal Government seems to have noticed it." And that, he added, made it likely that the issue would be ignored under Mr. Clinton's program.
But that was a stretch. After the hearing, the Senator said his point was that the nation's cities will be intolerable if few children in them have two parents. "I don't want another vast social program that makes no difference to the fact that our cities are becoming unlivable," he added.

 	 	 		. . .	 	It wasn't a hearing devoted to finding solutions to the problem of illegitimacy, however. Instead, it was intended to raise questions about whether health care was the big problem the nation ought to be wrestling with when it seemed to be ignoring social decay that would undercut any progress it might make on health.
One witness, Dr. Leroy Schwartz, president of Health Policy International in Princeton, even argued that health care costs were not the problem they seemed to be, since so much of them went toward solving the consequences of social problems.
That argument puzzled Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who said a patient with a gunshot wound had to be treated by doctors no matter what caused the shooting -- whether it was violence on television, as Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa contended, or the failure of Congress to pass the handgun ban proposed by Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island.
But there was a thoughtful theme throughout the session: that trying to fix the health care delivery system directly might not be worth the trouble if nothing was done to cure the social ills that increased medical costs.
As Senator Bradley said, the Finance Committee has taxes in its jurisdiction. And some social ills, like drinking, can be curbed by making alcohol more expensive.
One witness made the same point. Ted R. Miller, director of the safety and health policy program of the National Public Services Research Institute in Landover, Md., urged that alcohol be taxed at $1.38 an ounce. He estimated that that was the cost to society of drunken driving and other problems caused by drinking.
And Senator Bradley again urged higher taxes on guns and gun dealers to help pay for health care.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Two floors above the room where the Finance Committee was meeting, the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee was hearing testimony about how the President's health care plan would affect the economy. This afternoon it heard witnesses argue that having the Government run the system and pay the bills would be better than going through insurance companies.
That committee, led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, does not doubt that health care is the problem to solve in the next year. For that matter, neither do several members of Mr. Moynihan's committee, including Senators Chafee and John D. Rockefeller 4th of West Virginia, or the Senate majority and minority leaders, George J. Mitchell of Maine and Bob Dole of Kansas.
But on this question the chairmanship of Mr. Moynihan is an intellectual journey, testing his concern that "we don't have a health care problem, we have a social problem."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York presiding yesterday at a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee on health costs. He listened to testimony from Ted R. Miller, director of the safety and health policy program of the National Public Services Research Institute. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Universities Scrambling As Investment Incomes Fall Short of Past Levels

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Colleges and universities across the country are eliminating jobs or freezing hiring, declaring construction moratoriums and trimming student financial aid because of the declining return on endowments, a source of income that is often second only to tuition.
At Stanford Law School, a student loan program was saved only because three jobs were cut. At the University of Texas, building maintenance has been cut sharply. And at the University of Pennsylvania, three departments were closed last week and their professors moved to others. 
 For the last three years, the return on endowments has averaged about 9.9 percent, well below the 25 percent returns in the best years of the 1980's. Last year, the return was 13.1 percent, still down a full point from the average for the 10 preceding years, according to the National Association of College and University Business Officers. With a total university pool of $73.9 billion, a one-point drop in return represents nearly $1 billion.
The financial difficulty lies not in stocks and bonds, which grew in value about 20 percent last year, but in the continuing bust in real estate and oil and gas prices. While these investments have languished for years, many institutions keep these assets, hoping for better returns in the future and hedging their bets in the stock market. They are also making riskier investments overseas.
 
Real Estate Blues
 At Harvard, with a $5.8 billion endowment, the largest in the country, officials complain about depressed real estate values. The endowment income in fiscal 1992, ending June 30, provided about 22 percent of Harvard's $1.3 billion in annual operating expenses. Tuition pays for 31 percent.
The one bright spot is that the institutions can refinance debt at lower rates, but the savings come nowhere near making up for the shrinking return on endowments, a significant problem in an overall difficult time of less Federal support and already-high tuitions.
And while no major university is doing the unthinkable by dipping into the principal, many are spending more of the interest for operating expenses, rather than plowing the money back into the endowments.
The standard rule for institutions has been to spend just 4 to 5 percent of an endowment's total return and save the rest. But as returns have fallen, institutions must spend more of this money or cut their budgets.
The University of Texas system, with the nation's second-largest endowment at $4.4 billion, is a case in point. Investment income from the endowment -- which includes royalties from 21 million acres in West Texas with oil, gas and mineral deposits -- slipped to $247 million for the fiscal year, which ended Aug. 31, from $257 million for the previous year. Income is expected to drop by an additional $9 million in the current year.
 
More Cuts Expected
 This is not good news to the University of Texas at Austin, the system's flagship campus with 48,500 students. The institution shares proceeds from the endowment with 14 other campuses and the Texas A&M University system. After several years in which its share of the endowment income increased annually by about $2 million, the Austin campus saw its share drop by $2 million to $78 million this year, with a cut of $3 million expected next year.
"What this means is that we have less money to educate a very large student body," said Robert M. Berdahl, president of the University of Texas at Austin. "It means that already stretched resources are going to have to be stretched even more."
Although the university has got some relief from refinancing close to $1 billion in debt, the savings are not enough to stop the university from asking students to start paying for the university health clinic. A building moratorium was declared. And last year's $24 million maintenance budget was clipped to $10 million this year.
Officials also voice fears that less money may be available for the university's 800 endowed chairs and professorships on the campus, which are backed with as much as $1 million each. These positions have attracted people like Steven Weinberg, a physics professor and the 1979 Nobel Prize winner for physics, and former Representative Barbara Jordan, a professor at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs.
 
Bidding for Professors
 "It is a very significant problem," said G. Charles Franklin, the university's vice president for business affairs. "These funds are key in attracting top, key people."
Perhaps the most striking impact has been on individual gifts or legacies, established to create or support specific academic programs and separate from the general endowment funds. Many small funds do not produce the income necessary to support the activities required by the donors. At the Stanford University Law School, for example, a student loan-forgiveness program, created in 1987 by an initial $300,000 grant and enhanced by subsequent gifts, cannot meet the $100,000-a-year cost.
The program was intended to pay back part of the student loans of graduates who pursued public interest jobs. The longer the service, the larger the portion of the debt that was repaid. About 10 students from each class qualify, but the program faces a a 50 percent cut in money for the program.
Because of student protests, according to Associate Dean Frank Brucato, the program was spared, but other cuts were made, including shorter hours at the law school library and 3 of 45 teaching positions.
 
Ivy League Affected
 Not even the Ivy League is immune. With the oldest and biggest endowments of any of the nation's colleges and universities, Ivy institutions like the University of Pennsylvania are also feeling the strain.
Last week, the university's school of arts and sciences moved to eliminate its religious studies, civilization and regional science departments, fold its astronomy department into physics and bring outside administrators to overhaul the Slavic languages department.
The university's school of arts and sciences -- the largest division, with 28 departments -- has a small endowment that has not generated enough income to maintain services at current levels, said Rosemary A. Stevens, dean of the school. "We have a very keen awareness that we are living in a period of resource constraints," she said.
The flip side to the lower interest rates is in savings available from refinancing debt at more favorable terms. The University of Michigan recently refinanced $500 million, for a $15 million savings over the life of the loan. The slower economy has also resulted in an inflation rate of about 3 percent, which has helped institutions stretch taut budgets a little further.
 
Someplace With More Money
 "I would argue that the lower interest rates have benefited us," said Robert Taylor, the treasurer at Wesleyan University, which refinanced $37 million in debt and will save a little more than $1 million a year in interest payments.
These gains, however, do not offset the declining income from endowments and other gifts, prompting growing numbers of colleges and universities to invest more money abroad. Wesleyan University five months ago, for example, put $20 million of its endowment into stock markets overseas, in a trend that endowment managers say is expected to grow, risky though it may be.
"Sure you're nervous," said Farris Womack, the University of Michigan's executive vice president and chief financial officer, which recently invested 15 percent of its $797 million endowment overseas. "But it's important to recognize that stocks in foreign companies represent real opportunities to gain."
Institutions have tended to invest in established foreign companies, like the Mexican telephone company monopoly, and in large and growing European or Asian firms representing an array of fast-growing industries. "It reduces the risk," Mr. Womack said, "because it's unlikely that every market is going to experience its ups and downs simultaneously."

HEADLINE: Ukraine Now Says It May Keep Nuclear Weapons

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In a sharp change of tone, President Leonid M. Kravchuk said today that Ukraine may keep some of the nuclear weapons it inherited from the Soviet Union, and he accused the West of not providing enough financial assistance to dismantle the 176 strategic missiles on Ukrainian territory.
President Kravchuk's statement, that Ukraine may keep 46 SS-24 missiles, came only five days before Secretary of State Warren Christopher is to arrive here for talks in which Ukraine's nuclear weapons will feature high on the agenda. 
 Previously President Kravchuk had repeated his intent to dismantle all nuclear weapons on its territory, ratify the 1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (Start) and become a non-nuclear state.
Though Kiev has pressed the issue of financial compensation before, the threat of not complying with its agreement to disarm is new.
Ukraine is the third-largest nuclear power, with 1,656 warheads, larger than the combined arsenals of France, Britain and China. The SS-24 missiles, which can carry 10 warheads each, are the most modern weapon in the old Soviet nuclear arsenal.
President Kravchuk made the surprise statement to reporters in the corridors of Parliament during a closed session on national security.
"After the ratification of Start," he said, "we will immediately proceed with the destruction of the 130," a reference to the SS-19's. "But we can approach the remaining 46" -- the SS-24's -- "from a different standpoint. We can only remove them from active military alert and remove the codes so that they will not be aimed at the United States."
Ukraine's turnaround comes only a month and a half after Russia announced that Ukraine had agreed to transfer all its nuclear weapons to Russia. The agreement fell apart weeks later when the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry insisted that the agreement called for the transfer of only some nuclear weapons to Russia, not all of them.
Since the Russian-Ukrainian disagreement, the Clinton Administration has stepped up its contacts with Kiev in an attempt to address Ukraine's security concerns and financial needs. In addition to Secretary Christopher's visit, the Ukrainian Foreign Minister. Anatoly M. Zlenko, met with President Clinton earlier this month.
Ukraine has been asking the United States for $2.5 billion to dismantle and destroy its nuclear weapons. Today President Kravchuk reiterated that Ukraine wanted to be non-nuclear, "but we need help to be non-nuclear."
Kiev secured $175 million from Washington last year but the money has yet not been disbursed because of a delay in signing an umbrella agreement that governs how the missiles are to be destroyed.
Congress has earmarked another $400 million this year and United States officials have said more may be available later if the umbrella agreement is signed.
Assistant Defense Secretary Graham T. Allison has said Kiev is not required to ratify the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty in order for the money to be disbursed.
A Western diplomat said the delay in signing the umbrella agreement is due simply to "a few technical issues, and the gap is narrowing." Kiev and Washington have been negotiating for months and the agreement may be signed during Secretary Christopher's visit here on Monday.
Kiev did not consult with the United States prior to President Kravchuk's announcement today, and the Western diplomat said, "This is a corridor conversation, not an official position."
"It is a change from what he has said previously but we need to find out how much he means it," the diplomat said. "Our position is that President Kravchuk has openly committed himself to destroying all nuclear weapons."
While Kiev would like to see considerable economic assistance before nuclear disarmament, a senior United States official here noted that "ultimately, the basis for our relationship in the future rests on Ukraine becoming a non-nuclear state."

HEADLINE: Benazir Bhutto Returns as Leader of a Poor and Troubled Pakistan

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Benazir Bhutto, Pakistan's first woman Prime Minister, returned triumphantly today to the office from which she was banished in 1990 on charges of corruption and incompetence.
Assuming office a second time, Ms. Bhutto faces a desperately poor Pakistan and confronts a hostile India and severe economic and military sanctions by the United States because of Pakistan's nuclear weapons program. 
 Although her first administration was marked by paralysis and charges of ineptitude, there are some expectations that Ms. Bhutto may have learned from her first failed government.
"This is a moment for the rehabilitation and stabilization of democracy," Ms. Bhutto told Parliament, which only moments before had elected her over her archrival, former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, whose party came in second in the elections this month.
 
'Doubts in Their Hearts'
 "The country is passing through a severe economic crisis," she declared. "People have doubts in their hearts. A change in the system is called for. The people's government will be a government of reforms."
The expectation that Ms. Bhutto might do better in her second try as Prime Minister was based in part on a feeling that she and Pakistan's military and business establishment may have learned to live with each other.
"The fundamental difference between today and 1988 is that she has cobbled together a majority, but she no longer faces a hostile establishment," said Maleeha Lodhi, the editor of The News, a newspaper based in Rawalpindi. "Then she faced a hostile President, a scheming army chief and a civilian bureaucracy that had not come to terms with her party returning to power. This has all changed now."
 
After Transitional Leader
 Ms. Bhutto succeeds the three-month transitional government of Moeen Qureshi, a former vice president of the World Bank. In his tenure, Mr. Qureshi made sweeping economic and legal changes, including higher taxes for large feudal estates, which are widely acknowledged to have returned Pakistan's Government to solvency and created a framework for recovery.
Mr. Qureshi said that Pakistan's economic future depended to a great extent on the determination of the new Government to continue his policies.
"The economy today has been consolidated," said Mr. Qureshi. "We have initiated changes and reforms that are likely to bring about long-term improvements, but those changes and those reforms need to be adhered to by the elected Government. We are hopeful that will be the case."
Ms. Bhutto's return to power culminates a three-year political struggle with the country's powerful army and president, and re-establishes her at the center of the country's politics. By virtue of her gender and education, she is also likely to take her place once again on the global stage.
 
Moving Among Differing Views
 Yet, despite attending Harvard and Oxford universities, an education that persuaded many Western leaders and analysts to take an often benevolent view of her, Ms. Bhutto's political instincts and practical policies are embedded in the ruthlessness and opportunism of Pakistani politics since the country's creation in 1947.
Since she was dismissed as Prime Minister in 1990 by then President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, Ms. Bhutto has moved effortlessly among conflicting political tactics and principles. From having denounced Mr. Ishaq Khan as a traitor to the Constitution for forcing her from office, three years later she was able to join with him in an alliance to attack, and force the resignation of her successor, Mr. Sharif.
And despite her intense hostility toward the country's military -- General Zia ul-Haq, who ruled the country as one of its military dictators, had her father Zulfikar Ali Bhutto executed -- she made it clear during the last year that she would support any military action to remove Mr. Sharif.
 
Other Family Members
 In the election this year, other members of the Bhutto family attempted to unsettle Ms. Bhutto's monopoly of her father's popular legacy. Her brother, Murtaza, who had taken refuge in Syria after being accused of terrorism here, ran for several parliamentary and provincial assembly seats from exile.
He won a place in the assembly of Sindh province. Their mother, Nusrat, who was allied with Ms. Bhutto in 1988, switched allegiance this year to her son. The switch created a political rift in the family that was evident today when Ms. Bhutto failed to acknowledge her mother's presence in Parliament.
In large measure, Ms. Bhutto learned her political skills at the knee of her father, the country's first elected Prime Minister and a man riddled with contradictions of his own. One of the country's largest landowners, a member of what the landed gentry known here as "feudals," Mr. Bhutto drank Scotch, was a notorious philanderer and yet professed his adherence to Islam and socialism.
Ms. Bhutto accomplished little in her 20 months in office and introduced almost no legislation. Under her administration Pakistan's economy deteriorated, its people remained among the world's poorest and the oppression and mistreatment of the country's women, widely deplored by human rights organizations, continued.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Campaign to Pay Party Panel for Some Ads

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Under pressure from the city's Campaign Finance Board, the Dinkins campaign has agreed to reimburse the State Democratic Committee for more than $226,000 worth of political advertisements that the Giuliani campaign had complained were intended to circumvent spending limits.
The agreement was applauded by advocates of public financing as a sign that the board, created in 1988, was forcefully executing its mission. In agreeing to pay for the ads, the Dinkins campaign averted possible sanctions or fines from the board. But the payments are a blow to the Dinkins campaign because they will reduce the amount of money the campaign has to spend in the crucial last days of a tight race, city officials and mayoral aides said. 
 The dispute over the ads began two weeks ago, when the Republican-Liberal candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani, complained to the board that the State Democratic Committee was flaunting the spending limits by buying radio and direct-mail advertments that attacked Mr. Giuliani and lauded Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Under the city's campaign finance law, mayoral candidates cannot spend more than $4 million on the primary and $4 million on the general-election campaign if they wish to receive matching public funds. But political committees are permitted to spend whatever they want as long as the candidate can prove the campaign did not coordinate the extra advertising.
Such advertising is protected by the First Amendment to the Constitution, even though state political committees do not have to abide by the city's contribution limits of $6,500 per contributor. By comparison, state law allows contributions as large as $62,500 from a single donor.
The Mayor's campaign did not concede that it had asked the state committee to pay for the ads, Harold Ickes, a lawyer for the Dinkins campaign, said. He maintained that the advertisements, which attacked Mr. Giuliani's stands on abortion and urged Mr. Dinkins's re-election, were independently produced and consequently did not violate the Campaign Finance Board's regulations. But he said the Dinkins campaign did not want questions about the ads to divert attention from other issues in the mayoral race.
"It is our position that the expenditures were in fact independent," Mr. Ickes said. "But given that this is the last two weeks of a hard-fought campaign, we made a decision we did not want to take the time and resources to litigate this."
But lawyers for the Giuliani campaign portrayed the compromise as a defeat for the Mayor. "What we had here was the Dinkins campaign realizing it was nailed, caving completely and being forced to pay back the money," Mr. Giuliani's lawyer, Randy Mastro, said.
Nicole A. Gordon, executive director of the Campaign Finance Board, said that even though the board never officially ruled on Mr. Giuliani's complaint, it has ruled in the past that spending by political committees is presumed to be tied to the party's candidate unless the candidate can prove otherwise.
 
Dinkins Campaigns in Harlem
 Mayor Dinkins campaigned yesterday at a meeting of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce among some of his oldest, most loyal allies. The talk was of the pain and rejection they would feel if Mr. Dinkins, a lifelong Democrat in an overwhelmingly Democratic town, lost to Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Dinkins's mentor, Percy E. Sutton, an entrepreneur who was once one of Harlem's most prominent politicians, said in introducing him that race "is forever present" in New York City politics and pointedly noted that blacks in general and Mr. Dinkins in particular have supported Irish, Italian and Jewish candidates for mayor and governor.
"If the Democratic Party and its leadership is unable to engender support for someone as mild and nice and honest as David Dinkins, then what is the future for us with the Democratic Party?" Mr. Sutton said in an interview after the meeting. He added: "We have other places to go. We can organize a new party or join other existing parties or stay home."
Mr. Sutton, a former borough president, and other members of the Harlem chamber said the loss of support from such high-profile Democrats as Robert F. Wagner Jr., scion of a New York Democratic family, and Herman Badillo, who is running for comptroller on Mr. Giuliani's ticket, as well as diminished support from Jews, were particularly bitter pills.
The president of the Harlem chamber, Lloyd A. Williams, said many blacks think the Mayor has "been disproportionately concerned and supportive" of Jewish causes and are resentful that Jews have harshly criticized the Mayor's handling of the violent clash of blacks and Hasidic Jews in 1991 in Crown Heights.
Mr. Dinkins has called the stabbing of a rabbinical student by a group of young blacks in Crown Heights "a lynching," but many officials have said the Mayor did not act quickly enough to stop the violence.
Several chamber members said a Dinkins defeat could seriously undermine the prospects for future interracial voting coalitions.
Mr. Dinkins did not directly address the themes Mr. Sutton raised, but he did set aside his prepared remarks to "share a few stories" about his struggles to become the city's first black mayor and to speak proudly of how he has helped other blacks rise to influential positions -- themes that Mr. Dinkins rarely discusses and that some black ministers and officials have said they wished he would address more bluntly.
He told the audience that it was Mr. Sutton and Paul O'Dwyer, a City Council president, who salvaged his career after he had to withdraw as the city's first black deputy mayor in 1974 because he had not filed income-tax returns. Mr. Sutton helped persuade Mr. O'Dwyer to have Mr. Dinkins appointed city clerk.
"That's why I'll always love Paul O'Dwyer and Percy Sutton," Mr. Dinkins said.
 
A Light Day for Giuliani
 Mr. Giuliani eased his hectic campaign schedule yesterday for his lightest day on the stump in weeks, spending most of the morning and afternoon in private meetings.
At lunchtime, however, he emerged for a walking tour of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, stressing his concern for the environment as he spoke with pedestrians and shop owners.
Walking down Grand Street, he hugged women, kissed babies and paused in a shop that makes hot onion bialis. Yet he avoided giving a standard campaign stump speech, and kept his comments brief at every stop.
Responding to reporters' questions, Mr. Giuliani did not shy from restating his position on debates with Mr. Dinkins, saying he would debate the Mayor "anytime, anywhere" as long as it was one on one.
"Enough of the chickens and the comedy acts," he said, referring to the use of a rubber chicken to draw attention to Mr. Giuliani's refusal to participate in a debate on Sunday because the program was shared with the Conservative Party candidate, George J. Marlin.
"Mr. Dinkins has run away from 12 debates in 1989, and so far this year has run away from 8 of them," Mr. Giuliani said.
Mr. Giuliani also said he wanted three debates -- one on the economy, one on crime and one on education -- and urged television reporters coverng him yesterday to arrange debates at their stations.
Mr. Giuliani would not say with whom he met yesterday. But he has a full schedule for today.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE FLOOD WITH: Elizabeth Hanford Dole;
Power Player, Playing Cautiously

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

DATELINE: DES MOINES

 BODY:
ELIZABETH HANFORD DOLE, a smile fixed on her face and her charm at the ready, picked her way around the tangle of lumber and oozing mud, searching for flood victims.
Although the flood waters have receded here, the need has not. But the Red Cross van bearing coffee and sandwiches was drawing few takers that day, so Mrs. Dole, trim in a Red Cross T-shirt, khakis and smudgeless pink sneakers, marched gamely door-to-door. 
 "Red Cross here," she called. "Are you all hungry?" A 97-year-old woman, Bethel C. Anker, appeared at the screen door, telling her how grateful she was for all the help. Mrs. Dole said, "That warms my heart."
Mrs. Anker launched into a spirited description of her trials during the flood, and could have clearly gone on for some time, but Mrs. Dole gently eased herself away after some sympathetic murmurs and tongue-clucking. "Here we are, three bags for you," she said. "You take care. 'Bye now."
This was Elizabeth Dole at her very public best: effusive yet efficient, a woman who threads her way around obstacles with the same care, meticulous preparation and determination that have won and sustained her in visible jobs. She has been president of the Red Cross since 1991. Before that she served as United States Secretary of Transportation (1983-87) and Secretary of Labor (1989-90).
Watching her, it's easy to see why she won raves on the stump in 1988 during the brief Presidential bid of her husband, Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who is now Senate minority leader. She has an ability to connect, to make people feel heard even as she moves on to shake the next hand. But watching Mrs. Dole is to sense that she is also a woman of great control and caution, one who never loosens the tight rein on her spontaneity, never says the wrong thing, never reveals too much.
At 57, she has won praise for her stewardship of the Red Cross: fund raising, cost cutting, instituting more stringent blood screening tests and responding to a string of natural disasters, including Hurricane Andrew and the Midwest floods.
Her life with her husband has striking parallels to another Washington power couple, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton, whom the Doles will face if the Senator choses to run for President in 1996, as is rumored. Like Mrs. Clinton, Mrs. Dole has a career and is respected for her intelligence and drive. She is also said to be a more appealing campaigner than her husband, often able to disarm his opponents.
Senator Dole acknowledges his wife's drawing power. "Everywhere I go -- and I've been in four states this weekend -- people talk about Elizabeth," he said recently.
On the public stage, both Mrs. Dole and Mrs. Clinton have played out their struggles to reconcile their careers with their husbands' political ambitions. Mrs. Dole left her job as Secretary of Transportation in 1987 to campaign for her husband; Mrs. Clinton emerged from the campaign caricatures, which depicted her as a strident co-President or a subdued cookie-baker, to become a groundbreaking First Lady.
Mrs. Clinton's ability to be a substantive rather than ornamental First Lady suggests that Mrs. Dole could have done the same thing. But when Mrs. Dole resigned her post in 1987, many women spoke out against her choice. And at the time, her public comments suggested a trace of resentment about leaving her job. But today, she defends her decision in almost exactly the words she used then.
"To me, that's what we've been fighting for, for women to have opportunities to do what works best for themselves and their families," she said, sitting in a Red Cross regional office. "We don't have to fit into a mold. It would have been almost unthinkable not to be a part of the high point to date in my husband's career."
Mrs. Dole will not be drawn out on the subject of Mrs. Clinton or on Senator Dole's plans, and quickly returns to safe generalities, often using the same sentences and anecdotes she has in earlier interviews.
Mrs. Dole on life's purpose: "When you're in your 90's and looking back, it's not going to be how much money you made or how many awards you've won. It's really what did you stand for. Did you make a positive difference for people?"
On the need to acknowledge all of women's choices, she emphasizes "the women who choose to stay at home as full-time working mothers, volunteers -- oh, put a lot of stress on volunteers -- the ones who decide that should be valued every bit as much as what you and I are doing."
These answers are hardly surprising, coming from someone who has been interviewed countless times and has spent most of her professional life under public scrutiny. Why should she place her trust in a reporter? Why take a chance on spontaneity and slip up?
"People who are exposed to the media constantly tend to have tapes in their head," said an old friend and supporter of Mrs. Dole, who asked to remain unidentified. "Her nature is to be prepared and in control of the message she is sending."
During this interview Mrs. Dole is quick to list her accomplishments at the Red Cross and in previous Cabinets. But she is most animated talking about how she and her husband have forged a partnership that combines freedom with intense loyalty. The couple were married in 1975 and have no children. The Senator has a daughter by a previous marriage.
"When we first met and married, he felt, definitely, go on with your career," she said, describing her husband as an instinctive supporter of women, who needed no training from her. "There was never any hesitation. Sure, at times it would have been nice if I could have been at things that were important to him. But we just went forward together."
Her husband calls her a "sensible feminist," meaning that "she doesn't threaten anybody."
Both avoid the power dinner parties in Washington -- partly, Senator Dole said, because they are just too busy. A typical week's schedule: a late night at the Senate for the Senator on Monday, an attempt to eat together on Tuesday, an out-of-town trip for Mrs. Dole on Wednesday and meetings in New York for the Senator on Thursday. When they are both at home, they watch movies or work out on a treadmill, saving part of Sunday, when he is not on a talk show, for church and friends. "It seems to work all right," Senator Dole said.
Sometimes their jobs put the couple at public loggerheads, but that does not appear to bother either of them a bit. This year, her husband opposed President Clinton's bill on national service. Mrs. Dole, as the president of an organization dedicated to volunteerism, backed it. They didn't consult each other about their stances in advance, she said, and didn't talk about them afterwards.
Years ago, such public differences between spouses were more novel. When Mrs. Dole was a member of the Federal Trade Commission, she read that her husband was opposing the creation of a consumer protection agency.
"I remember calling him up and saying, 'What are you doing?' " she said. "You didn't tell me about this." She was about to give a speech and asked him whether he would join her and debate the pros and cons. They were asked to repeat the performance on "Good Morning America," and she recounted the reaction:
"We got an awful lot of mail. Someone wrote Bob, 'If you want to get anywhere in politics, you better get her to shut up.' And one man wrote in and said, 'I do hope you'll be able to resolve your marital difficulties.' " With that, she broke into a loud laugh.
It is evidently the only kind of marriage she can envision, because she bucked the conventions of her Southern childhood and even the expectations of her mother, who wanted her to major in home economics, marry and stay in North Carolina. But she chose to study political science at Duke University and declined a marriage proposal from her college boyfriend.
After Harvard Law School, she embarked on a career in government, eventually serving on the Federal Trade Commission and as head of President Reagan's office of public liaison before joining the Cabinet. Originally a Democrat, she became an Independent and then, about the time of her marriage, a Republican.
"She's always been a woman of a lot of power and force," said Mari Maseng Will, the principal of Maseng Communications, a Washington public relations firm, who served under Mrs. Dole as an Assistant Secretary of Transportation. "And she has retained some of the grace and charm of the world she was brought up in. I've often thought of her as a role model -- how she carved out a role as a strong and effective woman, how she did not threaten people and could still be a leader."
This quality is apparent in her interchanges with the Red Cross staff in Des Moines. People light up when they see her. The camaraderie built in the worst days of the flood is evident as she hugs the workers. But she also presses her management agenda, asking nearly everyone she meets what they think of a new disaster-services plan and an ambitious effort to raise standards for all local Red Cross affiliates.
Mrs. Will says the Red Cross post is the most fulfilling her friend has ever had. Mrs. Dole herself demurs at suggestions that the presidency of the Red Cross, with its highly visible opportunities to help people in distress, is a perfect launching pad for a future First Lady or even for a run for public office.
"I don't have plans to run for office right now," she said. "I enjoy people, I'm an extrovert. If the option presents itself someday to run for office, it's a possibility. It's not something I must do or I will not feel fulfilled in life."
Yet, Mrs. Dole understands that being a player means not just having ideas, but having power.
"Some people really have almost a distaste for that word," she said. "They feel it is alien to conscience. Power for power's sake, no. But the positive use of power for positive purposes is very important. You have to understand that. You've got to have a seat at the policy table if you want to make a difference. "

HEADLINE: 42d Street To Get A Theater For Youth

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The Victory Theater, an empty 93-year-old Times Square house with an illustrious past but no future until now, will become the city's first major midtown theater offering year-round programming for young audiences.
After a $7.9 million renovation, the Victory will become the first of nine historic theaters on West 42d Street to be restored and reopened, the project's organizer, the New 42d Street Inc., announced yesterday. 
 If renovation, which is to begin in February and end one year later, is finished on schedule, the theater -- on the north side of 42d Street west of Seventh Avenue -- will be the first tangible evidence of years of planning to overhaul the nation's most famous theatrical street. In addition, project planners announced, two other 42d Street theaters are to be renovated and will become the New York Information Center, a commercial venture that will offer sightseeing advice, hotel and restaurant referrals and a multi-media show for tourists.
The announcement follows by several weeks a report that the Walt Disney Company is considering presenting productions in the New Amsterdam Theater, a graceful 10-story Art Nouveau building in disrepair that was once the home of the Ziegfeld Follies. Disney is still negotiating with the New York City Economic Development Corporation, but no agreement has been reached.
 
The Oldest Established . . .
 After its renovation, the Victory will be renamed the New Victory. It will be "the oldest functioning legitimate theater in New York," said Hugh Hardy, the renovation's principal architect, from the firm Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates.
Programming at the theater will be primarily for teen-agers, pre-teens, and children with their parents. An audience of 150,000 a year has been estimated by the planners.
"This is the greatest concentration of theaters on any block in the world," said Cora Cahan, president of New 42d Street, a not-for-profit group founded by the city and state of New York in 1990 to determine new uses for six theaters situated within the 42d Street Development Project. "The replacement of X-rated films with family fare within a single theater will communicate a message of hope up and down the block."
Among the programs planned by New 42d Street for the inaugural season at the New Victory are productions by the Night Kitchen, a national children's theater company founded by Maurice Sendak and Arthur Yorinks; a free summer program by Theaterworks/USA; presentations by the Crossroads Theater Company, a black company in New Brunswick, N.J.; classical and contemporary plays for young people and adults by Theater for a New Audience, a New York-based company run by Jeffrey Horowitz, and work by Urban Bush Women, an ensemble of black theater artists.
Also planned is a film series assembled by Francis Ford Coppola and Martin Scorsese; a puppetry series from the Jim Henson Foundation, and a series of third-world films under the direction of Warrington Hudlin and the Black Film Maker Foundation.
Ms. Cahan said that turning the Victory into a legitimate Broadway theater was rejected because "it would probably have left the theater dark more than it was lit, and our mission was to get people on the street all year round."
She added that her organization had decided on a theater devoted to family-oriented productions because "it will be the first centrally located large-scale family theater in New York devoted solely to offering low-cost presentations." She said that large, centrally located children's theaters in Minneapolis, Seattle and Honolulu had become financial and popular successes.
When asked whether parents would feel comfortable taking their children to the hard-core precincts of Times Square, Ms. Cahan replied: "We have to prove to families that it's safe, and we believe it is. The area is cleaner and safer than it's ever been, and it's going to get better."
Many in the Times Square neighborhood have tired of "studies and plans and studies of the plans" for future development on 42d Street, Ms. Cahan said, "and it was time to jump-start development on the street by operating a visible symbol of its revitalization. We hope the New Victory will be a catalyst for other activities."
 
Historic Guidelines
 The reconstruction of the Victory is governed by historic-design guidelines imposed by the city and the state. Mr. Hardy said the theater's original brownstone stoop would be reconstructed, the cornice replaced, and the interior plaster and woodwork restored.
The Victory was opened as the Republic Theater on Sept. 27, 1900, by Oscar Hammerstein (its greatest hit was "Abie's Irish Rose," one of Broadway's longest-running plays) and was named the Victory after World War II. In the early 1970's it became a pornographic movie theater, and by 1990 was empty except for occasional theatrical productions.
The planned annual operating budget of the New Victory will be $3 million, half of it supplied by earned income and half to be raised by donations. The chairman of the New 42d Street is Marian S. Heiskell, and its members include Linda LeRoy Janklow, Bill Irwin and Terrence McNally.
The renovation will be paid for by Times Square Center Associates, a private real-estate partnership comprising Park Tower Realty and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. In 1988, the Center Associates signed leases with the city and state to construct four office towers at the corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, plans that were shelved in 1992 because of the recession's effect on office construction in Manhattan.
 
Financing Nonprofit Ventures
 The agreements required that the Associates provide $18.2 million to New 42d Street, with most of the money earmarked for nonprofit venues. Renovations for the New York Information Center will be paid for by the commercial leaseholder.
Ms. Cahan said that the concept for the New York Information Center had come from the design firm of Edwin Schlossberg, which had proposed a gathering place for tourists in Times Square featuring current information on Broadway and Off Broadway theater offerings, museum exhibitions, gallery shows and sports events.
Appoximately half the space of the information center will stand within the Times Square Theater, built in 1920 by the impresarios Edgar and Arch Selwyn. The other half will occupy one of two adjacent theaters: either the Academy (formerly known as the Apollo), a theatrical house built in 1920 and now used for for pop-music concerts, or the Lyric, built in 1903, which was most recently a movie theater and is now unused.

HEADLINE: For Blacks, Chef Jobs Finally Call

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
FOR hundreds of years there have been black cooks in America. Now there are also black chefs.
In the last few years, more blacks have begun achieving prominence and recognition as professionals in fine restaurants, diversifying a field that was once almost exclusively white, male and, in the most prestigious restaurants, European. 
 In the past, few blacks sought admission to the top cooking schools, which funnel graduates into the best restaurants.
"There was a tendency to look down on being in the kitchen because that's where we were relegated for so many years," said Doreen Thompson, a food-loving lawyer in Washington who founded the African-American Chefs and Cookbook Authors Association last April. "Now, it's being seen as an economically viable profession, and it's percolating up."
Historically, young blacks have not been able to look around and see many inspiring role models. That is changing, too, as blacks, like members of other minority groups and women, gradually move into jobs that are more visible and more powerful. Ms. Thompson's group is one of a number of new nonprofit organizations that support blacks in the food field through education, financial aid and publicity.
Significantly, black head chefs in fine restaurants -- like Steve Simmons of One Market, in San Francisco; Patrick Clark of the Hay-Adams Hotel, in Washington; Walter Hinds of Lolabelle, in Manhattan, and Jacqueline Cholmondeley of Livanos, in White Plains -- have generally found restaurant kitchens to be colorblind.
"When you're in the kitchen trying to turn out the food, there is no time for attitudes," said Mr. Simmons, the chef at One Market, a new restaurant. "In this kitchen we're chefs and cooks first." A graduate of Bates College who has been in the food business for 12 years, Mr. Simmons started as a busboy in San Francisco and eventually attending the restaurant program at City College there.
At the same time, this generation of chefs is also turning out food that tends to be colorblind. Prominent black chefs are cooking the way their white counterparts are cooking: contemporary American, with French, Italian, Asian and Caribbean influences.
While a great number of black cooks are still preparing soul food and barbecue, maintaining a culinary tradition for which blacks have long been celebrated, that kind of food does not lead to executive chef positions in top hotels and restaurants. Nor does it lead to the kind of acclaim that is showered on chefs like Mr. Clark, the executive chef at the Hay-Adams, who is regularly invited to cook alongside Wolfgang Puck and Larry Forgione at benefit dinners.
In the words of Mr. Hinds, the executive chef at Lolabelle, "A black cook is not a chef." A chef, he said, runs a kitchen and is responsible for more than just cooking. As soon as he finds the necessary financial backing, he plans to open his own restaurant, preferably in TriBeCa.
Mr. Hinds, who was born in Panama -- where his father was a chef -- and grew up in Port Jefferson, L.I., attended Peter Kump's New York Cooking School. His first job was in the kitchen of Safari Grill, a now-defunct restaurant on Third Avenue owned by David Keh. "There were many ethnic groups in that kitchen, so from the beginning, I haven't had any problem with discrimination," he said.
He calls his food, which features dishes like pepper-seared tuna with stir-fried Asian greens, crisp rice noodles and a soy-tomato vinaigrette, contemporary American. Some of his food also reflects his heritage. He often serves a side dish of mashed plantain and puts dandelion greens in his roast garlic risotto. "But I've gone way beyond any stereotype," he said.
Lola Bell, the owner of the restaurant where he works, studied at the French Culinary Institute to avoid being stereotyped. "Just because you're black doesn't mean you have to serve curried goat or black-eyed peas and smothered pork chops," she said.
At One Market, Mr. Simmons's specialties include a fried onion salad with smoked salmon and chervil creme fraiche and a beef tenderloin with a red wine reduction and bone marrow sauce.
This new group of young black chefs is proving, often to skeptical parents and high school students alike, that becoming a chef or embarking on a career in the food service industry can lead to success and financial independence, not a return to the servitude of generations past.
Statistics compiled by the National Restaurant Association, a trade group in Washington, show that blacks, who represented 10 percent of the total work force in 1992, held a higher-than-average proportion of jobs in food preparation and service, 13 percent.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics says that in 1992, blacks held about 44,000, or 13.2 percent, of the 338,000 supervisory positions in food service and preparation. In 1983 they held about 25,000, or 10.6 percent, of 239,000 supervisory positions.
"Maybe we'll start to bring a sense of the prestige you can have in this field," said Mr. Simmons, who was one of a group of black chefs honored in August at a benefit dinner held by the Sonoma County chapter of 100 Black Men. This group, a national organization, is dedicated to promoting positive role models and raising money for scholarships.
"The jobs are not just in the kitchen," Mr. Simmons added. "There are also careers in the front of the house, in management, but kids don't know what the opportunities are."
Ms. Cholmondeley, the executive chef at Livanos, a seafood restaurant, said: "We have to convince people that this is a creditable profession. They think of McDonald's and they're not aware of the possibilities."
A native of Guyana, Ms. Cholmondeley originally wanted to be a textile designer but became interested in food and decided to attend the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. She helped organize a new chapter of black alumni of the school, which is often considered the Harvard of professional cooking schools. The group hopes, among other things, to establish three full-tuition scholarships.
Jane Wallace, a director of the school who heads the enrollment committee, said blacks make up 4 percent of the student body. Over all, the minority enrollment, including Hispanics, Asians and American Indians, is 12 percent.
Industry observers also point out that high school guidance counselors need more information about opportunities in the food-service field. "Many of them do not understand that home ec can lead to management positions," said Michael Hurst, a restaurateur in Fort Lauderdale and former president of the National Restaurant Association, who is advising guidance counselors in Florida. The first black president of the restaurant association, Herman Cain, takes office next year. He is also the chief executive of the Godfather's Pizza chain.
Ms. Bell, the owner of Lolabelle, who started working in restaurants to supplement her income as an actress, regularly talks to high school students.
"The restaurant business is wonderful because you can be a success without a college degree," she said. "Where else can you start with nothing and wind up owning a business?"
Ms. Bell has also started an apprenticeship program in her kitchen, a step not without its disheartening aspects. One apprentice, she said, wound up selling drugs in the kitchen. "That was the downside," she said. "But then when I saw the progress made by one young man who could not look you in the eye at first, I knew it's worthwhile."
Many successful black chefs came from close-knit families. Where the family structure is fragile or nonexistent, mentors become even more essential.
Susy Davidson, the executive director of the new International Association of Women Chefs and Restaurateurs, said, "You have to have role models and actively network so you can help each other." Her group also plans to reach out to minority men, because they face problems similar to those confronting women.
Black women have long been professional cooks, a vocational track that evolved from the days when they were domestic employees. A number of them have become extremely successful, like Sylvia Woods, the owner of Sylvia's, a soul-food restaurant in Harlem, and Leah Chase, whose mother opened Dooky Chase, a Creole restaurant in New Orleans, in 1941.
If today's chefs have broadened their culinary horizons, they have not abandoned tradition. Edna Lewis, for many years the chef at Cafe Nicholson, a restaurant serving Continental food in Manhattan, is now the executive chef at Gage & Tollner in Brooklyn and is serving some Southern specialities.
Joe C. Randall, who was an instructor at California State Polytechnic Institute and is now promoting black chefs through cable television programs called "Cookin' With Soul," also started a group called A Taste of Heritage Foundation to highlight black contributions to the American table and to raise money for scholarships.
Ms. Thompson, the founder of the new African-American chef and cookbook author association, is hoping that as blacks become increasingly powerful in the food field, the status of black cooking will also rise.
"We need greater recognition of the African-American contribution to the American table," Ms. Thompson said. "There are very few upscale restaurants serving African-American food, and we need to encourage them."

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
WITH the peak wine-buying season coming up in the next few months, the wine industry in the United States shifts into high gear in October, with everyone from winery presidents to retailers asking the same question: will wine sales this year surpass those of 1992, the best year for sales since 1985?
The consensus is that, with the recession receding, 1993 should be slightly better than 1992. 
 In 1992, the industry reversed a seven-year decline. Shipments were up about 7 percent over those of 1991, at 185 million cases, compared with 173 million, according to Impact, a trade publication in New York. (Each case has 2.38 gallons of wine.) Wine consumption showed a modest increase: 2.43 gallons for every adult 21 or older, up from 2.32 gallons in 1991. That was still far below the levels of 1980, when the average wine consumption was almost 3.2 gallons for every adult American.
Wine industry leaders and economists who follow the business are chary about predictions because the industry's performance in 1992 was something of an anomaly. Americans bought more wine from Europe than usual in a panic buying spree. They were trying to avoid tariffs that the United States threatened to impose because of a dispute with the European Community over French farm subsidies.
The issue was resolved, temporarily at least, last November but not before importers had indulged in several months of panic buying. Imports of table wine from the European Community in 1992 were up 21 percent over those of the previous year -- but much of that wine has yet to be sold.
Not all import increases were driven by the tariff threat. Imports from Chile were up 50 percent in 1992 over those of 1991. Australian imports were up 30 percent, but with just 930,000 cases sold, it was a modest figure compared with the nearly two million cases from Chile. Australian wine's performance in this country is something of a mystery given the high quality and reasonable prices of so many Australian wines.
The industry continues to benefit from the effects of the so-called French paradox -- the theory, given immense publicity in late 1991, that the French, who consume a relatively high-fat diet, have a relatively low rate of heart disease. Noting that the French drink more red wine than Americans, the theory held that the moderate consumption of alcoholic beverages, red wine in particular, may be what lessens the incidence of heart disease in France.
The impact of the French paradox on wine consumption has been remarkable. According to a report prepared for the Seagram Classics Wine Company by Infoscan, a service that tracks consumer preferences from supermarket sales, red varietal wine sales were up 42 percent last year in the United States, while white varietals were up 13 percent. White zinfandel, the most popular of the so-called blush wines, a separate varietal category, was also up 13 percent, the report said.
Varietals, which bear the name of the principal grape from which they are made, were once an insignificant portion of this country's total wine market. The market has been dominated by the inexpensive generic wines that are blends of various grapes, with generic names like Burgundy and Chablis.
In 1992, generic wines accounted for 51 percent of all table wines sold in the United States, with varietals making up the balance. That was a 16 percent jump for varietals over 1991, while generic wines continued their long slide by dropping 1 percent, the Infoscan report said. This year, industry observers predict, varietals will probably dominate the market for the first time. The surge of varietals can be attributed to several factors: a more sophisticated public, immense plantings of premium grapes in recent years and the blush-wine phenomenon.
A decade ago, wine consumers were still conditioned to ask for a glass of white wine. Gradually, that gave way to a glass of Chablis and more recently to a glass of chardonnay. In spite of the French paradox, Americans prefer white wines by a wide margin. In sales of varietals in the United States last year, red wines accounted for 21 percent of sales; whites, 43 percent, and the blush wines, 36 percent.
One of the blush wines, white zinfandel, is America's favorite varietal. It is made from the red zinfandel grape, but most of the color is removed, resulting in a wine that is pale pink or salmon, usually sweet and often slightly fizzy. It is immensely popular, often with newcomers to wine who are put off by the dryness and astringency of traditional wines. Some 16 million cases of white zinfandel were shipped last year, according to Impact, an increase of almost 10 percent over 1991.
The most popular varietals after white zinfandel are chardonnay and cabernet sauvignon. Chardonnay shipments were up 26 percent last year, to 13.1 million cases, while cabernet sauvignon was up 33 percent, to 8 million cases. According to Infoscan, chardonnay accounted for 40 percent of all white varietal sales in the United States in 1992.
The surprise wine of the year turned out to be none of the above; it was merlot. While it accounted for only 11 percent of the red varietal category, its sales were up 92 percent over those of the previous year. Merlot is the second-most important grape of Bordeaux, after cabernet sauvignon, and is actually the principal grape in legendary wines like Chateau Petrus. It has been grown in California for many years but has come to prominence there only in the last decade, both in Bordeaux-style blends and on its own.
 
TASTINGS
Hargrave Vineyard chardonnay 1990 Lattice label, Long Island; about $14.
 
 It shouldn't, but it still comes as a surprise each time someone notes that Hargrave Vineyard has been making wine on the North Fork of Long Island for two decades. The North Fork has come of age. Should there be any lingering doubts about this achievement, here is a wine to put them to rest: a truly first-rate chardonnay from some of the oldest vines on the Island. This is a multidimensional wine, but it doesn't give up its charms easily. There are none of the by-now-familiar attractions of so many highly praised California chardonnays, like too much oak or alcohol and in many cases an initially pleasant roundness that often belies a lack of character. This chardonnay hints at minerals rather than apples and pears; Chablis rather than Montrachet. The wine spent spent time in small French oak barrels, but the effect is not intrusive. At Hargrave, there is talk of the wood "focusing" the wine's aromas. Well said. The wine should age elegantly.
