HEADLINE: Greenspan Supports Fed's Secrecy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, testifying alongside 15 senior Federal Reserve officials, said today that the economy would be hurt if Congress forced the central bank to operate with less secrecy.
Mr. Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said proposals to require detailed disclosure of its discussions would discourage the central bankers from speaking freely. 
 "Monetary policy would suffer, and the economy with it," Mr. Greenspan told the House Banking Committee.
His views were echoed, as if by a Greek chorus, by 5 other members of the Federal Reserve Board and 10 of the 12 presidents of the Fed's regional banks. More openness could upset a system that works well and could injure the economy, they said.
Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, called today's unusual mass hearing to ask for the bankers' views on his legislative proposals to require the Fed to disclose its decisions within a week of the meetings of its main policy-making committee. He has also called for videotaping those meetings and releasing the tapes, with detailed transcripts, within 60 days.
The Federal Reserve currently releases a summary of these meetings six weeks after they take place.
Mr. Gonzalez asserted that financial markets were injured by delays in announcing Fed decisions as well as by leaks of its decisions.
"Accurate information does not undermine markets," he said. "Partial information and leaked information undermines market efficiency."
Mr. Greenspan and several other Fed officials said that if meetings were videotaped Fed officials would not debate freely, but would instead rely mostly on prepared statements. Videotaping or requiring detailed disclosure, he said, "would so seriously constrain the process of formulating policy as to render those meetings nearly unproductive."
"The candid airing of views, the forthright give and take and the tentative posing of new ideas likely would disappear," he said.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, also opposed videotaping, saying "participants would hesitate to use hypothetical or speculative examples to explain points because these examples could be misinterpreted and cause unnecessary volatility in the financial markets."
He said policy discussions would tend to take place outside committee meetings, with Fed officials coming to meetings with preconceived views far more than was now the case.
Several central bankers said the rapid disclosure of the Fed's policy decisions -- which often call for raising or lowering interest rates conditioned upon an event that might not happen -- could make rates jump or drop when the central bank did not want any immediate change.
Several Fed officials seemed willing today to accept one change: to allow the release of highly detailed minutes five or so years after policymaking meetings. But these officials said sensitive material, like dealings with foreign central banks, should be omitted from the minutes.
The Fed released such minutes before 1976 but now releases much shorter summaries of its meetings.
Mr. Gonzalez said those summaries were not nearly detailed enough and often did not say which official argued which point in discussions.
James A. Leach of Iowa, ranking Republican of the House Banking Committee, asked the presidents of the regional banks which of three proposals they favored to assert more democratic control over the Fed: that they be appointed by the President, rather than by boards of local bankers; that they be stripped of their votes on the Fed's policymaking committee, or that the Federal Reserve Board appoint them.
Although most of the regional bank presidents opposed any change, the one they found most palatable would be having the Federal Reserve Board appoint them because that would leave the Fed less subject to political pressures than other proposals.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Greenspan, fourth from left, Federal Reserve chairman, testifying with other officials of the Fed before the House Banking Committee. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Pfizer, American Cyanamid and Upjohn said that 7,000 jobs would be cut over the next three years, adding to tens of thousands of pharmaceutical-industry jobs eliminated in recent months amid growing pressure to restrain health care costs. Many of the lost jobs will be in New York and New Jersey. [D1.] 
 Citicorp's third-quarter net income more than tripled, to $528 million, helped by reduced credit costs in both commercial and consumer lending and by strong trading revenue. The nation's largest banking company is on track for a record year. [D1.]
General Motors and the air pollution officials of 12 Northeastern states are competing to determine what emission standards will apply to cars sold in the region in the late 1990's. [D1.]
Bell Atlantic earnings slipped 2 percent to $378.5 million, but analysts were encouraged that the company is taking steps toward debt reduction that should help it complete its planned acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc. [D3.]
Chemical Bank said Walter V. Shipley, its president, would become chairman and chief executive on Jan. 1, when John F. McGillicuddy retires. It reported that net income rose 78 percent, to $502 million. [D4.]
Philip Morris earnings fell 24.8 percent, to $971 million, but Marlboro cigarettes' market share edged up 1.4 percent. [D4.]
Gencorp named John B. Yasinsky to succeed Jack L. Heckel, who is retiring early as president and chief operating officer. [D3.]
The Los Angeles Times is offering still another employee buyout, its third, seeking to eliminate at least 100 more jobs. [D18.]
 
The Economy
If Congress curbed Federal Reserve secrecy, the economy would be hurt, Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, said, testifying alongside 15 senior officials. [D1.]
At least 30 percent of cable television subscribers are paying higher rates since new Federal cable regulations took effect last month, an F.C.C. survey of 250 cable systems indicates. [D1.]
New housing construction reached a 3 1/2-year high in September, helped by low mortgage rates. Starts on single-family homes and apartments rose 2.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.35 milllion. [D2.]
State and local governments would pay whatever it cost for their share of employee health insurance under Clinton proposals, officials disclosed. By contrast, private employers would not have to contribute more than 7.9 percent of payroll totals. [A18.]
Business Technology
Union Camp stands out as a paper maker that delights environmentalists, by voluntarily taking steps to use more recycled fiber and use less chlorine. [D1.]
 
Markets
E. Gerald Corrigan, former head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, will join Goldman, Sachs & Company in January, concentrating on lining up new business, mostly overseas. [D2.]
A decline in Nasdaq issues spread to blue chips, sending the Dow industrials down 6.99 points to 3,635.32. [D6.]
The World Bank began selling its first mark-denominated global bond issue.[D14.]
Copper futures tumbled to 73.15 cents a pound, the lowest level in six years amid rising stockpiles. [D16.]
The dollar was little changed as traders awaited news on whether Germany would drop interest rates. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Ex-Chief of State Fed Joins Goldman

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday a prize catch: E. Gerald Corrigan, former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Starting in January, he will become a high-profile Goldman executive and concentrate on lining up new business -- mostly overseas -- for the firm. As the Fed's point man abroad, Mr. Corrigan dealt frequently with foreign central bankers and ministers, developing relationships that will undoubtedly be useful to Goldman. 
 The announcement, at a news conference, lacked the fanfare that accompanied the arrival on Wall Street in 1988 of another Fed leader, Paul A. Volcker. After serving as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Mr. Volcker joined Wolfensohn & Company as chairman and partner. Mr. Corrigan has hired on at Goldman as a salaried executive, not a partner.
"It is a role that does not involve him in line management," Stephen Friedman, Goldman's chairman, said in an interview. "There is flexibility designed into his role, to fit his druthers and ours."
Mr. Corrigan, who earned $250,000 a year as president of the New York Fed, will earn more in the new job, although neither he nor Mr. Friedman would say how much more.
Mr. Corrigan took pains yesterday to explain how flexible his new job would be. Until next July, the first anniversary of his departure from the Fed, he will stay away from securities trading and dealing with banks, although the law does not require this effort to avoid conflict of interest.
"The orientation of my work will be project driven," Mr. Corrigan said, adding that he would tailor his duties for a while "to make sure the umbilical cord with the Fed is unequivocally severed."
Even after next July, Mr. Corrigan said, he would stay away from trading and banking, acting mostly as a project adviser to help line up merger business, financing for corporations and governments or funds for a big construction project like an airport. "It is like being in a candy store and being 5 years old," Mr. Corrigan said, explaining that by nature he prefers to be where the action is.
The Goldman job is Mr. Corrigan's first in the private sector; he joined the Federal Reserve in 1968 while still getting his Ph.D. in economics at Fordham University. In his new career, his title will be chairman of the firm's International Advisers, a group of people in different countries who meet periodically to counsel the investment bank on strategy.
Mr. Corrigan, 52, said he would also continue, at least until year's end, as chairman of the Russian-American Enterprise Fund, formed last summer by the Clinton Administration, with $340 million in Federal money to invest in small and new Russian enterprises. Because of the potential conflict of interest, Mr. Corrigan said, he will recuse himself from doing business in Russia for Goldman.
 
Role in Helping Russia
 More than anyone else in the Federal Reserve system, Mr. Corrigan has played a role in helping Russia make the transition to free enterprise. He is still engaged in a project to reorganize Russian banking practices, and on trips to Moscow, he has met frequently with Boris N. Yeltsin, developing what American officials have described as a close relationship with the Russian President.
As president of the New York Fed for nearly nine years, Mr. Corrigan had regulatory responsibility for banks in the New York region, and he announced months ago that he would not take a job at a bank. He also played a role in the 1991 downfall and reorganization of Salomon Brothers, after that firm submitted false bids in Treasury auctions supervised by the New York Fed.
Salomon Brothers did not bid for Mr. Corrigan's services, Wall Street officials said. The negotiations with Goldman started in early August, two weeks after he left the Federal Reserve bank presidency.
"He had, as you would expect, several very nice opportunities on Wall Street and thereabouts," said Mr. Volcker, who was Mr. Corrigan's mentor at the Fed. "From all the sounds of his new job, they made it nice and flexible for him."

HEADLINE: Plan Seeks Improvement Package for Financial District

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
A two-year study of lower Manhattan concludes that a broad package of renovation, construction and marketing is needed to improve the area that includes the Financial District, Battery Park City and the South Street Seaport.
The 96-page plan for the area, released yesterday by the city Planning Department, proposes bolstering the business community and the tourist industry through a combination of tax breaks, city financing, zoning changes and a special business tax to finance promotion of the area. 
 Specific proposals include continuing the esplanade from the southwest tip of Battery Park City to the Brooklyn Bridge, building a tourist center off Battery Park and linking historical sites through a clearly marked path reminiscent of the Freedom Trail in Boston.
The plan, which is the first for lower Manhattan since the 1960's, combines projects already under construction with others in the planning stages and still others, like the long-discussed Second Avenue subway, that may be little more than wishful thinking. The commission has no authority to finance or carry out the plan, but says it has the support of city officials. And Robert R. Douglass, vice chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank and chairman of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association, says that the area's business executives are likely to adopt many of the proposals.
Richard L. Schaffer, head of the planning department, said that the proposal "puts the local government and the business community on the same track." William Rudin, a local developer whose family owns four downtown office buildings, called it "a blueprint for reestablishing lower Manhattan as a viable financial, cultural and residential community."
The area bounded by Chambers Street and Brooklyn Bridge to the north, and by waterfront on the other three sides, has lost 100,000 jobs since 1988, when employment peaked at 475,000 people. More than 22 percent of its available office space is empty, and many of its buildings are technologically obsolete.
As telecommunications have made it feasible for companies to relocate their back-office operations, jobs have moved to New Jersey and elsewhere. Lehman Brothers announced last week that it was moving 900 jobs to Jersey City, to the same building that captured 2,500 back-office jobs from Merrill Lynch last year.
The plan recommends tax incentives for companies that turn empty lots into clean open spaces. It proposes simplified zoning to encourage new uses for old buildings. It pinpoints streets that should be converted to pedestrian malls, piers that need renovation and routes that could use new bus service. And it proposes a marketing effort to attract more international business.
Beyond business incentives, the plan proposes renovating Battery Park and marketing the area to tourists, probably through a proposed business improvement taxing district. Most of downtown's attractions, including the trade center, the stock exchange, the Woolworth building, the seaport and Trinity Church, can be seen in a day or two, but the street grid is so irregular that many tourists do not realize they can walk from one to the other.
The lower Manhattan plan is vastly different from the last one for the area, issued in 1966. Back then, more than a third of the businesses downtown were in manufacturing. The city envisioned a bustling 24-hour community with 40,000 residents. Today there are 14,000 residents in the area, half of them in Battery Park City.
The projects that are already in the works include replacing the Whitehall Ferry Terminal, which was destroyed by fire, at a cost of $112 million. And many prominent office buildings, including the World Trade Center, are being upgraded.
About 150 architects, engineers and other private sector figures are to attend a half-day seminar on Empty Building Syndrome, to "develop concepts and ideas on how to use old, empty buildings that can't support today's technologically advanced businesses," said Louis J. Coletti, a senior vice president of Lehrer, McGovern, Bovis, a construction management firm that is one of the event's sponsors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Paper Maker Turns a Cleaner Page

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKLIN, Va.

 BODY:
At a time when many in the paper industry are resisting environmentalists' calls for more recycled fiber and less use of chlorine in paper making, the Union Camp Corporation stands out as a company that has voluntarily taken these steps.
At the sprawling paper plant here on the bank of the sleepy Blackwater River, a few miles from the North Carolina border, a confluence of history, geography and economics has led to the "greening" of Union Camp. 
 To ease the burden on the shallow river, the company last year started a bleaching line that uses ozone, a form of oxygen, instead of chlorine, a toxic water pollutant. And the company is now installing equipment that will remove ink from paper that is retrieved from trash bins, so the recycled fibers can go into new paper.
That means fewer trees will have to be cut -- no small consideration at a factory that is one of the world's largest producers of fine-finish writing and printing paper, rolling out 2,000 tons of the products each day.
Such actions by a big paper company delight environmentalists, who say the moves refute industry arguments that eliminating chlorine and adding a substantial amount of recycled paper are either technically impossible or not economic.
"It is important to recognize that this is one of the largest and most profitable fine-paper mills in the world," said Lauren Blum, a staff scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund. "It shows that this environmental stuff makes economic sense."
Indeed, Charles H. Greiner Jr., a Union Camp vice president and manager of its fine-paper division, described the investment of $108 million in the recycling equipment as "a market-driven decision."
"Customers want recycled products," he said. "There is a growing awareness that waste is a form of pollution, and that will keep demand for recycled paper high."
The paper industry and environmental groups are often at odds, if only because of the nature of the paper-making process. It involves chopping down trees and boiling and bleaching them in strong chemicals until the brown wood has been converted into white paper, consuming and discharging large volumes of tainted water in the process.
Environmentalists prefer to see trees standing in forests, and they put a high value on clean water and air.
Indeed, the two groups have been squabbling since last April over a pending Presidential order intended to promote recycling by directing Federal agencies to purchase paper with at least some recycled content.
The industry, represented by the American Forest and Paper Association, has argued that it cannot incorporate more than 10 percent recycled paper without disrupting paper mill operations. A coalition of environmental advocacy groups have said anything less than 20 percent would be ineffective in developing markets for recycled products.
President Clinton was expected to sign an order mandating the 20 percent standard for paper purchases by the Government. But no action has yet been taken, and the lobbying from both sides continues.
Union Camp plans to have its Franklin plant produce paper with 30 percent recycled content when the de-inking line goes into operation in February 1995. The company could increase that to 50 percent if market demand warranted it.
With $3.06 billion in sales last year, Union Camp, based in Wayne, N.J., ranks 11th among American paper companies, far behind the industry leader, International Paper.
Mr. Greiner said Union Camp was consciously trying to stay ahead of the bulk of the paper industry in recycling to gain additional sales. It also wants to take advantage of the mill's relative proximity to the urban "forests" of Washington, Philadelphia and New York, where used office paper is available in abundance.
"We are situated in a place with an advantage," he said. "That helped make this project feasible."
Environmentalists have also argued that the Government should buy chlorine-free paper because use of chlorine and chlorine compounds as bleaching agents results in discharges of dioxin, chloroform and other toxic materials. The industry has countered -- apparently successfully, in the case of the pending Clinton order -- that chlorine is an integral part of the process and that modern technology has reduced toxic discharges.
But at the Franklin plant, only the oldest of the three bleaching lines still uses chlorine. The second oldest uses an oxygen bleaching process, and the newest works with ozone. Union Camp's other fine-paper plant, a newer factory in Eastover, S.C., only uses oxygen bleaching.
Six paper machines, each a city block long, run almost continuously at the Franklin plant, making paper from a mixture of Southern pine and hardwoods.
As part of its recycling program, Union Camp is increasing the capacity of some of its paper-making machines. That means the additional recycled fiber can be used to raise the plant's overall output and will not require the company to curtail its existing pulping operations.
One reason the paper industry has resisted higher recycled-content standards is the fear of upsetting the finely tuned balance between pulping and paper-making operations at many mills. It is a use-it-all process in which a tree trunk goes in one end and a finished roll of paper emerges at the other.
While Union Camp's recycling effort has been motivated by hopes for increased sales, development of the ozone bleaching process was part of a longtime effort to solve a local environmental and logistical problem: the level of the Blackwater River is too low most of the year to absorb the 33 million gallons of water a day used in making paper.
"If you were to site a mill like this today, you would not put it here," said Norman C. Shroyer, technical director of the fine-paper division. "There is very little flow in the summer, so we have to store our effluent for eight months and release it in four months."
The mill's location is a historical accident, starting with a pre-Civil War sawmill that used the river as a convenient means of transporting logs. The company still has extensive lumber operations here, with scraps from the sawmill serving as a source of raw material for the paper plant.
With the chlorine-bleaching process, the used water must be discharged because it is too corrosive to metals to be re-used in other parts of the paper-making process. This meant that billions of gallons of water had to be stored in a pond covering 1,500 acres until the river was high enough to absorb the outflow. And even during the river's highest seasons, the dark colored water from the bleaching process was running afoul of regulations on water clarity.
Lately, environmentalists and pollution control officials in many states have been paying attention to another problem with chlorine bleaching: the formation of chlorinated organic compounds, many of them toxic. The Union Camp plant has not completely rid its paper-making operation of chlorine, but the use of chlorine has been significantly reduced.
Union Camp officials said they had been actively looking for substitutes for chlorine since 1980. The bleaching ability of ozone, an acrid gas formed by lightning and other electrical discharges, has long been known. But it was considered impractical for making paper because it weakened the wood fibers as it brightened them.
But company researchers developed a more refined process they say can bleach moist wood pulp without harming the fibers by carefully limiting the exposure to ozone. Last year, Union Camp replaced two of its old chlorine bleaching lines with a single one using ozone, which is capable of processing 1,000 tons of Southern pine a day and has been running ever since.
One advantage of ozone bleaching is that the residues from the process are not corrosive, so the water can be recycled and chemicals that are pulled out of the pulp can be recovered. That, and the virtual certainty of Federal rules eventually limiting the discharge of chlorotoxins drove the company to develop the process, officials say. It is not totally chlorine free, since chlorine dioxide is used to brighten the pulp, but the majority of the substance has been removed.
Mr. Greiner said the addition of the ozone process might give the company a competitive advantage when regulation tightens because the system was added as the old lines were becoming obsolete anyway.
"We may not eliminate chlorine completely," he said, "but we are headed in that direction."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Union Camp Corporation plans to have its Franklin, Va., plant producing paper with 30 percent recycled content by 1995. Rhenda Tindall checks pulp that has been bleached with ozone, rather than chlorine. (Len Rothman for The New York Times)
 
Diagram: "How Paper Is Made"
Paper mills like Union Camp's begin with logs whose bark is removed in a rotating drum. The stripped logs are ground into chips before loading in a digester -- a pressure cooker that uses heat and chemicals to separate out the cellulose fibers from which paper is made. After washing, bleaching and refiners the fibers are combined with water and piped into the "head box" of the paper-making machine. From here, the slurry flows onto a moving screen that allows the water to drain off and the fibers to mesh. A series of rollers use pressure and heat to drive off the remaining water and the The finished paper is wound onto a big reel, ready for cutting into smaller rolls for shipment.
 
"Whitening Agents"
Bleaching is the process that transforms brown wood fiber into the bright white fiber required for most printing and writing papers. Traditionally, chlorine, a potentially toxic water pollutant, been used to bleach paper pulp. But Union Camp has developed a bleaching process that uses ozone, a form of oxygen.

HEADLINE: Small Stocks Battered, and Dow Falls 6.99

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Investors abandoned stocks in small companies yesterday, slicing away at the gains that had pushed the Nasdaq market to record highs last week.
The declines on the Nasdaq hit technology issues particularly hard and also seemed to spread pessimism to stocks in other areas, including the blue chips. 
 Few investors, however, seemed concerned that yesterday was the sixth anniversary of the 1987 stock market crash.
Lower third-quarter earnings results of companies like Philip Morris apparently had more influence on stock trading yesterday than did the Government's report that construction of new homes had reached a three and a half year high in September, traders said. That report might point to a strengthening of the recovery, but it did not touch off a strong rally in stocks sensitive to the economy.
 
Worst Drop Since April
 Dragged down by technology stocks like Microsoft, which fell 2 3/4 to 80 1/4, the Nasdaq composite index declined 14.20 points, to 768.71. The 1.8 percent drop was the worst one-day dip since the index declined 1.9 percent last April 26.
The American Stock Exchange's composite index also fell sharply, giving up 5 points, to 476.10.
After a late-morning rally, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.99 points, to close at 3,635.32.
Transportation stocks were one of the market's few brights spots. The Dow Jones transportation average rose 8.98, to 1,664.89, apparently because investors were anticipating strong third-quarter profits from railroad and airline companies.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, a broader indicator of trading on the Big Board, dropped 2.24, to 466.21. Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2. Volume was active at 304.4 million shares, but down from 329.6 million on Monday.
Some traders traced the decline in small stocks, which began on Monday, to investors who were cashing in on the record highs of last week. The drop does not indicate that the Nasdaq market is entering a prolonged period of retreat, these traders maintained.
"You did have four or five consecutive highs last week, so you certainly have profit taking thrown in there," said William Rothe, head of Nasdaq trading at Alex. Brown & Sons in Baltimore.
 
'A Premium on Growth'
 "If you are looking at a truly low-growth, low-interest-rate environment, then the market is going to put a premium on growth," he said, explaining his optimism about Nasdaq issues. "In most circumstances, small-capitalization stocks are in a better situation to turn in growth than large, unwieldy companies."
Over all, analysts noted that the stocks that were battered most yesterday -- including those of banks and technology and communications companies -- were among those that have performed well recently.
Citicorp was the most active on the Big Board, rising 1/8, to 35 3/4, after it reported that its profits had more than tripled in the third quarter, coming in higher than analysts had predicted. Among other bank stocks, Chemical declined 1 1/8, to 40 7/8, after reporting a 78 percent jump in its earnings. And Chase Manhattan, which posted a 52 percent earnings gain on Monday, lost 3/8, to 33 3/4.
Philip Morris dropped 1 1/8, to 52 3/4 after it said its profits dropped 24.8 percent in the third quarter.
Shares of Polaroid fell 1 1/2, to 32 5/8, after the company reported a 10 percent drop in third-quarter earnings and said it would not meet its sales projections for its new medical imaging system.
Spectrum Information Technologies was the most active on the Nasdaq market for the second straight day. It lost some of its gains of Monday, falling 1 5/8, to 9 1/2. The company on Monday named John Sculley, the former chairman of Apple Computer, as Spectrum's chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: Florio-Whitman Debate Zeroes In on Ethics

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHIPPANY, N.J., Oct. 19

 BODY:
Meeting in their second debate of the campaign tonight, Gov. Jim Florio and his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, traded sharp accusations over ethics and took swipes at each other's records and proposals.
Trailing by double digits in a series of independent polls -- including a 15-point spread in the most recent New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll -- Mrs. Whitman was under greater pressure to perform well in both debates before a statewide audience. 
 Asked to comment on the negative campaigning that both camps have adopted -- including a Whitman ad that proclaims Mr. Florio "maybe the worst Governor New Jersey ever had" and a Florio ad that suggests his rival is "out to lunch" -- and whether things would get dirtier in the final two weeks, Mrs. Whitman responded:
"I do owe the Governor an apology. He's probably not the worst Governor. I give that honor to Benjamin Franklin's son, who was taken out of the state in handcuffs for supporting King George's tax increases."
Mrs. Whitman, aided by the Republicans who control the Legislature, has spent the last two weeks peppering Mr. Florio on ethical issues -- including the state's bond business and purported violations of campaign spending law -- and the G.O.P. candidate took up that club from the outset of tonight's debate.
 
Sharp Give-and-Take
 "I'm glad to hear the Governor talk about credibility, because he has none," Mrs. Whitman said in her response to the first question from a panel of journalists.
Mr. Florio gave no ground. "If we are going to talk about ethics, who it is on the right side of the law, I have not been accused and fined for failing to pay my income taxes, Mrs. Whitman has," he said in response to a question about Joseph C. Salema, his former chief of staff who resigned in May amid media reports of a Federal grand jury investigation of state bond business. "I have not hired illegal aliens, I have not been charged and found guilty of breaking the campaign law.
"I'm more than happy to match ethical levels with anyone in the room," he said.
That brought an angry retort from Mrs. Whitman.
"Just once I wish the Governor would get his facts straight, but given the fact that this administration has so many things hanging over it, I guess it is not surprising to make up things about us," she said. "We have never, ever been fined for non-payment of our income tax, Governor. Get that straight. I also understand that we are talking about an administration that has two grand juries investigating it.
"It's staggering how much has been going on and he stands here and has the gall to say to me that I have lower ethical standards. That's outrageous."
Tonight's debate was the second debate for Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman. The debates are required because both accepted state funds for their campaigns. The candidates have agreed to a third debate at 11 A.M. Sunday on WNBC-TV (Channel 4) in New York City.
The candidates were questioned by a panel of journalists -- Ren Scott of Channel 2, Ken Matz of Channel 10 and Michael Aron of the New Jersey Network, the state-sponsored public television system. A network anchor, Kent Manahan, was the moderator.
 
Allowed One Question
 But each candidate also was allowed to ask one question of his or her opponent, and both tried to throw the opponent off stride.
Going after what is perceived to be Mrs. Whitman's weakest political point, policy matters, the Governor asked her to explain how her proposed plan for a 30 percent income tax cut would "interact with that specific provision of the New Jersey Constitution that talks about income tax revenue distribution."
Mrs. Whitman appeared dumbfounded by the question, but recovered quickly and went into one of her rehearsed attacks on Mr. Florio.
"Income tax revenue distribution is going obviously to be affected by the amount of the decrease in over- spending," she said. "What it is going to do is to enable us and require us to have a discipline that we have not seen to date. We have not seen a discipline of controlling the rate of growth of government spending."
 
Jobs Questions
 Mrs. Whitman questioned the Governor over the state's unemployment and her contention that the state under his administration had become anti-business, citing a Wall Street Journal report to support her claim.
"In the light of these statistics, what can you possibly tell the people of New Jersey that you will do differently to reverse these trends and stop the hurting?" she asked.
Mrs. Whitman's campaign had attacked Mr. Florio over those very issues in a news release on Monday and the Governor seemed well prepared for the question tonight.
"I was troubled by that report in the Wall Street Journal and I went to check on it," Mr. Florio said. "It turns out that the article was based upon an article that was written in 1986 in the middle of the Kean administration that you were a member of."
Tonight's hourlong debate was sponsored by the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and televised live over WCBS-TV (Channel 2) in New York City, WCAU-TV (Channel 10) in Philadelphia and the New Jersey Network. An audience of nearly 900 chamber members and their guests was gathered at Birchwood Manor, the banquet hall that served as the site of the debate.
The candidates left immediately after the debate and left it to their campaign strategists -- James Carville for Mr. Florio and Edward Rollins for Mrs. Whitman -- to continue the face-off.
Mr. Carville honed in immediately on the constitutional question Mr. Florio put to Mrs. Whitman.
"That's kind of important," he said. "She doesn't know what the state Constitution says. That's sad."
Mr. Rollins stood not five feet away in the middle of another cluster of reporters, where he was playing down poll results and talking up his candidate.
"She did well," he said. "She made her points. She talked about what's critical to the voters of this state."
The Florio campaign was prepared before both debates to minimize any boost the Republican candidate might glean.
On the day after the first debate, President Clinton came to the state with Mr. Florio at his side in a headline-grabbing visit that the Governor and the White House billed as official and the Whitman campaign angrily criticized as blatantly political.
Only hours before the start of tonight's debate, the Florio campaign announced that the First Lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, would visit New Jersey tomorrow to campaign for the Governor and other Democratic Party candidates in events in Cherry Hill and in Teanack.
About the same time that Mrs. Clinton is stumping for Democratic votes, an administrative law judge in Newark is to hear arguments over a challenge by Mrs. Whitman's campaign that her Democratic rival should be forced to use campaign funds to pay for President Clinton's Oct. 8 visit to New Jersey as well as visits by Attorney General Janet Reno, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt and Health and Human Services Secretary Donna Shalala.
Mrs. Whitman plans to begin the last two weeks of her campaign on Wednesday with the start of a three-day bus tour that will take her through 14 of the state's 21 counties.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
7,000 Drug Jobs to Be Eliminated

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Amid growing pressure to restrain health care costs, three large drug makers announced plans yesterday to cut 7,000 employees over the next three years, adding to tens of thousands of pharmaceutical-industry jobs eliminated in recent months.
Many of those jobs will be lost in New York and New Jersey, where large multinational drug companies maintain headquarters, research laboratories or factories. But the three companies, Pfizer, American Cyanamid and Upjohn, declined to say how the cuts would be distributed across their worldwide operations until they tell the workers affected. 
 Pfizer said yesterday that it was eliminating 3,000 jobs to prepare for changes, which, it said, had transformed drug making into "a very fragile industry." The company said it had already eliminated 1,000 jobs in previously unannounced reductions after it sold or spun off 14 businesses.
Pfizer is one of the largest manufacturers still based in New York City, which has lost at least 270,000 manufacturing jobs since 1987. The company has 3,400 employees in the city and nearly 13,000 in the three-state region, and yesterday it said it would not leave New York.
 
Spreading the Pain
 "There will just be fewer of us here," said Henry A. McKinnell, a Pfizer executive vice president.
He added that the new cuts would be spread over 40,000 workers in 70 nations and would include early retirements and dismissals. Those leaving will get extra pay and benefits.
American Cyanamid, based in Wayne, N.J., said it would cut 2,500 jobs -- about 9 percent of its workers -- over three years. Most of those will be in medical divisions, which include Lederle Laboratories units in Wayne and in Pearl River, N.Y.
Upjohn, based in Kalamazoo, Mich., said it would eliminate 1,500 jobs through early retirements by December 1994 and close or reduce the size of 14 of 31 factories. Upjohn has cut its work force 17 percent, to 17,500, since early 1989 in preparation for the expiration yesterday of patents on two drugs -- Xanax, used essentially to treat anxiety, and Halcion, essentially for insomnia.
Trading in the three companies on the New York Stock Exchange was somewhat greater than usual yesterday. Upjohn gained 37.5 cents to close at $32 a share. Pfizer lost 75 cents a share, closing at $63. American Cyanamid closed at $57.50, down 37.5 cents.
Job reductions have spread through the industry, as buyers of managed health care use their growing strength to enforce price limits, cutting sharply into drug profits.
Last week, Bristol-Myers Squibb, which also has its home office in New York City, said it was offering voluntary retirement to 2,600 more employees based in the United States. The company had already cut 2,300 from its pharmaceutical and infant-formula divisions in the last year. And Eli Lilly & Company announced that it would cut 4,000 employees, mainly through early retirements in Indiana, where it is based.
"About 50 percent of the United States drug business now goes through price-sensitive Government and private buyers," said Ronald Nordmann, an analyst at Paine Webber Securities. In the 1980's, drug companies could raise prices almost at will. Many physicians did not consider the costs, which were often routinely covered by insurance.
 
A Pre-emptive Effect
 President Clinton's health care proposals include sanctions to punish drug makers that do not restrain prices. Many companies have already limited price increases to general inflation rates.
The actions by the drug companies yesterday followed job reductions announced over the last 12 months by Merck & Company, Johnson & Johnson, Marion Merrell Dow, Monsanto's Searle unit, Syntex and Ciba-Geigy.
Pfizer, one of the strongest companies, said it would report a $525 million after-tax charge against earnings in the third quarter for consolidating manufacturing, distribution and administrative functions. With the charge, it said it lost $214 million, or 65 cents a share, in the quarter. Revenue rose 2 percent to $1.87 billion, taking account of the sale of a minerals unit spun off last year.
Still, William C. Steere, Pfizer's chairman, said the company had strong operating results. Sales from continuing operations rose 9 percent to $1.87 billion in the quarter.
Mr. Nordmann said pharmaceutical sales, the most lucrative part of the business, rose 12 percent in the United States and 13 percent overseas in spite of unfavorable changes in currency rates. He said Pfizer's earnings gains were far ahead of other American-based drug makers'.
With half a dozen new products showing sales gains, Mr. McKinnell said, Pfizer is cutting costs to make the company "even stronger."
Mr. Nordmann said that "unlike companies forced into down-sizing to maintain any growth whatsoever, Pfizer is taking this prudent move before its back is to the wall."
Upjohn said it would take a $183 million charge after taxes in the third quarter. Including the charge, Upjohn said it lost $30 million, or 19 cents a share in the quarter. Sales were $899.9 million, up slightly from $894.4 million the year before.
American Cyanamid said it would take a restructuring charge of $150 million to $200 million in the three months ending Dec. 31.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 28, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Oct. 20, about plans by Pfizer Inc., the American Cyanamid Company and the Upjohn Company to eliminate a total of 7,000 jobs, misstated the number of manufacturing jobs lost in New York City since 1987. It is about 94,000, not 270,000.

HEADLINE: U.S. TELLS HAITIANS OF EMBARGO TERMS

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Sharply raising the stakes for the Haitian military, United States diplomats announced a stringent series of conditions today that they said must be met before international sanctions placed on Haiti this week can be lifted.
The conditions, which begin with the retirement of Haiti's army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, include an end to political violence and human rights abuses and call for the army to get rid of the fearsome police auxiliaries, known as attaches, who roam the streets here terrorizing neighborhoods. 
 In a news conference today a spokesman for the United States Embassy said that in order for the Haitian military to be considered in compliance with the agreement which it signed last July, the Army must request the return of an international human rights mission that was evacuated from Haiti amid rising violence last week.
 
Other Guarantees Required
 The embassy spokesman said that the Haitian Army must also guarantee security for a special session of Parliament, guarantee security for Government ministers and maintain order.
The demands came amid a flurry of diplomatic activity aimed at rescuing a settlement that would restore Haiti's deposed President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
Father Aristide was scheduled to return after two years of exile on Oct. 30, but the refusal of General Cedras to resign has thrown plans into disarray.
To punish the military, the United Nations on Monday reimposed an embargo on oil and military supplies to Haiti, and the United States and other countries have sent ships to make sure that it is respected.
 
Conservative Critics Sought
 At the same time as they pressed the military, representatives of the United Nations and the four so-called "friends of Haiti" -- the United States, Canada, France and Venezuela -- have begun to press Father Aristide to open his transitional Government to include conservative critics close to the military.
Father Aristide's Government, headed by Prime Minister Robert Malval, was named six weeks ago, and is dominated by figures who are close to the deposed President.
In recent interviews, Evans Francois, the brother of the powerful Port-au-Prince police chief, Lieut. Col. Joseph Michel Francois, has said that Colonel Francois and the country's other military leaders would cooperate with United Nations efforts only if Father Aristide's Government were to concede several key ministries.
General Cedras has said in recent interviews that he is awaiting the passage of a broad amnesty law by the National Assembly before he will consider retirement. Diplomats have repeatedly countered that the country's negotiated political settlement only calls for Father Aristide to issue a presidential amnesty, which has already been done.
The Haitian Parliament has been unable to meet because of the climate of violence and Haiti's Justice Minister, Guy Malary, was assassinated last week.
In an interview today, the United Nations special mediator for Haiti, Dante Caputo, said that the Malval Government had been asked to "open the Cabinet to some other people." He denied that this meant inviting allies of the military into the Government.
A senior aide to Mr. Malval said tonight that gasoline sales in the country would be prohibited starting Thursday in keeping with the international embargo.

HEADLINE: 3 Congressmen Seek to Change Senate Filibusters

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Three House liberals today called on talk show hosts and editorial writers who have demanded changes in House procedures to join them in demanding an end to the Senate filibuster rule that permits unlimited debate.
Raising an issue that House rules forbid them to mention in floor debate, Representatives Barney Frank of Massachusetts, David R. Obey of Wisconsin and Mike Synar of Oklahoma, all Democrats, said at a news conference that Americans wanted changes in procedures not for their own sake but so that Congress could deal with their problems. 
 Mr. Frank said filibusters were routinely invoked, not over major issues as they once were, but over such issues as "the fundamental right of cows to eat cheap grass," a reference to a threatened filibuster over legislation that would raise grazing fees on Federal land.
The Congressmen said the Senate filibuster rule was the biggest single obstacle to Congress's doing its job.
Mr. Frank said the rule had "more to do with gridlock than all the other procedures put together." He said the filibuster had forced Democrats to water down several major bills this year, blocked President Clinton's bill to stimulate the economy from even coming to a vote and imperiled health care legislation.
Under Senate rules, it takes 60 votes to end debate and bring a measure to a vote, except for rules changes, which require 67. If the 44 Senate Republicans stick together, they can keep the Senate from voting.
Mr. Obey said the change in the filibuster rule should be accomplished as part of the work of the current Joint Committee on the Organization of Congress. He said he and his two colleagues, along with 32 other Democrats, hoped to enlist public opinion to put the same kind of pressure on the Senate as the House felt recently before it decided to open up procedures for forcing bills to a vote.
There is no way the House can use the joint committee to force Senate action; under the Constitution, each chamber makes its own rules. But the Democrats said they would oppose proposed rule changes to give House Republicans "more leverage" unless Senate Republicans accepted majority rule.
 
'Stone Age Rules'
 The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said filibusters had been used by both parties and by bipartisan alliances over the years. A filibuster, he said, "doesn't just protect the interests of a partisan minority, but also the interests of economic and geographic minorities, including individual states."
Indeed, the rules of each body severely restrict discussions of the other's. House rules preclude members from even discussing Senate rules on the floor, unless they are relevant to a pending measure. So Mr. Obey could not even have raised the issue, let alone spoken of "arcane and ridiculous Stone Age rules," if he had been speaking in the House rather than holding a news conference a few yards away. Nor could Mr. Synar have called the filibuster rule the "single most onerous rule" in Congress.
The three indicated that they would be satisfied with a change that gradually lowered the number of Senate votes needed to halt debate, so long as a majority could act in the end. They also insisted that the Senate end its practice of allowing a single senator to impose an anonymous "hold" that prevents a bill or a nomination from being brought up at all.

HEADLINE: Clinton Uses Japan to Sell Mexico Pact

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Gearing up for the final weeks of an uphill battle to win Congressional support for the North American Free Trade Agreement, President Clinton has settled on a provocative strategy that treats Japan, not Mexico, as the most severe threat to American jobs.
The new approach emerged today at the White House, where Mr. Clinton was joined by Lee A. Iacocca, the retired chairman of the Chrysler Corporation. The two appeared under one of two giant tents erected on the muddy South Lawn for a sort of political yard sale showcasing businesses that support the trade agreement. 
 Surrounded by business people and lobbyists in dark suits promoting things as dirverse as hot dogs and forklifts, both men predicted that if the trade agreement failed, Japan would make its own deal with Mexico to flood the United States with goods that undercut American products.
"What would we do in America if we turn away from this and they make this sort of arrangement with Japan, or with Europe, and they make the investments there, and then we have to deal with their products coming through the back door from Mexico?" Mr. Clinton said, referring to actions the Mexican Government might take if the trade agreement is rejected. "What will happen to our job base? I'm telling you, everything people worried about in the 1980's will get worse if this thing is voted down, and will get better if it's voted up."
Mr. Iacocca, who is loathed by many in Japan for his frequent criticism of Japanese trade barriers, was even more blunt than Mr. Clinton.
In television advertising on behalf of the pact, Mr. Iacocca has described a vote against the trade agreement as a vote in favor of Japan and Europe. "The Japanese and the Europeans think Nafta is a bad deal," Mr. Iacocca says in the commercial, which began to be shown this week. "Why? Because it's good for us and it's bad for them."
And in his remarks today, Mr. Iacocca dismissed criticism from opponents of the trade agreement like Ross Perot who argue that jobs will be lost to Mexico.
"I'm perplexed by a lot of my friends, be they Ross Perot or others," Mr. Iacocca said. "They say we can't compete against little old Mexico when we're beating the hell out of Japan in the auto business."
Mr. Iacocca said that those who supported the trade agreement had failed to convince Americans that it would help the economy. "It's nuts," he said of opposition to the agreement. "It's absolutely nuts."
For weeks, the Administration has been seeking an effective approach to use in selling the agreement after opponents got off to what one official described today as a "head start" in the battle.
 
Trying to Use Old Habits
 Because Americans are more accustomed to seeing Japan as the enemy on trade matters, the Clinton Administration has seized on that as an opportunity to simplify the argument for the trade agreement and add an emotional element to it.
"If this does not work, then what you see happen is that Mexico turns to Japan," Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works on Tuesday. "They turn to Europe."
Hadeaki Domichi, the economic counselor at the Japanese Embassy, said that the Japanese Government had taken no position on the trade agreement.
"Certainly we would expect Mexico and other Latin American countries would be very much disappointed if Nafta does not succeed," Mr. Domichi said. "They may look to other countries, including Japan. That is a natural reaction. But our relationship with Mexico will go on, regardless of Nafta."
If the the trade agreement is accepted, Japan could make investments in Mexico, for instance, in a factory making goods that could be exported to the United States free of tariffs.
Sen. Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, announced that he would vote in favor of the pact after meeting with the President this morning. The House, where the vote is more critical, will vote first, on Nov. 17.
Members of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. tried to counter the President's appeal by arguing that the benefits of the trade agreement would not be as great as the Administration was projecting. The current American trade surplus of $5.4 billion with Mexico, union officials argued, has comes from transfers of plants and equipment, not from any increase in consumer purchases.
Saying he did not want Congress to "adopt this out of fear," Mr. Clinton criticized opponents of the agreement, saying, "There's been too much fear-mongering on the other side and all kinds of ridiculous statements made."

President Clinton was embraced by Harold Sumpler of H & H Industries, as Lee A. Iacocca, right, the retired chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, applauded. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Russia Threatens to Veto Any Sanctions West Seeks Against Libya

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct 20

 BODY:
Russia has threatened to use its Security Council veto to block new sanctions that the United States, Britain and France want to impose on Libya for refusing to hand over two citizens accused of blowing up Pan Am Flight 103 in December 1988, United Nations diplomats say.
The strongly worded threat, made in a letter to Secretary of State Warren Christopher that arrived last weekend, surprised and angered Administration officials. A total of 270 people died in the blast over Lockerbie, Scotland. 
 In response to Russia's move, Secretary of State Christopher will seek during a visit to Moscow later this week to find a compromise to insure that Libya will be able to repay its substantial debt to Russia after the Council has approved the new sanctions, diplomats said. The new penalties include a freeze on Tripoli's estimated $6.5 billion in overseas assets.
As a permanent member of the Security Council, Russia, along with Britain, the United States, France and China, has a veto over all Security Council decisions.
If Mr. Christopher's effort succeeds, the Council will vote next week on the new sanctions, which also ban the sale of oil drilling equipment and aviation services to LibyaAmerican officials say. The Security Council has already banned all civilian airlines from flying to and from Libya because of its refusal to surrender the suspects for trial.
Russia's objection to the current draft resolution is that it would prevent Libya from using its overseas assets to pay off these debts, which amount to more than $1 billion and are mainly owed for arms. If Libya is allowed to transfer some of these assets to Russia in settlement of these debts, the sanctions will be weakened because Libya's leader, Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi, will be under less financial pressure to comply with the Security Council's order and hand over the suspects..
Mr. Christopher is expected to try to find a way of forcing Libya to pay its debts to Moscow out of its current oil revenues instead of by liquidating foreign assets, the officials said.
It is unclear why Russia would challenge d the United States, Britain and France after their governments gave President Boris N. Yeltsin their full support in his recent confrontation with a rebellious Russian Parliament. But diplomats said that Mr. Yeltsin might still find it politically necessary to show that he is standing up for Russian interests rather than submissively acceding to the wishes of the West.
Russian diplomats at the United Nations have been telling their Western colleagues that they believe they can detect the influence of the Russian generals who helped Mr. Yeltsin win his struggle against hard-line lawmakers.
The new sanctions were originally supposed to come into effect on Oct. 1, if Libya had not handed over the two accused agents for trial in Scotland and agreed to cooperate with a French judicial inquiry into a terrorist explosion aboard a French airliner over Niger in 1989 that left 171 people dead.
But the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, saying that the Libyans were becoming more flexible, asked for a delay while he continued negotiations. Libya now says the two accused men are free to go to Scotland for trial if they wish, but refuses to hand them over. The British, American and French Governments increasingly believe it will never do so.
Under the new draft resolution, the Security Council offers to "suspend" all economic sanctions against Libya if it changes its mind and surrenders the suspects. But it also threatens to reimpose them after 90 days if the United Nations Secretary General does not report that Colonel Qaddafi's Government has renounced support for international terrorism.

HEADLINE: At Flashpoint of Rioting, Now Banality Is Jarring

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Nothing very remarkable happened today at the infamous corner of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central Los Angeles. The regulars came to get their chili dogs at Art's Famous Chili Dogs ("Since 1933"), neighborhood women got their hair done at Goldie's Beauty Salon, and all day long photographers and reporters came.
It was difficult to tell that this was the flashpoint, the epicenter where years of racial resentments exploded into the deadly disorders that rocked Los Angeles last year. It was difficult, under a warm hazy sun, to visualize the terror of Reginald O. Denny and other white and Asian drivers who were pulled out of their vehicles that day and brutalized. 
 Brian Weaver, a 34-year-old black man who works for a Christian relief organization, saw it happen, and he said it was evil incarnate. "The most remarkable feeling I had when I pulled up was the total absence of goodness; it was like evil, demonic," he said of the mobs of youths who terrorized the streets.
Today, Mr. Weaver came by to perform the mundane task of having his car washed.
 
Nonchalance Amid Ruins
 Indeed, the sheer banality of the intersection today is jarring. The northwest corner, where there was once a radiator shop, is nothing but a vacant lot with a tattered chain link fence festooned with hand-lettered commercial posters ("bathtubs reglazed"). Across the street are the boarded-up remains of a Shell service station.
Tom's Liquor store on the northeast corner and a Unocal service station on the southeast corner have both reopened. Above it all, incongruously, is a billboard from the Bank of America showing a middle-aged white farmer standing in front of rows of green crops.
Even if the men who beat Mr. Denny were as evil as Mr. Weaver said, they did not get off too leniently, in the view of the score or so of black passers-by interviewed today. No, they said, Damian M. Williams and Henry K. Watson, the two men charged in the beatings, only got the kind of gentle treatment that would have been accorded whites in similar circumstances.
"If it were two whites, they would have been charged with assault and battery, and there would have been a plea bargain," said Mr. Weaver, who can remember his youth when he was taught by friends to consider whites as "prey."
Nearby, James Scott, a 29-year-old unemployed handyman, sat on a stoop on Florence Avenue with a friend, Diane Williams. They also ratified the verdicts.
"It was cool," said Mr. Scott, adding that he knew one of the defendants, Damian Williams. "I feel they got justice." He recalled seeing the bloodied Mr. Denny in the street next to his 18-wheel truck and "felt sorry" for him. "It was awful," he said. "But what those police officers did to Rodney King was pretty awful too."
And Ms. Williams observed that very little had improved around Florence and Normandie, one of the poorest parts of the city. "They were going to put money in the community," she said. "I ain't seen nothing rebuilt."
Over at Art's, the blue-and-white chili joint, a black-owned establishment spared in the looting and arson, the counterman today pronounced the episode over. "It's all behind us now," he said, loading relish and mustard on hot dogs for two customers.
"I thought it was fair both ways," 27-year-old said Richard Wood, one of the customers, said, referring to the 30-month sentences given two police officers in the beating of Mr. King. "The cops got off easily, so why shouldn't these guys."
Rodney Walton, 34, the other customer, said shrugged and said, "Life goes on. I think everybody in the city is satisfied except Daryl Gates." Mr. Gates is the former chief of police, who personally arrested Mr. Williams last year.
They scanned the landmark intersection and wondered if there would be a monument erected there. Mr. Woods pondered the notion and then, with perverse humor, suggested a suitable monument: an 18-wheel diesel truck.

HEADLINE: BHUTTO STANDS BY NUCLEAR PROGRAM

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Oct. 20

 BODY:
In comments that seem certain to unsettle Pakistan's already fragile relations with Washington, the new Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, said today that her country would continue to pursue its nuclear program, which American intelligence officials maintain is devoted to the development of nuclear weapons.
"We will protect Pakistan's nuclear program and will not allow our national interest to be sacrificed," Ms. Bhutto said in a recorded television address that was broadcast tonight. 
 Her remark was consistent with those of previous Prime Ministers, who have adamantly rejected demands that Pakistan dismantle its weapons development programs yet never explicitly acknowledged that the country has nuclear arms.
But it was a change in emphasis for Mrs. Bhutto, who promised the United States in 1989, during her previous term as Prime Minister, that Pakistan did not possess a nuclear weapon and had no intention of developing one.
 
Warning to India Seen
 Though ambiguously worded, her statement today seemed intended mainly to assure the country's powerful military that it would retain nuclear options and to warn India, with which Pakistan has fought three wars, that her country is not about to scale back its military capabilities.
Coming a day after she took office, Ms. Bhutto's statement nettled the Clinton Administration and suggested that Washington's relations with Islamabad would remain distant.
A senior Administration official in Washington described Ms. Bhutto's statement as "not very helpful."
Under a measure approved by Congress in 1990 and known as the Pressler Amendment, no American aid can go to Pakistan until the President of the United States certifies that Pakistan does not possess nuclear weapons.
After a three-year battle to regain the office from which she was dismissed in 1990, Ms. Bhutto returned to power on Tuesday, heading a minority Government.
 
Little Elaboration
 Ms. Bhutto did not elaborate on Pakistan's nuclear intentions in an interview today in her office. But she said she intended to raise the issue of the aid cutoff with the Clinton Administration.
"We will be examining the aspect of regional non-proliferation, and we will also be examining the questions of taking up the issue with the United States on the whole question of Pressler and how it can be removed," she said. "The first thing is to start a dialogue on this issue."
Ms. Bhutto also said today that she would re-examine many of the economic changes introduced by her predecessor, Moeen Qureshi, a former vice president of the World Bank who had served as interim Prime Minister for the last 90 days. Many of those changes, including taxes on feudal estates and an end to some Government subsidies, have won praise from international bankers and aid donors.
Pakistan stepped up its nuclear program in the 1980's in response to reports that India was rapidly expanding its nuclear capability and amid tensions between the two nations over the disputed territory of Kashmir. India conducted an underground nuclear explosion in 1974.
 
Pakistani Forces Deteriorate
 Since the cutoff of American aid in 1990, Pakistan's conventional forces have deteriorated as parts for American-supplied equipment dried up.
Pakistan has scoured the globe for new military supplies. Lately, scores of arms dealers from Europe have visited Islamabad, including an Italian team that is now here trying to sell a missile system.
Already Ms. Bhutto has begun distancing herself from the sweeping economic changes begun by Mr. Qureshi. Among his changes were a devaluation of the overvalued rupee, steps to make the central bank independent of political influence, elimination of many price subsidies and an agricultural tax on the country's rich landowners. Many of those steps were intended to win back assistance from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and to insure that the country can repay its international debts.
 
Support From Landowners
 Ms. Bhutto, who comes from a family that has been one of the country's largest landowners and who has broad political support from the landed aristocracy, or feudals as they are known here, said she would re-examine the agricultural tax.
She also said she was troubled by the nine percent devaluation of the currency, intended by Mr. Qureshi to stimulate exports by making them cheaper, discourage imports and pave the way to the convertibility of the rupee.
Ms. Bhutto's first term as Prime Minister ended after 20 months with her dismissal on charges of corruption and incompetence in 1990. She was widely criticized by women's groups in Pakistan for not introducing any policies to enforce women's rights or lessen the economic and legal disadvantages they face.
Though she rejected the criticism, Ms. Bhutto said that she intended to repeal discriminatory legislation against women now that Islamic fundamentalists have been resoundingly defeated in this month's elections.

HEADLINE: A Wary Reply to South Africa's Call

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Sprung from its economic shackles after more than a decade of sanctions, South Africa is seeking foreign investment to help cushion its transition to a multiracial democracy. But many American companies are so leery of the country's volatile politics that they are staying away and, it now appears, will not play a major role in shaping the start of this new era.
Despite recent pleas from leaders like President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela, president of the African National Congress, who last week shared the Nobel Peace Prize for their efforts to end the apartheid state, many of these companies say they face a host of obstacles to doing business in South Africa. And some point out that they are wary of entering the country not only because of conditions there, but also because of concerns about the reaction in the United States to such moves. 
 "There is no doubt that there is a tremendous amount of promise in South Africa," said Witney W. Schneidman, a senior vice president at Samuels International Associates, a consulting firm in Washington that specializes in South Africa. "But there are also a lot of questions that need to be resolved before that promise is realized."
 
Many Inhibiting Concerns
 Some American companies are worried about the policies of the African National Congress, which is expected to take power after the transition and once espoused hard-line socialist views -- particularly about nationalizing important industries like mining -- before its recent disavowal of them.
Others fear factional violence. Still others note that South Africa is competing with many emerging markets for capital, including those in Eastern Europe. The Ford Motor Company, which sold its assets in South Africa in 1988, says that whatever the political situation, the South African vehicle market is too depressed for it to make money by building or buying factories there.
And some companies that do business with state and local governments in the United States emphasize that they cannot seriously consider South Africa until those jurisdictions lift their sanctions, which helped force more than 200 American companies to leave the country in the 1980's.
Citing these factors, big conglomerates like the General Electric Company, the Procter & Gamble Company, Citibank and Eastman Kodak are expressing little enthusiasm about returning immediately to South Africa. The Mobil Corporation, which left in 1989, when it had $400 million in assets in South Africa and was the largest American company there, also says it has ruled out replanting roots for now.
There appears little chance in the near future that an American company will commit itself to the kind of investment South Africans seek: construction of factories or other projects that create new jobs for a recession-ridden economy saddled with an unemployment rate estimated at 45 percent.
 "In our business and other businesses that are capital intensive, you just don't move in and out according to the political winds," said an executive at a major American industrial company that left South Africa in the late 1980's.
 
A Tempting Market

 
 Even as the large American conglomerates are shying away, their European and Japanese counterparts, which faced much milder sanctions from their governments in the 1980's, continue to invest heavily in South Africa. Their interest shows that despite the drawbacks, the market is tempting.
South Africa has a population of nearly 40 million people with a growing black middle class, an excellent transportation system, abundant natural resources like coal, a stock exchange and a sturdy network of banks and other financial services companies. English is widely spoken. The country can be also used as a base to pursue other opportunities on the continent.
South Africa is particularly eager to do business with American banks, which called in loans to the Government in the 1980's, preventing it from rolling over its debt, as most countries periodically do. The Government then had to begin paying off principal, so it became a net exporter of capital and had to deprive its own industries of financing.
And in an odd twist, some analysts predict that by the end of the decade, the American companies that were once pressed to leave South Africa by some stockholders and elected officials may find that they are being pressured by the same people to establish a presence there to insure a peaceful transition. Already, some institutional investors, like the Calvert Social Investment Fund, are looking for business in South Africa for that reason.
So the country may be attractive to some companies, particularly privately held ones, which do not have to contend with shareholders still sensitive to dealings with South Africa. The Investor Responsibility Research Center, a monitoring group in Washington, says that at least 28 American companies have gone into South Africa since July 1991, including 11 computer or software companies. Fifteen of the 28 are privately held.
The Digital Equipment Corporation, the second-largest American computer company, said in May that it would open an office in South Africa for the first time. Its subsidiary will sell and service its products, employing about 50 people in its first year.
The Pillsbury Company, the Minneapolis food processor now owned by Grand Metropolitan of Britain, said last month that it would invest $25 million in a joint venture with Foodcorp, a South African company, to modernize existing plants. The new company, Pillsbury Africa Ltd., will make and distribute vegetable products and frozen pizzas in South Africa. And the H. J. Heinz Company, the food conglomerate, says it is also ready to return.
 
A Likely Path: Nonequity Links
 Analysts say that because of doubts about South Africa's stability, American companies that do enter the country will probably take the route of Digital and Pillsbury, gingerly investigating the market through exports, joint ventures or licensing agreements.
That seems to be why the number of American companies pursuing nonequity links to South Africa -- like licensing or distribution agreements -- has jumped from 109 in 1987 to 430 this month, the Investor Responsibility Research Center says. The number of companies with direct investments has barely changed.
Such arm's-length investment may be prudent for American companies, but it does not draw an enthusiastic response from South Africans, who have less interest in undertakings in which Western goods are imported or manufactured at existing plants than in those ventures that create jobs.
"I would not be surprised if you find that investment-intensive companies might go quite a bit more slowly than others because of the need to insure that the return on investment is there," Kenneth Brown, a spokesman for Ford, said. "Setting up a branch of an international tourism company is much different than building an automotive plant or setting up a diamond mine."
 
Dismantling Sanctions
 Beyond economic issues, there is the legacy of sanctions. From Mobil to General Motors to RJR Nabisco, American industry fled South Africa in the 1980's, hastily selling or closing down hundreds of millions of dollars in assets. The restrictions have been eased over the last two years as the white Government has agreed to give up power.
Earlier this month, the United Nations General Assembly called for the end of nearly all sanctions and Congress is about to repeal the last Federal ones. But hundreds of state and local sanctions remain, though Los Angeles and Massachusetts have already repealed their laws and New York City is expected to follow soon.
"We hope that the actual repeal of U.S., state and local laws happens quickly, because so long as these sanctions remain on the books, we and other U.S. companies will be inhibited from doing business in South Africa," William R. Rhodes, vice chairman of Citibank, recently told a group of African finance ministers.
But the effect of sanctions will linger even after they are repealed, some executives say. If they want to return, American companies that left South Africa by spinning off subsidiaries will have to decide whether to buy them back or, in perhaps an awkward alternative, compete with them. Some South African workers are resentful toward American companies that abandoned the country.
And Daniel O'Flaherty, executive director of the United States-South Africa Business Council, said he believed that some cities or states would replace their sanctions with laws requiring codes of conduct for companies doing business in South Africa. Such regulations would certainly dampen some executives' interest, he said.
"If you have to comply with a multitude of codes of conduct and reporting requirements and you're not making that much money," he said, "there is a limit to how much compliance and supervision is acceptable before you will invest instead in, say, Malaysia or Thailand."
Mr. Schneidman, the consultant, agreed, stressing that many American companies still needed to be convinced about South Africa.
"Though Mandela has called for the lifting of sanctions, there is still anxiety about whether this is the right time," he said. "All this hoopla has signaled the end of one era and the beginning of a new era -- the post-sanctions era. It has not signaled the onslaught of capital going into South Africa."
