HEADLINE: Odd Couple: Iran and Iraq in First Talks Since 1990

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Deputy ministers from Iran and Iraq ended two days of official talks in Baghdad today, the first between the Persian Gulf antagonists since 1990, when they agreed on a limited exchange of prisoners of war.
The negotiations, which took place in the context of much talk in both Teheran and Baghdad about a new alliance to confront "American hegemony," have aroused some anxiety in Israel and a few Western capitals. 
 Officials from both countries said the talks focused on an exchange of prisoners from their eight-year war, which ended in 1988. Iran holds about 20,000 Iraqis; Teheran says Iraq is holding about 5,000 Iranians.
 
United in Hostility
 If the two countries unite in their opposition to a Middle East peace accord and their hostility toward the West, and the United States in particular, the regional political balance would be radically changed. But Iranians, Saudis, Egyptians and Persian Gulf Arabs interviewed today played down the significance of the meeting.
The delegations were led by two deputy foreign ministers, Mohammed Javad Zarif of Iran and Saad Abdelmeguid al-Faisal of Iraq.
Iraqi newspapers and Iranian radical leaders have argued loudly that it is in the vital interests of both countries to team up to resist pressure from the West. But experts interviewed expressed doubt that the two countries could overcome the deep ideological and territorial disputes that led them to war, or the ties between the Shiite Muslim Government in Iran and the Iraqi Shiites, a relationship that the Sunni Muslim leaders of Iraq see as threatening.
"I don't see these talks as significant," said Baqer Moin, an Iranian affairs expert with the British Broadcasting Corporation. "They are largely meant to tie up some loose ends. Otherwise there are too many ideological, religious and political differences separating the current regimes."
 
'I Don't See It Happening'
 Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, the first President of Iran after the Islamic revolution and now an exile in Paris, said: "The idea of a comprehensive strategic understanding between the two countries has been touted a lot by the radical clergy in Teheran, and I suppose that in theory it can be done, as both regimes are totalitarian enough to decree peace, so to speak. But I don't see it happening. Too much has happened to allow this.
"The two countries are still at war, with their border dispute unresolved. There are thousands of prisoners of war on both sides unaccounted for. The war waged by Iraq has destroyed a whole generation of nearly a million people in Iran. I think the Iranian leadership would have great difficulty persuading its own clergy, let alone the population, to forgive and forget Iraq."
There are other profound disagreements. These include some $100 billion in war reparations demanded by Iran and Iran's insistence on obtaining equal navigation and ownership rights in the Shatt al-Arab estuary, which forms the border between the two countries at the head of the Persian Gulf.
 
'Marriage of Convenience'
 Baghdad also continues to support Iranian anti-Government guerrillas.
Iraq has demanded the return of 148 planes that were sent to Iran for safe-keeping during the Persian Gulf war in 1991. Iran has refused to do so, saying it was confiscating the planes as part of its compensation claim.
But Iranian affairs experts said the two nations had been drawn closer by the impact of economic sanctions and the "dual containment" policy advocated by Western nations.
Some experts said that the two countries could be trying to give the impression of a potential alliance largely to fend off common enemies rather than to seek a real peace, but that such a fragile arrangement could not blossom.
"In terms of the long run, I would find it very difficult to see this as more than a temporary marriage of convenience," said Medhi Verzi, an oil expert who closely follows Iran and Iraq.
Oil experts argue, for example, that it is not in Iran's interest to help Iraq sell its embargoed oil because this would give the West an excuse to impose official sanctions on Iran. Also, they say, with oil prices depressed, Iran, Saudi Arabia and the other oil-producing countries along the Persian Gulf worry that Iraq could flood the oil market and depress prices even more.

Deputy Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, right, head of the Iranian delegation, talked to reporters on Sunday as he arrived in Baghdad. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Once Again, Burger King Shops for an Agency

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Burger King, which changes advertising agencies practically at the flip of a Whopper, is doing so again.
The company, the No. 2 fast-food chain behind McDonald's, said yesterday it would put into review the bulk of its domestic advertising account, which has been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York. 
 Burger King's decision epitomizes the fierce competition among the nation's fast-food chains, which is intensifying as customers, more value conscious than ever, insist they want the steak instead of the sizzle.
D.M.B. & B., which has been responsible for an estimated $150 million to $175 million of Burger King's $250 million account, created the current campaign carrying the theme, "I Love This Place!" The agency said it would probably not participate in the review.
D.M.B. & B.'s expected absence sets up, you should pardon the expression, a feeding frenzy among other agencies. One shop eagerly tying on its bib is Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, which has shared the account with D.M.B. & B. since 1989.
Trade publications had speculated for some time that Burger King would join the ranks of agency changers among advertisers in competitive consumer-product categories like restaurants, soft drinks and automobiles.
The company's penchant for switching shops and slogans has been accelerated by often quarrelsome relations with its franchisees, who have been notably vocal in complaining about D.M.B. & B.'s work.
This time, however, the change stemmed from a decision to seek "a fresh approach to our advertising campaign that will reflect the company's 'back to basics' philosophy," Sidney J. Feltenstein, executive vice president of worldwide marketing at the Burger King Corporation in Miami, said in a statement.
His reference was to a marketing strategy that the company adopted only two and a half weeks ago, focusing on an "everyday value" approach to pricing that emphasizes lower-priced basic fare and specially priced combination meals.
Burger King has long been reluctant to stress value rather than glitzy advertising or gimmicky giveaways, even though consumers, feeling economically pressed, have been signaling for some time that saving money takes precedence when eating out. Chains like Taco Bell and Wendy's, which advertise menu items at everyday low prices, and regional chains like Rally's and Checkers, with pared menus emulating 1950's drive-in restaurants, have blazed a trail their larger rivals find themselves forced to follow.
Indeed, Burger King's belated value-oriented approach marks an about-face after a year spent trying to give the chain, with more than 7,000 company-owned and franchised outlets, a more upscale persona by selling higher-priced fare like dinner baskets and offering table service. The image-building effort centered on a youth-oriented campaign by D.M.B. & B. that imitated the rapid-fire pace and irreverence of MTV. Not only did the television commercials use the slogan "BK Tee Vee," they featured Dan Cortese, a hunky MTV host, as the pitchman.
But according to Technomic Inc., a restaurant industry consulting company in Chicago, Burger King last year achieved the weakest sales gains, and lost the most market share, of the four biggest burger makers. Burger King's systemwide sales of $5.3 billion rose only 2.7 percent, compared with a 7 percent gain for the overall market, and its market share fell to 16 percent from 16.6 percent in 1991.
Burger King's adoption of the everyday value strategy reflects a realization that "we're in the hamburger business," Cori Zywotow, a spokeswoman, said.
"It's not a matter of whether 'BK Tee Vee' was or wasn't working," she added. "In a marketplace like today's, where one year ago is a completely different environment, we owe it to ourselves to see what else is out there."
That is a feeling Burger King has acted on frequently in recent years as it lurched from campaign to campaign and agency to agency. In 1987, the company left J. Walter Thompson, its agency since 1976, after Thompson produced a campaign, called "Herb the Nerd," that became one of the most notorious flops in marketing history. Burger King then hired Ayer Inc., which was dismissed in 1989 after creating a confusing campaign carrying the theme "We Do It Like You'd Do It."
Burger King then doubled its agency roster, dividing the account between D.M.B. & B. and Saatchi. The balance between the two has tilted toward D.M.B. & B., which was awarded national creative assignments; regional account service, through a field force that worked with Burger King franchisees; media planning and buying, and the international Burger King account.
D.M.B. & B., which also handles accounts for Anheuser-Busch, Kraft General Foods, General Motors and Procter & Gamble, was told of Burger King's decision on Tuesday night. Roy Bostock, chairman and chief executive at D.M.B. & B., said yesterday: "The issue of whether we'll participate is under discussion. No decision has been made yet, but it's unlikely."
Michael Keeshan, Saatchi's president and chief operating officer, had a different response.
"Needless to say, we would love to participate," he said. In addition to its current duties for Burger King, he added, his agency has also worked previously for Wendy's and Arby's. Saatchi's responsibilities now involve creating advertising and promotional campaigns for the Burger King Kids Club, a program aimed at wooing children to the chain's restaurants.
Ms. Zywotow said the review would be handled by a committee including Mr. Feltenstein and franchisees. Richard Roth Associates, a consulting company in Chappaqua, N.Y., will be involved in sending questionnaires to participants, she added, and asking finalists for marketing briefs. A decision is expected by early next year.
It is possible, she said, that the account might be "unbundled" as a result of the review, meaning that one agency might be awarded the creative portion and another other responsibilities like media services. If that should occur, D.M.B. & B., even if it decides against participating in the review, might yet retain those other duties while another agency assumed the creative assignment.

HEADLINE: As Bills Flourish and Symphony Suffers, Some in Buffalo Ask Why

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Every autumn, as the first cold gusts whip off Lake Erie, this area begins to swagger. During football season Buffalo is in the same league as New York and Los Angeles, and when the Bills win, Buffalo gets a chance to call those towns losers.
This year, however, some are asking whether Buffalo is deluding itself about how it stacks up with other big cities. While the region cheers its team toward a possible fourth straight Super Bowl, its philharmonic orchestra is in danger of shutting down. 
 Last week, a member of the Erie County Legislature, Joan K. Bozer, proposed postponing improvements to county-owned Rich Stadium, where the Buffalo Bills play, until the Legislature convenes a "summit meeting" of political and business leaders to solve the philharmonic's problems.
Nobody -- not even Ms. Bozer -- is proposing taking money from the stadium and giving it directly to the philharmonic. In fact, the stadium would pay for itself, while the orchestra does not.
 
What Price Culture?
 But even though Ms. Bozer's proposal is expected to be rejected by the county Legislature on Thursday, the plan has provoked the city to take a look at the price it is willing to pay to accommodate sports and the arts.
Alan M. Ross, a violinist and head of the orchestra musicians' negotiating committee, said that while the philharmonic has toured Europe and played Carnegie Hall, it feels unappreciated at home -- something that could never be said about the Bills.
"Whenever any sports team needs anything here, millions of dollars gets thrown into that pot right away, whether they're tax dollars or not," Mr. Ross said. "But when the orchestra is struggling for its existence with a million-dollar gap, everyone says, let's cut the orchestra size down."
The orchestra, which Mr. Ross said has been ranked among the top 15 in the nation, has been in financial trouble for years, battered by recession along with other orchestras around the country that do not have major endowments to get them through lean times. This year it faced a $900,000 deficit -- despite getting county aid of $792,000. Last month orchestra management laid off the 80 musicians and canceled the Sept. 10 opening performance of Verdi's Requiem.
The musicians were rehired and performances resumed earlier this month with a temporary arrangement under which management and musicians will seek ways to increase revenues and reduce the orchestra's $7.5 million budget. Among the proposals are reducing musicians' base salary of $34,000 and reducing the number of musicians.
If there is no resolution by Nov. 4, the orchestra will shut down Nov. 22.
Ms. Bozer, a former Republican who is seeking re-election as a Democrat, has been accused of grandstanding with her proposal linking the Bills and the philharmonic, and she concedes there is no direct relationship.
 
Question of Conscience
 But she said she could not vote "in good conscience" for stadium improvements while the philharmonic is foundering. "I think it would be a very negative message that we don't care about music, we only care about sports," she said.
The Legislature is to vote Thursday on a Rich Stadium plan that includes a $11.6 million county bond for a video scoreboard, new luxury seating and other improvements. Principal and interest on the bond would be repaid by surcharges on stadium tickets and parking fees, and revenues from the new seating.
The project comes several months after the county agreed to contribute $20 million toward a new $115 million hockey arena for the Buffalo Sabres. County officials said the money will come from an existing 5 percent tax on hotel rooms and a quarter-percent surcharge on arena tickets.
The County Legislature's Chairman, Leonard R. Lenihan, a Democrat, said the Rich Stadium work is important because "it begins the process of renegotiating the lease to keep the Bills here."
The Bills' 25-year lease on Rich Stadium expires at the end of the 1997 season, and renewal talks are to start in January 1994.
Mr. Lenihan said Ms. Bozer is wrong to link the philharmonic to the Bills. "The two issues are just unrelated," he said.
Even philharmonic supporters are uneasy with a proposal that would appear to make lawmakers choose between the orchestra and the football team.
"I think it's a very unpopular move," said Peter Walsh, a 32-year-old stockbroker. "People will do anything to keep the Bills in town."
 
'A Sense of Pride'
 Dennis Gorski learned that in 1988, when at the start of his first term as Erie County executive he said there was no big rush to start lease renewal talks with the Bills. The telephone lines to the sports-talk shows nearly melted.
"We all make mistakes in public life," Mr. Gorski said this week. He now finds himself in the more comfortable position of supporting the Bills. "I'm not saying that sports is the be-all of our existence in Buffalo," Mr. Gorski said. "But the Buffalo Bills have given us a sense of pride.
Bills fans hardly seem put off by the team's three consecutive Super Bowl losses, a record. "The way the Buffalo fans look at it is, we're going to do it until we get it right," Mr. Lenihan said.
Ms. Bozer, who attended two of those Super Bowls, said she did not think her proposal would hurt her re-election bid.
But Ms. Bozer said she merely wants local leaders to put more emphasis on solving the philharmonic's problems. "I believe once the commitment is made we'll find a way to do it," she said.

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN TRAIL;
Rabbis Criticize Dinkins For Passing Up Forum

BYLINE: By CATHERINE S. MANEGOLD

 BODY:
The president of the 800-member New York Board of Rabbis, in the past staunch supporters of Mayor David N. Dinkins, criticized the Mayor yesterday for turning down an invitation to appear at a forum with Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The board's president, Rabbi Jeremiah Wohlberg, said the Mayor's campaign had pressed the board to include the Conservative Party candidate, George Marlin, in their forum and had finally "pleaded the presence of Vice President Al Gore" in declining the invitation to speak. 
 Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal challenger, attended the Board of Rabbis meeting on the Upper East Side yesterday.
The Board of Rabbis has been an influential force among Jewish New Yorkers and was a staunch supporter of the Mayor until late last year. A break between City Hall and the board occurred when its leaders accused the Mayor of making a "rush to judgment" in the beating of a 25-year-old black man, Ralph Nimmons, in Crown Heights. Mr. Dinkins called that case a bias crime, a conclusion that was disputed by the board.
"We asked the Mayor and his campaign managers, as a sign of respect," Rabbi Wohlberg said, "to go to the rabbis represented by this board -- who are over 800 in number and represent the entire spectrum of the New York metropolitan area rabbinical community of Orthodox, Conservative and Reform -- to go to them and show concern for the constituents that they represent."
Responding to Rabbi Wohlberg's complaint, Leah Johnson, the press secretary for the Mayor's campaign, said yesterday that Mr. Dinkins had always insisted that Mr. Marlin be included. "Since the original request came in," she said, "we have maintained all along that we would participate in a three-way forum. That never wavered. That never changed." She said Mr. Gore's presence in the city was not used as a last-minute excuse because their position had not changed and Mr. Marlin had not been invited.
Rabbi Wohlberg stressed that yesterday's meeting was never intended as a debate, "but rather, consecutive appearances" by the two leading candidates, sharing their views with the board members and taking questions from them.
Asked by the Mayor's campaign team to accept a surrogate in Mr. Dinkins's place, Rabbi Wohlberg said the board "could not accept those restrictions or those guidelines."
Rabbi Wohlberg said his group kept pressure on the Mayor's office "until the very end."
Appearing alone, Mr. Giuliani revived his jokes about the WNBC debate to which Mr. Marlin toted a rubber chicken. Then Mr. Giuliani gave his standard speech about the need for safer streets, an end to violence within the school system and the city's overall need to turn away from the tyranny of special-interest groups and toward a legal and political system blind to differences in race, sex, religion, sexual preference and ethnicity to embrace a single standard for all New Yorkers.
Asked what specifically he would do to diminish racial, ethnic and religious tensions in the city, Mr. Giuliani said the city is more divided today than it was four years ago and promised to work with community groups to ease tensions. "You are not going to find the same excessive partisan political separation," he said, promising an administration representing all parties and all groups.
 
Just In From Washington
 Campaigning with Mayor Dinkins yesterday, Vice President Al Gore joined the long line of Clinton Administration officials who have flown to New York City in the last month to assure voters that Mr. Dinkins, "this great and good man," will have special influence in the White House.
Through the visits, the Clinton team also seems to be trying to convince New Yorkers that the President himself has a vision for America's cities, despite the defeat of its economic stimulus package, which Mr. Dinkins says would have provided $400 million for New York.
In a speech to the City Council yesterday, Mr. Gore announced a new Federal plan to promote recycling, presenting it as a major boon to cities, and credited Mr. Dinkins with persuading the President to go forward with it.
"This new policy on recycling would not have come about except for the vigorous and able leadership of David Dinkins," Mr. Gore told reporters after his speech.
The executive order signed by the President requires that the hundreds of thousands of tons of paper purchased by the Federal Government contain at least 20 percent recycled paper. Mr. Gore said the policy will be important to cities like New York because it will create a market for the waste paper they collect.
The appearances over the last month by Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary; Mr. Gore, his wife, Tipper, and his parents, Al and Pauline, and what seems to be a Cabinet officer a day are part of a coordinated effort to bolster Mr. Dinkins's claim in stump speeches that the city needs a Democratic Mayor to work with a Democratic President.
The day followed the usual rituals of a visit from a Washington big shot. Mr. Dinkins stood under an umbrella in the rain to embrace the Vice President as he descended from his plane. They then posed, thumbs up, with Mr. Dinkins's running mates, Mark Green and Alan G. Hevesi.
And Mr. Dinkins listened appreciatively as the Vice President praised him for lowering the crime rate, balancing budgets and helping to keep the peace in a multiracial city.
"His voice in the White House is the loudest, clearest and most sensitive, especially when it comes to providing solutions to the problems of America's great urban centers," Mr. Gore said.
Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Gore also courted Jewish voters, a critical constituency in this election, with a joint appearance at the dedication of the America-Israel Friendship Grove in Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Flushing, Queens.
Mr. Dinkins sat beaming on the stage next to the Vice President as Colette Avital, Consul General of Israel, said of the Mayor, "We know this friendship is sincere and so it is inscribed in our hearts." She later added, "He repeatedly condemned anti-Semitism, often by his own people."
 
Giuliani Urges Hiring Freeze
 Challenging Mr. Dinkins to establish firmly the amount of an expected deficit in this year's budget, Mr. Giuliani yesterday called for a hiring freeze within the city government, tighter controls on administration spending and a broad effort to reduce expenditures in overtime for New York City workers for the remainder of the fiscal year.
He also recapitulated arguments that he has made for months chastising the Mayor for using "phony numbers" to create the impression of a balanced budget.
At an afternoon speech at the Sheraton New York Hotel, Mr. Giuliani singled out anticipated revenues from the sale of the Off-Track Betting Corporation, two prison barges and "an illusory $150 million check for unrestricted Federal aid" as "one-shots and wishes that will never materialize." The speech was made before an audience of supporters and those who have made financial contributions to his campaign.
Mr. Giuliani said he would consider a hiring freeze himself, if elected, but said his overall policy of backing cuts through attrition with a variety of exemptions "has not changed."
He also repeated earlier campaign pledges to trim the Mayor's staff by 10 percent.
Little in his speech was new to his campaign. And several of his comments during a brief question-and-answer period afterward were clearly planted by supporters handing him openings for some of his most standard campaign lines. Questions focused on crime, the Mayor's reaction to the riot in Crown Heights and how he would help small businesses.
The woman who questioned Mr. Giuliani about how his response to reports of a disturbance in Crown Heights would have been different from Mr. Dinkins's had spoken on Sept. 7 at The Jewish Center at 131 West 86th Street, where Mr. Giuliani had said he would have arrested the first rioter on the first day. Yesterday's question was the same. So was his answer.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New Price Reports With Caveats

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The next couple of reports on the Consumer Price Index could prove a little disturbing for the bond market because adjustments used to smooth out seasonal price variations could exaggerate an actual increase in prices.
The report that the index was unchanged in September was the factor that propelled long-term interest rates to new 25-year lows last week. 
 But analysts, including those at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which assembles the C.P.I., say the index could now jump as much as four-tenths of a percent in October because of the seasonal adjustment. Earlier this year, that kind of a jump was enough to send the bond market reeling.
 
A Neutralizing Factor
 Patrick Jackman, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that for the rest of the year seasonal adjustments would add four-tenths of a percent to the index. This means if there were no actual price increases over these three months, the seasonally adjusted index that is reported would still rise about four-tenths of a percent.
The reason for this adjustment factor is that many prices, like those for energy, usually decline at this time of the year, Mr. Jackman said. Thus, the seasonal adjustment factors that are used to smooth out regular price fluctuations effectively neutralize the impact of normal price declines.
So an actual decline that is expected in the seasonals will not help lower the overall seasonally adjusted index, while any increase in actual prices would be even larger after the index is seasonally adjusted. The seasonal factors are based on the performance of prices last year.
Seasonal adjustment factors affect the index every month and can often be a cause for actual price increases being understated. But good news on inflation is not a worry to the bond market, so less attention is paid to the problem then.
But for the rest of the year, if jumps in the index of three-tenths and four-tenths of a percent are reported each month, it would appear that the annual rate of inflation, which is 2.7 percent through September and below last year's 2.9 percent, is accelerating. And that would worry the bond market.
 
Energy Fluctuations
 One of the big contributors to this problem will be energy prices, which are normally assumed to be falling at this time of year. Mr. Jackman said the adjustment factors assume a decline in energy prices over the next three months that would bring the index down about three-tenths of a percent.
But instead of falling this year, energy prices are expected to rise, especially this month. One reason is the introduction of the 4.3-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax that was part of President Clinton's deficit reduction plan. In addtion, the reformulation of gasoline to lessen air polution is likely to add to prices.
It is also unclear what will happen with apparel prices, which the seasonal factors assume will decline in December.
While investors and traders should be aware that the seasonal impact could be exaggerating the actual rate of inflation, a large jump could still be enough to disturb the credit markets when it is at the lowest yields in 25 years.
"If it comes in at four-tenths, people should know it is overstated," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chemical Securities. "Still the market does tend to react to these kind of things."
At the least, he added, such a report might "temper any gains until we see the next number."
Mr. Fine is forecasting a four-tenths of a percent increase in the October C.P.I. But he does not think that it represents in any way an acceleration in inflation. All that is really happening, he said, is that some of the earlier over statements on the downside are now being smoothed out.
For example, he said, a four-tenths of a percent increase in October combined with the unchanged index in September averages to a two-tenths of a percent rise. That is closer to the pace at which inflation is moving and is a rate, he said, that should keep long-term interest rates in their trading range of 5.75 percent to 6 percent.
 
Treasury Market
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32yesterday, as the yield fell to 5.82 percent, down from 5.84 percent on Tuesday. Prices of Treasury notes were little changed as the market remained in a tight trading range after long-term yields broke to new 25-year lows at the end of last week.
In the when-issued market, the two-year note to be auctioned on Tuesday was trading at a yield of 3.86 percent, while the yield on the five-year note to be auctioned on Wednesday was 4.67 percent.
In the corporate bond market, BHP Finance, a subsidary of the Australian mining, steel and oil company, Broken Hill Proprietary, sold $300 million of seven-year notes and $200 million of 20-year bonds. Morgan Stanley & Company was the lead underwriter. The so-called Yankee issue, which is denominated in American dollars, was priced to yield 5.67 percent on the seven-year notes, 68 basis points over the comparable Treasury note, and 6.79 percent on the 20-year notes, 78 basis points over the 7.25 percent 30-year bond due in February 2023. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
A Clean-Air Minuet

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
General Motors and the air pollution chiefs of 12 Northeastern states are engaged in a double-or-nothing gamble over what emission standards will be applied to cars in the region at the turn of the century. The car company is rolling the dice in the courts and lobbying in legislatures for weaker rules, as state officials consider running to the Clinton Administration to lay down the law to enforce the strictest standard available.
But for the first time in a long battle between Detroit and the state capitals, the two sides are approaching negotiations. 
 The complex maneuvering will determine how heavily cleaning the air will fall on drivers, auto makers and fuel refiners, as opposed to electric utilities and other industries -- or directly on consumers by restricting products like lawn mowers and motorboats and maybe even by setting rules on who may drive on which days. The arguments now under way may also determine whether electric vehicles will have a mandated mass market, and whether clean-air policy will be set by Washington or by the states, led by California, whose program the Northeast states want to copy on a regional basis.
 
 
State Officials Meet
 At the moment, the air pollution officials of the 12 states from Virginia to Maine are committed, at least on paper, to adoption of the California Low Emission Vehicle standards, including electric cars. But some legislatures have balked, and in New York the courts have stepped in and blocked at least part of the program.
The state officials met in Mystic, Conn., on Monday and Tuesday under the aegis of the Ozone Transport Commission, an entity formed by the Clean Air Act amendments of 1990 to work out regional solutions to smog. The states decided to draft a formal petition to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, to ask it to enforce the California standard in the East; the state officials will meet again in February to decide whether, in fact, to submit the petition.
The double-or-nothing gamble is raised by a new response from General Motors, which is quietly circulating a counterproposal under which Detroit would offer cars cleaner than the current Federal standard -- but not as clean as those that will be required in California. G.M.'s proposal notes that the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990 allow the Federal E.P.A. to decide late in this decade whether to require something called the Tier 2 car. Starting in about the 2004 model year, it would meet a stricter emission standard in 49 states. (California is allowed to set its own standards, and other states can choose between the Federal and California standards.)
G.M.'s idea is not fully formed, and the company said it would not discuss it because it did not yet have the assent of other car makers. Some, though, are clearly interested.
G.M. is offering the Eastern states something akin to the Tier 2 car. But if the states stick to their guns, they may end up with the California standards, depending on the outcome in the courts. Another risk is the political will of more than 2,000 state legislators in 12 state capitols, facing armies of lobbyists representing foreign and domestic car producers, car dealers and oil refiners on one side, and environmentalists and health advocates on the other.
 
 
Mixed View of Talks
 In lieu of legislative and legal warfare from Richmond to Augusta, will negotiation work?
The chairman of the Ozone Transport Commission this year is Scott A. Weiner, Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and Energy. In a telephone interview yesterday, he said: "For the first time G.M. and the other auto manufacturers have said they want to sit down and engage in serious discussions. That's an entree I was happy to embrace." But the commission will move ahead with its petition, he said.
Others are suspicious. Thomas C. Jorling, the New York State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, testified before a House subcommittee in Washington this month that "introduction of this proposal at this critical time is solely designed to divide and divert the states of the Ozone Transport Commission from proceeding with regionwide adoption of the California Low Emission Vehicle program."
At the Northeast States for Coordinated Air Use Management, an association of air-pollution-control officials from New England, New York and New Jersey, Michael Bradley, the executive director, said, "It's an encouraging sign that the auto industry would come forward with an alternative proposal for a car that's cleaner than what's mandated in the Clean Air Act."
But his position was the legal equivalent of "peace through strength."
"It's obvious that the Northeast states' look toward the California vehicle prompted them to come to the table with a proposal," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company after Citicorp, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell slightly from the preceding quarter and were only about 3 percent higher than a year earlier.
"They never had the immense buildup of bad loans a few years ago like many other large banks, so their profits have not had the benefit recently of sharply reduced expenses from credit problems," said James Rosenberg of Lehman Brothers. 
 BankAmerica said that its holdings of troubled loans had declined in the last year and that it had provided $175 million to its loan-loss reserve in the third quarter, down from $200 million the previous quarter and $260 million a year earlier.
Profit growth was also hurt by weakness in the California economy and weak loan demand. Total loans at the bank averaged $121.8 billion in the third quarter, down 1 percent from the second quarter and down 6.7 percent from a year ago.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Subdued Start for Tokyo Car Show

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The gargantuan Tokyo Motor Show began today with the theme of "ecolution," a Japanese-coined combination of ecology and evolution that is meant to refer to cars that do not harm the environment.
But the environment Japanese auto makers really worry about these days is not the earth's but that of their business. "The current business environment is like nothing we have ever experienced," Nobuhiko Kawamoto, president of the Honda Motor Company, said Tuesday. 
 Indeed, Japan's auto industry is facing the equivalent of a global climatic change -- from a growth industry to a cyclical one. And unless they can adapt, at least some of the 11 species of car makers here are expected to become extinct. Analysts estimate that as many as 9 of Japan's 11 vehicle manufacturers are now losing money.
 
 
Fewer Models, Fewer Mini-Skirts
 This makes for a very subdued auto show, which opened for press previews today. People who have long attended the show, said there were fewer new car models, fewer female models in colored mini-skirts, and fewer attendees than in the past. Advanced technology, always a focus of attention at the Tokyo show, tended toward fuel conservation, electric vehicles and enhanced safety features, not high power and luxury.
"They are not talking about the market," said Carnie R. Colliver, an analyst at AutoPacific Group Inc., a consulting company in Santa Ana, Calif. "It's almost like they want to hide the problems."
With Japan in a recession, the emphasis this year is on giving consumers good value for their money and on cutting costs by eliminating unnecessary frills. Asked what this meant, a Toyota spokesman pointed under the fender of a new Celica to an unpainted spot that would be hard for customers to see. "It's much cheaper if you don't have to be perfect," he said.
Japan's once nearly invincible auto makers are finding their home habitat is shrinking and their ability to forage abroad is being reduced by political restrictions and by the strong yen. And foreign predators, mainly the American automobile companies, are suddenly becoming far stronger, just as the United States Government is pressing Japan to open its market further and to buy more American auto parts.
 
 
What's New in Midget Cars
 It is this environment that the industry hopes will brighten with the two-week auto show, as 352 auto and parts makers from around the world display the latest in hydrogen-powered vehicles, midget cars, drowsiness monitors and collision-avoidance systems.
"In a sense, a motor show is a festival, and those people who participate in a festival are energized," Yutaka Kume, the chairman of the Nissan Motor Company and of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association, said recently.
But almost nobody, including Mr. Kume, thinks the auto show will do the trick. Mr. Kume said the Japanese auto industry, faced with the "most serious predicament since its very establishment," needs "very bold and audacious restructuring."
The reason people are not buying cars, particularly in Japan and Europe, has little to do with a lack of new products and a lot to do with the economy.
"All of these problems will not be solved overnight, even if you introduce three new cars," said Koji Endo, an analyst with Lehman Brothers Japan. "It will take two or three years. And two or three years might be too long for some makers to adjust."
Mr. Endo said only two of Japan's auto makers were clearly profitable -- Mitsubishi Motors, which has a strong position in the popular sports-utility category, and Suzuki Motor, which has a niche selling small vehicles in developing nations.
 
 
Different From U.S. Industry
 Of course, the problems of Japan's industry should not be exaggerated.
"What Japan views as a crisis, the Americans would have liked to have experienced and been able to call a crisis," said Maryann N. Keller, managing director and auto analyst at Furman Selz Inc. in New York. The year-to-year production declines the Japanese are experiencing -- down 5.6 percent this year from a year earlier and off 7.5 percent from a peak of 13.5 million in 1990 -- would be nothing for American manufacturers, whose production is cyclical.
The problem, Ms. Keller said, is that the Japanese "are not prepared for cyclical markets." Becoming prepared might involve scrapping some cherished policies, like lifetime employment, which works well when companies want to hold employees but not when they have to adjust to fluctuating volumes.
Domestic sales in Japan, having grown about 3 percent a year from 1970 to 1990, are in their third consecutive year of decline. And exports, which account for nearly half of Japan's production, are shrinking in part because of export restrictions and in part because Japanese companies are shifting more production abroad for political reasons or to cope with the rise of the yen, which makes exporting unprofitable.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Dollar Has Mixed Showing As Investors Take Profits

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other currencies yesterday as investors sold dollars to lock in profits from its rise against the German mark this week.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.6395 German marks, down from 1.6411 marks on Tuesday. But it rose to 107.42 Japanese yen from 107.16 yen. 
 The dollar rose during European trading as expectations mounted that Germany would cut interest rates.
But the German central bank lowered its repurchase rate -- which influences money-market rates -- less than traders expected. The central bank fixed the lowest rate for 14-day securities repurchase agreements at 6.67 percent, slightly lower than the previous 6.70 percent.
Investors sold off the dollar during New York trading after it failed to rise above 1.6210 marks, traders said. But they did not expect the dollar to tumble.
"The market seems bullish on the idea that lower German interest rates are coming, although not this time," said Tom Benfer, senior market representative at the Bank of Montreal's office in New York.
Traders said it seemed likely the German central bank, the Bundesbank, would cut the key discount rate by year's end, as long as inflation stayed in line. Germany's main M-3 gauge of money-supply growth, a key indicator of inflation, eased to an annual rate of 7 percent from 7.2 percent, according to monthly figures released yesterday.
But few traders expect a cut in the discount rate at today's meeting of the Bundesbank's policy-setting Central Council.
Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Paine Webber, said the dollar still seemed to be in strong demand.
"There's a general assumption of continued Bundesbank easing and U.S. numbers improving," he said.
The British pound edged up slightly yesterday in New York to $1.4899, from $1.4897 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday, included: 1.4500 Swiss francs, up from 1.4465; 5.7920 French francs, down from 5.8045; 1,597.00 Italian lire, down from 1,599.00; and 1.3167 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3253.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A giant in the profession gives a lift to economic history.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
CRACK just about any college history text, and you'll find it is full of economics: hardly anyone these days would write about, say, the decline of Spain in the 17th century without paying obeisance to economic causes.
But try the converse experiment with most introductory economics texts, and you might be left with the idea that the world was created somewhere around 1950. Movers and shakers in economics, it seems, just aren't accustomed to pondering the past. 
 That is why many economic historians find the Nobel Memorial Prize awarded to Robert Fogel of the University of Chicago a double pleasure. For not only do they respect Mr. Fogel for his achievements -- "Fogel has always been in the thick of things," said Gavin Wright of Stanford University -- they see the prize as a sign that economic history now has as great a claim to status in the profession as a dozen other specialties.
Mr. Fogel is better known for what he wasn't than for what he is. As the co-author of the best-selling "Time on the Cross" (Little Brown, 1974), he infuriated some social commentators with what was widely viewed as an apology for pre-Civil War slavery. But Claudia Goldin, an economist at Harvard and a former student of Mr. Fogel, allows that many of the critics "never opened the book." If they had, she says, they would have discovered a startling, but hardly racist, thesis.
Southern plantations, argued Mr. Fogel and his co-author, Stanley Engerman of the University of Rochester, were one-third more efficient than the small family farms of the North. What's more, plantation owners had the financial wherewithal (and were typically smart enough businessmen) to "maintain" their slaves at material living standards close to those of free Northern workers. Hence, slavery was not doomed as a method for organizing labor. Indeed, the only way to rid the nation of the "peculiar institution" was to challenge it on the ground of morality.
Why, then, the tempest? Greater "efficiency" means more output for a given quantity of inputs. In this case, though, it is unclear whether a unit of slave labor was equal to a unit of free labor. Many economic historians now believe that plantations were only more efficient in the sense that they drove their workers harder -- an interpretation that does not undermine the core implication that slavery was there to stay, but does suggest that the language was unnecessarily provocative.
The storm over "Time on the Cross" has also had the unfortunate effect of obscuring Mr. Fogel's less controversial achievements. "Railroads and Economic Growth" (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1964), strongly influenced by the Nobel laureate Simon Kuznets, challenged the foundations of development economics.
Before the book, theorists from Joseph Schumpeter to Walter Rostow had asserted that the rise of single industries brought about the development of whole economies. But Mr. Fogel calculated that the leading candidate in the case of America -- the railroads -- was far from indispensable in the opening of the Great Plains. Ms. Goldin points out, incidentally, that the indispensability theme is as relevant today as it was in the 1960's: the Clinton Administration is now making the case for subsidizing high technology as the solution to America's productivity woes.
Quite possibly, though, Mr. Fogel's most enduring research will be his effort to measure changes in living standards over very long time spans. Certainly it shows him at his most versatile.
Wearing his administrator's hat, he is coordinating the most ambitious project ever attempted in economic history, one involving dozens of researchers and millions of dollars. And wearing his interdisciplinary researcher's hat, he is going where no economist has gone before. Among the tentative findings: In Europe of the early 18th century, malnutrition was such a serious drag on productivity that roughly one-fifth of the adult population did not have the caloric intake to work.
The effort to document changing living standards is extraordinary. But then, Mr. Fogel is nothing if not extraordinary. Donald McCloskey of the University of Iowa notes that he is marrying "biology, the history of medicine, demography, social history, economic history, nutritional history, pediatrics, clinical nutrition, embryology, historical sociology, tropical medicine, public health, historical geography, epidemiology, agricultural history, physical anthropology, gynecology, international economics, industrial history, toxicology, genealogy and development economics to discover the link between nutrition and life chances."
Just where the project will end is unclear. But Mr. Fogel is already up to his old tricks of knocking received wisdom off its moorings: it is plausible, he suggests (if yet to be proved) that the average American's rise in material living standards from the early 1830's to World War II was almost fully offset by the detrimental public health effects of urbanization, industrialization and immigration.
This prize is probably the most controversial handed out in economics. Make no mistake, though: Mr. Fogel is a giant of the profession.

HEADLINE: WORLD SERIES: ON BASEBALL;
Will a Realignment Be Good for the Game?

BYLINE: By Murray Chass

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The Toronto Blue Jays and the Philadelphia Phillies played Game 4 of the World Series last night. Was it the last game the players would play with integrity? It might be, major league baseball officials and owners believe, if the players received money for the rest of the games. As long as the players play for nothing past Game 4, officials and owners have no fear about the legitimacy of any World Series games.
Players' post-season shares have always come from the net gate receipts of the first four games of a series, whether it be the league series or the World Series. That way, they have no financial incentive to extend a series. 
 Now that the clubs want to introduce a new round of playoffs, adding a division champion and a wild-card team from each league, and now that the owners themselves will be receiving revenue from advertising time that television will sell, the players think that policy should be re-examined. The clubs say the policy is inviolate.
 That's why all the talk about three divisions in each league next year remains premature. The difference of opinion over money, or equity, has prevented the two sides from reaching agreement on the proposed changes. No agreement, no three divisions, no new round of playoffs.
It was supposed to be a simple step, but representatives of the two sides met again yesterday and when they finished, the format for 1994 had not changed.
"We had further discussions," Eugene Orza, associate general counsel of the Players Association, said. "I continue to remain optimistic that more rational heads will prevail."
With the clubs adamantly opposed to increasing the players' post-season shares, Orza's optimism may prove to be unfounded. If it is, the new format will not come about.
While the clubs dwell on the players' integrity, the change in baseball's national television package has spawned a different question of integrity: the owners' integrity.
Through this World Series, the television networks paid major league baseball a rights fee for regular-season and post-season games. Whether a post-season series went four games or seven, the payments were the same.
Beginning next year, rights payments will not exist. The Baseball Network, a newly formed venture of major league baseball and two networks, ABC and NBC, will sell commercial time for the games and divide the revenue based on a formula. In the case of post-season games, the longer a series goes, the greater the advertising revenue.
CBS has sold an estimated average of $18 million in commercial time per game. If next year's World Series attracts similar revenue and lasts seven games, the clubs, under terms of the new agreement, would share approximately $45 million extra over what they would receive for a four-game series. Similarly, they would gain additional revenue from a five-game (instead of three) first-round series and a seven-game (instead of four) league championship series.
Would it not be to the clubs' benefit to have the series run longer than the minimum number of games, just as it would be to the players' economic advantage? If the players' integrity would be subject to question, wouldn't the same perception exist for the owners?
"I'm not sure I agree with that," Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, said yesterday. "It's always been in the owners' best interest to have the most games possible. The better the networks do, the better the clubs do. And owners aren't playing. They're not on the field. They can't influence anything."
No, the owners cannot throw a fat pitch down the middle of the plate or strike out with the bases loaded or let a ground ball roll between their legs with the game tied and a runner at third. But owners could exert influence to make sure an umpire makes the "right" calls or a pitcher throws the "right" pitches.
Preposterous? Maybe so. But no more preposterous than suggesting that the players would throw a game or two to create higher shares.
If last year's post-season had gone the maximum 21 games instead of 19, the winning World Series share for the Blue Jays would have been $12,284 higher than the share each player actually received. The winner's actual share was $30,703 higher than the loser's share.
 Do the owners really think the Blue Jays would have risked $30,000 and the World Series championship by throwing a game each in the league playoff and World Series to gain an additional $12,000? Not in this lifetime.
Yet Selig said, "One would assume the players' payment should be in the same format as it has always been."
That stance, according to the players association, will guarantee the continuation of the format that has existed for 25 years: two divisions in each league, league championship series and World Series.
Nevertheless, Selig said, "I just hope we get it wrapped up and move ahead on it."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
Playing on Uncertainties About the Health Plan

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
SPONSOR: The Coalition for Health Insurance Choices, financed by the Health Insurance Association fo America.
 
ON THE SCREEN: A couple, Harry and Louise, is sitting over breakfast. He is reading a newspaper, she a published version of the President's health care plan. The camera angle changes, and we see the health care plan from above as Louise underlines a passage with a yellow marking pen. At the end of the ad, an 800 number appears along with a tag identifying the sponsors.
 
THE SCRIPT: Harry: "I'm glad the President's doing something about health care reform."....Louise: "He's right. We need it."... Harry: "Some of these details--"... Louise: "Like a national limit on health care?"... Harry: "Really." ...Louise: "The government caps how much the country can spend on all health care and says, 'That's it!"'...Harry: "So what if our health plan runs out of money?"...Louise: "There's got to be a better way."
 
ACCURACY: The implication of the ad is that under the President's plan, only a certain amount of money can be spent on health care, and after that, patients will be out of luck. The President has proposed a complicated set of regulations to limit the rate in increase in health care spending to the inflation rate. Among other things, these regulations would limit the amount that health insurance premiums could rise each year. Many health care providers are concerned that the limits would adversely affect the quality of care and that some health care plans might actually run out of money. The President's proposal also calls for each state to set up contingency funds to bail out insolvent plans.
 
SCORECARD: The ad purports to reflect the concerns of average citizens, and it effectively appeals to a generalized sense that the Clinton Administration's plan doesn't quite add up. But the ad has an melodramatic, overacted quality that may make viewers suspicious. And once they learn the ad is sponsored by the insurance industry, these suspicions are only likely to increase. ELIZABETH KOLBERT

HEADLINE: The Mayoral Campaign -- At Issue: Health Care;
New York's Health Challenge

SERIES: The Mayoral Campaign: At Issue: Health Care

 BODY:
New York City's next mayor will confront alarming rates of infant mortality, tuberculosis and AIDS. And he will need to re-invigorate public hospitals and clinics that are understaffed and underfinanced. It will be a daunting challenge when the city must cut its budget.
Mayor David Dinkins and Rudolph Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal challenger, offer health care proposals that read like pages out of the same hymnal. Both advocate neighborhood clinics, health maintenance organizations, preventive care and turning city medical facilities over to nonprofit groups. The difference between the two is that Mayor Dinkins can also be judged by his deeds. After a shaky start -- and up against the need to make large budget cuts -- Mr. Dinkins has launched innovative programs to improve the health care of the city's poorest families. The health effort may be his strongest program. 
 At the heart of the Dinkins policy is a program to incorporate Medicaid recipients into managed-care plans, like H.M.O.'s. Most of the city's poor seek medical treatment only after they become seriously ill, and then in the most expensive way possible -- at overcrowded inner-city emergency rooms. By enrolling in H.M.O.'s, the families will now have their own doctors and get well-baby visits and other preventive care, largely free. Treating Medicaid enrollees in H.M.O.'s should, by catching medical problems before they fester, improve the quality of the care the poor receive.
The Mayoral Campaign
At Issue: Health Care
The Dinkins administration's program floundered when it was buried in the Human Resources Administration. But since it was moved to City Hall in 1992, enrollments have taken off. Almost 150,000 are now signed up -- putting the program ahead of a timetable set by Albany.
The city has converted 13 neighborhood facilities into full-service medical clinics, staffed by about 100 physicians. Mr. Dinkins also started a program that will tap loans from the state to provide nonprofit groups the capital they need to build 30 clinics in low-income neighborhoods. By placing the Medicaid population in managed care plans, the city can take full advantage of the Federal reforms proposed by President Clinton.
To his credit, Mr. Giuliani also supports the idea of creating nonprofit clinics in low-income neighborhoods, though he reasonably criticizes Mr. Dinkins for moving too slowly. He also blames Mr. Dinkins for pulling too much money out of public health programs early in his term. Mr. Giuliani argues that this added to the increase in tuberculosis, sexually transmitted diseases and rodent infestation.
Yet Mr. Giuliani's attack lacks credibility because his economic plan -- which relies on a series of tax cuts -- threatens to worsen the fiscal plight that drove Mr. Dinkins to make the cuts in the first place. The tax cuts would increase pressure to cut programs, and there's no assurance that worthy programs like public health would be spared.
Beyond criticizing the Dinkins record, Mr. Giuliani proposes his own reforms, like building comprehensive school-based health clinics. That's an interesting idea that might be usefully coordinated with Mr. Dinkins's neighborhood-based clinics. Mr. Giuliani also proposes privatizing a couple of municipal hospitals to see if turning them over to nonprofit groups would improve care and cut costs.
That is a worthy experiment. But privatization is not likely to generate huge budget savings because the city has already cut its hospital losses in half and much of the remaining expense will still have to be paid to care for prisoners, firefighters, police and others.
Mr. Dinkins, meanwhile, has actually privatized Medicaid clinics throughout the city. Thus on this as on many health issues, both candidates embrace many of the same reforms. The question voters face is which man will more likely institute the sentiments they share.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Laughter After Nafta

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Anything that Ross Perot, Pat Buchanan, Ralph Nader and Jesse Jackson line up against -- I'm for.
But that is hardly a high-domed argument for Nafta, which offers the most stupefyingly boring acronym since MEGO (my eyes glaze over) itself. 
 Face it: Only your grim sense of civic duty, or your fear that you will be asked your position on this by your overeducated children, causes you to read about anything with Nafta in its title. I'm the same way, taking sips of supercaffeinated coffee as I write this to keep my forehead from crashing down onto the wrist support of my computer keyboard.
But we hafta. And not because the refusal of Congress to approve the lowering of tariffs negotiated by two Presidents would strangle the Clinton Presidency in its crib. The White House tried that desperate argument with its tax-and-spend budget, and a President gets only one act of mercy from his party per term.
Here, quick and dirty, are the real reasons to support the free-traders and rout the protectionists:
1. Breaking down the barriers may throw some people out of work now, but will help all our kids get better jobs tomorrow.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. can trot out a parade of captive economists to show how, in the short run, jobs will be lost to low-wage Mexico. But to paraphrase Lord Keynes, in the short run we are all exhausted; a counter-parade of the dismal scientists will show you how free trade expands trade, which means more jobs and a higher standard of living for all.
Expert opinion won't settle this debate. Common sense says that opening new markets enlarges the pie, and what is good for all business is good for all workers.
2. Here's our chance to help Mexico, and ultimately all of Latin America, move away from the Socialism and dictatorship that poverty spawns.
The best President Mexico ever had has taken a gutsy stand for free enterprise and all-Americanism; shall we saw off the limb he's on? That would be self-defeating, inviting hordes of hungry Mexicans to swim the Rio Grande and wind up on welfare here. (Clinton is now getting the hang of a little nativist counter-demagoguery.) Better to give Mexico a bright capitalist future, attracting investment that will pay higher wages and create consumers for U.S. goods.
3. Protectionism and isolationism are sisters under the skinheads; if we turn inward and adopt a "Festung Amerika" philosophy, we lose our competitive edge, lose business, lose jobs, lose world leadership and turn into a nation of losers.
Look to the East: a free-trading bloc is forming there that could knock our made-in-China socks off. Look to the West: the French farmers behind "So Be It" Balladur are leading Europe into an us-against-them Common Market, holding a GATT to the head of world trade.
Hey, protectionists: Wouldn't it be nice to have a whole hemisphere with us -- 370 million strong -- to keep the Europeans and Asians from ganging up? (This is not an argument that free-trade purists make, but it's time we gave wider meaning to "America first"; eat your heart out, Pat.)
Perot, Jackson and the rest of the America-lasters (this is not as dull as I thought) would have us believe a free-trade bloc on our side of the Atlantic and Pacific somehow dilutes U.S. sovereignty. Baloney; Nafta's free-trade zone is the free-enterprise answer to the schemes of U.N. bureaucrats and Law-of-the-Seaniks to socialize our system.
4. We can cut from current spending the few billions we now get from restrictive tariffs.
Mr. Clinton wants to put on cross-border fees to make up the difference, which Republicans resist as new taxes. This "don't take us for granted" grumbling is a way to hold the Clinton feet to the fire, lest his wooing of liberals lead him to promise them the moon on environmental spending. "The funding will not kill the Nafta," Mickey Kantor assures me. (Our new trade rep is no Carla Hills, but he'll do; note Mr. Kantor's correct usage in "the" Nafta.)
Principled Republican support against the defeatist fears of America-lasters has this requirement: Clinton more up front and enthusiastically on the line. If he cannot get 130 votes in the House on this from his own kind, the Democrats don't deserve to govern.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Time Is Ripe for Single-Payer Health Reform

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Partisans of the Clinton health care reforms, most of whom are closet single-payer advocates, have given up on the latter, because they say it is not "p.r." (politically realistic). They and the Clinton Administration might do well to heed the words of their own guru in the White House, Paul Starr, who in his "Social Transformation of American Medicine," wrote about the Medicare battle of 1964 as follows: 
 Medicare "received the highest priority among Great Society programs. However, strategists for the bill, still smarting from past defeats by the [American Medical Association], were against expanding its provisions to include physicians' services or to cover any broader groups than the aged. At a time of expansive reform, they continued to back a measure framed in the more conservative 1950s." It took Representative Wilbur Mills, who paid attention to public opinion polls at the time, to include doctors' services and a program for the poor.
Similarly today, the 80's are mercifully behind us, and as the commentator Kevin Phillips and others have noted, there is a backlash against that profligate decade and a demand for social reform arising from the more hostile economic climate of the 90's.
It is not surprising in this new environment that more than 70 percent of the American people favor a universal, single-tier, single-payer system of national health insurance. It remains to be seen whether there are enough legislators with the courage and ingenuity to go beyond lip service to a Canadian-style plan and wage a serious fight for it. Otherwise we will never know the limits of the possible.
 
JOHN V. WALSH, M.D.
Professor of Physiology, University
of Massachusetts Medical Center
Worcester, Mass., Oct. 13, 1993

HEADLINE: Dinkins Message: Despite Problems, a City on the Mend

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
As he circulates around New York City in search of a second term, Mayor David N. Dinkins these days seldom uses Rudolph W. Giuliani's name, deliberately mislabeling his opponent as a "Republican conservative candidate" and describing him as a man without compassion for the homeless or appreciation for the city's diversity.
In stump speeches that he delivers several times a day, everywhere from centers for the elderly in Bushwick to catering halls in Bay Ridge to Harlem churches, the Mayor has been working to shift the race from a referendum on his four-year term to one on Mr. Giuliani's politics and ideology. 
 "I want folks to know just who Rudolph Giuliani is," Mr. Dinkins told supporters at a campaign rally last week at the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Harlem in a rare use of Mr. Giuliani's name. Then he rattled off a list of what he called the "different philosophies, different attitudes" between himself and his challenger.
The Mayor told the rally that Mr. Giuliani opposed the all-civilian police review board created last year, that he would dismantle a Dinkins administration program to grant more city contracts to companies owned by members of minorities and women, and that Mr. Giuliani's Republican "friends" in Congress had blocked President Clinton's economic-stimulus plan, which he says would have been worth about $400 million to New York City.
 
A Recurring Theme
 It is a strategy that blends easily with another recurring theme -- New York, while it surely has problems, is on the mend.
At a recent meeting with community leaders in a Brooklyn Heights church, a woman told the Mayor that many of her neighbors had become so discouraged by the city's seemingly insurmountable problems that they were ready to give up and leave.
"Do not give up," said Mr. Dinkins, who had appeared tired at the meeting's outset but snapped alert under the questioning. "New York's best days are ahead of it, not behind it. Some folks talk about the good old days, but the good old days never were, in many instances."
 
Jogging for Hugs
 Mr. Dinkins's own mood has been noticeably more upbeat in recent weeks, in part, no doubt, because the polls have also shown improvement in his standing with voters after a summerlong onslaught of politically damaging developments. Mr. Dinkins, who endured the summer stoically if sometimes petulantly, seems calm and confident now. He appears genuinely to enjoy campaigning, greeting old friends with his trademark, "Hi, buddy," and literally jogging to every baby stroller in sight for hugs and kisses.
While he would never be confused with Fiorello H. La Guardia as a spellbinding orator, Mr. Dinkins has shed some of the stiffness that can make him appear distant and disengaged. He has gone before many campaign audiences without the prepared speeches that he ordinarily favors and that he generally reads dispassionately.
Yes, he admits, he has made some unspecified mistakes, but he has learned from them and now does his job better. Yes, there is a broad perception that crime is pervasive, but he has hired a record number of new police officers and the statistics show crime is falling. Yes, the prolonged recession has cost New York more than 350,000 private-sector jobs, but he has still managed to balance four budgets and carve out some modest but innovative new programs.
The Mayor's stump case against his Republican-Liberal opponent complements his television advertisements, which have highlighted, among other things, Mr. Giuliani's changing views on abortion rights early in the 1989 campaign. It also adds to the standard campaign speech that Mr. Dinkins has been delivering all year, a compendium of achievements in which he shapes his case for re-election.
 
Closing Budget Gaps
 The Mayor tells audience after audience that he has closed huge budget gaps, expanded the police force and cut crime, even in the midst of a crushing recession. And he argues that he needs four more years to complete the job.
In addition to marshaling facts and figures, the Mayor also relies on small group of jokes and stories that he repeats almost verbatim. At the church rally last week in Harlem, he told a story that he has told to great effect many times before in many places.
"We were riding along in a city limousine one day, my wife and I, and I said, Joyce -- that's her name, Joyce -- I said, 'You see that fellow over there with the shovel, digging a ditch?' " Mr. Dinkins said.
"She said, 'Yeah.' I said, 'Isn't that the fellow you used to date?'
"I said, 'Now, wait a minute, don't misunderstand. There's nothing wrong with digging ditches. I have dug ditches, waited tables, worked in factories, did all kinds of jobs. There's nothing wrong with digging ditches. In fact, it is the fellow you used to date, isn't it?' "
"She said, 'Yes, as a matter of fact it is.' I said, 'See, if you'd married him you'd be the wife of a ditch-digger.' She said, 'No, if I'd married him, he'd be mayor.' "
He also used another familiar example of his self-deprecating humor that night, reminding people that he spent a good part of his adult life trying to get elected Manhattan borough president.
"You know, I ran three times," he said. "The people in their wisdom rejected my candidacy on two occasions, and it wasn't until the third time that I won. As a matter of fact, along the way, I'd meet people, they'd say, 'What do you do?' And I'd say, 'I run for borough president.' "
 
Encouraging Youngsters
 Mr. Dinkins also has a set piece in which he encourages young people to study hard and be ambitious. "Kids, listen up," he says, beginning a five-minute homily in which he advises children, especially black and Hispanic youngsters, to respect their parents, shun violence and learn to think. He cites Nelson Mandela, saying it was his ability to reason that helped him survive nearly three decades of imprisonment in South Africa.
Mr. Dinkins tells the children, as he did during a rally at a housing project in East New York, Brooklyn, "You can be anything you want to be." He tells them that they can become doctors, lawyers, teachers and police officers. "And you know you can be mayor," he says, wrapping up his talk with a flourish.
Sometimes the Mayor arrives at campaign events holding notes brimming with statistics -- generally when he goes before groups with whom he might feel uncomfortable, as he did at a forum in Manhattan sponsored by an environmental group and another held by a group of small-business owners in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. But more often he comes to campaign stops these days without notes or a prepared text, giving his presentation more immediacy.
Mr. Dinkins talks of the difficulties of balancing the city budget and always highlights several programs he created in the last two years: new primary-care health centers in poor neighborhoods, the opening of some schools in the afternoons and evenings for programs for children and adults, and the opening of public libraries six days a week.
 
Ideological Differences
 The Mayor has been hammering at these points since January, when he laid out what has become his election-year platform in his State of the City address. Over the last month or so, he has also begun emphasizing his ideological differences with Mr. Giuliani, trying to portray his opponent as a hard-core Republican in a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans by nearly 5 to 1.
The goal is to try to depict Mr. Giuliani as someone unsympathetic to minorities and lacking compassion for the poor, a perception that would help Mr. Dinkins with the coalition that elected him four years ago: black, Hispanic, liberal white and gay New Yorkers.
Whatever the outcome of the election, the Mayor seems at ease. Several aides say he has told them recently that he wants to win very badly but that he thinks he could live with defeat better than Mr. Giuliani could.
Mr. Dinkins, who has long had a wary relationship with the press, has even seemed more relaxed around reporters. He was standing on West 52d Street on a recent Saturday, telling several reporters that four rallies planned for that afternoon in Brooklyn had been canceled. "What will you do this afternoon?" someone asked.
With a twinkle in his eyes, the Mayor, known for his wardrobe and a fastidious attention to fashion, responded: "I'll go back to the mansion and do some housework. Got to press the other suit."

HEADLINE: Economist Takes Reins at University of Chicago

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Hugo F. Sonnenschein, an economist and former provost of Princeton University who almost flunked out of college as an 18-year-old undergraduate, was inaugurated today as the 11th president of the University of Chicago.
Speaking in the Rockefeller Memorial Chapel about the university's "especially fierce commitment" to ideas, including "uncomfortable" ones, the new president defended Robert W. Fogel, a University of Chicago economist who last week won the Nobel Prize in Economics. 
 Mr. Fogel has been criticized for his 1974 book, "Time on the Cross," and later writings in which he contended that slavery, although morally reprehensible, was an efficient means of economic organization. "The clear, correct reading of his work is that as a society we cannot be guided by what is economically efficient," the new president said. "To do so would be to deny our humanity."
Mr. Sonnenschein added, "If you want to seek the truth, then you have to take risks, and it helps to be in an environment that supports truth seekers."
In an interview on Tuesday, Mr. Sonnenschein, a 53-year-old specialist in microeconomic theory, said the biggest problem facing the university was sharply curtailed Federal support.
"You have to decide what to do less of," Mr. Sonnenschein said. "You have to ask, Is a given project worthwhile, relative to the most outstanding opportunities?"
 
Faculty Is Happy With Choice
 While declining to cite specific cuts, he said his predecessor, Hanna Gray, had "chosen wisely" in reducing administrative expenses and closing the geography department in 1986 and the Graduate Library School in 1988.
Mrs. Gray plans to return to teaching history next fall.
The faculty appears to be happy with the choice of Mr. Sonnenschein, who has been at Chicago since July. "He has all the right instincts," said Richard A. Epstein, a law professor who serves as the faculty spokesman.
Mr. Epstein recalled that last March, when Mr. Sonnenschein visited the university's Laboratory Schools, a 6-year-old girl made him a gift of a slightly squashed M & M. A few days later, the girl received a thank-you letter from the new president.
"That's the kind of guy he is," Mr. Epstein said.
Born in New York City, Mr. Sonnenschein graduated from the University of Rochester in 1961. During his freshman year there, he said, his grades were so low that he had to take summer courses in mathematics and modern poetry at the University of Chicago. Eventually, he went on to earn a master's degree and Ph.D. at Purdue University.
He was appointed provost of Princeton in 1991 after teaching economics and serving as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of Pennsylvania.
 
Past Laurels, Fresh Talent
 Among Mr. Sonnenschein's challenges will be maintaining the talent level of a faculty that has included the physicist Enrico Fermi, who directed the construction of the world's first nuclear reactor; the late ultraconservative historian Allan Bloom, and the novelist Saul Bellow, who was lured away by Boston University last year.
"An institution can't live on what it's been," Mr. Sonnenschein said. "It must celebrate that, but it must also look to the future and continue to attract the finest young scholars and support them."
As an example of fresh talent on the faculty, he cited Shulamit Ran, a native of Tel Aviv and a Pulitzer Prize winning composer who is now composer in residence at the university.
Mr. Sonnenschein said that as an economist, he took particular pleasure in Mr. Fogel's sharing the Nobel Prize with Douglass C. North of Washington University in St. Louis. This was the third year in a row that a Chicago University economist has won the prize.
A T-shirt popular among students here is inscribed with the names of the university's 63 Nobel laureates before Mr. Fogel.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1993, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the installation of Hugo Sonnenschein as president of the University of Chicago misstated the number of Nobel Prizes awarded to members of the university's economics department since 1990. It is four, not three.
