HEADLINE: New Proposal From Cuomo For Yankees

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
A $150 million plan to keep the Yankees in the Bronx through 2032 will be offered in the next few days to George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.
The new offer follows a far less detailed project proposed by the Governor last month, which offered the Yankee owner a 50,000-seat stadium on Manhattan's West Side at a cost of $530 million. That proposal was quickly opposed by city officials and community leaders as too extravagant and impractical given the traffic congestion in the area. 
 Mr. Cuomo was also sharply criticized by city officials for failing to make a forceful effort to keep the ball club in Yankee Stadium, where the team has thrilled fans since 1923 with 22 World Series titles.
 
Preemptive Move by Cuomo
 The Governor's new proposal is in line with Mayor David N. Dinkins's single-minded strategy of keeping the Yankees in their traditional home, but it is also another preemptive move by Mr. Cuomo, who if the Yankees stay put would be able to take political credit as the man who kept the Yankees from moving to New Jersey.
The plan, which had not been seen by the Mayor, is almost identical to one offered by the city to Mr. Steinbrenner six years ago, and would be the most substantial overture to counter what city and state officials believe is a longstanding informal invitation from the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to lure the Yankees across the Hudson with a $250 million ball park and lucrative financial guarantees.
"Mr. Steinbrenner says it's not economically feasible for him to stay in Yankee Stadium because attendance isn't what it should be," the Governor said. "Maybe he won't sign a new lease, but then he'll have to show why he doesn't like this plan economically. It gives him what he wants."
 
What New Jersey Can't Match
 Whether the plan for a new lease -- the current one runs through 2002 -- equals in economic impact what Mr. Steinbrenner could get from New Jersey "will be argued," Mr. Cuomo said.
"But our plan gives him something New Jersey can never match: that's New York," he said.
A sense of urgency on the part of Mr. Cuomo has been apparent since June, when the Governor concluded that the Yankees might leave the state. The competition with New Jersey, which has never made a formal offer but has repeatedly indicated a willingness to accommodate Mr. Steinbrenner, led Mr. Cuomo to float the possibility of alternative sites in New York, including the expensive riverfront project on the Long Island Rail Road storage yards south of the Jacob Javits Convention Center.
Mr. Cuomo has never stated why he has spearheaded proposals to keep the Yankees, but if he runs for a fourth term as Governor, few announcements could be as debilitating as one by Mr. Steinbrenner that his Yankees were leaving for New Jersey.
The latest proposal was put together by Vincent Tese, the chairman of the state Urban Development Corporation. He expected that it would be presented to Mr. Steinbrenner in the "next four or five days."
The Yankee owner will see a plan almost identical to a $90 million deal he agreed to in principle six years ago with former Mayor Edward I. Koch.
Based on details provided by Mr. Tese, the plan calls for the construction of 24 luxury suites to augment the 18 now leased at the Stadium. Shea Stadium currently has 46 suites selling for about $90,000 each. Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands has 72 suites, which produced $6.5 million in revenues in 1992.
It also addresses Mr. Steinbrenner's demands to provide adequate parking and transportation access to fans, many of whom live outside the city. A new parking garage with at least 3,000 spaces, would be built adjacent to the Stadium.
 
Link to Northern Suburbs
 A Metro-North station would create the first railroad link between the Stadium and fans from northern suburbs.
Access from the Major Deegan Expressway would be improved to ease vehicular access in and out of the Stadium.
Mr. Steinbrenner could not be reached yesterday, and a spokesman for him, Howard J. Rubenstein, said, "He has not received the offer and he'll await it before he makes any comment."
The 1987 agreement was never signed, collapsing a year later over the city's demand to receive a percentage of the Yankees' cable television revenues. At the time, Mr. Steinbrenner said he would agree to a flat fee. Several weeks after the deal fell through, the Yankees signed a 12-year cable deal with the Madison Square Garden Network worth nearly $500 million.
There is no provision for the city to receive cable revenue in the revised proposal.
"It's not intelligent to fight over $1 million in cable money when you could have him sign a lease for 30 years," Mr. Tese said. "That was a big mistake. The city did not see the forest for the trees back then."
 
No Serious Talks Since 1988
 Since 1988, there have been no serious talks about extending the lease on Yankee Stadium, due mainly to Mr. Steinbrenner's two-years-plus exile from baseball, which ended last spring, and the growing litany of complaints by Mr. Steinbrenner and his aides about conditions at the Stadium.
Mr. Steinbrenner has cited parking, security, sanitation and traffic problems for depressing Yankees attendance despite the improved play of the team this past season. Early this season he complained that his attendance lagged the Mets, an inferior team, and challenged fans to show their support for keeping the team in the Bronx by attending important series.
But the drawing power of a winning team was shown as the Yankees stayed in contention for the American League East championship until the final days of the race. Attendance, which totaled 979,218 at midseason, rose to 2,416,941 by the end of the season.
In recent months the city worked aggressively on improving Stadium conditions, a move that has been a prerequisite for Mr. Steinbrenner to discuss a new lease. In June, city and Bronx officials announced an ambitious plan to rebuild the Bronx's downtown. A month later the city announced plans to renovate the Bronx Terminal market, a collection of warehouses and stores just south of the Stadium.
Mr. Dinkins has spoken only of keeping the Yankees in the Bronx. Other city officials, like Betsy Gotbaum, the Parks Commissioner, and Fernando Ferrer, the Manhattan Borough President, have questioned the feasibility or advisability of building a ball park on Manhattan's West Side, insisting that the only viable alternative already exists at 161st Street and River Avenue, Yankee Stadium.

HEADLINE: Reassuring Eastern Europe, Christopher Praises Hungary's Reforms

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Secretary of State Warren Christopher cast himself in the role of diplomatic booster today, praising Hungary's economic and political reforms in Budapest and signaling his staunch support for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
In Hungary, Mr. Christopher's first visit to an Eastern European country in his nine months as Secretary of State, the Secretary sought to assuage Hungarian fears that the United States does not care sufficiently about the problems facing Eastern Europe. 
 "I assure you we would never disregard or in any way underrate the significance of these countries," Mr. Christopher told reporters in a joint news conference with Hungary's Foreign Minister, Geza Jeszenszky.
Mr. Christopher decided to add Hungary to his trip, which includes visits to the four nuclear states of the former Soviet Union -- Russia, Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus -- and Latvia, only after last month's parliamentary elections in Poland in which former Communists won over a number of pro-Western democrats.
 
Two Views of Polish Elections
 The State Department is divided about the significance of the Polish elections. Some analysts fear that Poland and Hungary may turn to right-wing authoritarianism in the next two to three years. These officials have urged the Administration to press for the expansion of NATO to the East. Other State Department officials dismiss that view as alarmist, arguing that liberal democracy has taken root firmly in Central Europe, according to senior officials.
Mr. Christopher is said to have been persuaded that the United States could not take the democratization and economic reform of Eastern Europe for granted and that he needed to display his personal support by paying a visit to the region.
But Mr. Christopher did not come to Hungary with promises of aid or pledges to ease the economic burden of economic sanctions against Serbia, which have hurt the economies of Hungary and other countries who had traded with Belgrade. Nor did he bring an outright promise to embrace Hungary's demand that it join NATO, although one of his top aides told reporters on Wednesday that the Administration wanted to "open the door" to the eventual expansion of NATO that could include Russia and other countries of the former Soviet bloc.
But in meetings with NATO Defense Ministers in Germany, Defense Secretary Les Aspin has played down the possibility of expanding the 16-member alliance, at least in the next few years.
For his part, Mr. Jeszenszky went out of his way to praise the American proposal even though it fell far short of Hungary's demands, saying, "The very idea that there is a possibility or even the need for such an expansion is something that is welcome."
 
'Strategic Partnership'
 Privately, some European officials and diplomats expressed puzzlement that Mr. Christopher allowed Mr. Aspin to make a major policy statement on the future of NATO and did not articulate the policy himself.
En route to Moscow this evening, Mr. Christopher said he was making the trip because Mr. Clinton wanted him to build on the American "strategic partnership" with Russia.
Mr. Christopher, who will join Mr. Yeltsin, Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev and other senior Russian officials in two days of meetings, also said he wanted to get a sense of the preparations for the December 11-12 parliamentary elections in Russia. He said that his conversations with Mr. Kozyrev have convinced him that the Russian leadership has focused "like a laser" on the elections, to be held in the wake of Mr. Yeltsin's dissolution of Parliament last month and the showdown between the Russian Parliament and President. Mr. Christopher plans to raise the issues of Russia's economic reform and the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Turning to the situation in Georgia, in which the Government of Eduard A. Shevardnadze is facing two rebellions, Mr. Christopher praised Mr. Shevardnadze, who was the Soviet Union's last Foreign Minister, as a leader who "has long exhibited his friendship" for the United States, and noted his "commitment to democratic values." Mr., Christopher said, without elaboration, that the United States hoped to "help him any way we can."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Clinton Offers Georgian Support
 TBILISI, Georgia, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Georgian Government today released a letter from President Clinton offering Mr. Shevardnadze support and inviting him to Washington. Mr. Clinton also offered to assist in peace talks with Abkhazian separatists.
"I have been following closely the tragic events unfolding in your country and want to assure you of my continued full support for your leadership and for Georgia's territorial integrity and sovereignty," Mr. Clinton wrote.

HEADLINE: Body and Dreams Trampled, a Riot Victim Fights On

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The verdicts in the Reginald O. Denny case are in, and this bruised city anticipates a new beginning. But for at least one victim of the mayhem at Florence and Normandie Avenues, who is now broke, sick and scared, the spiral of misery has no end.
He is Fidel Lopez, a Guatemalan immigrant, who after 20 years of toil had seized the American dream for his wife and three daughters, a dream that was dashed in seconds when he drove his pickup truck into an intersection just blocks from his home where fires roared and bedlam reigned. 
 Mr. Lopez was thinking about how well things were going that April afternoon 18 months ago as he unwittingly drove toward the unfolding unrest. He owned a three-bedroom house in South-Central Los Angeles, his small contracting business was getting off the ground, and he was planning his family's first real vacation.
 
Blood, Pain and Terror
 Then, like Mr. Denny, Mr. Lopez was dragged from his truck and beaten senseless by a mob that included Damian M. Williams and Henry K. Watson. His forehead was slashed under the blows of a stereo speaker. His left ear was nearly severed. His genitals were spray-painted black, and his body was doused with gasoline, apparently for the purpose of setting him afire.
A black preacher threw his body on Mr. Lopez's and saved his life. But since that miracle moment, the news has all been bad.
Mr. Lopez is broke because of the months he could not work, the debts incurred replacing thousands of dollars of equipment in his burned truck, the mortgage payments he continues to make on a house that his family is afraid to live in and the tens of thousands of dollars he had invested in a job that he was unable to finish. He works seven days a week now, as does his wife, Coralia, who is a maid.
And Mr. Lopez, 48 years old, is in failing health and has no medical insurance. After being patched up in an emergency room the night of the riots, he has received virtually no medical care.
He complains of headaches, vomiting and dizziness, sometimes so severe that his co-workers must help him off a ladder. He says he has back and chest pain and is deaf in his left ear. Members of his family say that his halting speech has nothing to do with fluency in English. He used to be more coherent, they say, but now loses his train of thought.
"They destroyed me, physically and economically," Mr. Lopez said without bitterness the other evening, as his daughters did homework and laundry in the shabby one-bedroom apartment where the family now lives some 10 miles from South-Central Los Angeles.
"We had problems before, but nothing like this," said 17-year-old Melissa, the Lopez's middle daughter. "Everything was turned upside down."
Yet the Lopez family is philosophical about the lenient verdicts this week and showed no malice toward the assailants, whom Mr. Lopez was not able to identify in his testimony but who were visible in the videotapes.
For the attack on Mr. Lopez, Damian Williams was found guilty of misdemeanor assault but acquitted of felony assault with a deadly weapon. Mr. Williams faces a maximum sentence of six months in prison and a $1,000 fine.
 
'Better It's Over'
 "It's all right," Mr. Lopez said of the verdict. "If they sent those guys to jail, those people would be mad and do it all over again. It's better it's over. And for me, everything that is broken I can't anyway get back."
His daughter Melissa, too, is magnanimous. If the verdict was unfair to her father, she said, it is also a reminder that "this verdict is the kind of injustice black people always get."
Melissa came to court when her father testified, looked his assailants in the eye and "saw they were human beings, too."
What angers the Lopezes more is the police response to the rioting. "There was no protection for nobody," Mr. Lopez said. "Whose fault is that?"
The minister who saved Mr. Lopez stood guard with Bible in hand, transported his body home and then to a hospital when no ambulance crew would brave the neighborhood. The 60-year-old minister, the Rev. Bennie Newton, befriended the Lopezes. They were at his bedside last spring when he died of leukemia.
"For all the thoughts I had against black people, preacher Bennie was like a piece of cotton with love going 'round my heart," said Mr. Lopez's brother-in-law, Luis Barrios. "He was there to show us that in every situation, just like the Bible tells us, there is good and bad."
But it was their life before the beating, as one of two Hispanic families on an otherwise black street where neighbors helped neighbors, that predisposed the Lopez family to forgive.
"Everybody says, 'It's your dad, don't you hate black people?' " Melissa said. "Well, the thing about us, thank God, is that we grew up all our lives around black people. We know there are good people, bad people, O.K. people. There was really no hatred. I understood why they were so mad."
 
Recalling a Terrible Night
 On the night of the riots, 19-year-old Vanessa accompanied her father to the hospital, both of them covered with a towel in the back seat of Mr. Newton's car so they would not be seen and stoned for being the wrong color.
Vanessa then spent more than 24 hours with her father in a building riddled with gunfire and jammed with howling, bloody victims. She has little to say about that experience except that "I had to stay calm because I was the only one there for him."
Melissa, despite her words of solace, flinches when people come too close to the car she is riding in on the way to her father's work site in South-Central Los Angeles. Her father says she is quicker to anger than she used to be. She adds that concentrating in school has become a struggle.
After the riots Aileen, who is 9, was petrified in the family home in South-Central, and thus they moved to the small apartment next to Mr. Barrios. "This little girl, she be crying every day," Mr. Lopez said. "She believed they would come again and get me."
There was no margin of error in Mr. Lopez's young business. He lost his $8,000 truck, $2,000 worth of tools, $3,000 worth of insulation and dry wall, and many personal possessions, including his green card.
Meanwhile, a few blocks away, his job site was trashed by the rioters, who tore copper pipes from the walls and stole equipment. Because of his injuries, Mr. Lopez never completed that job, in which he had invested $35,000 of his own money in the expectation that he would make it back in the end.
Then there is the family home, which sat empty for months because no one wanted to buy or rent it in the riot-torn neighborhood. Recently, Mr. Lopez found a tenant, who he says has turned out to be a deadbeat.
 
Working Day and Night
 Desperate for money, Mr. Lopez works day and night. "I tell him he must go to the doctor," Mr. Barrios said. "He tells me, "Yeah, but I have to work.' He is a tough guy when it comes to work. Nobody will stop him. He has the American dream in his head all the time."
Melissa hugged her father with special urgency when he came home from work early one day because he was tired. "Hi, Daddy, you O.K.?" she asked, trying to sound nonchalant.
Outside Mr. Lopez's hearing, the teen-ager said she was afraid: "That's a proud man. He doesn't like to say exactly what's going on. But I know there is something wrong with him. Sometimes he keels over."
From the porch next door, Mr. Barrios watched father and daughter embrace in the fading light of evening. Mr. Barrios is a relative newcomer to this country, here just six years, and he talks of hardship in the context of what America promises.
"We all believe in the magic of this place," Mr. Barrios said. "This is heaven. So where did heaven go? Who took it away?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: "They destroyed me, physically and economically," said Fidel Lopez, who was seriously injured in the rioting last year in Los Angeles. (Scott Robinson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Surprise German Rate Cut Spurs Big Gains for Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar staged a broad rally yesterday after Germany stunned the currency markets with interest rate cuts that set off similar rate reductions throughout Europe.
 The cuts prompted money to flow into dollar-denominated assets as yields fell on investments based on European currencies. 
 In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.6667 German marks, from 1.6408 marks on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for December delivery fell $1, to $372.80 an ounce.
The Bundesbank confounded expectations in the currency markets yesterday by cutting half a point off its key discount rate, to 5 3/4 percent, and its Lombard rate, to 6 3/4 percent. The central bank also set a fixed short-term repurchase rate for next week at 64/10 percent, below the 62/3 percent of this week.
 Belgium, Switzerland, the Netherlands and Austria followed suit, partly to keep exchange rates level with the mark.
 
Bundesbank 'More Optimistic'
 "The fact that they have decided to cut really would suggest the Bundesbank is more optimistic on future price moves," said Brian Martin, an economist at Citibank in London, citing the prospect of falling German inflation.
 The fiercely independent German central bank has often eased credit when least expected. "This highlights just how foxy the Bundesbank can be at the old game plan of trying to outwit the market," said David Brown, chief economist at Tokai Bank in London.
 Some viewed the cut as a shift in Bundesbank policy under its new president, Hans Tietmeyer, even though he has said the bank will continue easing credit cautiously.
 
Dollar Rises to 108.35 Yen
 The dollar, which surged against the Japanese yen on heavy buying in Tokyo, widened its gains in late New York trading, rising to 108.35 Japanese yen, from 107.42 yen on Wednesday.
"The market is more comfortable holding long positions now," said Ichiei Kuki, customer dealer at Tokai Bank in Tokyo.
 Meanwhile, the British pound finished in New York at $1.4844, below $1.4939 on Wednesday. Other late dollar rates compared with Wednesday's quotes included: 1.4695 Swiss francs, up from 1.4515; 5.8367 French francs, up from 5.7950; 1,606 Italian lire, up from 1,597; and Canadian $1.3095, down from $1.3176.

HEADLINE: Anxious Haitians Start Building Boats Again

BYLINE: By GARRY PIERRE-PIERRE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PETIT-GOAVE, Haiti, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Colbert St. Vil sat under a wooden boat with a chisel, carving the last touches on a vessel he said he was building to transport bags of rice and cement from ships docked at a nearby port to this coastal town.
This fishing hamlet, however, is one of the villages from which many Haitians have fled in rickety boats, trying to reach the United States and appeal for asylum from the military Government that overthrew President Jean-Bertrand Aristide two years ago. And Mr. St. Vil's new cargo boat could quickly become a passenger boat. 
 In towns like Petit-Goave, people are hastily building boats to make the 600-mile journey to the United States because of increasing economic hardship and political repression.
"If he does not return, we'll take matters into our own hands," Mr. St. Vil said, referring to President Aristide. "I don't mean on land; I mean the ocean. It's our only way out."
If Haitians do take to the sea, it will create yet another refugee problem for the Clinton Administration, which is struggling to restore Father Aristide to power. The flood of refugees from Haiti was a major factor in persuading the Administration to push hard for Father Aristide's return in the first place.
In two years of negotiations, diplomats have failed to persuade the military to accept the return of Father Aristide as President.
The restoration of democratic rule seemed to be in sight in July after the Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, signed an accord agreeing to resign and accepting the return of Father Aristide by Oct. 30.
But last week the treaty fell apart when General Cedras refused to resign and plainclothes paramilitary forces assassinated President Aristide's Justice Minister, Guy Malary.
While diplomats try to salvage the accord, Haitians are making plans in case they fail.
In Petit-Goave, about an hour from Port-au-Prince, people speak about the fear and the hardships they have endured since the coup. They speak about nightly "disappearances" and about not being able to speak freely.
Tension in this quaint town, dotted with colonial gingerbread homes, increased last week when a soldier was killed while on duty. When word spread through the open-air market, vendors scurried to get home, creating a sense of panic.
"Every night I go to sleep, I dream of Guantanamo," said Yvon St. Lot, referring to the United States Naval Base on the southeastern coast of Cuba where he and other Haitians were held after they were picked up at sea. "At least I was able to eat twice a day."
 
When the Exodus Stopped
 After the coup, more than 40,000 Haitians left by boat, hoping to reach the United States. Thousands left from Petit-Goave. During the Bush Administration, about 10,000 were allowed into the United States as political refugees. But the exodus halted when the Coast Guard began stopping boats at sea and repatriating the Haitians.
Mr. St. Lot, 30, like many here, fled twice by boat. The first time, his boat was intercepted by the Coast Guard and he spent two months at Guantanamo before being returned to Haiti. Eight days after his return, he tried again and ended up in Cuba, which also sent him back to Haiti.
 
'Now They Just Shoot You'
 "Now things are worse than before," said Mr. St. Lot, who does not sleep at his home because of fear. "They used to beat you up," he said of the military thugs. "Now they just shoot you."
What is also driving ordinary Haitians to flee is a sense that the United Nations embargo against Haiti will hurt them the most.
In the past, Haitians used to say they were fleeing for fear of their lives; now many readily admit they will be leaving because of economic hardship.
Prices in Haiti have skyrocketed. In just a few days, gasoline prices went to $3.70, from $1.50, and the price of rice quadrupled. Unemployment is spreading rapidly; every day, young men here sit idly under the verandas and play cards to pass the time.
 
Blaming Aristide
 Marie-Judith Theodore, an unemployed teacher, said: "If it was up to me, the Americans can have this country. Under these conditions, it's better to be occupied. I know that a lot of people don't want the whites here, but at least I would work."
But Miss Theodore blames President Aristide for the economic deterioration.
"His return is impossible," she said with strong conviction. "The other side will boycott him. There will be problems. I know the United States is playing with him because if they wanted him to return, a little country like Haiti could not stop them."
Asked if she would take a boat to the United States, Miss Theodore just smiled. But as she walked away, a man who was standing nearby said her boyfriend was a soldier. "Don't listen to her," he said.
 
Two Hard Choices
 The political situation remains murky. Many of the men playing cards said wryly that it was not support for President Aristide that led them to sleep at a different locations every night. As they spoke, others kept watch. And whenever a stranger appeared, they kept quiet.
"Every night people disappear," said Jeuly Prophete, 25. "You never know what happens to them."
To many Haitians, their options are few: Stay and go hungry and face the wrath of soldiers, or risk their lives aboard a leaky boat in hope of finding a better life somewhere else.
Luc Selmot, who was playing poker, said a phone call from President Clinton would be enough to solve the crisis. But he also plans to leave no matter what the outcome.
"When I leave, nobody is going to send me back here," he said. "The United States knows what's going on here, so when I leave they can't send me back. They might as well kill me on the spot. That's what the military will do to us."
